column16: Recognition
column20: Notes

column15: Stringer Main Span; Concrete Girder Approach Spans

column2: Abandoned Elk River Bridge North of Dorfee
column20: All that remains of the former pedestrian suspension bridge are the cables and towers. Just a few wood planks from the deck remain. The 1997 West Virginia Atlas and Gazetteer shows a dashed line starting from Dorfee Road in Dorfee running along the east bank of the Elk River and crossing this bridge. Dorfee, established in 1907, was a mining community. Since this bridge could only be a pedestrian bridge, could it have been part of some sort of trail to get to the mines? Suspension bridges such as these are more commonly privately-owned, connecting to the property on the other side of the waterway. It is important to note that the cables extend above Elkhurst Road and are anchored into the hillside. Would this be allowed for a privately-owned bridge? Maybe it would be more likely for a mining company than a landowner.

column2: Admiral T. Joseph Lopez Bridge (Chelyan Bridge)
column20: The 1997 Admiral Lopez Bridge replaced the former 1929 Chelyan Bridge. The Chelyan Bridge was a National Register-Eligible continuous Baltimore truss. Continuous truss bridges from before World War II are very rare. There is not another bridge like it anywhere in the region. At least the bridge was replaced by a modern continuous truss. HDR Inc. is a leader in modern truss bridges, designing Warren trusses with no verticals. The new bridge has an impressive 594 foot main span. Admiral Lopez was a distinguished Naval officer who has served as Commander in Chief of U.S. Naval Forces, Europe, and Commander in Chief Allied Forces, Southern Europe.

The 1891 Aetnaville Bridge is the oldest vehicular truss bridge over the entire Ohio River. It is a rare Pennsylvania camelback truss. The bridge is also noteworthy for its decorative portal ironwork. The bridge was closed to traffic in 1988 but has functioned as a pedestrian bridge since then. Its future status is uncertain; the bridge may be demolished.

column16: Longest lenticular truss bridge in America, Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Corrugated Metal Company (Berlin Iron Bridge Company)
column20: The Aiken Street Bridge (Joseph Ouellette Bridge) is the longest lenticular truss bridge in America (in total length of trusses). The bridge consists of five spans. It is the only remaining lenticular truss bridge in America with more than three spans. Like all of America's lenticular truss bridges (except for Pittsburgh's Smithfield Street Bridge), it was built by the Corrugated Metal Company, which became the Berlin Iron Bridge Company in 1883. The bridge is the second oldest lenticular truss in Massachusetts. The historically significant bridge was rehabilitated in 1998 and continues to carry traffic.

column15: Inclined thru girder and floorbeam system
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: Lowell's Northern Canal was constructed in 1848, completing the city's canal system. The Northern Canal and feeder were built to increase and regulate hydropower for the canal system. In 1897, the Aiken Street Bridge over the canal was replaced with the current bridge. It is a rare example of a steel thru girder in which the girder is thicker at mid-span than at the ends of the span.

The Akelson Bridge, dating from 1904, is one of several remaining similar Nelson & Buchanan truss bridges. The comparable bridges are either three or four panels; the Akelson Bridge is one of the longer four-panel designs. The Nelson & Buchanan bridges are noteworthy for being early riveted pony truss bridges in which each panel has an X shape. The Akelson Bridge has been strengthened by longitudinal floorbeams added below the floorbeams.

column15: Pratt half-hip riveted, supported by load-bearing stringers and intermediate piers
column20: The Akerley Road Bridge was constructed in 1930 as a 40-foot riveted half-hip Pratt pony truss. According to the PAHBI, ''According to PennDOT records, the original Pratt pony truss superstructure was replaced in 1988 by the addition of steel stringers and two concrete barrel piers. The Pratt trusses were kept as railings.''

The Albright Bridge is a 1950's riveted steel stringer built on the masonry abutments of the previous bridge. It was rehabilitated in 1988, receiving a new deck and the standard West Virginia railings.

The Albright Power Station Bridge provides access to Allegheny Energy's Albright Power Station, a coal-fired power plant. The bridge crosses a dam in the Cheat River. It likely dates to the 1952 construction date of the power plant.

column15: Closed spandrel prestressed elliptical concrete arch
column20: In 1985, the Alewife Station opened as the terminus of the Red Line. The northern end of the station was the right-of-way from the Fitchburg Cutoff or B&M Freight Cutoff Railroad. It is now used by the Alewife Station Access Road as well as the Fitchburg Cutoff Path and the Cambridge Linear Park. As part of the station's development, the MA 2 / US 3 bridge over the right-of-way was replaced by the current non-historic prestressed arch.

column16: Second newest Suspension Bridge in America, only major suspension bridge in America with no stiffening truss
column18: FCI Constructors / Cleveland Bridge California (Contractors), Ishikawajima Harima Heavy Industries (Fabrication of the roadway)
column20: The Alfred Zampa Memorial Bridge is named after an ironworker who worked on many San Francisco Bay Area bridges. The bridge is America's first new major suspension bridge built in over 20 years!

column16: Only active pony truss bridge in Cameron County
column20: The Allegheny Avenue Bridge is Cameron County's only state standard Parker pony truss. The bridge retains historical integrity complete with its original lattice railings. According to the PAHBI (evaluation by JPH), 'The 1933, single span, 116'-long, rivet-connected Parker pony truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls. The upper chords are built up box sections, the lower chords are channels with battens, and the verticals and diagonals are rolled sections. The bridge is an example of a state highway department standard design rivet-connected truss bridge.'

column16: Only Pratt truss bridge over the Kiskiminetas River
column20: According to the PAHBI (MEM Reviewer), ''The skewed, 6 span, 704' long bridge consists of 4, riveted, 149' long Pratt thru truss spans over the river and a steel stringer span at each end (1 @ 60', 1 @ 26'). The substructure consists of ashlar abutments and piers with concrete caps. The piers have been repaired with concrete on their upstream side. The upper chord and inclined end posts are built up box sections, and the verticals and diagonals are rolled section. The bridge has no innovative or distinctive details. It was built to a state standard design in 1939.''

column2: Allegheny River Trail Mill Creek Bridge
column20: The Allegheny River Trail Mill Creek Bridge was constructed for the Allegheny Valley Railroad around 1915. Around 2000 it was converted to carry the Allegheny River Trail.

column2: Allegheny River Trail Spur Mill Creek Bridge
column20: The stone arch bridge was constructed for a railroad in the Allegheny Valley in likely the late 1800's. Long abandoned, the bridge is used to connect Dotter Road with the Allegheny River Trail. The bridge could either be on an old alignment of the Allegheny Valley Railroad or could have been on a competitor's alignment.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: H. G. Hinkle (Engineer), Augustus Fogle & Company (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The one span, 107'-long, reinforced concrete deck arch bridge built in 1911 is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls and finished with incised panel concrete parapets. The bridge is one of 13 surviving reinforced concrete deck arch bridges designed by the Blair County engineer between 1908 and 1913.'' The PAHBI determines the bridge to be historically significant because it is a ''wide longer example for date by local engineers outside of major contemporary concentration of reinforced concrete bridges.''
The Allison Avenue Overpass is the only rigid frame overpass built for I-70 (except for the bridges of the Pennsylvania Turnpike).

column18: Chaney & Armstrong, Engineers, Hardy & Rankin, Contractor
column20: According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, ''The skewed, 60'-long and 27' wide, reinforced concrete deck arch bridge built in 1921 is one of over 15 similar deck arch bridges in Washington County designed by the Chaney & Armstrong, Engineers, later styled as Chaney Engineering Company, in the 1910s and 1920s for the county. Most, like this example, are finished with incised panel parapets topped with beveled coping and plain spandrel walls and incised panels on the spandrel walls.''

column16: Possibly Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: T. J. Wilkerson, Beaver County Engineer; American Bridge Company; The Dravo Contracting Company; Purdy & Sanders
column20: Ambridge, Pennsylvania, was the company town for the American Bridge Company. Across the Ohio River was Woodlawn, a town eclipsed by the expansion of the Aliquippa Works of the Jones & Laughlin Steel Company. As the area grew and prospered, it became apparent that a bridge was needed. In 1926, the Ambridge-Woodlawn Bridge opened. The superstructure was built by the American Bridge Company, which was fitting since the bridge connected the company town to the J&L steel mill. Supposedly it was one of the easiest bridges to build, since it connected a steel mill with a bridge fabrication company. The substructure was built by Dravo Contracting. American Bridge built some of the largest bridges throughout the world, such as the New River Gorge Bridge in West Virginia and the East Bay Spans (both the original and the replacement) of the San Francisco Oakland Bay Bridge. The Ambridge-Aliquippa Bridge, as it is now called, is one of the oldest surviving truss bridges over the Ohio River. It is also the only cantilever with four towers in Pennsylvania. It is the only one with four towers over the Ohio River upstream of Louisville, Kentucky. As such, the spans between the first and second towers and between the third and fourth act as anchor spans, giving the bridge three suspended spans (at the center and at the ends of the bridge). While the bridge was to be replaced as part of the now-cancelled Crows Run expressway, a much needed northern beltway to Pittsburgh, it is now scheduled to be rehabilitated. As part of the project, the bridge will be repainted gray.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Wheelwright, Haven and Hoyt (Designer), John R. Rablin (Chief Engineer), Massachusetts Metropolitan District Commission
column20: In 1662, the first bridge to span the Charles River, the Great Bridge, was constructed at this location. It was replaced in 1862 and again in 1915 by the current bridge. The 1915 bridge was made possible by the gift of Larz Anderson to be a memorial to his father, Nicholas Longworth Anderson, who was a general in the United States Army and a Civil War veteran. Though the Anderson Memorial Bridge is constructed from reinforced concrete, it was styled to match the buildings of Harvard University. The spandrel walls are finished to resemble rough-hewn stone, and the arch rings and piers are accented by brick. The parapets are paneled. The bridge once had gilded street lights. A plaque on the Cambridge side reads, ''Connecting the College Yard and playing fields of Harvard, be an ever present reminder to students passing over it of loyalty to country and Alma Mater.''

The Anderson Road Bridge is a closed spandrel arch with its build date, 1911, inscribed in the side of the spandrel wall. According to the PAHBI, ''The one span, 45' long reinforced concrete deck arch bridge built in 1911 is finished with concrete parapets with incised panels. The parapets continue across the flared wingwalls to define the approaches.''

column18: Allegheny County, Vernon Covell, American Bridge
column20: The Seventh Street (Andy Warhol Bridge) is one of the ''Three Sisters Bridges,'' which are three self-anchored suspension bridges side by side by side over the Allegheny River connecting downtown Pittsburgh with the North Shore. The Seventh Street Bridge is 66 feet longer than the other two. The three previous bridges were replaced at the same time due to navigational clearance requirements. The Pittsburgh Art Commission mandated suspension bridges for the replacement structures. Since the foundations were unsuitable for conventional anchorages and an elevated railroad was located along the Allegheny River on the Pittsburgh side, the self-anchored design was used. This was the first time the self-anchored design was used in the United States. The Seventh Street Bridge was renamed after Andy Warhol, a famous pop artist from Pittsburgh. The Andy Warhol Museum is near the northern end of the bridge.

column2: Ann W. Richards Congress Avenue Bridge
column15: Concrete adjacent box beam over decorative open spandrel concrete barrel arches
column16: Austin Landmark
column20: Congress Avenue is the main north-south road in Austin, going straight to Texas's capital. It is not often when three bridges built at the same location on such an important route still survive. Well, sort of. In 1884, a iron six-span iron Whipple truss bridge was constructed at this location. Though the bridge was dismantled in 1910, half of it was re-erected over Onion Creek at Moore's Crossing in 1915. A flood destroyed those spans the same year. The remaining three spans were re-erected at that location in 1922, and they are still standing. The replacement Congress Avenue Bridge, completed in 1910, is an example of an open spandrel barrel arch. The barrel arch (solid arch) is much less common than the ribbed arch. In 1980, the bridge was reconstructed in which the piers were enlarged and the deck was removed. Load-bearing concrete box beams were installed from pier-to-pier over the arches. In other words, the Congress Avenue Bridge is a 1980's beam bridge built over the now-decorative 1910 bridge. If you visit the bridge, note the gap between the top of the arches and the beams. Building a new solid bridge over the old solid barrel arches also created an unintended consequence: the creation of an ideal bat roost. The Congress Avenue Bat Colony is home to up to 1.5 million migratory Mexican free-tailed bats. Viewing the bats emerging from the bridge at night is one of the most popular Austin tourist attractions.

column2: Antioch Bridge (Senator John A. Nejedly Bridge)
column20: The Antioch Bridge replaced a vertical lift bridge that was plagued with problems. In 1970, a collision resulted in the lift span being stuck open for three days. The bridge tender was stuck in the control room and was rescued after three days.
This bridge replaced the former Apollo Bridge, a pony truss visible in the background of the photo. The photograph was taken before the new bridge was open to traffic.

According to the PAHBI (MEM Reviewer), ''The 6 span, 704' long and 24' wide riveted, Warren with a polygonal top chord pony truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments and piers with concrete caps. The top chords and inclined end posts are built-up box sections, and the diagonals, floorbeams, stringers and lower chords are rolled beams. The deck is steel open grid, and the lattice railings appear original. The bridge was built as part of the rebuilding effort following the devastating 1936 St. Patrick's Day flood when over 275 bridges, mostly in the western and central portions of Pennsylvania, were destroyed or damaged beyond repair. It is an example of a state standard design, and it has no innovative or distinctive details.''

The Apple Gate Bridge is a small 49-foot Warren truss just over the West Virginia line in Pennsylvania. It is one of the shortest Warren truss bridges on this entire website. Although the bridge company is not documented, the bridge looks similar to bridges by either the Penn Bridge Company, the York Bridge Company, or the Nelson & Buchanan Company.

column16: Last truss bridge with more than two spans over the West Branch Susquehanna River Bridge
column18: Lycoming County, Mark Krause, Co. (Engineer), Bethlehem Steel Co. (Contractor)
column20: In the mid 1900's, there were many long multi-span truss bridges over the West Branch Susquehanna River. One by one, all but the Arch Street Bridge were torn down. As of 2009, the bridge stands as the last remaining truss bridge with more than two spans over the entire West Branch! There are 7 spans in all, one of fewer than 10 truss bridges in the state with 5 or more truss spans. Unfortunately, the bridge won't be the last remaining example for long. It is to be torn down as early as in 2011. The Arch Street Bridge is a rare example of a camelback truss. A camelback is distinctive since the top chord is divided into 5 distinct segments. There are no other Camelback truss bridges in Lycoming County or on the Susquehanna River in Pennsylvania. The Arch Street Bridge also retains historic integrity, including its original railings and decorative concrete approach portals (see the Flickr link for photos).

The bridge was built as part of the 1932 US 30 (Lincoln Highway) bypass of the Turtle Creek Valley. The bridge carries the bypass over Electric Avenue (Old US 30) at the foot of the climb to the George Westinghouse Bridge. The bridge is an example of a deck girder on trussed bents.

The bridge was built as part of the 1932 US 30 (Lincoln Highway) bypass of the Turtle Creek Valley. The bridge carries the bypass over Electric Avenue (Old US 30) at the foot of the climb to the George Westinghouse Bridge. The bridge is an example of a deck girder on trussed bents.

column15: Pratt pin-connected with a Pratt pin-connected half-hip pony approach span
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The pin connected, 3 span, 281'-long bridge consists of 2 Pratt thru truss spans over the channel and a single half-hip Pratt pony truss approach span. The bridge is supported on ashlar piers and abutments. The structure is historically and technologically significant as a complete example of an increasingly rare bridge type and design. Adding to its significance is its documentation to the Pittsburgh Bridge Company and its agents, Nelson & Buchanan Company, regionally prominent and prolific fabricators of highway bridges in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Arsenal Street Bridge is one of a few similar Warren polygonal pony trusses in San Antonio. Most bridges built in the area in the 1920's were multi-span concrete tee beam bridges instead of single-span truss bridges. The truss bridges are unusual because the ends of the truss are inclined and the center section has a flat top chord.

The 1903 Ash Road Bridge is an early example of a riveted Pratt truss. It can also be classified as a queen post, since there is only one panel between the inclined endposts. The bridge is one of several similar Nelson & Buchanan truss bridges in the county. The bridge underwent a rehabilitation in which channel and cover plates were welded to the top chord. Some of the lower connections have also been welded.

In 1988, a few replacement Pennsylvania Turnpike overpasses were steel frames, such as the Ashcom Road Overpass. After building two or three, the Turnpike Commission decided against the widespread use of this type of overpass.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Augusta Street Bridge is one of San Antonio's three remaining lenticular pony truss bridges. All were built by the Berlin Iron Bridge Company of Connecticut. Other than in Texas, lenticular truss bridges were mostly built in the northeast. The Augusta Street Bridge is an exceptionally nice example, since it retains its decorative finials and it has an artful paint job detailing the bridge's intricate members. In the late 1920's, many bridges over the San Antonio River were replaced as part of a flood control project that involved the creation of the San Antonio River Bypass Channel. All bridges on the main channel and bypass channel south of the Augusta Street Bridge were replaced.

column16: Last remaining deck truss bridge in Delaware
column20: The original Augustine Bridge was completed in 1885 for the B&O Railroad. It was a Pratt pin-connected deck truss with inverted kingpost approaches. As train loads became heavier, the adjacent stone arch was constructed in 1910, and the 1885 bridge was converted to a vehicular bridge. The bridge was closed to traffic in 1979, and the superstructure was replaced in 1980. The original piers remain. The new bridge, a Warren truss, was designed to loosely maintain the appearance of the lost historic bridge. It is the only vehicular deck truss bridge in Delaware.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 41'-long, reinforced concrete deck arch bridge built in 1914 has stepped concrete wingwalls, concrete coping, and incised panels near the top of the spandrel walls. One and two high metal pipe railings with plumber fittings were added to the bridge ca. 1960.''

column15: Parker riveted with Pratt pony approach
column16: Unusual example of state-designed bridge in which the web consists of rolled H-section members
column20: According to the PAHBI (reviewed by MEM), ''The bridge built in 1937 consists of 2, 215' long, riveted, Parker thru truss spans and a 91' long Pratt pony truss approach span on the south end and 41' long stringer span at the north approach. ...The web members are all composed of rolled section.''

column16: Only Baltimore truss in county
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Freeland McHale & PA (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI (MEM Reviewer), ''The skewed, 2-span, 358'-long bridge with a 283' long riveted Baltimore thru truss main span and a thru girder approach span is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls and a concrete pier. All members of the high capacity truss are built up. The panels are subdivided with a substrut and a hanger to pick up the intermediate floor beam. The plaque states that the first bridge at this crossing was placed in 1823. This is the fourth bridge.''

column15: Pratt pin-connected; modified to be continuous in 1954
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Bairs Mill Road Bridge (York County Bridge No. 64) has been listed in PennDOT Cultural Resources' Bridge Marking Website since 2003. The bridge is to be demolished in 2011. PennDOT's Bridge Marketing website gives the following information about the bridge: ''York County Bridge No. 64 carries T-773 (Bair's Mill Road) over the Kreutz Creek, in Hellam Township in eastern York County, Pennsylvania. York County Bridge No. 64 is a single-lane, two-span (originally single-span) pin-connected iron Pratt through-truss bridge measuring 26.5 meters (87 feet) long. The curb-to-curb width of the bridge measures 3.81 meters (12.5 feet) wide. In 1993, York County Bridge No. 64 was determined eligible for listing in the National Register of Historic Places as a contributing feature in the (ca. 1878) Strickler's (Bair's) Mill Rural Historic District. The Wrought Iron Bridge Company of Canton, Ohio constructed York County Bridge 64 in 1893. The bridge is a good (albeit altered) example of a pin-connected wrought iron Pratt Through-truss Bridge. Pratt trusses were a bridge type popular in the mid-19th and early 20th Centuries for their ease of shop prefabrication and subsequent construction in the field, and for their weight-bearing capabilities. Bridge No. 64 replaced a ford used since 1821 at this location. The bridge is an altered example, but one of only five remaining wrought-iron pin-connected Pratt Through-truss bridges constructed by the Wrought Iron Bridge Company in York County. Records indicate conversion to a two-span structure by addition of a concrete center pier in 1954. Deteriorated stringers were replaced, the wooden deck was replaced with an open steel grate, and the steel guiderails were also installed in 1954. In 1993, York County Bridge No. 64 was determined eligible for listing in the National Register of Historic Places as a contributing element to the Strickler's (Bair's) Mill Rural Historic District. The bridge is slated for replacement, because a one-lane height-restricted bridge is functionally obsolete for vehicular traffic at this location.''

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic places
column20: The Baker Bridge is a two-span concrete arch, listed in the National Register of Historic Places in 1990. The bridge is distinctive in that the arches are composed of two parallel ribs, with the deck cantilevered outwards. Such a design represents economy of materials.

The Bakerstown Road Bridge is designated historically significant by the 1997 Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory due to its association with the Bessemer & Lake Erie Railroad. It is the only single-span deck truss bridge in Allegheny County. In 1921 the Culmerville Railroad Tunnel was daylighted, so the bridge was constructed to carry the road over the new cut.

column2: Bald Eagle Valley Road Big Fill Run Bridge
column18: Rehabilitated and widened by the Pennsylvania Department of Highways
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 40'-long, closed spandrel, concrete deck arch bridge, built in 1913, has standard design concrete balustrades. The arch was widened on both the upstream and downstream sides in 1940 which seriously compromised the bridge's design integrity.''

column2: Bald Eagle Valley Road Tributary Big Fill Run Bridge
column20: The Bald Eagle Valley Road Tributary Big Fill Run Bridge is a state-standard example of a small concrete slab.

Dating from 1935, the Baldwin Street Bridge is one of the later examples of an Allegheny County concrete arch. After 1936 the type was rarely used for stream crossings. Only two concrete arch bridges over small streams built between 1937 and 1945 survive. It is possible that the design fell out of favor due to the 1936 flood. The Baldwin Street Bridge appears to be in much better condition than many similar bridges from the time. The architecture of the bridge is reminiscent of earlier Allegheny County stone arch bridges.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Bethlehem Steel Company (Fabricator), J. Lee Plumer (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1937, skewed, 2 span, 300'-long, riveted Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments and piers. In 1983 concrete barriers were placed inside the truss lines. The bridge, built to a state highway department standard design, is an example of a common technology used since ca. 1895. It has no innovative or distinctive details. It was part of the rebuilding efforts following the devastating 1936 St. Patrick's Day flood when over 275 bridges were destroyed or damaged beyond repair. The bridge is neither historically nor technologically significant. Nor is the highway historically significant. Although now designated US 6, it was not a part of the original highway developed across Pennsylvania's northern tier. In the 1910s and 1920s it was part of SR 5, promoted as the Lakes to the Sea Highway, one of the many tourist trails in the state. Following the adoption of the federal numbering system in 1926 it was renumbered SR 19. It was redesignated as part of US 6 following WW II.''

column15: Wooden covered Burr arch truss supported by load-bearing steel girders
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the National Register of Historic Places nomination, ''The Bank's Bridge crosses Neshannock Creek in Wilmington Township northeast of New Castle. This bridge was built in 1889 and is the most recent of the two Lawrence County covered bridges. It uses the Burr arch trussing system and has interior portal walls similar to Bucks County covered bridges.... The Bank's Bridge is a typical Pennsylvania style Burr arch bridge.''

The Barr Run Road Bridge is an unremarkable concrete beam bridge from the early 20th century. It is one of many in Pennsylvania. The substructure of the bridge has been rated a 4, or ''poor.'' Deterioration is evident in the photograph.

column15: Burr arch truss, wooden covered bridge
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1980
column20: The Barronvale Covered Bridge is the longest covered bridge in Somerset County. It is a rare surviving multiple-span Burr arch truss. The bridge was originally built as an multiple kingpost. The bridge identification signs give a build date of 1830, though VisitPA states the bridge was built around 1845. The bridge was modified in 1907 in which the arches were added, converting the bridge to a Burr arch truss. Unlike most covered bridges, the Barronvale Covered Bridge retains historic integrity since it is still truss-supported. The bridge was bypassed in 1962 and is open to pedestrians only.

column15: Prestressed concrete fin back (inverted haunched beam)
column16: Only finback bridge in America
column20: The Barton Creek Boulevard Bridge is America's only example of a concrete fin back beam bridge. The type is so unusual, the National Bridge Inventory classifies it as an ''other'' for material design and an ''other'' for design construction. The first fin back bridge every built was a commuter railroad bridge in Nuremburg, Germany in 1969. Several large examples have been built in Mexico since the 1990's. According to highestbridges.com, the fin back ''. . . is a prestressed beam bridge with a highly variable depth of prestressing. The fin back design is unique for having the internal cables at their highest as they pass over the piers, enclosed in a wall or 'fin' of concrete. The double hump profile may look similar to a cable-stayed or extradosed bridge, but the engineering has more in common with a pure beam bridge. Many consider the lower profile to be more attractive than a conventional prestressed beam bridge.'' In other words, a fin back bridge is a prestressed concrete beam bridge in which the haunches are inverted above the road deck at the piers. rather than below. (Haunches are defined as the part of the girders that are thicker over the piers, usually coming to a downward point). Despite the Barton Creek Bridge being such an innovative bridge, it is rather obscure. Bridgemapper.com is the first major bridge website to include it! Neither the bridge nor the bridge type has a Wikipedia article (as of 2010)! In 1992, the Consulting Engineers Council of Texas named the Pennybacker Bridge (Loop 360 Bridge), not the Barton Creek Boulevard Bridge, as Texas's most innovative bridge. Note there are a few rare examples of inverted haunched girder bridges throughout America. The fin back is unique because only a single girder is haunched as a fin in the center of the structure.

The Barton Springs Road Bridge is an open spandrel concrete arch bridge in Zilker Park in Austin. The land for Zilker Park was donated to the city in 1918, though not developed into a park until the 1930's. The beautiful open design of the 1920's concrete arch bridge fits right in with the park. The area around the park has several natural springs. Main Barton Spring feeds the creek, as well as Barton Springs Pool, a public swimming pool located in the creek! It is the largest natural swimming pool in an urban area in America.

column18: Frederick Law Olmstead (Designed the grounds of Biltmore)
column20: The Biltmore Estate was completed in 1895 to be the summer house of George Washington Vanderbilt, grandson of Cornelius Vanderbilt. The original estate was 125,000 acres, though most was sold to become part of Pisgah National Forest. The estate is billed as America's largest home. Vanderbilt hired Frederick Law Olmstead to design the grounds of the estate. A dam was built on Formalie Branch to create a lake for fishing called The Bass Pond. The Bass Pond Bridge was built crossing the upstream reaches of the lake. It is a very rare example of a curved brick arch.

column18: Frederick Law Olmstead (Designed the grounds of Biltmore)
column20: The Biltmore Estate was completed in 1895 to be the summer house of George Washington Vanderbilt, grandson of Cornelius Vanderbilt. The original estate was 125,000 acres, though most was sold to become part of Pisgah National Forest. The estate is billed as America's largest home. Vanderbilt hired Frederick Law Olmstead to design the grounds of the estate. A dam was built on Formalie Branch to create a lake for fishing called The Bass Pond. Today a wooden bridge crosses over the top of the dam on the Bass Pond Trail. While the bridge is not historically significant, it certainly is scenic.

Under Charles Davis in the late 1800's, Allegheny County built many stone arches. Around 1910 under James Chalfant, many stone-faced concrete arch bridges were built. Starting in the 1920's, unadorned concrete arches were constructed under Vernon Covell. After 1936, only a few more were built. In 1943, the Bateman Road Bridge was completed, the last of the small Allegheny County arch bridges. Technological advancements developed for World War II led to improved bridge technologies. What would likely be a small arch or truss before the war became a beam after the war.

According to the National Bridge Inventory, the 1896 Bayard Truss Bridge is possibly eligible for the National Register of Historic Places. The bridge is a pre-1900 pin-connected Pratt truss in a region with very few historic bridges. As of 2007, it is one of only two truss bridges in Grant County, West Virginia. The other is a state-standard truss from 1931. Likewise, it is one of only two old truss bridges in Garrett County, Maryland. The other one is a state-standard truss from 1934. The next closest county, Tucker County, has no remaining old truss bridges. The bridge is also unusual for having concrete-filled metal cylindrical piers. The bridge was closed to traffic in July of 1988, and is to be replaced sometime before 2014. When that happens, the entire tri-county area will be without a pin-connected truss bridge.

column16: Only pin-connected pony truss in Centre County
column20: The Beech Street Bridge is the last remaining pin-connected pony truss bridge in Centre County. The bridge survives is because it has been abandoned for many years, probably at since the 1980's if not earlier. The PAHBI gives no build date for the bridge; the NBI gives a date of 1915. If the bridge is from 1915, it is a late example of a pony truss; riveted truss bridges were constructed starting in the 1890's. According to the PAHBI (JPH Reviewer), ''The one-span, 65'-long, pin-connected Pratt pony truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with wingwalls. The truss members are composed of eye bars for the tension members and standard built-up shapes of plates, angles and channels for the compression members. The rolled I-beam floorbeams are attached to the lower-chord pins by U-shaped hangers. Timber stringers and deck are missing or deteriorated. The builder and date of construction are undocumented by available state and township records, but it dates by style to the turn of the century. It is traditionally composed with no unusual features or patented details that would provide clues to its builder.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The picture of the Beachy Street Bridge was taken before it was closed to traffic around 2005. The bridge is nearly identical to the now-demolished Moser Road Bridge which was over the Casselman River nearby. It is also similar to the Spring Creek Bridge in Elk County, Pennsylvania, which is to be demolished in 2010 or 2011. According to the PAHBI, ''The 7 panel, pin-connected, 108'-long, Pratt thru truss bridge, built ca. 1894, is supported on concrete abutments with flared stone wingwalls. The lower chords and the diagonals are fabricated from forged eyebars, and its upper chords are built-up from channels and cover plates. It is technologically and stylistically similar to [a former] bridge in the township ... documented to the Horseheads Bridge Company of Horseheads, New York. This bridge was undoubtedly constructed by the same company. The bridge is a technologically significant example of its type, and its knee braces, which feature quartets of twisted bars radiating from the ends of the top lateral struts and portals, is a distinctive detail.''

column2: Bear Creek Drive Pennsylvania Turnpike Overpass
column20: In 1957, the Pennsylvania Turnpike Northeast Extension opened to traffic. Mainline overpasses consisted of stringers, thru girders, and deck girders. The Bear Creek Drive Bridge is an example of a stringer with a cantilevered main span.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1875, 86'-long bowstring pony truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with wingwalls. The bridge was rehabilitated in 1991 when two verticals were replaced. The bridge is a remarkably complete and important example of an early metal truss bridge, and it is historically and technologically significant. It has all of the features described in Wrought Iron Bridge Company's 1874 catalogue for a column iron arch bridge.'' After the bridge was replaced, the a historical marker was erected at the site of the replacement bridge. ''Beatty Mills Bridge was a rare c1876 bowstring pony truss bridge that stood at this site until 2008. It was built by the Canton Wrought Iron Bridge Company, Canton, Ohio. A bowstring bridge functions much like a hunting bow: the arched truss ties into the bridge deck under tension. Beatty Mills Bridge was named for the adjacent mills owned and operated by the Beatty family during the 19th century. The old bowstring bridge was dismantled in 2008 and replaced by a new span.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The one span, 90' long, reinforced concrete, deck arch bridge built to a 1910 plan was originally finished with concrete parapets with incised panels and concrete wingwalls. The spandrel walls were plain. The south part of the bridge above the arch ring was lost as a result of a flood. It was reportedly rebuilt in 1998. The bridge is not historically or technologically significant. Ninety feet long spans by 1910 are not uncommon, and much of the span is new fabric.''

column2: Beaver Road Little Sewickley Creek Bridge
column15: Closed spandrel stone arch incorporated into concrete arch
column18: Allegheny County, Charles Davis (original bridge), John Chalfant (widened bridge)
column20: The 1918 Beaver Road Bridge was rebuilt as part of the ''second generation'' of Allegheny County arch bridges, consisting of a concrete arch faced in masonry. According to the plaque, the bridge incorporates an older 1841 stone arch, and in 1918 that bridge was widened and lined. The 1841 bridge is not visible at all. Beaver Road was once part of the Lincoln Highway (now US 30) and was part of an important route connecting Pittsburgh along the Ohio River.

column18: H. G. Hinkle (Engineer), York Bridge Company (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The single span, 40'-long, reinforced concrete arch bridge with concrete abutments and flared wingwalls was built in 1913 as a 23'-wide bridge. In 1947 the state highway department widened the bridge in kind to each side and reset the original concrete parapets with incised panels.''

column16: Only Pratt thru truss in Clinton County, only riveted Pratt thru truss in Centre County
column20: The Beech Creek Veterans Memorial Bridge is an example of a state standard Pratt thru truss. The bridge was dedicated to the veterans of Beech Creek. The bridge is the only Pratt thru truss in Clinton County, and it is the only riveted Pratt thru truss in Centre County. According to the PAHBI (JPH Reviewer), ''The 1935, skewed, single span, 149'-long, 7 panel, rivet-connected, Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls. The upper chords are built up box sections, and the lower chords are channels with battens. Verticals and diagonals are rolled I section. In 1985, the bridge was rehabilitated with the replacement of several floorbeams and new stringers, concrete deck, and replacement bearings. Lattice railings were removed and replaced by concrete parapets inside of the truss lines. A single sidewalk with a replacement aluminum railing is cantilevered off of the north side.'' The bridge is not structurally deficient and has a sufficiency rating of 81.6%. Though many such bridges are being replaced, this evaluation shows that 1930's state standard truss bridges can be rehabilitated to adequately carry traffic loads.

column18: City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works, E. M. Wichert Company
column20: The bridge was built to be a grand entrance into Schenley Park. The deck featured ornamental bronze lamp fixtures attached to concrete lampposts, balustrades with decorative urns, and decorative pylons. In 1980, the bridge was rehabilitated, and the original concrete deck was replaced with a steel one. All ornamentation was removed except the pylons and balustrades at the approaches. The arch ring has deteriorated so badly, netting was installed and a temporary bridge was built over the interstate to catch debris. Since the previous attempt at repairing the concrete arch has failed, the bridge was replaced.

column16: Probably oldest cantilever in West Virginia.  Second oldest vehicular truss over entire Ohio River.
column18: J. E. Greiner and Company (engineering), Mount Vernon Bridge Company (superstructure), J. E. Moss Iron Works (superstructure), R. R. Kitchen Company (deck), Vang Construction Company (substructure)
column20: The 1926 Bellaire Bridge was probably the oldest cantilever in the entire state of West Virginia when it was demolished in summer of 2010. It was the second oldest truss bridge (not counting railroad-built bridges or back channel bridges) over the entire Ohio River! The bridge was also famous, since some scenes from the movie Silence of the Lambs were filmed on it. The Bellaire Bridge was one of three privately-owned bridges over the Ohio River between Ohio and West Virginia. In May 1991 the Interstate Bridge Company sold the right of way of the Ohio ramp to ODOT, who demolished the ramp to make room for the OH 7 freeway. Note that the ramp was at an angle to the bridge, connecting to 32nd Street. The bridge itself was sold to Roger Barack, who was going to reconnect the bridge with Bellaire, Ohio. This never happened because Mr. Barack was unable to obtain a permit. Barack tried again in the early 2000's, but was still unsuccessful. Since then this ''bridge to nowhere'' has sat as a barrier, separating Bellaire and Benwood. Other than the deck of the approach span, the bridge was in remarkably good condition. The bridge was undergoing refurbishment just prior to its closure, and most of the pins along the top chord were replaced. New floorbeams were also added to support the deck. With the bridge unused, the Coast Guard was concerned about the bridge collapsing and impeding navigation, and Norfolk Southern Railroad wanted a bridge pier off their property. Facing lawsuits, the bridge was sold in 2010 to a company to demolish the bridge for scrap. It is unlikely a new bridge will ever be built connecting Bellaire and Benwood.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1988
column20: After 21 years on the National Register of Historic Places, the Bells Mills Bridge was demolished in 2009. The bridge carried 265 cars per day. The single-span truss was replaced by a four-span concrete beam bridge on a different alignment. The bridge was unsuccessfully listed on the Pennsylvania Bridge Marketing site. According to the National Register nomination form, ''The bridge in Greenwood Township is a typical example of a Pratt through truss. It was built in 1892 by King Bridge Company, a leading nineteenth century manufacturer of metal truss bridges in the United States. It is one of fourteen representative examples of the Pratt through truss included in this nomination. Most bridges of this type are located in the northwestern portion of the state. This bridge is unusual in that it is one of a few truss bridges located in the central part of Pennsylvania.'' The bridge was also noteworthy for its 197 foot long main span, an unusually long length for a pin-connected Pratt truss. Most comparable truss spans of that length are either Whipple, Parker, Baltimore or Pennsylvania trusses. Despite the demolition of the bridge, the builder's plaque was retained and installed at the site of the replacement bridge.

column15: Burr arch truss wooden covered bridge supported on wood beams
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1979
column20: This is the last covered bridge in Westmoreland County. It was strengthened with the addition of wooden beams. In 2009 the bridge was damaged by fire, but has since been repaired and reopened.

The Belltown Bridge is an early example of the steel stringer style frequently built in Pennsylvania in the 1960's and 1970's. The bridge retains its original guardrails. The bridge replaced a Pennsylvania truss which was on a different alignment. The abutments of the old bridge remain. When the bridge was demolished, it was dropped into the river and never removed.

column15: Pennsylvania pin-connected with Pratt pin-connected deck truss approach spans
column16: Oldest truss bridge accessible to the public over the Allegheny River
column18: King Bridge Company, American Bridge, Thomas McNally Company
column20: According to the website of the Allegheny Valley Trails Association, ''The spectacular Belmar Bridge over the Allegheny River was built in 1907 as part of a railroad built by local oil man Charles Miller and John D. Rockefeller intended to connect New York with Chicago. Ultimately, it transported much of the coal from Clarion County to Ashtabula on Lake Erie. Be sure to climb the stairs to see the river valley from the bridge.'' The bridge was built for the Franklin & Clearfield Railroad.

column15: Warren/Baltimore cantilever truss with Warren thru truss approach
column18: Ashland-Coal Grove Bridge Company, Kentucky Highway Commission
column20: The Ben Williamson Memorial Bridge (12th Street Bridge) is one of the few remaining pre-WWII cantilevers over the Ohio River. It might be the only one that has just been rehabilitated (instead of replaced). The bridge was built to replace the Winona ferry. Construction began in 1928 and concluded in 1932. Due to the 1928 Murphy Toll Bridge Act, the bridge was built with bonds paid with tolls. Once the bridge was paid off, the bridge became a free bridge in 1941. In 1985, the parallel Simeon Willis Memorial Bridge was completed, and the Williamson Bridge was converted to southbound traffic. The bridge was refurbished in 1999, and again in 2007. As part of the 2007 project, the bridge was repainted bright green from the gray you see in the photo from 2005. The bridge stands as an excellent example as an alternative to the replacement of a historic bridge.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 48'-long, 3 panel, pin-connected, Pratt pony truss bridge was built in 1885 by the Penn Bridge Works of Beaver Falls, PA. It is supported on ashlar abutments with flared, stepped wingwalls. The substructure is concrete capped. In 1993 the bridge was rehabilitated, at which time the bearings were encased in concrete, and 2 inclined endposts and 1 vertical member were repaired with bolted splice plates. In spite of the modifications, because of its age and documentation, the bridge is significant as an early example of a pin-connected Pratt pony truss bridge. It is also significant because it is a contributing resource to a potential rural historic district.''

column16: Last remaining pin-connected pony truss bridge in Elk County
column20: The Main Street Bridge in Benezette is the last remaining example of a pin-connected pony truss in Elk County. The bridge is attributed to the Pittsburgh Bridge Company / Nelson & Buchanan Company since the imprint from the removed plaque is diagonal, like the distinctive standard Nelson & Buchanan plaque. Nelson & Buchanan built other bridges in the county, including the now-demolished Maxwell Run and Arroyo Road bridges. The Main Street Bridge is a traditionally composed example of a half-hip Pratt pony truss. The bridge used to serve the main road through Benezette. In 1934, the bridge was bypassed when the state highway (PA 555) was developed. At some point the bridge was abandoned or sold, since it is no longer listed in public bridge inventories. The bridge remains open for pedestrian use, connecting the two sides of Benezette across Trout Run.

column16: Longest deck truss bridge in region
column20: The Benicia - Martinez Bridge is the largest deck truss bridge in the area. Though the lower chord of the bridge remains at a constant depth, the cantilever bridge consists of anchor spans and suspended spans. In 2007 a new parallel bridge was completed (a concrete segmental girder), and the bridge was converted to carry southbound traffic.

column2: Bergholz New Somerset Road Bridge Near Bergholz
column20: The Bergholz New Somerset Road Bridge Near Bergholz is the only Pratt riveted truss bridge remaining in the entire county. It is not a state-standard design.

column2: Bergholz New Somerset Road Bridge Near Holt
column18: The Ohio Bridge Corporation (U.S. Bridge Company)?
column20: The Bergholz New Somerset Road Bridge Near Holt is a welded Warren polygonal truss. The Ohio Bridge Corporation built their first bridge in 1952 and built many ever since. Dating from ca. 1950, this bridge is one of the oldest examples.
The Berlin Street Bridge is an example of a state-standard multi-beam (stringer).

According to the PAHBI, ''The single span, 132'-long steel rivet-connected Parker pony truss bridge built in 1936 is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls. The truss members are built-up top and bottom chord sections, with rolled I beam sections used for the verticals and diagonals. Rolled floorbeams and stringers support a concrete deck. The original railings were replaced with W-beam guide rails when the deck was replaced in 1986. The bridge is an example of a state highway department standard design rivet-connected truss bridge that was used with great frequency beginning in the mid 1920s.''

column2: Bessemer & Lake Erie Railroad Bridge Over the Pennsylvania Turnpike
column20: The bridge was built as part of the 1951 Western Extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike. All mainline vehicular overpasses were either thru girders or deck girders in the extension. Though railroad overpasses were rare, they were mostly built as thru girders. The notable exception is the pony truss overpass built west of the Beaver Valley Interchange. This bridge was built for a spur of the Bessemer & Lake Erie Railroad. Note how tall the girders are as opposed to that of a vehicular overpass. After the spur was abandoned, the bridge was taken over by the Pennsylvania Turnpike. The bridge now serves as a service road, allowing authorized vehicles to turn around.

Bethany College, a liberal arts college, is the oldest degree-granting institution in West Virginia. It was founded in 1840 (in what was then Virginia). Most of the campus is north of Main Street (WV 67), except for the athletic facilities to the south, connected by the Bethany College Bridge. It is an unusual variation of a kingpost truss with a suspended deck.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Flinn-Moyer Company of Weatherford, Texas; Rebuilt by the Austin Bridge Company
column20: According to the Texas Historic Bridge plaque, ''In the late 19th century, San Saba lacked direct access to developing railroad lines needed to reach expanding markets. The Beveridge Bridge, a single-lane suspension bridge, was constructed in 1896 to fill this need. The bridge was named for Irish immigrant John H. Beveridge, a former British merchant captain who settled in San Saba in 1849. He originally spanned the river with a dam known as the 'Beveridge Crossing.' By the 1890's locals petitioned county commissioners for a more reliable crossing. The Flinn-Moyer Company of Weatherford, Texas, built the Beveridge Bridge at a cost of $2275. County commissioners appointed John H. Beveridge to personally oversee the construction of the bridge that would replace his dam. Completed on June 24, 1896, the bridge was 190 feet long with a 140 foot suspended span. It extends approximately 300 feet between anchorages. The Beveridge Bridge withstood floods in 1899, 1922, and 1938. After the 1938 flood, county commissioners requested bids for its reconstruction. The Austin Bridge Company of Dallas was hired to carry out the work. In 1938, the bridge was reconstructed as an unstiffened suspension bridge with new parallel wire main cables spun in-situ on the original 1896 pipe truss towers using No. 9 gauge galvanized steel wire. In 2004, the bridge was closed to vehicular traffic due to deterioration of the main cable underground. The Texas Department of Transportation used Federal Highway Administration Transportation Enhancement Funds to replace the main cables and restore the bridge for pedestrian use. The bridge continues its transportation legacy as a pedestrian bridge and remains a county-owned landmark.''

The Birmingham Bridge is the widest bridge over the Monongahela River, designed for an urban highway that was never built. It is one of only two tied arch bridges over the Monongahela River (the other being the Fort Pitt Bridge). The bridge replaced the two-lane Brady Street Bridge. On February 8, 2008 a rocker bearing of a northern approach span failed, causing the girders to fall eight inches onto a pier. The bridge has since been repaired.

column16: Oldest truss bridge in Blair County, last remaining active pin-connected truss bridge in Blair County, documented by HAER
column18: J. A. Patterson (Engineer), M. H. Stebbins (Contractor), C. H. Reimard (Inspector)
column20: The Birmingham Bridge is the last remaining pin-connected thru truss bridge in Blair County. There is one other pin-connected truss in the county, a small pony truss, and that bridge has long been closed to traffic. According to the HAER Report, ''This single span pin-connected Pratt through-truss is unique for a Pratt truss in that the portals contain hip verticals that carry compressive stresses (hip verticals for the standard Pratt truss type carry tensile stresses only).'' The HAER Report gives the following history for the bridge, ''The bridge was erected in 1898 by the Penn Bridge Company of Beaver Falls, Pennsylvania, to replace a wooden bridge constructed in 1852. As built, it included a pedestrian sidewalk on the downstream side, which was later removed.'' The PAHBI has a different view of the bridge: ''The 145'-long and 16' wide, pin connected Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with wingwalls. It is dated 1898 based on the inscription on the masonry abutments. The trusses are traditionally composed, and the portal bracing is finished with a pediment-shaped strut with quadfoil punched decoration. The lateral and sway bracing is deep given the length of the span. The lower panel point has been changed significantly with the original hanger replaced with riveted connections to plates attached to the verticals. The floor beams appear to have been replaced when the connection was changed. The bridge is an altered example of a type and design that is well represented in the region and state. It is not historically or technologically significant because of the alteration to the lower panel points.''
The Bittinger Road Bridge is a state-standard concrete slab bridge from the 1930's.
This is the only truss bridge over the Gulf Coast Intracoastal Waterway south of the Tampa, Florida, area. The bridge was added to the National Register of Historic Places on March 29, 2001.
The Blacksville Bridge is a state-standard Pratt thru truss. The bridge has been well-maintained, and it is not structurally deficient.

column15: Segmental stone arch, with reconstructed concrete arch main span
column16: Ohio's Official Bicentennial Bridge, Location of Ohio Historical Marker, Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Blaine Hill S Bridge is one of the most historic and important bridges in Ohio. This bridge and the other surviving National Road bridges are the oldest bridges in Ohio. The Blaine Hill bridge is called an S bridge because the approaches are at an angle to the creek crossing. This was done because engineers did not know how to make a skewed stone bridge in the early 1800's. The 1828 Blaine Hill S Bridge has the distinction of being the longest example of this type of bridge in Ohio. The bridge was bypassed in 1932 by a longer and straighter bridge, although it continued to carry light local traffic until 1994. By then the bridge had become so deteriorated the western arch was on the verge of collapse. Though the bridge was due to be demolished, the community formed the Blaine Bridge Community Preservation Project (BBCPP). In 1999, the BBCPP successfully campaigned to save the bridge. The bridge was restored and the western span rebuilt with a concrete arch in 2005. Sue Douglass, Chief Officer of the BBCPP stated, 'Our Bridge was a vital link in the United States transportation history, an essential connection to this country's entire history. It is our responsibility, our obligation to preserve this treasured artifact, which tells the story of the American Adventure.'

column16: Location of Ohio Historical Marker, Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Blaine Hill Viaduct opened in 1932 as a realignment to the original National Road. The old road went along the hillside at a 6.3% grade and over the Blaine S Bridge. The new taller, longer bridge allows for a straight alignment over the creek and up the hillside. It is the only open spandrel concrete arch in the region. In 1964 Interstate 70 opened nearby, bypassing the Blaine Hill Viaduct in the same way the Blaine Viaduct bypassed the Blaine S Bridge. The Blaine Hill Viaduct is named 'The Arches of Memory' in dedication to Belmont County's World War I Veterans. Ironically, the original name for the bridge is all but forgotten.

The bridge replaced a large deck cantilever. The bridge is the highest deck girder in Pittsburgh. The bridge received the AISC (American Institute for Steel Construction) ''1989 Prize Award for Medium Span High Clearance,''' and the ''Outstanding New Bridge Design 1986'' award from ABCD (Association for Bridge Construction and Design).

column16: Oldest cable-stayed bridge in America; Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1977
column18: Runyon Bridge Company, Weatherford, TX (Initial Construction); Flinn-Moyer Bridge Company (1899 Rehabilitation)
column20: The Bluff Dale Suspension Bridge is the oldest surviving cable-stayed bridge in America, if not the world! It was designed as a variation of a suspension bridge by Edwin Elijah Runyon in 1890. According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''The Bluff Dale Suspension Bridge is the oldest surviving cable-stayed suspension bridge in Texas and may also be the oldest in the United States. One of seven Texas suspension bridges surviving from before 1940, it is part of a once extensive regional tradition of vernacular suspension bridges. Repaired in 1899 by the Flinn-Moyer Bridge Company and moved in 1934, the Bluff Dale bridge is also the only known surviving example of Edwin Elijah Runyon's bridge patents. The structure was nominated to the National Register of Historic Places in 1977.'' According to the Texas Historical Commission Marker, ''For at least 20 years vehicles had to ford the Paluxy River to reach Bluff Dale and points west. Wagon traffic increased after the Fort Worth & Rio Grande Railroad line reached the town in 1889. This iron bridge began to serve the public by spanning the Paluxy about 1891, on the main access road that became State Highway 10 and later U.S. 377. By 1933 arterial highway travel demanded a wider bridge. In 1934 authorities moved the ''swinging'' bridge 1.5 miles upstream where it serves local traffic.''

column15: Single Towers; Fan Arrangement of Cables; Concrete Segmental Girders
column18: Figg & Muller Engineering Group / American Bridge Company
column20: The Travel Channel rated the bridge #3 in the world. It was the longest bridge in the world with a cable-stayed main span when it opened. It replaced a pair of cantilever trusses, one of which collapsed in 1980 after being struck by a ship, the Summit Venture. 35 people were killed.

The Bobtown Mine Bridge is an abandoned bridge that was part of the electric locomotive system for the Bobtown Mine, owned by the Shannopin Coal Company. As evidenced by wooden walkways and guide rail railings, the bridge probably served some pedestrian traffic. Since the mine opened in 1926, it is likely that the bridge was built at that time. The mine closed in 1993 and has been abandoned ever since. The bridge connected the general offices on the south end of the bridge with the mine on the north end. There is some talk of restoring the offices for tourism as part of the Rivers of Steel National Historic Area. The bridge has an uncommon skewed configuration in which the panels are parallel to each other so that the cross braces are perpendicular. To make up for the skew, two narrow panels are opposite a regular-sized panel at the ends of the bridge.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, formerly the only Warren polygonal thru truss in county
column20: According to the PAHBI (MEM Reviewer), ''The one span, 310'-long, riveted Warren with verticals and a polygonal upper chord thru truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments. The top and bottom chords and inclined end posts are composed of rolled H section, and most of the diagonals and all verticals are laced channels. The metal railing used to finish the one cantilevered sidewalk is repeated inside the opposite truss line. The bridge is a county-built structure that was placed in 1937, probably a replacement of one lost in the great 1936 flood. The use of rolled section for chords and end posts is not common, but it is not an early example instate application.''

column16: Oldest truss bridge in Butler County, Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1895, pin connected, single span, 56'-long, Pratt pony truss bridge with the floor beams above the lower chords is supported on ashlar abutments with concrete wingwalls. The trusses are traditionally composed, and there are no innovative or distinctive details, but the bridge is complete, and it appears to have been fabricated by the Pittsburgh Bridge Company. It ranks as one of the oldest complete truss bridges in the district and it is historically and technologically significant based on its date of construction, which is based on its design, and its completeness.''

column15: Pratt, pin-connected, half hip, supported by stringers
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Bordell Crossroads Bridge is the only pony truss in McKean County that has been determined to be eligible for the National Register of Historic Places. The bridge was rehabilitated in 2001, in which load-bearing stringers were added below the road deck. According to the PAHBI (JPH Reviewer), 'The single span, 48'-long, pin-connected Pratt pony truss bridge built ca. 1890 is supported on concrete abutments. It has eyebar tension members and built-up compression members. Although traditionally composed, it has two distinctive details, the arrangement of the upper chord/vertical connections and the paired U-shaped floorbeam hangers. The upper chord/vertical connection consists of a pin plate placed inside of the toe-out channel built-up box section chord, and then riveted to angles which are in turn riveted to a plate located at the top of the vertical composed of toe-in angles with lacing. The rolled floorbeams are supported by two U-shaped hangers at each lower chord pin connection rather than the more common variation of one hanger. The bridge builder and date of construction are not documented by available records, but the bridge does reflect the variety of truss details used before widespread standardization and the preferences and activities of a fabricator active in this region of the state during the late-19th century. The bridge is historically and technologically significant as an increasingly rare and complete example of its type and design with distinctive details.'

column18: Allegheny County Department of Public Works (Norman Brown, Director; Vernon Covell Chief Engineer), Fort Pitt Bridge Works
column20: The Boston Bridge is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. It is the only remaining example of a thru cantilever over the Youghiogheny River. The bridge is unusual that it is more like a pony truss, with bracing just at the towers. The bridge was designed in-house by the Allegheny County Department of Public Works. As with the other county bridges at the time, the bridge's form mattered as much as its function. Unlike most bridges of similar type, the top chord is curved, mimicking a suspension bridge. The tower bracing is arched, similar to that of the county-designed Three Sisters bridges (Roberto Clemente, Andy Warhol, and Rachel Carson) over the Allegheny River in Pittsburgh. The only lacing used in built-up members is hidden on the underside of the top and bottom chords; all vertical members are rolled steel. Even the connections connecting the suspended span with the anchor spans are hidden by cover plates. The bridge was rehabilitated in 2010 - 2011 by Trumbull Corporation for $17.3 million. As part of the project, the bridge deck was replaced, though the original decorative railings have been repainted and reinstalled.

column15: Brace ribbed thru arch with closed spandrel concrete segmental arch approaches
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Andrew Canzanelli, The Phoenix Bridge Company; to be rehabilitated by STV Inc (Design Consultant), Unified Construction Inc. (Contractor)
column20: The Boston University Bridge is known as one of the few crossings where you can drive over a train over a boat, since the bridge spans a CSX Railroad Bridge over the Charles River. The approach spans are closed spandrel concrete segmental arches. To achieve clearance over the railroad bridge, the main span is a thru arch. It is one of only a few thru arches in Massachusetts and the only one in Boston. The thru arch is flanked by ornamental pylons. The bridge was originally named the Cottage Farm Bridge, though it was renamed the Boston University Bridge in 1949 at the request of Boston University students. It is undergoing rehabilitation in 2010.

column2: Boulevard of the Allies Bridge Over Brady Street and Forbes Avenue
column18: City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works
column20: Two large deck girder trestles were built for the original 1921 Boulevard of the Allies between Oakland and Downtown. One was constructed over Second Avenue Downtown and the other over Forbes Avenue and Brady Street in Soho. Both bridges were extensively modified due to transportation improvements in the area. The I-376 interchange was incorporated into this bridge over Brady Street and Forbes Avenue in the early 1950's. As part of the changes to the bridge over Brady Street and Forbes Avenue, the bridge was converted to carry inbound (westbound) traffic. An outbound ramp of I-376 was added to the center of the structure, and inbound ramp of I-376 was added towards the western end of the structure. A new bridge (with a ramp to I-376) was constructed to carry outbound traffic. The Birmingham Bridge was built above the structure, with ramps below the structure. The 1921 Boulevard of the Allies Bridge is well hidden due to all the alterations and new structures.

column2: Boulevard of the Allies Bridge over Forbes Avenue
column15: Continuous thru girder and floorbeam system
column18: McClintic - Marshall Company / City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works
column20: The bridge was one of three major structures (the other two deck girders on trussed bents) built for the Boulevard of the Allies. The Boulevard of the Allies was one of several urban boulevards built in the 1920's to connect Downtown Pittsburgh with the city neighborhoods and suburbs. The bridge was the longest thru girder in the City. It was decorated with architectural features, such as concrete eagle medallions. The girders were faced with concrete along the roadway. The bridge was historically significant due to its association with the Boulevard. After being in a state of advanced deterioration for many years, the bridge was replaced in 2008 with a deck girder bridge.

column2: Boulevard of the Allies Ramp to Forbes Avenue Bridge
column15: Continuous thru girder and floorbeam system
column18: McClintic - Marshall Company / City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works
column20: The bridge was one of Pittsburgh's oldest bridges built to be a ramp. It was constructed to connect the outbound Boulevard of the Allies with Forbes Ave. The Boulevard of the Allies was one of several urban boulevards built in the 1920's to connect Downtown Pittsburgh with the city neighborhoods and suburbs. Since it was built to be a bypass for Forbes Avenue through Uptown, ramps were used to connect it with Forbes. The bridge was historically significant due to its association with the Boulevard. After being in a state of advanced deterioration for many years, the bridge was demolished in 2008. Since Forbes Avenue was converted to carry one-way traffic and the new ramp connects on the left, a replacement bridge was not needed.

column15: Pratt pin-connected thru truss supported by a load-bearing tied arch
column16: Last remaining pin-connected truss bridge over the West Branch Susquehanna River built originally for vehicular use
column20: In the 1980's and 1990's, there were many pin-connected truss bridges over the West Branch Susquehanna River. As of 2011, the only one still standing intact is a railroad bridge converted for vehicular use. While the Bower Bridge is now officially considered an arch bridge, since a load-bearing tied arch was installed in 1988, the arch carries the last pin-connected truss over the West Branch Susquehanna River built for vehicular use. The arch retrofit was done as a low-cost rehabilitation solution to avoid the expense of total replacement. The same technique was done on only a few other bridges in Pennsylvania. The vast majority of comparable bridges are replaced. According to the PAHBI, ''The one-span, 132'-long, steel thru arch bridge was built in 1988 and fitted into the previous ca. 1910 pin-connected Pratt thru truss bridge. The Pratt trusses now merely serve as ornaments that are attached to a modern steel arch superstructure.''

Though the new 1927 McKeesport Duquesne Bridge was built parallel to the old bridge, the bridges connected McKeesport on opposite sides of Crooked Run (the stream is below 5th Avenue / Route 148). The new bridge is on the downstream (right) side. At first, the old bridge ended with just a curve to Bowman Avenue. Drivers trying to get to McKeesport had to make a right onto Bowman, make two more right turns, then a left turn, just to get to 5th Avenue at the bottom of the hill, east of Cliff Street (these streets were destroyed when the ca. 1970 interchange was built). The direct connection from the bridge to 5th Avenue was not completed until 1935, when Bowman Avenue was extended from the bridge over the Crooked Run Valley. This road was mostly built on fill, except for this rigid frame bridge built over Cliff Street. It seems that this connection and bridge should have been part of the original design. Note that the railings of the McKeesport Duquesne Bridge are integrated, also suggesting the structures were to be built together. Possibly the delay of the bridge was a result of the Great Depression, which started in 1929. Allegheny County was at the forefront of rigid frame technology, with the earliest structures built ca. 1930.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Brackenridge Park Bowstring is a rare example of a bowstring arch-truss, one of only a few such bridges in Texas. Based on the style, the bridge is attributed to the King Iron Bridge Company of Cleveland. The bridge appears to have been moved to Brackenridge Park. It is located near the Brackenridge Park Bridge, which was moved to the park from downtown in 1937. Interestingly, few historic bridge sites even mention the historically significant bridge.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Brackenridge Park Bridge is a rare example of a lenticular thru truss, the only such bridge in Texas. Bridgehunter.com indicates that the only other lenticular thru truss bridges in America are located in the Northeast (Pennsylvania, New Jersey, New York, Connecticut, and Massachusetts). According to the Historic Bridge Foundation, ''Visitors to San Antonio's Brackenridge Park are met by a regal lenticular through truss adorned with elaborate iron cresting and finials. Built in 1890 over the St. Mary's Street crossing of the San Antonio River, the unique [bridge] was moved to it's present site in [1925].''

The Brady Bridge is distinctive since it is a half-hip pony truss with a main span of 82 feet. Typically, bridges of that length are full slope pony or thru trusses. According to the PAHBI, ''The 83' long and 14' wide pin-connected, Pratt pony truss bridge dates stylistically to ca. 1905. The trusses are traditionally composed, and the bridge has no innovative or distinctive details. Some rivets have been replaced with bolts.''

column2: Brandywine Park North Bank Trail Stone Bridge
column16: Brandywine Creek Park is listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The stone arch bridge carries the trail along the north bank of the Brandywine Creek in Brandywine Creek Park. Designed by Frederick Law Olmstead, Brandywine Creek Park was acquired and developed in the late 1800's and early 1900's. The bridge spans a channelized tributary of Brandywine Creek. Much of the tributary's valley was filled in when I-95 was constructed in the 1960's.

column15: Cable, double intersection Warren stiffening truss
column16: Possibly eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: In 1879, a pedestrian suspension bridge was built over Brandywine Creek near the location of the current bridge. A railroad bridge was built next to the suspension bridge in 1885. A year later, land was purchased to become Brandywine Creek Park. The suspension bridge became the northern limit of the park. In 1909, the B&O Railroad replaced its original bridge with a new structure at the site of the suspension bridge. The piers of the 1885 bridge still serve as piers of the modern Augustine Bridge. The railroad built a replacement suspension, the existing Swinging Bridge, just downstream of its 1909 stone arch bridge. Today it is a rare pedestrian suspension bridge that is over a hundred years old.

According to the PAHBI, ''The skewed, 42'-long and 16' wide, reinforced concrete closed spandrel deck arch bridge built in 1916 is neither technologically nor historically significant. The bridge is an example of a common type with no distinctive or innovative details. It has flat paneled parapets atop flared wingwalls. The reinforced concrete deck arch bridge gained popularity quickly in the state in the 1900s and was used with great frequency.''

In 1940, the first stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike opened between Irwin and Somerset. The original mainline overpasses consisted of arched concrete rigid frames, steel thru girders, and concrete tee beams. The remaining tee beams were replaced in the 1990's. Beginning in the late 1990's and continuing through at least 2020, the entire original turnpike is being reconstructed and widened. Almost all original overpasses are being replaced as part of the project. This will include the Briar Valley Road Overpass. It is an example of a thru girder.

This private driveway bridge over Little Yellow Creek is a rare four panel Pratt pony truss. The five panel half-hip pony truss is much more common than the two-span full slope pony truss. The bridge exhibits standard details from the Wrought Iron Bridge Company.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Reed & Kuhn (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The four-span continuous, 325'-long, steel stringer bridge (72'-90'-90'-72') built in 1947 is supported on concrete piers and abutments with wingwalls. The beams are made continuous by riveted splice plates. The bridge has standard metal railings, concrete deck, and steel diaphragms. Continuous steel stringer highway bridges were introduced nationally in the late 1920s and early 1930s. The Pennsylvania State Highway Department adopted the design in the late 1930s and built a number of continuous steel stringer bridges before WW II steel shortages curtailed their construction. Widely built after WW II, more than 150 pre-1957 examples are found statewide.''
The bridge is a common example of a post-World War II steel stringer.

column15: Pratt pin-connected, cast and wrought iron
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The one-span, 74'-long, wrought- and cast-iron Pratt thru truss bridge built ca. 1885 is supported on stone abutments. The bridge exhibits uncommon surviving period details including the cast-iron connecting pieces, flat bar lower chords with bolted lap joints, and verticals composed of I beams. The bridge members are joined by a combination of pin connections and compression fittings. The details are distinctive of the work of the Columbia Bridge Works of Dayton, OH. The bridge is a rare and exceptionally complete example of a cast- and wrought-iron truss bridge. Its construction is representative of the historically significant era of experimentation in metal truss bridge construction following the Civil War when bridge builders developed a diversity of iron truss bridge designs and details. The bridge is historically and technologically distinguished.''

column15: Parker riveted thru with Parker thru and Parker pony approach
column20: The Bridgewater Rochester Bridge is the longest simple truss bridge in Beaver County. Although it is an example of a state-standard Parker thru truss (one of only two in the county), it is unusual in that it has a large (367 foot) main span, a smaller thru span (over the former Fort Wayne Division of the Pennsylvania RR), and a pony approach span. The concrete substructure of the bridge incorporates portions of the stone substructure from the previous bridge.
