column18: Allegheny County, Charles Davis, Engineer, Charles Driver, Builder
column20: The Brighton Road Bridge is one of the turn of the century Charles Davis Allegheny County stone arch bridges, dating from 1896. It maintains a high degree of historical integrity. Though the arch is perpendicular to the creek, the abutments form part of a U-shaped curve of Brighton Road through the Spruce Run Valley. The area (and the 17 foot bridge) was essentially bypassed by the 630 foot long high-level Ohio River Boulevard Bridge in 1930, demonstrating how far technology and road building has progressed in 34 years.

This bridge is a rare example of an open spandrel concrete arch bridge built specifically to span a highway. The Parkway East is an old example of a limited access freeway, constructed by Pennsylvania prior to the passage of the Interstate Highway Act. The bridge is also noteworthy that the deck has a horizontal curve of about ten degrees.
The current toll is $1.00.

The Broad Ford Suspension Bridge was built on the piers of a former 1883 P&LE railroad bridge. Once the railroad stopped using the bridge in 1921, employees of the A. Overholt & Co. Distillery used the bridge to get to work. That railroad bridge was replaced by the current suspension bridge. The suspension bridge was abandoned in 1945, and the distillery closed 10 or so years later when it was bought out by Jim Beam. Today, not much is left except for the towers and the main cables.

According to the PAHBI, ''The bridge carries a three-lane section of US 22 with shoulders and a sidewalk over the Beaverdam Branch of the Juniata River. The Petersburg branch of the Pennsylvania Railroad mainline (now Conrail) parallels the bridge in a post-WW II commercial strip development. The bridge is south and outside of the Hollidaysburg Historic District. US 22 was the William Penn Highway, an early automobile tourists trail created in the late 1910s. It was one of a number of cross-state routes. Although it had regional and local importance, it has limited national or state historical significance. The skewed, two-span, simply supported, 108'-long, steel stringer bridge, built in 1951, is supported on a cutwater concrete pier and abutments with wingwalls. It has a reinforced concrete deck and standard 1950s steel railings.''

The Broadway Avenue Bridge is one of the turn of the century Allegheny County stone arch bridges, built under the direction of Charles Davis. The PA HBI dates the bridge at 1900. The stone arch bridge is composed of rusticated ashlar. The northern parapet was removed when a stringer-supported sidewalk was added in circa 1929. The original southern parapet remains, featuring tooled, bullnosed cap stones.

The bridge was repainted gold in 2007, a few years after the photograph was taken. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1951, 2 simple span, 147'-long, steel stringer bridge is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls and a concrete pier. The bridge has a concrete filled steel grid deck and period steel railings with vertically scored concrete endposts. The bridge carries a 2 lane road, 2 shoulders, and 1 sidewalk over the Casselman River on the west edge of Meyersdale borough. Most of the borough was determined by PHMC to be a historic district with a period of significance of ca. 1870 to 1930.''

column18: The Ohio Bridge Company (U.S. Bridge Company)
column20: The Brookdale Avenue Bridge is a modern truss bridge from 1973 built to the proportions of a much older bridge. It is an uncommon Warren truss with a flat top chord on trussed bents. It was built by the Ohio Bridge Corporation. Most of the company's bridges have inclined top chords. Note how the road is curved in the center of the structure.

The Brownlee Bridge is one of three Warren pony truss bridges in Washington County. Note that the compression members such as the upper chords, endposts, and some diagonals are V-laced, and the tension members such as the bottom chord, verticals, and the other diagonals are laced with battens. This reflects an economy of materials often seen in older truss bridges.

Browns Island is a large island in the Ohio River north of Weirton, WV. Weirton Steel built a coke plant there, which was in operation until 1982 (Weirton Steel has had several different names, but was called Weirton Division of the National Steel Corporation at the time of the closing). Weirton Steel constructed and owned two bridges to the island, one to connect to Ohio over the back channel and one to connect to the main furnaces of Weirton Steel over the main channel in West Virginia. The bridge over the back channel is a thru girder on trussed bents. It is the only bridge with a thru girder main span over the entire Ohio River. In 2008, Arcelor Mittal Steel, which owns Weirton Steel, Browns Island, and the bridge, announced it would be selling most of the Weirton Steel site, including the island. A potential developer could use a historic bridge to lure interest to the island. However, it is more likely that the bridge will be demolished. Due to the placement of the freeway interchange, the location of this bridge is the most likely place to construct a new crossing to the island.

Browns Island is a large island in the Ohio River north of Weirton, West Virginia. Weirton Steel built a coke plant there, which was in operation until 1982. (Weirton Steel has had several different names, but was called Weirton Division of the National Steel Corporation at the time of its closing.) Weirton Steel constructed and owned two bridges to the island, one to connect with the main furnaces of Weirton Steel over the main channel in West Virginia and the other to connect with Ohio over the back channel. The bridge over the main channel is a Warren cantilever thru truss. Due to recent bridge demolitions, the only other cantilever over the Ohio River in West Virginia that may be older is the Bellaire Bridge (which is abandoned and is to be demolished). In 2008, Arcelor Mittal Steel, which owns Weirton Steel, the island, and both bridges, announced that it would be selling most of the Weirton Steel site, including the island. A potential developer could use the historic bridges to lure interest to the island. However, it is more likely that the bridges will be demolished.

column2: Brownsville Road Bridge Over Lick Run
column20: Around 1950, according to the PA Historic Bridge Inventory, the bridge was widened with an addition of a concrete slab on the downstream side. The upstream side (pictured) was encased with concrete and new flat paneled concrete parapets were built. The arch and slab have a brick lining as protection from acid mine drainage.

column2: Brownsville Road Bridge Over Piney Fork
column20: The Allegheny County concrete arch bridge was widened circa. 1950 and rehabilitated in 1987, in which the bridge was re-decked and the parapets were replaced by concrete barrier.

According to the PAHBI (MEM Reviewer), ''The county-designed, skewed, 56' long and 24.6' wide reinforced concrete deck arch bridge is finished with custom, Neo-Classical balustrades with urn-shaped balusters. It was built in 1921, and it exhibits sections of spalling on the end posts and arch ring that have resulted in the loss of original fabric.''

column15: Steel culverts supporting a Warren pony truss
column20: Instead of demolishing the 1907 pony truss, fill on top of steel pipe culverts was added to support the structure. The trusses now serve just as railings. This is a cost-effective solution in which the bridge was replaced, though the important trusses were salvaged.
The bridge widened in 1938 with the addition on two T beams to each side. New railings and a new deck were placed at that time.

Buena Vista Road Extension once connected Linhart (at the current intersection with Thompson Run Road, Larimer Avenue, and Rodi Road) with Monroeville along James Street. The road is long abandoned. Between Thompson Run Road and the bridge, Buena Vista Road Extension (aligned with what is now Rodi Road) shared a narrow tunnel, approximately 300 feet long, under the Union Railroad with Chalfant Run. The road would have only been suitable for one-lane of traffic with a low height clearance. Much of the Union Railroad (which connected United States Steel factories) was rebuilt and improved in the 1930's and 1940's, due to the increase in production to World War II. Maps from ca. 1910 do not indicate the existence of the Buena Vista Tunnel, since the alignment of Chalfant Run was different. Therefore, it is possible that the tunnel and realignment of Chalfant Run and Buena Vista Road Extension were all built as part of the Union Railroad reconstruction. Aerial photos from 1938 show both the bridge and tunnel. The next bridge upstream also is at the foot of a comparable tunnel under the Union Railroad. Though the tunnel is shown on the 1938 aerial photo, the road was not realigned to cross the creek after the tunnel until 1940. The bridge is a comparable stringer. This indicates that work was done circa 1940 to realign the roadways, not just the valleys. Therefore, it is likely that the abandoned Buena Vista Road Extension Bridge dates from the same period, but prior to 1938.

column2: Buffalo and Pittsburgh Railroad Yard Bridge
column15: Pratt riveted with thru girder and deck beam spans
column16: Only active thru truss in Butler County
column20: The Buffalo and Pittsburgh Railroad Yard Bridge is the last active thru truss bridge in Butler County. The bridge has two skewed state-standard Pratt trusses over the two rail lines (Buffalo and Pittsburgh Railroad, Bessemer and Lake Erie Railroad). The bridge was rehabilitated in 1984 in which the stringer spans between the thru trusses were rebuilt. The advantage of thru trusses is that they provide higher vertical clearance over railroads than the deck girder spans.

column2: Buffalo Pittsburgh Highway West Branch Clarion River Bridge
column15: Closed spandrel parabolic concrete arch culvert
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Putman & Greene (Contractor)
column20: The Buffalo Pittsburgh Highway West Branch Clarion River Bridge is an example of a state-standard arch culvert. The road rests on fill above the arch. According to the PAHBI (EPV Reviewer), 'The single span, 28'-long, reinforced concrete arch culvert has concrete wingwalls at all 4 corners. The arch ring is accented with score mark.'

column18: D. E. Taylor (Engineer), Farris Engineering Company (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1925, 4 span, 386'-long (4 @ 96'), simply supported, built up riveted thru girder bridge is supported on concrete abutments. A cantilevered sidewalk has a metal railing. The floorbeams and the bottom flanges of the girders of the span above the railroad are encased in concrete to provide protection from locomotive exhaust. In 1990, a new deck with protective parapets inside the thru girders was placed. Bearing and superstructure repairs were also made.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1906, riveted, 7 span, Warren pony truss, is supported on ashlar abutments with wingwalls. The bridge was determined eligible as a result of the Section 106 consultation process.''

In 1940, the first stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike opened between Irwin and Somerset. The original mainline overpasses consisted of arched concrete rigid frames, steel thru girders, and concrete tee beams. The remaining tee beams were replaced in the 1990's. Beginning in the late 1990's and continuing through at least 2020, the entire original turnpike is being reconstructed and widened. Almost all original overpasses are being replaced as part of the project. This will include the Bugle Road Overpass. It is an example of an arched concrete rigid frame. The original parapets have been replaced. Most rigid frame bridges have plain abutment walls with vertically scored columns at each end of the span, an accented low chord, and balustrades. The Bugle Road Overpass is the alternate design with scored abutments, no columns, a recessed plain spandrel span, and closed parapets.

column15: Closed spandrel elliptical concrete arch, faced with ashlar
column18: Allegheny County, James Chalfant, Vernon Covell
column20: Under Allegheny County Engineer James Chalfant, several stone-faced concrete arch bridges were built throughout the county. The Bull Creek Road Bridge was built in 1922, the year of Chalfant's death. Only one more of these similar bridges (Union Avenue over Robinson Run in Oakdale) would be built after this structure. Chalfant was succeeded by Vernon Covell. Small arch bridges under Covell were bare concrete without stone facing.

The 1912 Bull Run Bridge is one of the nicest historic truss bridges in West Virginia. It is a rare pin-connected Pennsylvania truss built before World War I. The bridge towers over the Cheat River in the scenic Cheat River Gorge. Other than Preston County's Rockville-Mt. Nebo Bridge, this may be the most challenging bridge to access. Approach it from the west on a long narrow dirt road on the side of a cliff. If you approach from the east side, you'll need an SUV or truck with high ground clearance, since the road is a steep, rocky path that descends into the gorge. The challenge of the journey makes the bridge even more worthwhile to see!

The Buncic's Bridge at the end of Urbania Road is in an area that is anything but urban. In fact, the bridge carries only 25 vehicles per day -- the gravel road is barely passable. The riveted Pratt pony truss has a concrete deck with a brick wearing surface, which is an uncommon, although long-lasting, surface for a bridge. It is the oldest riveted truss bridge in Fayette County.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 57' long and 15' wide pin-connected Pratt pony truss bridge is supported on stone abutments. The trusses are traditionally composed with the verticals being angles joined with lattice. The floorbeams, stringers, and timber deck with runners were replaced in kind in 1984....Cable counters have been added.''

column15: Burr arch truss, wooden covered bridge supported by stringers
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1980
column20: The Burkholder Covered Bridge was built as a multiple kingpost bridge. It was retrofitted with arches at a later date, making it a Burr arch-truss. The bridge was rehabilitated in 1990, in which load-bearing steel beams were added.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The one span, 109'-long, pin-connected, Pratt thru truss bridge was fabricated in 1885 by the Pittsburgh Bridge Company. The bridge is one of six identified truss bridges (ca. 1870-1924) in Franklin County [as of 2010, only three remain], and the only Pratt thru truss. The bridge, composed of standard built-up sections, has no significant alterations. It is supported on stone abutments with flared wingwalls. The Pittsburgh Bridge Company, established in 1878, was a successful fabricator and marketer of bridges in the state in the last two decades of the 19th century. The company had an important Franklin County connection in Thomas M. Nelson of Chambersburg, who operated as an agent contractor for the erection of the company's bridges beginning in 1883, and served as the company president from 1896 to 1900. The bridge is historically and technologically significant in the context of late-19th-century metal truss bridges in Franklin County.''

column15: Pratt riveted with deck girder and floorbeam system approaches
column16: Prior to demolition, the only deck truss bridge in Butler County, eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 12 span, 839' long viaduct built in 1918 has a 185' long riveted Pratt deck truss main span and approach spans composed of both built up deck girder and stringer span supported on concrete abutments and built up steel column bents. The bridge is traditionally composed, and there are no innovative or distinctive details. In 1972 the original balustrades were removed and a cantilevered deck section and modern metal railings were added. The bridge is an example of common period technologies, and it is not individually technologically significant. It is however, historically significant in association with the Bessemer & Lake Erie RR that was developed south of Butler after 1895. It is one of the most important short lines in the region.''

The bridge was built as part of the 1951 Western Extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike. Around 2005, the section of mainline around the Butler Valley Interchange was reconstructed. Instead of being replaced like most of the mainline overpasses, the Butler Valley Interchange Bridge was rehabilitated. It was repainted from gray to brown (no, it is not made of weathering steel). The bridge is an example of a deck girder (stringer).

The Bypassed Freeport Road Bridge is an example of an Allegheny County stone arch. It was abandoned when Freeport Road was realigned and widened to the east of the bridge. The newer Freeport Road structure is a culvert. As per the Allegheny County stone arch bridges, the structure is unusual since the arch is relatively short but tall. The bridge appears to be a stone arch, rather than a stone-faced concrete arch. Therefore, it would have been designed by Allegheny County under the direction of Charles Davis.

The Bypassed Verona Road Bridge is one of the several surviving Allegheny County stone arch bridges designed under Charles Davis. With a span of only 8 feet, the bridge has the shortest main span of the surviving Davis stone arches. Despite the small arch, the bridge has 37 foot long and over 15 foot high parapets. This is atypical of Davis's arch bridges. However, the design best fits a ravine deeper than it is wide. The bridge was bypassed when Verona Road was realigned. Now it serves as an entrance to a parking lot for the Rosedale Volunteer Fire Department and the Rosedale Park.

The Cornelius H. Charlton Bridges are named after a Korean War Medal of Honor recipient who was born in West Virginia. He sacrificed his life for his country in 1951, three years before the original (now SB) bridge opened. He served in the 24th Infantry Regiment, the last all-African American regiment in the war. The original West Virginia Turnpike opened in 1954, predating the 1956 Interstate Highway Act. Due to the extreme cost of building a road through such a mountainous state as West Virginia, only 88 miles of roadway were constructed (from south of Charleston to Princeton). The limited access highway was a 'Super-2,' since only one lane was constructed in each direction. Once Interstate 77 was connected to each end of the turnpike, it was apparent that the turnpike needed to be widened and brought up to interstate standards. As part of the project, the C. H. Charlton Bridge was twinned in the 1979, and the original was rehabilitated in 1984. The newer northbound bridge is shown in the photograph. The original West Virginia Turnpike had two similar deck trusses, the C. H. Charlton Bridge and the Bender Bridge (named after another Medal of Honor recipient). Both bridges were distinctive for the X-shape of the trusses directly above the main piers at the downward point of the trusses. Typically, that shape is a either a diamond or a V. The bridges were also distinctive in that the trusses were very deep over the two piers, creating an arch-like center span. The Bender Bridge was located at the eastern end of the Memorial Tunnel. The Bender Bridge was closed and subsequently demolished after the Memorial Tunnel was bypassed with an open cut in 1987. Now the old span of the C. H. Charlton Bridge is the only one like it in West Virginia, if not the country. The newer twin span of the C. H. Charlton Bridge is a more typical deck cantilever truss.

The Cornelius H. Charlton Bridges are named after a Korean War Medal of Honor recipient who was born in West Virginia. He sacrificed his life for his country in 1951, three years before the original (now SB) bridge opened. He served in the 24th Infantry Regiment, the last all-African American regiment in the war. The original West Virginia Turnpike opened in 1954, predating the 1956 Interstate Highway Act. Due to the extreme cost of building a road through such a mountainous state as West Virginia, only 88 miles of roadway were constructed (from south of Charleston to Princeton). The limited access highway was a 'Super-2,' since only one lane was constructed in each direction. Once Interstate 77 was connected to each end of the turnpike, it was apparent that the turnpike needed to be widened and brought up to interstate standards. As part of the project, the C. H. Charlton Bridge was twinned in the 1979, and the original was rehabilitated in 1984. The newer northbound bridge is shown in the photograph. The original West Virginia Turnpike had two similar deck trusses, the C. H. Charlton Bridge and the Bender Bridge (named after another Medal of Honor recipient). Both bridges were distinctive for the X-shape of the trusses directly above the main piers at the downward point of the trusses. Typically, that shape is a either a diamond or a V. The bridges were also distinctive in that the trusses were very deep over the two piers, creating an arch-like center span. The Bender Bridge was located at the eastern end of the Memorial Tunnel. The Bender Bridge was closed and subsequently demolished after the Memorial Tunnel was bypassed with an open cut in 1987. Now the old span of the C. H. Charlton Bridge is the only one like it in West Virginia, if not the country. The newer twin span of the C. H. Charlton Bridge is a more typical deck cantilever truss.

column2: C. L. Schmitt Bridge (New Kensington Bridge)
column20: The 1927 C. L. Schmidt Bridge is the third oldest multi-span truss bridge over the entire Allegheny River, as of 2009. The only structures that are older are the Vandalia Bridge in Vandalia, NY (which is abandoned) and the Hulton Bridge in Oakmont (which is to be replaced). It is one of the many Allegheny County designed bridges built in the 1920's and 1930's, during Allegheny County Department of Public Works prominence in bridge engineering. However, the C. L. Schmidt Bridge and the similar 1927 McKeesport-Duquesne Bridge over the Monongahela River are the only Allegheny County thru truss river crossings built in this time period. The bridge is named after C. L. Schmidt, who served in the Pennsylvania State Legislature.

According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, ''The two-span simply supported, 58'-long, steel stringer bridge, built in 1939, is supported on concrete abutments and a cutwater concrete pier. It has an open steel grid deck and welded steel railings.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1902, riveted, single span, 61'-long, Pratt pony truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with wingwalls. The upper chords are built up box sections, the lower chords are channels with battens, and the verticals and diagonals are angles with battens. The bridge, one of nine riveted Pratt pony truss bridges from the early 20th century remaining in Butler County, is historically and technologically significant as an early, complete example of its technology. It represents the transition from pinned to riveted field connections in highway applications.''

The Caledonia Pike Bridge is one of only two thru girders in Elk County. According to the PAHBI, ''The 2 span, 177'-long built-up steel thru girder bridge is supported on a concrete pier with an ashlar curtain wall and concrete abutments with wingwalls. Rolled stringers support the concrete deck. The bridge is a well preserved example of its type, although not an early example since the type has been used with great frequency since the 1890s.''

column2: California Avenue Bridge over Jacks Run
column18: Allegheny County, John F. Casey Co.
column20: The California Avenue Bridge was the longest-spanning concrete arch bridge in Allegheny County when it was built in 1924. Today it is second, behind only the George Westinghouse Memorial Bridge. This was the last of all the grand concrete arch bridges to retain its original railings and architectural features. However, as an Allegheny County Bridge, the original railings were steel instead of concrete balustrades. The only other bridge to retain its deck is the soon to be demolished, buried Heth's Run Bridge, built by the City of Pittsburgh. The deck of the California Avenue Bridge was replaced as part of an $8.9 million reconstruction in 2010. The California Avenue Bridge is also noted for carrying the Lincoln Highway (now US 30), though the highway was rerouted a few years after the bridge opened. The bridge stands as a monument to the use of an open spandrel design for its aesthetic appeal for a national road in an urban area.

column2: California Route 120 West to Interstate 5 South Connector Bridge
column20: As former Route 120 between Tracy and Stockton became busier in the 1930's and 1940's, a twin span was built across the San Joaquin River in 1949. When the road was upgraded to become Interstate 5 in 1971, the bridge was retained for ramps from west Route 120 to South Interstate 5. The moveable span is no longer used.
The Callensburg Bridge is a state-standard steel stringer bridge. It was built on the abutments of the previous 1901 bridge.

According to the National Bridge Inventory, the Calvert Hill Road Bridge was constructed in 1915. This is a late date for a pin-connected pony truss; many small truss bridges were riveted with gusset plates by that time. Despite a 1939 rehabilitation, the bridge has mostly been unaltered since its construction.

The Cambridge Springs Bridge is a rare example of a pin-connected Pennsylvania truss. As of 2010, it carries a major US highway with no weight limit. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1901, pin connected, single span, 203'-long, Pennsylvania thru truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls. The trusses have no innovative or distinctive details. The bridge was modified in 1986 when the lower end of all verticals had plates bolted and welded to them and the sub-ties were strengthened by added material.''

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Roberts Supply Co.
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The single-span, 81'-long, steel built-up through girder bridge, built in 1930, is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls. The upstream side has a metal lattice railing, and the downstream side has a solid concrete parapet. Girder bridges were first developed by the railroad industry in the 1850s, and they were used on roadways beginning in the late 19th century.''

column15: Pin connected Pratt thru with Pratt pony approaches
column20: The Camp Creek Road Bridge is the oldest bridge in Clay County. It is one of, if not the oldest vehicular bridge over the Elk River. The National Bridge Inventory dates this bridge from 1925. That is clearly incorrect, since pin-connected truss bridges date from before World War II. The bridge looks to have been built around 1900. It is possible that the bridge was moved to this location in 1925, though unlikely due to the pony truss spans (which appear to be the same age as the bridge). Behind the Elkhurst Suspension Bridge, this is Clay County's second most historic bridge.

Camp Rainbow is a summer camp located along Connoquenessing Creek in eastern Beaver County. A two-span Warren thru truss connects the two parts of the camp. It is the last Warren truss bridge over the entire Connoquenessing Creek and one of only two remaining two-span trusses. Since the early 1990's, all eight publicly owned truss bridges over the creek have been demolished. Being a private bridge, the Camp Rainbow Bridge is the only one left.

In Zion National Park, the Canyon Overlook Trail extends under a cliff over the side of the Pine Creek Gorge on this small pedestrian bridge. It is not often one walks on a bridge over a cliff under a mountain!

column16: Last surviving span of the 1948 Carey Avenue Bridge
column20: In 1948, a new bridge at Carey Avenue opened across the Susquehanna River. The bridge had seven Parker thru trusses over the river and an island. At the north end, the bridge had an at-grade intersection with Beade Street and then a pony truss span over the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad. In 2002 the replacement Carey Avenue Bridge opened to traffic, and the old bridge over the river was subsequently demolished. Only this pony truss span over the abandoned railroad remains. According to the PAHBI, ''The single span, 137'-long, steel Parker pony truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with concrete caps. The bottom chord and floor system are encased in concrete. The vertical and diagonal members are rolled sections, and the top chords are built-up members. Standard pipe railings with bar fill are placed to the inside faces of the trusses. The Parker truss, a variation of the Pratt truss with polygonal top chord, was developed by American engineer Charles Parker in the early 1870s. The rivet connected Parker truss was adopted by the state highway department as a standard in the 1920s because the well established technology offered an economic alternative to other bridge types in a span range of approximately 100' to 250'.''

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Carlton Bridge is a rare surviving example of a multi-span thru truss from the Columbia Bridge Works of Dayton, Ohio. The Columbia Bridge Works bridges are distinctive since compression members are rolled I beams, rather than the built-up members used by most other bridge companies. According to www.mercercotrussbridges.com, ''The Pratt Through Truss bridge features the distinctive, idiosyncratic details of its fabricator, the Columbia Bridge Works of Dayton, Ohio. Company trademarks include the extensive use of I-beams and bolted connections, such as those on the lower chords, which the company called lap-jointed ''Flat Bar Chords.'' The company's designs reflect the experimentation that characterizes early truss bridge designs. The Columbia Bridge Works of Dayton, Ohio was established in 1852 by David H. Morrison (1817-1882), Dayton's first city engineer. Morrison ranks among the earliest engineers to recognize the possibilities of metal truss bridge technology, establishing one of the first bridge companies in the nation, and reportedly building the first all-iron bridge west of the Allegheny Mountains. The firm specialized in Morrison's patented designs, the most successful of which was a bowstring arch-truss built throughout the Midwest in the 1860s and 1870s. In the early 1870s, the Columbia Bridge Works began to produce variations of the Pratt truss design. Like many bridge builders of the period, Morrison developed a number of distinctive, idiosyncratic details. Trademarks were the extensive use of I-beams, which Morrison correctly believed to be an ideal shape for primary members, and bolted lower chord connections that Morrison called lap jointed ''Flat Bar Chords.'' He claimed that the chords increased stiffness and reduced vibrations from large moving loads. Morrison passed away in 1882, but his company continued under the direction of his son, Charles Carroll Morrison, who had joined as a partner in 1868. The company remained in operation into the 1890s.''

In the late 1940's, Legislative Route 71 (redesignated I-70) was constructed, cutting through part of Carlton Drive Extension. South of LR 71 (I-70), the road was abandoned up to and including the bridge. The Carlton Drive Extension Bridge is a common example of a pre-World War II stringer.

The Carmel Achor Bridge is probably the most significant of Columbiana County's great selection of thru truss bridges. It is a rare example of a Whipple truss built by the Columbia Bridge Works of Dayton, Ohio. Columbia Bridge Works bridges are distinctive in that they used rolled I-beams instead of the typical V-laced built-up members. The bridge is also noted for its decorative features. The Carmel Achor Bridge, as well as the Grimms Bridge, Columbiana County's two Whipple truss bridges, are the only Whipple trusses in this entire region of Ohio. Thankfully, the bridge was completely restored in 2002. If only other counties would restore their historically significant bridges!

column15: Steel stringer supporting wooden covered Queenpost
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1979
column20: The 1889 Carmichaels Covered Bridge is a rare example of a Queenpost wooden covered bridge. It was rehabilitated in 1998 with the addition of load-bearing steel stringers. (This type of rehabilitation is rarely performed on metal truss bridges). The bridge is one of seven covered bridges in Greene County and is part of the annual Covered Bridge Festival.

According to the 1997 Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, the Carothers Street Bridge is the longest single-span Warren pony truss in the state and is thus historically significant. Unlike the Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Allegheny County, who designed the bridge, primarily used Warren trusses.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The photograph was taken in March of 2007, as the bridge was being demolished. According to the Historic American Engineering Record (HAER), ''The Carquinez Bridge is a cantilever truss structure which carries three lanes of westbound Interstate-80 traffic across the Carquinez Strait. (Eastbound I-80 traffic is carried by a parallel structure, erected in 1958.) The 1927 bridge was the first major auto bridge in the San Francisco Bay Area, predating by a decade the Golden Gate and San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridges. Replacing an auto ferry across the Carquinez Strait, the bridge was an important link in north-south traffic from the Bay Area to Northern California and the Pacific Northwest, as well as connecting the Bay Area to Sacramento and points east. The bridge's importance as a north-south link diminished somewhat with the opening of the Golden Gate Bridge in 1937, but it remains a critical highway link between the Bay Area and Sacramento, carrying an average of more than fifty thousand vehicles per day. With two main spans of 1100' each, the Carquinez Bridge at the time of its completion was the fourth largest cantilever truss bridge in the world, and the second largest in the United States. (The Queensboro Bridge in New York City, constructed in 1909, was the largest cantilever truss bridge in the U.S., with spans of 984' and 1182'.) Only five bridges of any type in the U.S. had spans exceeding 1100' in 1927 (the four being suspension spans). The Carquinez Bridge was the largest bridge west of the Mississippi River, and the first major bridge designed to resist seismic forces. One of the biggest challenges for the engineers was the construction of piers in the deep and swift waters of the Carquinez Strait. Two of the bridge's piers extend approximately 135' below mean high water to bedrock, through 80'-90' of water and 45'-55' of earth beneath the channel. These were the deepest water piers ever constructed at that time, a record later surpassed by the Golden Gate and San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridges.''
The 1958 bridge was built as a twin span for the 1927 Carquinez Bridge. As such, the bridge was built to the same dimensions of the previous bridge, though the deck was widened to carry four lanes.

The bridge in the foreground of the photograph is a CSX Railroad Bridge. It was built in 1915 and is a rolling lift through truss. Tampa may replace the Cass Street Bridge if funding becomes available.

column15: Segmental stone deck arch with stepped ribs, widened with concrete tee beams
column20: The Castle Shannon Boulevard Bridge is most likely one of the Allegheny County stone arch bridges designed under Charles Davis. It was built circa 1900. The bridge is unusual since it is on a skew. To accommodate the skew, each arch ring is offset or ''stepped'' from the previous one. In circa 1920, the bridge was widened by the addition of concrete T beams. As shown in the photo, the stone arch is now obscured, since the widened eastern side has been extended over the creek to meet the perpendicular Poplar Avenue. The western side of the creek is in a narrow channel between buildings. Most people have no idea that they are actually crossing a stone arch bridge.

column16: Last remaining multi-span arch bridge in Blair County
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 2 span, 146'-long (2 @ 73'), reinforced concrete deck arch bridge with a concrete substructure was built in 1910 as an 18'-wide bridge. It was widened in kind to 31' in 1941, and the original flat paneled parapets were reset.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The 3 span, 89'-long T beam bridge built in 1937 is supported on reinforced concrete abutments with wingwalls. It is finished with standard concrete balustrades. Light standards originally on the bridge have been removed.''

column16: Last remaining pin-connected thru truss in Warren County
column18: Pittsburgh Bridge Company, Nelson & Buchanan Company
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1889, pin connected, single span, 103'-long, Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on dry laid ashlar abutments. The floorbeams are connected to the lower panel points by Z-shaped hangers, a detail associated with the Pittsburgh Bridge Company, one of the most prolific fabricator of metal truss bridges in the state. One of two pin connected truss bridges in Warren County, the structure is historically and technologically significant as a complete example of its technology. Adding to its significance is its association with the Pittsburgh Bridge Company and its agent, Nelson & Buchanan Company.''

column2: Cemex Wampum Plant Bridge (Formerly Medusa Cement Company)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The bridge carries an abandoned single-lane road owned by Medusa Cement Company [Cemex] over a two-lane road. The 50'-long, closed spandrel reinforced concrete elliptical deck arch bridge, built in 1930, has paneled concrete parapets. The reinforced concrete deck arch gained popularity quickly in the 1900s and was used with great frequency in Pennsylvania on local and county roads in the 1910s. There are better, and earlier, examples in the survey population.''

The Center Avenue Bridge over Lowries Run is the only example of a modern deck arch (newer than 1960) in Allegheny County. It uses welded and bolted connections and weathering steel. The other modern ravine bridges are all either deck girders or steel frames.

In 1940, the first stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike opened between Irwin and Somerset. The original mainline overpasses consisted of arched concrete rigid frames, steel thru girders, and concrete tee beams. All of the tee beams were replaced in the 1990's. Beginning in the late 1990's and continuing through at least 2020, the entire original turnpike is being reconstructed and widened. Almost all original overpasses are being replaced as part of the project. The Center Avenue Overpass is one of the few (possibly the only) overpass that has been spared. This is because the bridge has a longer span since it crosses an acceleration lane. It is also in a built-up area in which the new bridge would have to be built in the same place, resulting in a detour on heavily traveled road.

The bridge was built as part of the 1951 Western Extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike. All mainline vehicular overpasses were either thru girders or deck girders in the extension. The bridge will be replaced as part of the Turnpike widening, which will happen sometime after 2010. The Center Road Bridge is an example of a deck girder.

According to the PAHBI, ''The pin connected, single span, 49'-long, Pratt pony truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with flared wingwalls. The bridge dates stylistically to ca. 1895; its fabricator and construction date are not documented in available records. The upper panel points were strengthened ca. 1990 by plates bolted to the verticals below the pins. The lower portion of the verticals have been repaired with welded plate.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Center Street Bridge is one of the most significant remaining bridges in Crawford County. According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''Center Street Bridge is an unusually ornate example of a late-nineteenth century, pin-connected Pratt through truss roadway bridge. It is one of four surviving Crawford County bridges built by the Youngstown Bridge Company of Youngstown, Ohio, a nationally significant metal bridge manufacturing firm.'' According to the PAHBI, ''The 1896, pin connected, single span, 79'-long, Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on concrete-filled, built up caissons. Fabricated by the Youngstown Bridge Co., the bridge stands as a remarkably complete example of its type and design with its decorative cresting and handsome cast and wrought iron railing at the cantilevered sidewalk. The trusses themselves are traditionally composed, but the lattice filled portal brace and knee braces with radiation pattern fill are characteristic of the fabricator. The bridge stands out in a rich collection of metal truss bridges in Crawford County, and it is historically and technologically significant.''
The Center Street Bridge is a state-standard example of a post-World War II steel stringer.

column15: Pratt riveted with plate girder approach
column20: The truss span of the Center Street Bridge was originally built for a railroad bridge sometime in the late 1800's or early 1900's. In 1944, the end panels of the span were removed, and the remaining center section of the truss was relocated to its current location. A plate girder span was added to the north by the Pennsylvania Department of Highways. The original configuration or location of the truss span is not known.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 66'-long stone arch Center Street Bridge built in 1914 has Neo-Classical-style concrete balustrades with vase-shaped balusters. The bridge was built within the ca. 1870-1930 period of significance of the determined eligible historic district, and it is thus a contributing resource.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Karl A. Miller, Tonawanda Engineering Corporation
column20: The Center Street Bridge over Oil Creek in Oil City was designed and built along with its twin, the South Franklin Street Bridge over Oil Creek in Titusville. According to the PAHBI, ''The bridge was evaluated as a contributing resource to the Oil City Historic District that was listed in the National Register 10/24/97.'' The PAHBI has the following description of the South Franklin Street Bridge: ''The 1939, single span, 185'-long, tied arch bridge was designed and built by the Tonawanda Engineering Corporation. It is supported on ashlar abutments. The ribs are built-up riveted box sections and the ties are pin connected eyebars. The bridge is historically and technologically significant as an example of a rare type and design in Pennsylvania.'' According to HAER, the '' tied plate-girder through arch designed by Crawford County Engineer Karl A. Miller, and its twin in Oil City, Venango County, are examples of bridge building at the twilight of riveted steel superstructure design and the local efforts of a gifted engineer.''

The Central Avenue Bridge is a state-standard Parker truss from 1934. It is the larger of only two similar bridges in Washington County. The bridge has sidewalks outside the truss lines on both sides of the bridge, with their original state-standard railings and concrete end caps.

In 1955, US 290 (now I-35) was upgraded to a freeway though Austin, with two lanes in each direction. The road was only about 80 feet wide, including shoulders. Several rigid frame bridges were built over the freeway, including this one on Cesar Chavez Street. I-35 soon became congested, and this section of road was widened in 1962 with a northbound bridge over Cesar Chavez Street. The road under the bridge was converted to only carry southbound traffic.

column15: Warren riveted supplemented with load-bearing stringers
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1910, riveted, single span, 43'-long, Warren with verticals pony truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with flared wingwalls. Ca. 1996 the lower panel point connections were changed from riveted to welded, a number of verticals and diagonals were replaced in kind, lower chord members received welded repairs, and modern beam guiderails replaced metal lattice railings.'' In 1998 load-bearing stringers were added.
The Chapline Hill Road Bridge, built over a deep I-470 road cut, is an A-frame girder. The bridge is similar to the Fern Hollow Bridge in Pittsburgh, PA.

column15: Pennsylvania pin-connected (2 spans) with a Parker pin-connected approach spans, as well as modern stringer approaches
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1988
column18: Mercantile Bridge Company (John Tener, President), Emil Swensson (Engineer), American Bridge Company (Contractor)
column20: Until 2011, the 1907 Charleroi-Monessen Bridge is the oldest bridge over the entire Monongahela River outside of Allegheny County. With two 400-foot Pennsylvania truss main spans, it was the only simple truss bridge in the entire region to have two such spans back to back. It was an increasingly rare surviving relic of the once prosperous steel industry, connecting the glass-making borough of Charleroi with the steel town of Monessen. The bridge was built so a streetcar line could connect Monessen and Westmoreland County with Pittsburgh via Charleroi. A group of local businessmen led by future Pennsylvania governor John Tener reorganized the Mercantile Bridge Company to build the bridge. It was engineered by Emil Swensson, who at times worked for the Pennsylvania Railroad and the Keystone Bridge Company before forming his own practice as a consulting engineer in Pittsburgh. This bridge was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1988. In 1985 the truss superstructure was rehabilitated and the approach spans replaced From then until 2009 the bridge carried traffic with no weight restriction. However, a 2009 inspection revealed dangerous deterioration in some pins and vertical members. One of the 200-foot approach span pin hangers had bent directly over the railroad tracks. This may have been due to the steel being weakened from the steam trains that had been in use when the bridge opened. The bridge was demolished on July 11, 2011. The new bridge, a steel girder, will open to traffic in either late 2012 or early 2013. The new bridge will reuse the 1985 approach spans. It will be named after John Tener. After serving the area for over 100 years, the new bridge is anticipated to serve the area for the next 100 years.

column15: Wichert Truss; Deck Pratt Cantilever Truss
column18: City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works, E. M. Wichert Company
column20: The Charles Anderson Bridge is an extremely rare deck cantilever truss with the Wichert Self-Adjusting Truss, which is a hinged open diamond shape that makes each span of the continuous truss statically determinate. Fewer than five Wichert trusses exist anywhere. The only other one in the Pittsburgh, which is the prototype, is the Homestead High Level (Homestead Grays) Bridge. The bridge is also noted for its art deco pylons and railings.

column2: Charles C Rogers Bridge (Cotton Hill Station Bridge)
column20: The previous 1927 Cotton Hill Station Bridge, listed on the HAER, was a multiple span simple Pratt deck truss (with a Warren deck truss over the railroad tracks). It was similar to Clay County's Hartland Bridge over the Elk River and Harrison County's now-demolished Gypsy Bridge over the West Fork River. West Virginia Route 16 was built under the influence of the local and statewide Good Roads Clubs to connect US Route 60 and US Route 19. This road opened this part of Fayette County up to more manufacturing and commercial opportunities.

column2: Chartiers Creek Bridge Near Bower Hill Road
column20: The abandoned Pratt pony truss connects a factory in Kirwan Heights, Collier Township, with an abandoned road in Bridgeville near Bower Hill Road. The bridge appears to have served as an entrance to a factory as opposed to a through road that was taken over by the factory. Another pony truss is located nearby to the west, and is still used as an entrance to the factory.

column2: Chartiers Creek Bridge Near Union Street
column20: The Pratt pony truss serves an entrance to a factory in Kirwan Heights, Collier Township, connecting the factory with the parking lot in Bridgeville, on the other side of Chartiers Creek. Though Allegheny County once had many bridges built for factory employees, most have been abandoned or demolished. An abandoned pony truss to the same factory sits nearby, downstream.
The Cheat Lake Bridge is the only deck truss bridge over the entire Cheat River. It is one of the few (possibly the only) deck cantilever truss bridges in West Virginia with more than one main span.

The bridge spans a narrow section of the Parkway East at the bottom of a long 5% grade. When the Parkway East was reconstructed in 1981, the elevation of the roadway underneath the bridge was lowered by a foot to provide greater vertical clearance. When the Parkway was overlaid with asphalt in 2007, the 1981 concrete was removed to maintain vertical clearance. All original structures of the Penn Lincoln Parkway are considered to be historically significant, since the Parkway is an early example of a post-World War II urban highway.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Frank P. Graham (County Engineer), Wendell P. Brown (Consulting Engineer), The Roberts Supply Company of Lima, Ohio (Contractor)
column20: The Chestnut Street Viaduct was one of two open spandrel concrete arch bridges in Mercer County as of 2000. By 2008, both were replaced. According to the Mercer County Engineer's Office website, ''Mercer County Bridge No. 3116 was a structure eligible for the National Register of Historic Places. An Historic Bridge Recordation document was prepared to permit replacement of this structure. The Chestnut Street Bridge was located between Harvard and McConnell Streets in the Borough of Grove City, Mercer County, Pennsylvania and spanned Wolf Creek. The reinforced concrete, six-span bridge was built in 1930 to improve vehicular and pedestrian access between sections of the borough bisected by the creek. The bridge had an overall length of 312 feet (95 meters), and consisted of three adjacent open spandrel concrete arch spans on the east and three adjoining concrete T-beam spans to the west. The 92 foot (28-meter) long channel span over Wolf Creek was the largest of the bridge's six spans and was flanked on either side by a 44-foot (13.4-meter) open spandrel span. The arch span ribs had an approximate width of 3.5 feet (1 meter) in width and were strengthened by perpendicular concrete struts at the crown and spring lines of the main arch. The arch spans adjoined to a series of three 44-foot (13.4-meter) long T-beam spans on the west. Immediate access to the bridge was provided by a 76.5-foot (23-meter) long approach fill within retaining walls near McConnell Street on the west and a 40-foot (12-meter) approach fill with retaining walls near Harvard Street on the east. Bridge width was 34 feet (10.4 meters) from outer parapet edges, and included a 20-foot (6.1-meter) wide asphalt-paved roadway flanked by two five-foot wide sidewalks. Along the northern and southern elevations, the parapets consisted of forty reinforced concrete panels, each measuring approximately 3 feet (0.95 meters) in height by 7 feet (2.12 meters) in width. Aluminum tube handrails at the eastern terminus of the bridge provided additional protection against the steep slopes below Harvard Street. The six Chestnut Street Bridge spans were supported by ten square concrete piers (i.e., five along each elevation); these were set on squared concrete footings and had been scored on their outer face to imitate cut stone blocks. The steeply curved eastern reinforced concrete abutment at Harvard Street was stepped and received the base of the easternmost arch at the spring line. The western bridge abutment was square in form and served as a transition between the free-standing T-beam portion of the bridge and the adjacent earthen approach fill that leads to McConnell Street. The Chestnut Street Bridge contained two metal bridge plaques; these were situated along the northern and southern inner parapet walls, near Harvard and McConnell Streets, respectively. Both plaques were identical and listed the structure's official bridge number (Mercer County Bridge No. 3116) and its 1930 completion date. The plaques also identify the County Commissioners at the time of construction (W A. Bone, Harry Hunter, and Harry Gibson and lists Frank P. Graham (Mercer County engineer) and Wendell P. Brown (consulting engineer) as the designers of the bridge. The Roberts Supply Company of Lima, Ohio was listed as the builder. These plaques were transferred to the Mercer County Historical Society for preservation. Urban development in the project vicinity during the 1920s led directly to the construction of the Chestnut Street Bridge in 1930. According to the minutes of the Mercer County Commissioners, the commissioners entered into an agreement with Grove City Borough authorizing construction of the bridge on June 17, 1929. Construction bids from 11 competing Pennsylvania and Ohio firms were opened on September 10, 1929, and the contract awarded to the Roberts Supply Company of Lima, Ohio, for its low bid of $66,300 At the time of its 1930 completion, the Chestnut Street Bridge was the longest bridge in the county and was one of four Grove City bridges carrying automotive traffic across Wolf Creek during the early 1930s. The Chestnut Street Bridge is a significant representative example of the many reinforced concrete automotive bridges built across Pennsylvania and surrounding states during the first half of the twentieth century to facilitate efficient transportation within the state's emerging highway system. Construction of the bridge in 1930 contributed to Grove City Borough's increasing integration within the local and regional economy. The construction of the bridge in 1930 occurred as part of an evolutionary trend in bridge design that sought to improve the strength, ease of construction, and cost-effectiveness of highway bridges, using lighter and stronger materials.''

column15: Pratt riveted with modern steel stringer approach spans
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The skewed, 5 span, 319'-long bridge consists of a riveted, 153' long Pratt thru truss main span built in 1922 and four continuous stringer approach spans placed in 1975 replacing the original T beam approach spans. There are modern safety shape barriers on the approach spans. The truss span is traditionally composed with built up members, and it does not have any innovative or distinctive details. The cantilevered sidewalk on the truss span is finished with a lattice railing, and the same railing is inside the opposite truss. The bridge was significantly altered in 1975 when the approach spans were replaced. Its original appearance and associative significance with the B & O have been lost.''

When the PA Historic Bridge inventory was performed in 1997, PA 188 had five concrete arch bridges near each other. Four were over Tenmile Creek, and this bridge, the Children's Home Bridge (or Swart Bridge), was over Ruff Creek. One bridge over Tenmile Creek was an open spandrel; the rest were closed spandrels. Within a few years after the inventory, three of the closed spandrel arch bridges were replaced. In 2009, the other two bridges were replaced, including this one. The Children's Home Bridge had plain spandrel walls with paneled parapets. Due to spalling along the arch ring, only a narrow center lane of alternating traffic was allowed prior to replacement.

The original Chuck Yeager Bridge was built for the 2-lane West Virginia Turnpike in 1954. It was twinned in 1986 with the similar looking (though wider) bridge. In the photograph, the newer northbound bridge is on the right and the older southbound bridge is on the left The original West Virginia Turnpike opened in 1954, predating the 1956 Interstate Highway Act. Due to the extreme cost of building a road through such a mountainous state as West Virginia, only 88 miles of roadway was constructed (from south of Charleston to Princeton). The limited access highway was a 'Super-2,' since only one lane was constructed in each direction. Once Interstate 77 was connected to each end of the turnpike, it was apparent that the turnpike needed to be widened and brought up to interstate standards. As part of the project, the Chuck Yeager Bridge was twinned in the 1980s (completed in 1983). The bridges are arched cantilevers, in which the cantilever truss support structure is arched, with the road suspended below. The bridges are the only ones of this type in all of West Virginia.

The original Chuck Yeager Bridge was built for the 2-lane West Virginia Turnpike in 1954. It was twinned in 1986 with the similar looking (though wider) bridge. In the photograph, the newer northbound bridge is on the right and the older southbound bridge is on the left The original West Virginia Turnpike opened in 1954, predating the 1956 Interstate Highway Act. Due to the extreme cost of building a road through such a mountainous state as West Virginia, only 88 miles of roadway was constructed (from south of Charleston to Princeton). The limited access highway was a 'Super-2,' since only one lane was constructed in each direction. Once Interstate 77 was connected to each end of the turnpike, it was apparent that the turnpike needed to be widened and brought up to interstate standards. As part of the project, the Chuck Yeager Bridge was twinned in the 1980s (completed in 1983). The bridges are arched cantilevers, in which the cantilever truss support structure is arched, with the road suspended below. The bridges are the only ones of this type in all of West Virginia.

The Church Street Bridge was one of the oldest thru girders in Allegheny County prior to its 2008 demolition. It was one of several built by the Fort Pitt Bridge Works. The bridge was closed to traffic in the mid 1990's, though it remained opened for pedestrians until its demolition.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1919, 2 simple span, 164' long and 17' wide built up thru girder bridge is supported on concrete abutments and a concrete pier. The bridge has knee braces, built up floorbeams encased in concrete to protect them from locomotive exhausts, and concrete deck with a brick wearing surface. There are cantilevered sidewalks with metal fence-like railings at each side. Girder bridges were first developed by the railroad industry in the 1850s, and they were used on vehicular roadways in Pennsylvania beginning in the late 19th century. The bridge is not the first at this grade crossing of the B & O RR main line through Pennsylvania, and it is not historically significant in association with the line.''

The Church Street Bridge is one of a few surviving stone arch bridges in Fayette County. The bridge has been repaired by coating the east side with concrete, rebuilding portions of the wingwalls, and crudely repointing the masonry.

According to the PAHBI, ''The skewed, single span, 125'-long, rivet-connected Parker pony truss bridge is supported on concrete pargetted stone abutments with ashlar wingwalls. The top and bottom chords are built-up members, and the verticals and diagonals are rolled I beam sections.''

column18: B. M. French, County Engineer, The Canton Bridge Company?
column20: Though several truss bridges were recently rehabilitated in Columbiana County, the Clarks Mill Road Bridge was not one of them. The bridge was destroyed in 2007. It was a late example of a pin-connected Pratt truss bridge. It can be attributed to the Canton Bridge Company based on similarities with the Echo Dell Bridge. The Clarks Mill Road Bridge was modified with a jack arch deck, in which arched corrugated steel was placed between the stringers and filled with concrete. The problem with such a deck is that with time the steel rusts through, which leads to concrete deterioration. The deck had many metal plates in the years leading to demolition. Though the decks of several similar bridges in the county were replaced, the Clarks Mill Road Bridge deck was not. This is too bad, especially since the bridge retained some of the decorative metalwork above the portals.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, H. W. Baldwin (Contractor)
column20: The Clarks Mills Bridge is the only state-owned arch bridge in Mercer County. After the future replacement of the Race Street Bridge, it will be the last remaining arch bridge in the county. According to the PAHBI, ''The reinforced concrete, closed spandrel deck arch bridge was originally built in 1929. In 1986 the bridge received a new cantilevered concrete deck and parapets, widening the road by 3'.''
The Clarks Summit Bridge is one of the longest and highest Pennsylvania Turnpike bridges.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Conemaugh Township
column20: The Clarksburg Road Bridge is a state-standard concrete tee beam bridge. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1930, skewed, single span, reinforced concrete T beam bridge with concrete balustrades is supported on concrete abutments.''

The Clarksville Road Bridge was built to span a cut created for the Cumberland Mine Railroad (now owned by the Consolidated Rail Corp.). The bridge is a decorative example of a closed spandrel arch, with an accented arch ring, paneled parapets, and horizontal scoring. The former Cumberland Mine Railroad was a spur of the Monongahela Railroad, a coal-hauling line from Brownsville, PA, to Fairmont, WV.

column15: Burr arch truss wooden covered bridge supported by load-bearing stringers
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Relocated and rehabilitated by Joseph Lehman, Inc.
column20: According to Bedford County's website, ''This bridge, which stands at the entrance to Old Bedford Village, just north of Bedford, was built in 1880. It was built in Reynoldsdale and was moved to its present location in 1975. A pedestrian walkway was added to the original structure. It is a burr truss design which has been reinforced with steel to support bus traffic that frequents Old Bedford Village. The structure is unpainted. The roof is constructed of Cedar shakes and the deck consists of crossboard planks. It sits on poured concrete abutments. The sides are totally enclosed.''

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, John Maguire Construction
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 2 span, reinforced concrete, closed spandrel deck arch bridge with concrete balustrades was built in 1930 from a standard PA Highway Dept. plan.'' Note that while the road is sloped, the arches are not.

column2: Clearfield Curwensville Highway West Branch Susquehanna River Bridge
column15: Haunched continuous thru girder and floorbeam system
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, B&B Construction Co.
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The skewed, 3-span continuous, 348'-long, built up thru girder bridge (109'-130'-109'), built in 1940, is supported on concrete piers and abutments with wingwalls. The haunched girders have the characteristic greatest depth over the piers where the stresses are greatest. The girders support rolled floorbeams, stringers and a concrete slab deck. A sidewalk with standard metal railing is cantilevered off of the west side of the bridge. The continuous girder bridge technology, which achieved greater economy of material over simple span bridges of comparable length, was introduced nationally in the late 1920s and 1930s. Continuous designs were adopted by the Pennsylvania State Highway Department's Bridge Unit in the late 1930s, and they were an important improvement in steel stringer and girder bridges. They proved extremely adaptable to bridge building conditions in Pennsylvania because of their economy of material, ease of erection, permanence, and deck joint reduction, and they were built in increasing numbers after World War II. This 1940 continuous thru girder bridge is historically and technologically significant as an early and complete example of a long-span continuous steel girder bridge designed by the state highway department.''

column15: Pin-connected Whipple with riveted Warren approaches
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, Texas Historic Landmark - 1996
column18: Wrought Iron Bridge Company of Canton, Ohio
column20: According to the state historical marker, ''Built in 1884 by the Wrought Iron Bridge Company of Canton, Ohio, at a cost of $6,465, this bridge spans 150 feet across the North Bosque River. This type of bridge, called a Whipple truss, was named for its designer. One of the few remaining Whipple truss bridges in the state, it opened up travel routes from the south and west to the north and east. Withstanding many floods, the bridge provided an important transportation connection for Bosque County residents from 1884 to 1941 when traffic was routed west of the Bosque River to the newly constructed Highway 6. Recorded Texas Historic Landmark - 1996.'' The Warren approach spans were added at a later date, possibly in 1941. They replaced either wood or iron stringer approach spans.

column16: Pre-1900 example of a riveted deck truss
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 3 span, 258'-long, Warren deck truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments and piers. The bridge was built ca. 1898, and its design and narrow width indicate that it was originally a railroad facility. There are no floor beams at the panel points, as in a conventional truss. There are cross beams spaced close together bearing on the top chord. In 1974 it was extensively rebuilt. The original deck and railings were replaced with an open grid deck and beam guide rail railings. New upper chord box sections with welded connections were built around the original upper chords, and the lower chords were replaced in kind but with welded connections. Many of the diagonals and verticals have welded repairs, and rivets have been replaced with high strength bolts.'' Despite the alterations, the bridge was one of the oldest riveted deck truss bridges in use by vehicles in Pennsylvania when the bridge was demolished.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to Historic Highways of Pennsylvania (PHMC/PennDOT), ''This early twentieth century stone arch bridge imitates the camelback style of nineteenth century Pennsylvania highway bridges. It was constructed of rough, rock-faced ashlar in a semi-circular arch spanning thirty feet. The date of this bridge's construction was 1911, which was carved into a datestone located above the arch keystone. The extremely narrow wall above the arch crown accentuates the camelback shape of this bridge. Concrete coping caps the stone parapet walls of this arch bridge.''

The Clinton Frankfort Road (Murdocksville Road) Bridge is a stone arch dating from 1936. This indicates it was likely built with WPA funding. Note the difference of the stonework to that of the Allegheny County stone arch bridges built prior to 1910 under Charles Davis. According to most maps, this bridge is actually in Beaver County. However, since it is listed in both the National Bridge Inventory (NBI) and Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory (PAHBI) as an Allegheny County Bridge, it is included in Allegheny County on this website.

The Clyde Coal Company began their first mine in 1900 at Fredericktown and shortly began two other mines. The Clyde No. 3 Mine operated on the west side of Tenmile Creek near the site of this pedestrian swinging bridge. Frame houses were built by the company for bachelor miners; the area became known as Shantytown. The swing bridge was built to connect the mine and the houses of Pitt Gas across Tenmile Creek. The bridge is unusual in that three continuous cables are strung next to each other along each side, and they are braced together with horizontal members. The towers are composed of riveted angles. After a nearby mine disaster in 1944, the mine was temporarily closed, sold a few years later, and eventually shut down. By the 1960's, only ruins remained of Shantytown. The swinging bridge was abandoned.

The Coal Center Bridge carries Water Street over Pike Run just before it empties into the Monongahela River. The bridge is one of five remaining pin-connected Pratt thru truss bridges in Washington County. Note the unusual detail of the diagonal endpost connection with the top chord. The diagonal and the vertical are connected with separate pins. The top chord projects over the diagonal endpost. This is characteristic of Penn Bridge Company bridges from the 1870's through the 1880's. Some original plates which cover the extended top chord give the date as 1888. The bridge is similar to the Evans Bridge. In 1984 the bridge was rehabilitated, at which time a sidewalk was added, some floorbeams were replaced, and cover plate was welded to the bottom of the upper chords. Although this impacted the historic integrity of the bridge, it also gave the bridge a sufficiency rating of near 50 percent.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 5 span, 351' long, reinforced concrete ribbed rigid frame bridge built in 1942 is composed of 3 continuous girders with hinged joints to allow for expansion and cantilevered end spans. Expansion and rotation at the joint is accomplished by providing a hinge composed of eyebars with two pins fastened to channels embedded and anchored in the ends of the concrete girders at the joint location. The bridge is supported on 3-column concrete piers and stub abutments.'' The PAHBI also states that the bridge is eligible for the National Register of Historic Places since it is an early innovative adoption of its type.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Alex C. Bailey Contractor
column20: Dating from 1930, the Cochranton Bridge an early example of a state-standard truss bridge. It features the portal bracing composed of angles, seen almost exclusively on state-standard bridges from 1930. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1930, two span, 315'-long, riveted Parker thru truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments and a concrete pier. The trusses are composed of built up members.'' The bridge is to be replaced.

According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1910, skewed, riveted, 54'-long, Warren with verticals pony truss is supported on ashlar abutments with flared wingwalls. An example of a standardized design, the trusses have no innovative or distinctive details. The upper chords and end posts are built up box sections, and the verticals and diagonals are angles with either laced or lattice webs.''

The Colliers Road Bridge is on a bypassed section of Colliers Road (the new alignment is called Harmon Creek Road). Colliers Road used to cross a second bridge over Harmon Creek about 2000 feet to the south. That bridge has since been demolished, rendering the old alignment a dead end. The Colliers Road Bridge now just connects to an empty field. The bridge is a standard-looking concrete arch bridge from the 1910's, probably constructed by the Luten Bridge Company. On the same old road near the Pennsylvania border is a similar-looking bridge, built by the Luten Bridge Company in 1912.

The Coloma Road Bridge is an example of a cantilevered deck girder, built by American Bridge in 1965. Note the pins in the structure showing the connection of the suspended span to the anchor spans. The previous 1948 bridge was washed out in December of 1964 when the Hell Hole Dam broke, flooding the valley. In the 1970's, the Auburn Dam was to be constructed on the American River. The resulting lake would have flooded the bridge. However, after some work began, the project was cancelled due to environmental and seismic instability concerns.

column2: Colonel Drake Highway Bear Run Bridge
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, David Bailey (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1931, skewed, single span, 66'-long, T beam bridge with standard concrete balustrades is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls and a concrete pier. It has no innovative or distinctive details.''

column15: Parker riveted with concrete beam approaches
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1990
column18: Kansas City Bridge Company, G. G. Wickline (State Bridge Engineer), R. E. Schiller (Resident Engineer)
column20: The Colorado River Bridge at Bastrop is the only Parker truss in Bastrop County. It was built to accommodate increasing traffic on the highway connecting Austin and Houston. The bridge was bypassed by a wider bridge in 1993. Rather than demolishing the structure, it was taken over by the City of Bastrop as a pedestrian bridge. Events such as the annual ''Art on the Bridge'' are held on the structure. The bridge also has decorative lighting at nighttime. The converted bridge is an excellent example of historic bridge preservation!

column15: Open spandrel concrete arch with concrete tee beam and deck girder approaches
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: James B. Long (Consulting Engineer), Wiley-Maxon Construction Company (Contractor)
column20: According to HAER, ''The Columbia-Wrightsville Bridge is an outstanding example of innovation in bridge engineering. It demonstrates that concrete can be economical and aesthetically pleasing while showing that the material is well suited to the challenges of an unusually wide crossing. The span between Columbia and Wrightsville Carried the Lincoln Highway, which was traveled by increasing numbers of motorists in the late 1920's. [The Lincoln Highway was the nation's first coast to coast route]. The construction of the Columbia-Wrightsville Bridge was a cooperative effort between Lancaster and York counties, an innovation in itself, to relieve traffic jams caused by the previous bridge. [The previous bridge was shared with the Pennsylvania Railroad. Traffic was stopped on the bridge whenever a train needed to cross]. The Wiley-Maxon Construction Company made the most of the site's advantages and used creative means to adapt the extreme length of the bridge, approximately 1.26 miles. The span continued to carry the bulk of traffic between Lancaster and York counties until a wider [steel and] concrete girder bridge was constructed upstream along the U.S. 30 bypass in 1971. The Columbia-Wrightsville Bridge was designated a National Historic Civil Engineering Landmark on 16 October 1984. Today it continues to serve traffic on State Route 462.'' HAER states, ''When it was dedicated on Armistice Day, 1930, the Columbia Wrightsville Bridge was the longest multiple-concrete arch bridge in the world. Twenty-eight three-ribbed open-spandrel reinforced concrete arches, each spanning 185'-0'', carry the bridge across the Susquehanna between Lancaster and York counties. Another twenty spans make up the bridge's 6657'-0'' total length. The span's construction was innovative because it involved the cooperative effort of the two counties. Four bridges preceded this span at this historically important river crossing. The Columbia-Wrightsville Bridge was designated a National Historic Civil Engineering Landmark in 1984 and was listed in the National Register of Historic Places in 1988.'' The piers of the previous bridge remain to the north of the current structure. The second structure was destroyed during the Civil War, just prior to the Battle of Gettysburg. According to HAER, ''On 28 June 1863, Confederate troops were marching north under command of General John B. Gordon in an effort to capture Philadelphia when they reached the Wrightsville shore. Union forces on the Columbia shore first tried to blow up the bridge. When that effort failed, they set the entire structure on fire to prevent the Confederates from crossing the Susquehanna.'' Troops were thus unable to cross the river, and they returned to Gettysburg to join in the battle.

The Columbus Avenue Bridge is unusual in that the two pony truss spans are built at an angle to each other. The center pier consists of built up trussed bents and is much wider than the bridge. This is because there used to be a parallel bridge that angled in the opposite direction. The bridge was rehabilitated in 1990, and new steel members were welded and bolted to all built-up members.

As a response to a 1921 flood, a channel was dug to bypass a U-shaped stretch of the San Antonio River downtown. Work began in 1925, and the channel was completed in 1929. The Commerce Street East Bridge was built as part of the project to cross the bypass channel.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: The Oregonia Bridge Company, J. H. Sweetman (County Engineer)
column20: The Great Flood of 1913 swept away almost every river bridge throughout the south central part of Ohio. The flood was so devastating, a system of flood control reservoirs were built to prevent such future floods. The Commercial Point Road Bridge is one of many replacement bridges constructed in 1913 and 1914. As of 2009, it is one of the last surviving examples. It is the last of the large multi-span truss bridges over the Scioto River, and is the only historic bridge spanning the river from Franklin County (Columbus) to its mouth at the Ohio River. The bridge is a rare example of a camelback truss, one of the last remaining in state. Despite a replacement bridge being constructed on a new alignment, the historic Commercial Point Road Bridge is to be demolished in 2010.

The Parkway East Bridge over Commercial Street is the only multiple-span concrete arch bridge in the City of Pittsburgh and one of only three in Allegheny County. The bridge is near the eastern portal of the Squirrel Hill Tunnel. The structure is distinctive for its transverse Gothic style pointed arches between the arch ribs. The only other concrete arch built for the Parkway is the Brinton Road overpass.

column15: Warren cantilever with deck truss and stringer approach spans
column16: Longest cantilever span in the United States
column20: As of 2010, the Commodore Barry Bridge is the longest-spanning cantilever bridge in America. The main span is 1,644 feet long. The bridge is the fourth longest in the world, behind the 1917 Pont de Quebec in Canada, the 1890 Forth Railway Bridge in Scotland, and the 1973 Minato Bridge in Japan. The bridge was built to connect Interstate 95 in Pennsylvania with an unbuilt expressway in New Jersey that would have ran to the Atlantic City Expressway near Hammonton. Commodore John Barry was a Revolutionary War hero, known as the ''father of the American Navy.''

column18: T. J. Wilkerson, Beaver County Engineer?; Penn Bridge Co. Contractor?
