column20: The Concord Church Road Bridge was demolished in late 2008. It was one of only two similar Warren pony trusses in Beaver County. The other was Garvins Bridge on State Line Road. Due to its similarities with Garvins Bridge, it was likely designed by T. J. Wilkerson, Beaver County Engineer, and built by the Penn Bridge Company. At some point, the bridge was turned over to the state and later rehabilitated, at which point the builder's plates were probably removed.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1914, riveted, single span, 55'-long, Warren with verticals pony truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls. The bridge was modified in 1988 with the addition of welded steel angles to the lower chords at the end panels and the welding of supplemental steel angles at the connection between the floorbeams and verticals.'' The Conneauttee Road Bridge has been closed to traffic, since its abutment is failing. It is only a matter of time before the bridge is either demolished or it collapses on its own.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The one span, 93'-long, 14' wide, riveted, double intersection Warren thru truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls. The upper chords and inclined end posts are built up box sections, and the diagonals are angles with battens or lacing. The rolled floorbeams are framed into the gusset plates at the lower panel points. The stringers and open grid deck date to 1962, but otherwise the bridge appears to be complete. It is one of 3 double intersection Warren thru truss bridges built between 1904 and 1907 in Bradford County. This is the earliest. All are historically and technologically significant based on the rareness of the double intersection Warren truss design and their completeness.''

The new Convent Street Bridge was built in 1929, the year the city's flood control project was completed and the bypass channel opened. It is a concrete tee beam with ornamental balustrades. Many other similar bridges were built as part of the project.

The Conway Railroad Yard Northern Footbridge was a pedestrian bridge built to span the Conway Rail Yard (originally part of the Pennsylvania Railroad), one of the largest and busiest railroad yards in America. The yard is still in operation for the Norfolk Southern Railroad. The yard can hold 11,000 rail cars and can classify 6,000 cars per day. Pedestrian bridges were built to span the tracks in the northern and southern parts of the yard. The northern bridge is shorter, with two Warren thru truss spans.

The Conway Railroad Yard Southern Footbridge was a pedestrian bridge built to span the Conway Rail Yard (originally part of the Pennsylvania Railroad), one of the largest and busiest railroad yards in America. The yard is still in operation for the Norfolk Southern Railroad. The yard can hold 11,000 rail cars and can classify 6,000 cars per day. Pedestrian bridges were built to span the tracks in the northern and southern parts of the yard. The southern bridge is longer, with three Warren thru truss spans.

The Coons Crossing Road Bridge is a single span pin-connected Pratt truss. It is attributed to the York Bridge Company, due to its distinctive railings with a rectangular design instead of the much more common lattice design. The PAHBI (GMK Reviewer) states, 'It is traditionally composed of built-up compression members and eye-bar tension members. Ca. 1970, the bridge deck was replaced with a bituminous-filled steel deck, the lower chords were strengthened by post-tensioning with steel cables, welded repairs were made to the eye bars at the lower panel points, and the floorbeams were picked up by hangers welded to the verticals.'

The new Coraopolis Bridge (1995) is the second newest river bridge in Allegheny County (after the 2011 Pennsylvania Turnpike Allegheny River Bridge). It replaced a brittle steel truss that had to be closed during cold weather.

column15: Cable with double intersection Warren stiffening truss
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Roebling & Son (Wire Rope Fabricator), Reading Steel Products, Inc. (Fabricator)
column20: According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''Located on the Raystown Branch, one-half mile south of its junction with the main current of the Juniata River, this one-lane, single-span, lightweight suspension bridge is 320' long, and 12.5' side. Its main cables measure 2-3/8'' in diameter. The prestressed wire rope cables, manufactured by Roebling & Son of Trenton, New Jersey, are supported on 39'-tall steel towers and anchored in concrete deadmen. The bridge is stiffened by a double intersecting Warren truss and has a macadam-paved wood deck. High cut-stone and concrete abutments with wing walls support fill at the bridge approaches. This suspension bridge, also called the Corbin Bridge, was constructed in 1937 to replace a bridge swept away when a Penelec hydro-electric dam on the Raystown Branch gave way in the 1936 St. Patrick's Day flood. County bridge records state that the suspension bridge was fabricated by Reading Steel Products, Inc. The bridge type is highly unusual for the area -- it is the only suspension bridge in the six-county Pennsylvania Department of Transportation (PennDOT) district which includes Huntingdon.''

In 1940, the first stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike opened between Irwin and Somerset. The original mainline overpasses consisted of arched concrete rigid frames, steel thru girders, and concrete tee beams. The remaining tee beams were replaced in the 1990's. Beginning in the late 1990's and continuing through at least 2020, the entire original turnpike is being reconstructed and widened. Almost all original overpasses are being replaced as part of the project. This will include the Cornell Road Overpass. It is an example of a thru girder.

column16: Longest bridge in Warren County
column20: In 1965, the Kinzua Dam was completed, a hydroelectric dam built for flood control along the Allegheny River. The lake created by the dam is 24.2 miles along the Allegheny River, and the area of the lake is normally 12,080 acres (21,180 acres if the reservoir is full). As part of the dam and lake project, Pennsylvania Route 59 was relocated, and a new bridge was built to cross the lake near where Kinzua Creek flows into the Allegheny River. The bridge is the longest structure in Warren County, and it is the only deck truss bridge in the county. In 1796, a treaty was signed giving Seneca chief Cornplanter a land grant along the Allegheny River ''forever.'' When the Kinzua Reservoir was created, the land grant was flooded, and Cornplanter's grave was relocated. Though the bridge was called the Cornplanter Bridge, the name was later changed to the James Morrison Memorial Bridge.
The Cottage Lane Bridge is an example of a state-standard multi-beam (stringer).

The Council Road Bridge is one of four similar concrete arches in the county. (Photographs of three are on this website.) It is likely they were all built by the Luten Bridge Company. The Council Road Bridge is the largest concrete arch bridge in the county. Unfortunately, the bridge is not in good condition, as seen in the photograph. It has the lowest sufficiency rating of the four.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1895 single span, 80' long, Pratt pony truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments. The bridge is not traditionally composed, and its construction details reflect the experimentation indicative of small fabricators and period thinking about efficient design. Non-standardized details include the built up shaped ''fishbelly'' floor beams that are placed above the lower chords and connected with riveted connections to the lower portion of the verticals and with pin plates to pick up the lower chords. The upper chords and end posts are angles and plate rather than the more common channels and plate. The bridge appears to be complete, and it is historically and technologically significant because of its idiosyncratic details.''

column16: Possibly the oldest remaining cantilever in Pennsylvania (until its demolition), Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the Historic American Engineering Record (HAER), the significance of the bridge is as follows: ''The Coverts Crossing Bridge consists of two bridge segments, as it combines a reused bridge with a new one. It is a significant example of a metal truss bridge because it exhibits transitional technology with its use of steel, cantilevering, and two kinds of joinery methods. Both pin and rivet connection techniques are in evidence on this bridge.'' HAER elaborates on the bridge with the following documentation: ''The Coverts Crossing Bridge was built at a time of technological transition and innovation, reflected in both its relatively early use of steel rather than iron, and in its cantilever design. Its construction in 1887 occurred within 10 years of the nation's first all-steel truss bridge, erected over the Missouri River by the Chicago & Alton Railroad in 1878-1879.... The use of a cantilever truss design in the Coverts Crossing Bridge was a relatively early engineering response to its overall length of 301 feet (91.6 meters) across the Mahoning River, a major regional drainage. The bridge's transitional character is also evident in its reliance on both pin connections and rivets to join its various structural members. The use of rivets in American bridge construction was rare before the 1890's. Historically, American bridge builders continued to use pin connections long after their British counterparts had switched to the use of rivets. During the late nineteenth century, this American technological conservatism was driven by both economic factors and safety considerations. Bridges using pin connections required substantially less construction time and were considered safer than structures joined by rivets.... Several other engineering aspects of the bridge reflect an unusual degree of non-standardization in design and construction. These include the use of pin-connected eyebars to form the lower bridge chord of the southernmost truss section, while riveted steel channels (girder guides) were used to form the lower chords among the central and northern truss sections. Also notable are the markedly divergent ornamental styles found on the northern and southern portal gussets; decoration on the northern gusset consists of a geometric field of circles, while the southern gusset involves a cloverleaf-like pattern. The use of these various non-standardized components suggests that the bridge fabricators utilized whatever stock materials happened to be on hand when the materials for the bridge were ordered in 1887, and/or that no specific, standardized pattern set was available at the time of construction.''

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Cox Farm Covered Bridge is a rare example of a Kingpost truss. Built in 1940, it is newer than most covered bridges and most metal truss bridges. It is rare in that it is still functioning as a truss. Most covered bridges have been retrofitted with steel stringers. The bridge was built out of wood due to steel shortages leading up to World War II. It is painted white, which is less common than the traditional red or unpainted covered bridges. Note that, unlike covered bridges, metal truss bridges built in 1940 are considered to be common examples of well-established technologies and therefore not historic. The Cox Farm Covered Bridge is on the National Register of Historic Places.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1896, pin connected, single span, 80'-long, Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments. Fabricated by the Youngstown Bridge Co., the bridge stands as a remarkably complete example of its type and design with its decorative cresting and handsome cast and wrought iron railing at the cantilevered sidewalk. The trusses themselves are traditionally composed, but the lattice filled portal brace and knee braces with radiation pattern fill are characteristic of the fabricator. The bridge stands out in a rich collection of metal truss bridges in Crawford County, and it is historically and technologically significant.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1895, pin connected, single span, 72'-long, Pratt pony truss bridge is supported on one concrete and one ashlar abutment. The traditionally composed trusses have no innovative or distinctive details. The upper chords and end posts are built up, the lower chords and diagonals are eye bars to facilitate the pinned field connections, and the verticals are laced angles. The fabricator and construction date are not documented in available records.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Crellin Underwood Road Bridge is one of several standard-looking closed spandrel concrete arch bridges in West Virginia and western Maryland. The bridge retains excellent historic integrity and is a longer than usual example of this type of bridge.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Crockett Street Bridge is one of San Antonio's three remaining lenticular pony truss bridges. All were built by the Berlin Iron Bridge Company of Connecticut. Other than in Texas, lenticular truss bridges were mostly built in the northeast. After a flood in 1921, the San Antonio River was to be bypassed and this section to be filled in. While the bypass channel was constructed, public outcry prevented this section of river from being destroyed. Today the bridge is a valuable historic attraction, as noted by the horse-drawn carriage ride over the bridge.

column18: Chaney Engineering Company (County Engineer), Fort Pitt Bridge Works (Contractor)
column20: The Crosscreek Road Bridge is located in the village of Avella. The bridge is one of several thru girders in Washington County. Many regional thru girder bridges, including this one, were constructed by the Fort Pitt Bridge Works. This bridge, as well as the other thru girder on SR 4018, is to be replaced with a modern structure.

Culbertson's Mill was a five-story grist mill that was built from 1840 to 1844 and closed in 1907. It collapsed in 1920. The ruins of the mill are adjacent to the Culbertson's Mill Bridge (Fredericktown Bridge). This bridge is an 1893 truss bridge built by the Penn Bridge company of nearby Beaver Falls, PA. It was rehabilitated in 2004 and the deck replaced. It is great to see another restored truss bridge in Columbiana County! A visit to see the bridge and the ruins of the mill is highly recommended.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Rehabilitated and widened by the Pennsylvania Department of Highways
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 38'-long stone arch bridge was built ca. 1905 with a 19.5' width. It was extended by 11.5' by adding a reinforced concrete arch on the downstream side in 1935. The original spandrel wall and ring stones were carefully reused to finish the extension giving the bridge its original appearance on both elevations. The bridge is 1 of 7 similar handsome ashlar stone arch bridges in the county built between ca. 1905 and ca. 1915. It is technologically significant as one of the earliest, and it is historically significant as a contributing resource to a potential Brothers Valley rural historic district with a period of significance through 1947.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1935, 26'-long, reinforced concrete, closed spandrel filled deck arch bridge has plain concrete parapets and wingwalls. It is a typical example of a common bridge type used frequently in the state from the 1910s through the 1950s.''

The Curry Avenue Bridge connects Morganza Road and I-79 with a factory on the other side of Chartiers Creek. Since the bridge is not listed on bridge inventories, it may be privately owned. The bridge is one of the largest concrete arch bridges in Washington County. It has plain spandrel walls and paneled concrete parapets. Stylistically this bridge is similar to those built by the Chaney Engineering Company in the 1920's.

column15: Concrete encased girder on steel bents
column20: The bridge was built as a Federal Emergency Administration of Public Works Project during the Great Depression. It is an uncommon example of a concrete-encased deck girder. The bridge is scheduled for replacement.

column16: Last remaining Warren truss in Clearfield County
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1916, single span, 52'-long, rivet-connected Warren with verticals pony truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls. The trusses are traditionally composed with built up members. The bridge is an undistinguished example of a type and design used with frequency since the early 20th century. It has no innovative or distinctive details, nor is it documented to builder.''

column2: Curwensville Grampian Road Anderson Creek Bridge
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Ryan Bros Inc. (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1952, 2 simple span, 127'-long, T beam bridge (2 @ 62') with concrete balustrades is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls and a concrete pier. The balustrades have endposts with Art Moderne-style detailing.''

The Cypher Station Bridge was rehabilitated in 2004 in which the deck was removed and replaced. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1936, riveted, 2 span, 237'-long, Parker pony truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments and a concrete pier. Built to a state highway department standard design, the bridge is an example of a common technology with no innovative or distinctive details. It was erected as part of the rebuilding efforts following the devastating 1936 St. Patrick's Day flood. Over 275 bridges, mostly in the western and central portions of Pennsylvania, were destroyed or damaged beyond repair. Heavy truss bridges were favored because it was perceived that they could withstand future flood episodes.''

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1984
column18: Ira G. Hendrick, Hendrick and Cochrane (Consulting Engineers); M. R. Ash (Associate Engineer); Corrigan, Lee, and Halpin (General Contractor); Gulf Concrete Construction Company (Foundation Sub-Contractor)
column20: According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''At the time of its construction, the Dallas-Oak Cliff Viaduct at Houston Street was the longest reinforced concrete highway viaduct in the world, and it was the first high-level, all-weather crossing of the Trinity River at Dallas. The Houston Street Viaduct was nominated to the National Register of Historic Places in 1984.'' According to the Historic Bridge Foundation, ''Built in 1910, one source claims that this was the longest concrete bridge for a short period of time. This open spandrel arch bridge spans the Trinity River. It is between I-30 and I-35E and runs next to the Jefferson Street bridge. The Houston Avenue bridge carries southbound traffic, while the Jefferson Street bridge, which is newer, carries northbound traffic.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The 30'-long, closed spandrel, reinforced concrete deck arch bridge, built in 1941, has plain concrete parapets. Concrete deck arch bridges were used by the state highway department with great frequency beginning in the early 20th century.''

column2: Dante B. Fascell Long Key Channel Bridge
column16: FHWA 1st Place Award, cost savings innovations; second longest bridge in use in the Florida Keys
column20: According to FIGG's website, ''This bridge was completed eight months ahead of schedule in June 1982 at cost of $29 per square foot ($15.3 million). In 1982, the Federal Highway Administration honored the bridge with a first place award for cost saving innovations stating, 'Concrete segmental Long Key Bridge saved $2.6 million over an alternate conventional I-beam design.' Long Key Bridge will celebrate its 30th birthday in 2010 - and remains a landmark bridge for the many unique features incorporated in its design that are relevant today.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The skewed, 21'-long and 18' wide reinforced concrete deck arch bridge finished with plain spandrel walls and parapets with incised panels is one of about 6 surviving similar examples built between 1911 and 1913 in the county. The bridges have no innovative or distinctive details, and they are examples of the short span deck arch bridges that were built by a number of contractors for counties prior to World War 1. The bridge is an example of a type that is common in the region and state, and neither it nor its setting are historically or technologically significant. 37 3008 0040 0000 is also on Darlington Road in New Beaver Twp.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The skewed, 48'-long and 19' wide reinforced concrete deck arch bridge finished with plain spandrel walls and parapets with incised panels is one of about 6 surviving similar examples built between 1911 and 1913 in the county. The bridges have no innovative or distinctive details, and they are examples of the short span deck arch bridges that were built by a number of contractors for counties prior to World War I. The bridge is an example of a type that is common in the region and state, and neither it nor its setting are historically or technologically significant. 37 3008 0030 0000 is also on Darlington Road in New Beaver Twp.''

The Darnell Hollow Bridge is a late example of a masonry arch bridge. Given the 1936 date of construction, it is likely a WPA bridge. The Darnell Hollow Bridge is located along a sharp U-shaped turn along CR 857. Damage to the parapets is evident due to the sharp turn, since guide rail (which is frequently damaged) has replaced the original stonework. The spandrel wall has been repaired by concrete, as seen in the photograph. CR 857 is the main road between Interstate 68 and the Pennsylvania terminus of the Mon Fayette Expressway. In 2010, the West Virginia stretch of highway is to open, connecting Interstate 68 and the expressway in Pennsylvania and bypassing this road and bridge.

column16: Only welded truss bridge in region
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1953, 94' long welded Warren with verticals and a polygonal top chord pony truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls. All members are composed of rolled I or H section. The bridge is a late example of a bridge technology that was developed in the late 1920s and first used in Pennsylvania in the mid 1930s.''

column18: City of Allegheny Department of Public Works, Fort Pitt Bridge Works, Gustave Kaufman
column20: The Davis Avenue Bridge was the oldest remaining deck cantilever truss in Allegheny County, as well as in the entire region. The bridge was built over the steep Woods Run valley to connect to Riverview Park. The decorative railings represent an emerging turn of beautifying public structures and urban parks. Unlike Pittsburgh's bridges in Schenley Park, the cantilever was otherwise a purely form follows function bridge. This may explain why the 1911 book Bridge Engineering by Henry Grattan Tyrrell notes that the Davis Avenue Bridge has ''an outline that cannot be commended.'' The bridge was strengthened in 1986 when material was added to encase parts of the lower chords and verticals. Unfortunately, this work led to the decline of the bridge. The weld quality was called ''questionable'' by Chuck McClain, a project manager for the Allegheny County Department of Public Works, in a Pittsburgh Tribune Review article. After two structural members failed, the bridge was demolished in May of 2009.

In 1940, the first stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike opened between Irwin and Somerset. The original mainline overpasses consisted of arched concrete rigid frames, steel thru girders, and concrete tee beams. The remaining tee beams were replaced in the 1990's. Beginning in the late 1990's and continuing through at least 2020, the entire original turnpike is being reconstructed and widened. Almost all original overpasses are being replaced as part of the project, including the Davis Lane Overpass.

The Davis Bridge was an example of a state standard Pratt thru truss. It was the only remaining vehicular truss bridge in all of Tucker County (though a welded pony truss was built in 2005). There are no more historic truss bridges or even arch bridges in all of Tucker County! While people may visit the county for the Canaan Valley or for Blackwater Falls, they certainly will not visit the area for the bridges!

According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1895, pin connected, single span, 56'-long, Pratt pony truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with wingwalls. In 1975 the lower panel points and bearings were encased in concrete, making the connections rigid in nature. The bridge is an altered example of a common type and design, and it is not historically or technologically significant. Pin connected truss bridges are common in Venango County. Sixteen examples ranging in date from 1880 to 1904 remain.''

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1988
column20: The historic Deanville Road Bridge is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The bridge is composed of concrete arches with cut stone spandrel walls. It was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1988.

column15: Cable with Warren stiffening deck truss, Warren deck truss and stringer approaches
column16: Most Beautiful Large Steel Span, 1951 American Institute of Steel Construction
column18: Othmar Ammann (Designer), American Bridge Company (Prime Contractor), Whitting-Turner Contracting Company (New Jersey Side Contractor, Paving), James Julian Company (Delaware Side Contractor, Paving)
column20: The Delaware Memorial Bridge is the longest-spanning twin suspension bridge in the world and one of the world's top 30 long-span bridges. Since the 1920's, residents began to push for the construction of the bridge. Both the War Department and pro-Philadelphia authorities and businesses fought against the bridge, arguing that it could be an impediment to shipping and could be a vulnerable target to block the Philadelphia Navy Yard. The original bridge (eastbound) was finally authorized in 1945 (state) and 1946 (Congress) and completed in 1951, replacing a ferry. Upon opening, the bridge had the 6th largest main span in the world. It served as a design model for such future bridges as the Walt Whitman Bridge, the Throgs Neck Bridge, and the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. The Delaware side caisson set the record for the largest continuous pour, consisting of 27,000 cubic yards of concrete. Within 15 years, traffic was already double the original estimate (8.2 million vehicles per year), so a twin span was planned. The twin bridge (westbound) was completed in 1968, and it was designed to match the appearance of the original bridge. The bridge is different in that the deck is a few feet wider, the lights are brighter, and the sidewalk is concrete instead of grate. The Delaware Memorial Bridge is the southern most bridge over the Delaware River and is the only Delaware River crossing in the state. It is the only vehicular suspension bridge in Delaware. The bridge is dedicated as a memorial to the service men and women from Delaware and New Jersey who were killed or missing in action in the line of duty. The bridge area includes a War Memorial Area with a wall with a list of names, a statue, and a reflecting pool. Veterans are honored in ceremonies each Memorial Day and Veterans Day.

column15: Cable with Warren stiffening deck truss, Warren deck truss and stringer approaches
column16: Most Beautiful Large Steel Span, 1951 American Institute of Steel Construction
column18: Othmar Ammann (Designer), American Bridge Company (Prime Contractor), Whitting-Turner Contracting Company (New Jersey Side Contractor, Paving), James Julian Company (Delaware Side Contractor, Paving)
column20: The Delaware Memorial Bridge is the longest-spanning twin suspension bridge in the world and one of the world's top 30 long-span bridges. Since the 1920's, residents began to push for the construction of the bridge. Both the War Department and pro-Philadelphia authorities and businesses fought against the bridge, arguing that it could be an impediment to shipping and could be a vulnerable target to block the Philadelphia Navy Yard. The original bridge (eastbound) was finally authorized in 1945 (state) and 1946 (Congress) and completed in 1951, replacing a ferry. Upon opening, the bridge had the 6th largest main span in the world. It served as a design model for such future bridges as the Walt Whitman Bridge, the Throgs Neck Bridge, and the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. The Delaware side caisson set the record for the largest continuous pour, consisting of 27,000 cubic yards of concrete. Within 15 years, traffic was already double the original estimate (8.2 million vehicles per year), so a twin span was planned. The twin bridge (westbound) was completed in 1968, and it was designed to match the appearance of the original bridge. The bridge is different in that the deck is a few feet wider, the lights are brighter, and the sidewalk is concrete instead of grate. The Delaware Memorial Bridge is the southern most bridge over the Delaware River and is the only Delaware River crossing in the state. It is the only vehicular suspension bridge in Delaware. The bridge is dedicated as a memorial to the service men and women from Delaware and New Jersey who were killed or missing in action in the line of duty. The bridge area includes a War Memorial Area with a wall with a list of names, a statue, and a reflecting pool. Veterans are honored in ceremonies each Memorial Day and Veterans Day.

The Dellslow Bridge is a closed spandrel concrete arch bridge with decorative spandrel walls. Several concrete arches have similar adornments in West Virginia. This stretch of WV Route 7 in the Deckers Creek Valley is a very beautiful and scenic fall drive.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''he 1889, pin connected, single span, 78'-long, Pratt pony truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with wingwalls. The trusses are traditionally composed. The built up shaped floorbeams are original. Crawford County is rich in pin connected metal truss bridges with 35 ranging in date from 1870 through the early 20th century remaining. This bridge stands out as a complete, early example of its type and design. It is historically and technologically significant.'' Note that in the 2008 inspection, the Depot Road Bridge was not rated structurally deficient.

column15: Warren polygonal riveted with some pin connections along the lower chord
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, bridge was used in Rolling Rock commercials.
column18: Westmoreland County (W. A. Wynn - Road Engineer); Pennsylvania Department of Highways
column20: According to the PAHBI (MEM Reviewer), ''The 2 span, 259' long, Warren with polygonal top chord pony truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with wingwallls and a concrete pier. The members are rolled section, and it has riveted connections save for the lower panel points that are pinned. The approximately 125' long spans are long for pony trusses, and the pinned lower chord connections are for ease of construction... The pinned lower chord is unusual feature, this bridge is significant for its 'retarditaire' use of pinned connections.'' The bridge was also featured in Rolling Rock commercials in the early 2000's, before Budweiser purchased the brand and moved production to New Jersey. The bridge was replaced in 2009.

column16: Second oldest of three remaining truss bridges in county
column20: The bridge is similar to the Johnson Road Bridge over the Grand River and the Horton Road Bridge over Conneaut Creek, both in Ashtabula County, Ohio. According to the PAHBI, ''The one-span, 116'-long, pin-connected Pratt truss bridge built in 1902 is supported on ashlar abutments. The trusses are traditionally composed with the upper chords being built up box sections, the lower chords and diagonals being eye bars, and the verticals being channels with lacing. The lattice portal struts have plaques and quarter-circle brackets with star-shaped cutouts. Rolled floorbeams with U-shaped hangers support steel stringers and an open steel grid deck (1953). Verticals, diagonals, and upper lateral bracing have been irreversibly altered with welded splices and/or plates at all of the panel points.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Dewey Road is the most significant surviving metal truss bridge in Erie County. It is the last remaining thru truss as well as the last functional pin-connected truss. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1889, pin connected, single span, 120'-long, Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with wingwalls. Verticals, end posts, and upper chords are built up. Lower chords and diagonals are eye bar. The bridge was built by the Wrought Iron Bridge Company, a prominent fabricator of metal truss bridges, and it has the company's distinctive hip verticals with four pronged connection details at the lower chord panel points. The bridge is historically and technologically significant as a complete, early example of its type and design.''

column16: Only active thru truss bridge on the Upper Allegheny River
column20: The Dexter Hollow Road Bridge is the only active thru truss bridge over the entire Upper Allegheny River north of the Tidioute Bridge in southern Warren County. According to JPH of the PAHBI, 'The single-span, 107'-long, pin-connected, steel Pratt thru truss bridge built ca. 1900 has lattice railings and ashlar abutments. It is traditionally composed of built-up compression members and eye-bar tension members. Rolled floorbeams with U-shaped hangers support steel stringers and a wood deck from ca. 1980.'

column2: Dick Henderson Memorial Bridge (St Albans/Nitro Bridge)
column20: The 1934 Dick Henderson Memorial Bridge is the oldest cantilever over the entire Kanawha River. The structure is unusual for several different reasons. It is an extremely rare example of a cantilever in which the entire top chord is divided into only 9 sections. With most cantilevers, the top chord curves upwards to form pointed towers. With the Dick Henderson Bridge, the top chord has a linear upwards slope and towers with flat tops. It is the only cantilever bridge like it in the area. In the early 1930's, virtually all steel bridges were comprised of built up v-laced compression members. The Dick Henderson Bridge only uses rolled H-section beams for all of its members. H-section rolled beams did not even begin to be used on bridges until around 1920. The beams are more often seen on bridges from around 1940 and beyond, making the Dick Henderson Bridge look much more modern than it is. Unfortunately, the bridge is to be replaced around 2013. Why is a historical restoration not considered an option for this unusual, innovative bridge? The National Register Eligible bridge should be considered the most significant bridge over the entire Kanawha River!

In 1940, the first stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike opened between Irwin and Somerset. The original mainline overpasses consisted of arched concrete rigid frames, steel thru girders, and concrete tee beams. The remaining tee beams were replaced in the 1990's. Beginning in the late 1990's and continuing through at least 2020, the entire original turnpike is being reconstructed and widened. Almost all original overpasses are being replaced as part of the project. This will include the Diehl Road Overpass. It is an example of an arched concrete rigid frame. The original balustrades have been replaced.

column18: H. C. McCrea (County Engineer), Farris Engineering Company
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 155'-long, 2 span, reinforced concrete deck arch bridge with flat paneled parapets is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls and a concrete pier with scour protection.'' The bridge is to be replaced in 2011.

column16: FHWA Award of Excellence, 1992
column20: Like most of the other river crossings in Columbus (as well as southern Ohio), the metal Broad Street Bridge was destroyed by the Great Flood of 1913. To prevent the same thing from happening to future bridges, just about all the post flood bridges were constructed from concrete. As such, the 1917 replacement bridge was a closed spandrel concrete arch. That bridge lasted until 1990, when it was demolished to make room for the current 1992 Discovery Bridge. The bridge's name is to commemorate the 500th anniversary of Columbus's arrival to the Americas. The new bridge is a post-tensioned concrete girder bridge with arch-shaped fascia panels. The arch-shaped panels were designed to replicate the appearance of the old bridge. This design won a Federal Highway Administration Award of Excellence. The bridge also includes decorative lighting and river viewing platforms. It was the catalyst that led to the redevelopment of the parks along the Scioto River.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, only remaining Pratt truss bridge in Jefferson County
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1901, riveted, single span, 70'-long, 4 panel Pratt pony truss bridge is supported on concrete-filled steel caissons bents. The light trusses are traditionally composed with the lower chords, verticals, and diagonals being angles with battens. The upper chords and end posts are built up box sections. The oldest of seven surviving riveted truss bridges in the county, the bridge is historically and technologically significant as a complete, early example of its technology, built during a time of transition from pinned to riveted connections.''

FL 886 is a state highway shorter than a mile. The bridge is illuminated at night with blue lights by Brilliant Lighting Design. The old bridge is still standing south of the new bridge. It is closed, and the bascule span has been left in the open position.

In 1940, the first stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike opened between Irwin and Somerset. The original mainline overpasses consisted of arched concrete rigid frames, steel thru girders, and concrete tee beams. The remaining tee beams were replaced in the 1990's. Beginning in the late 1990's and continuing through at least 2020, the entire original turnpike is being reconstructed and widened. Almost all original overpasses are being replaced as part of the project. This will include the Dogwood Lane Overpass. It is an example of an arched concrete rigid frame. Dogwood Lane is a private road that carries little traffic. As a result, the bridge is one of the only original concrete overpasses retaining its original balustrades as of 2008.

The first sections of Interstate 64 in West Virginia (not counting the West Virginia Turnpike), including the Donald Legg Bridge, were completed in the western part of the state in 1962. Interstate 64 has three other Kanawha River crossings nearby in Charleston, though one serves the West Virginia Turnpike. The other two were not built until the mid 1970's. They are a deck girder and modern bowstring thru truss. The Donald Legg Bridge is distinctive for the relatively low height of the trusses. Even the towers are not much taller than the rest of the bridge.

The Donald Lobaugh Bridge is the only bridge to cross through Allegheny County without beginning or ending in it, connecting Butler and Westmoreland Counties. The bridge crosses the Allegheny River only 100 feet away from the corner of four counties (the above plus Armstrong County). It replaced the 1888 Garvers Ferry Bridge, a Parker truss. The Lobaugh Bridge is the only deck truss in Allegheny County built after the late 1950's/early 1960's transition from riveted trusses to welded and bolted trusses. It is the only Allegheny County truss similar to the failed Minnesota I-35W Bridge. Donald Lobaugh was a Congressional Medal of Honor recipient who sacrificed his life to save his platoon in World War II. In 2011 - 2013 the bridge is to be rehabilitated. As part of the project, only the truss will be retained. The rest of the bridge will be replaced.

The 1901 Donaldson Bridge was an early riveted Pratt truss bridge. It was built by the Nelson & Buchanan Company, which built several other riveted pony truss bridges in Washington County. The Donaldson Bridge was a five panel truss; the others are three and four panels. The smaller examples consist of just X-shaped diagonals; this larger example consisted of just a single X in the center panel. The bridge was replaced with a modern bridge in 2009.

column18: Farris Bridge Company, J.D. Dougherty (Engineer), H.B. Groves (Contractor)
column20: The Donley Road Bridge crosses Bear Creek parallel to the Butler Armstrong county line. The bridge was a joint project between the two counties. While maps show the bridge to be entirely in Butler County, the bridge is owned by Armstrong County. While it is possible that the county line is shown at an incorrect location on the map, it is more likely the bridge is owned by Armstrong County because the approach roads are both in Armstrong County. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1913, riveted, single span, 83'-long, Warren with verticals pony truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with flared wingwalls. The 5 panel trusses have built up box section upper chords and steel angle lower chords, verticals, and diagonals. The bridge has no innovative or distinctive details, and it reflects the standardization of the design.''

column15: Warren riveted with girder approach spans
column16: Longest truss span over the Monongahela River
column20: In the early 1950's, the Pennsylvania Department of Highways began to build Legislative Route 71, a new limited-access highway to connect US 40 and Washington, PA, with the industrial Mon Valley at Speers/Belle Vernon and the Pennsylvania Turnpike at New Stanton. The road, completed in 1960, eventually was designated as I-70. However, there was no good connection between the important industrial center of Donora and I-70, several miles to the south. In the 1970's, industry along the Monongahela River was in decline as cheaper imports and lack of good road access strangled industry in the valley. As a result, PennDOT planned to built a new Mon Fayette expressway parallel to the river and a highway connecting the expressway with Donora and I-70. The first component to be built was the Donora Monessen Bridge, a deck cantilever with a 608-foot main span, the longest truss span over the entire Monongahela River. The bridge was begun in 1972 and opened in 1974. Unfortunately, highway expansion slowed to a halt in the late 1970's with the collapse of the manufacturing industry and the fuel price shocks. It was not until 1989 that the connection to I-70, the C. Vance DeiCas Highway, was built. While the Mon Fayette Expressway finally opened in the region in 2002, the connection to the Donora Monessen Bridge was never built. While the bridge does serve as a crucial highway link to Donora, it is lightly traveled because little industry exists to use it. The bridge was rehabilitated in 2009 for around $20 million. The bridge was repainted a bright yellow orange color.

column15: Pennsylvania pin-connected with Parker pin-connected approach spans
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1998
column18: Washington County, Westmoreland County, W. Wylie (Engineer), Sofias Construction Company
column20: On December 4, 1908, to much celebration, the Donora-Webster Bridge was completed to connect the towns of Donora and Webster. It was considered to be ''another important link to the march of progress in Donora.'' Rebecca Donora Castner, the first person to be born in Donora, cut the ribbon to open the bridge. Much has changed in Donora since then. At first industry brought prosperity, but then, tragedy. In 1948, an inversion of smoke and fog killed 20 people, the infamous event known as the Donora Smog. Within the next 30 years, most of the industry that brought wealth to the town shut down, leaving hard times behind. The bridge is one of the few relics that remain. But for how long? In 2009, an inspection revealed dangerous deterioration, closing the bridge to traffic. Options stated at public meetings included removing the bridge for $2.5 million, repairing the bridge for $15.15 million, restoring the bridge for $21.82 million, or replacing the bridge for $25 million. Does it make sense to spend tens of millions to rehabilitate the bridge or replace the bridge since it is lightly used? Does it make sense to spend money to repair the bridge even though the bridge will still have height and weight restrictions? The federal Section 106 Process will therefore be followed to determine the best course of action for the bridge. Some bridges, like the Smithfield Street Bridge and the Old Brownsville Bridge, have been rehabilitated. Others, like the nearby Monongahela Bridge, have been replaced. Even if the bridge is demolished, through the Section 106 process the bridge will probably be documented. Other than the Smithfield Street Bridge, the Donora Webster Bridge is the last remaining multi-span pin-connected truss bridge over the entire Monongahela River. It is the oldest bridge over the river outside of Allegheny County. It also is noteworthy for its 515-foot main span, likely the longest in all of Western Pennsylvania (possibly in all of Pennsylvania) when it was built. The bridge has been listed in the National Register of Historic Places since 1988.

The 138 foot suspended span of this riveted cantilever truss bridge is attached to the anchor spans with pin connections. The original Allegheny County style fleur-de-lis railings were removed and replaced with chain-link fence in the 2002 rehabilitation.

column18: Pittsburgh Bridge Company, F.L. Garlinghouse, Engineer
column20: The Dorrington Road Bridge from 1888 was the third oldest public-owned truss bridge in Allegheny County, behind the 1883 Smithfield Street Bridge and the 1886 Leet Street Bridge. However, both of those bridges have been heavily modified, unlike the Dorrington Road Bridge. Other than the asphalt overlay of the wooden deck, the bridge matched its original drawings from 1888. Even the railings were original. The significant bridge was a rare example of a truss with vertical endposts, and it was an early example of a skewed truss. The bridge was composed of wrought iron, with some cast iron connections. Eric DeLony, the Chief Emeritus of the Historic American Engineering Record remarked, ''Despite the wealth of historic bridges in Pennsylvania, I'm confident the bridge will be at the top of the list regarding its value, significance, condition and preservation potential.'' The bridge was replaced in 2009 with a concrete beam bridge. The new bridge is two lanes wide and has no weight restrictions, improving emergency access for the two homes on the other side of Robinson Run.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1885, skewed, pin connected, single span, 62'-long, Pratt pony truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with wingwalls. The traditionally composed trusses have built up upper chords, end posts, and verticals. The lower chords and diagonals are eye bars. It was fabricated by the Smith Bridge Company, and the bridge is distinguished as an early and complete example of its type and design. There are 3 Smith Bridge Co. truss bridges in the county, and all are significant.'' Since the survey was performed, the other two Smith Bridge Company trusses have been demolished.
The Dotyville Road Henderson Run Bridge is a common example of a concrete beam bridge. Its original concrete parapets are heavily spalled.

According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1910, riveted, single span, 84'-long, Warren with verticals pony truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls. The standardized trusses have no innovative or distinctive details.'' The bridge's outriggers appear to be original.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Woods & Golden (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1929, 2 span, 140'-long reinforced concrete deck arch bridge was built in 1929 by the state highway department. It has plain spandrels. The original deck was removed and the present deck with cantilevered sections was placed in 1976. The original railings were removed and replaced with modern beam guiderail railings at that time.''

column15: Load-bearing steel stringer with ornamental pin-connected Pratt thru truss
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1988
column20: In 1859, Col. Edwin Drake pioneered the first commercially successfully oil well in Oil Creek, near the site of the Drake Well Bridge. Shortly thereafter, many oil boomtowns appeared, with Titusville and Oil City at the center of the oil industry. The developing oil industry led to the need of new and improved bridges, such as the 1882 Drake Well Bridge. The bridge was a long example of a wrought iron Pratt truss. Due to the historic significance of the bridge as well as the important oil heritage tourism in the area, most of the original truss was saved when the new steel stringer/girder bridge was constructed in 1999. The truss was mounted on top of the modern bridge, serving as decoration. This is a noteworthy compromise of building a new bridge and keeping the old.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Roberts Supply Co.
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The single-span, 96'-long, steel built-up through girder bridge, built in 1930, is supported on concrete abutments. The roadway is flanked by solid concrete parapets. Girder bridges were first developed by the railroad industry in the 1850s, and they were used on roadways beginning in the late 19th century.''

The Driftwood Bridge was a three-span thru girder in one of the most scenic areas of the state. It was built on the ashlar abutments of the previous bridge. The bridge was one of the last bridges constructed prior to World War II. Bridges of this length constructed after the war were typically steel stringers. The bridge was replaced in 2008 by a concrete beam bridge visible in the background of the photograph.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Dry Hole Road Bridge is the last remaining non-beam bridge in Hays County. As such, it is listed on the National Register of Historic Places

column15: Open spandrel concrete arch with closed spandrel, stone-faced fascia arches
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: D.H. Overman, Ohio Department of Highways, Public Works Administration
column20: The Dublin Bridge is one of the last of Columbus's ornate concrete arch bridges. Though the bridge is an open spandrel concrete arch, the fascia spandrels are filled with concrete and a stone veneer, giving the bridge the appearance of a Roman viaduct. Many Public Works Administration Great Depression structures, such as this bridge, include decorative stonework. The bridge was rehabilitated in 1987 in which the original deck and balustrades were replaced with a wider one devoid of such architectural features. The bridge is the last of several concrete arch bridges over the Scioto River in Franklin County. The Dublin Bridge is eligible for listing in the National Register of Historic Places.

The bridge is the oldest thru girder in Pittsburgh and might be the oldest thru girder in the area. It is thus eligible for the National Register. The bridge crosses Nine Mile Run where it flows into the Monongahela River at Brown's Landing. A Salt Works was built in the mid 1800's, with Salt Works Road (now Saline Street) built to connect to the Four Mile Run section of Pittsburgh. After the 1936 flood, the original deck of the bridge was replaced by an open grate. One Pittsburgh bridge book states that this is the first bridge in the country to have an open grate deck. The bridge used to carry Second Avenue, which followed the Monongahela River to Downtown Pittsburgh. The road was truncated at the Glenwood Bridge, so the bridge now just connects McFarren Street to the tiny Duck Hollow or Skeetersville area of Pittsburgh. The nearby slag dump in the Nine Mile Run valley limited the neighborhood to just a few homes, and destroyed all access out of the neighborhood except for this bridge. As a result, these residents have to depend on this narrow, weight-restricted bridge. Therefore, the bridge is to be replaced with a new structure on a different alignment. It is not yet known whether or not the Duck Hollow Bridge will be demolished once the new bridge opens.

column16: Last remaining camelback truss in Luzerne County
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The single span, 134'-long, pin-connected, steel camelback thru truss bridge built in 1905 is supported on stone abutments. The truss members are eyebars and rods for the tension members and built-up sections for the compression members. The bridge has A-frame portals, stock metal lattice railings, open steel grid deck (ca. 1960), steel stringers, and rolled floorbeams. The diagonals in the middle panel have welded repairs at the lower panel points (ca. 1960). The camelback truss design is a Pratt truss with polygonal top chord of exactly five slopes. It found limited application for spans in the range of 100' to 200' because of the economy of design of the polygonal top chord which offered bridge engineers the ability to vary the depth of the trusses, and thus achieve savings of material. By 1890, the Pratt and Pratt variation truss designs, including camelback, had emerged as the most popular of the pin-connected designs because of their simplicity of design and economy of fabrication and erection, especially the use of eye bars to facilitate field connections. They continued to be used through the first two decades of the 20th century.''

If the next bridge downstream, the 1934 Dick Henderson Memorial Bridge, looks newer than it is, the 1953 Dunbar Bridge may look older than it actually is. Instead of sold members, many are built up with perpendicular lacing. Interestingly, the Dick Henderson Bridge is the oldest cantilever over the Kanawha River and the Dunbar Bridge is the second oldest. The Dunbar Bridge is still known as the Dunbar Toll Bridge, though the tollbooths were removed.

The Dundon Truss Bridge was a four span Pratt thru truss bridge with deck girder approach spans on the east end. As seen in the photograph, all but one truss span was demolished in September of 2008. The two 150 foot center spans were slightly longer than the two approach spans. See the External Links for an image of the bridge before the truss spans were demolished. Though the replacement bridge was built on a different alignment, the old bridge was still torn down anyway. Now we can only imagine what it was like to cross what used to be the longest bridge in Clay County.

The Dunkard Bridge was a state-standard skewed Parker thru truss bridge, the only one of its type in Greene County. The bridge had a cantilevered sidewalk with its original railing. The single-span bridge was replaced with a three-span concrete girder sometime around 2000 (between site visits in 1997 and 2004).

column15: Cast iron deck arch, elliptical tubular ribs
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Army Corps of Engineers, Keys & Searight (contractor)
column20: The 1839 Dunlap's Creek Bridge is the oldest metal bridge in the United States. It is one of the most significant bridges in America. In the early 1800's, the National Road (Cumberland Road) was built through the important port of Brownsville, Pennsylvania, along the Monongahela River. The first two bridges on this site collapsed, and the third lasted only 12 years before it needed to be replaced. All metal truss bridges had not yet been used in America, and such a large stone arch bridge was very difficult to build. The Army Corps of Engineers decided to do something unprecedented in America -- design a cast iron arch. The first cast iron arches in the world were built in England starting in the late 1700's. However, in America, cast iron arch bridges were prohibitively expensive; only the Federal Government could afford them. The bridge opened to traffic in 1838 and was completed in 1839. Since then, the only major modification was the addition of sidewalks. Due to the growth of trade at Brownsville, located at the intersection of the National Road and the navigable Monongahela River, the town prospered in the early 1900's. There was such a demand for retail space along the road that stores were built over the creek on either side of the bridge. However, when heavy industry collapsed and a new alignment of US 40 was built bypassing the town, the Brownsville Bottoms area surrounding the bridge was all but abandoned. Hopefully the area surrounding the bridge will be redeveloped to show off and promote such a nationally significant bridge.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Duquesne Slag Bridge was built to carry a private road connecting Duquesne Slag and the Jones & Laughlin Steel Mill over the former P&LE Railroad and PA 51. The bridge is an unusual deck cantilever, with a bottom chord that is not continuous between the suspended spans and anchor spans. It is the only example of such a bridge anywhere in the region. The bridge is historically significant for its early use of rolled sections (instead of the built-up sections commonly seen on truss bridges built at the same time).

column16: Last remaining pin-connected pony truss bridge in Blair County
column20: The Dysart Road Bridge is closed to vehicular traffic. A narrow wooden walkway was built over the existing wooden deck of the bridge. The bridge is the last remaining pin-connected pony truss bridge in Blair County. The only other pony truss is riveted, and it is abandoned with several spans missing. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1903, pin connected, 53'-long, Pratt pony truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with wingwalls. The floorbeam connections have been altered by the addition of welded plates and floorbeam hangers to the verticals. The bridge has been significantly modified by changing the floorbeam hanger connections to welded connections at an unknown date.''

column16: Last surviving double intersection Warren truss bridge in Mercer County
column18: James R. Gemmill, Sharpsville Steam Boiler Works of Sharpsville, PA; Relocated by Mr. Narlee of Sharpsville Steel Erectors
column20: The bridge was built by the Sharpsville Steam Boiler Works of Sharpsville, Pennsylvania, which built other bridges in the region in the early 1900's. According to Nate Clark (courtesy of www.historicbridges.org), ''This little pony truss is a former county- or township-owned span that was moved in 1967 from the Hamburg/Big Bend area when roads in the future Shenango River Reservoir basin area were being relocated to higher ground or abandoned. According to his sons, Mr. Narlee of Sharpsville Steel Erectors split the truss lengthwise and trucked it to property he owned in Mercer, the county seat. The span is now privately owned, on the same site, by Edward and Earl Michaels, owners of E&E Welding & Exhaust just off U.S. Rt. 19 and Rt. 62 (the two highways split, going northbound, about 100 yards from this bridge). It crosses Munnell Run, a small stream along Fairgrounds Road, just down the hill from the Mercer County Courthouse, and provides access into the back parking area of E&E.''

column18: City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works, Fort Pitt Bridge Works
column20: The Swindell Bridge has the largest span of the Pittsburgh (and Allegheny County) ravine bridges at 515 feet. The bridge uses riveted connections, except for the tension diagonals that are pinned. The bridge has the standard City of Pittsburgh fleur-de-lis railings from the time period. The bridge is named after E. H. Swindell, who was a prominent businessman.

column15: Warren polygonal thru truss with deck girder approaches
column20: The Earl Vickers Bridge has the longest simple truss span over the entire Kanawha River (486 feet). Interestingly, the span is longer than that of three cantilever bridges. Unlike the pre-World War II bridges with a long simple truss, the post-World War II Vickers Bridge has girder approach spans.

The East Brady Bridge was built in 1934 as a four-span state-standard Pratt thru truss bridge. The bridge was unusual in that Pratt trusses instead of Parker trusses were used. The two northern (Armstrong County side) spans were replaced, due to damage from flooding. They were replaced by truss spans of the same dimensions. According to the PAHBI, ''The skewed, 771'-long, 4 span (1 @ 161', 1 @ 198', 1 @ 199', and 1 @ 197'), riveted Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on an ashlar substructure raised with concrete extensions. The trusses are traditionally composed with rolled section used for the verticals and diagonals. Original bolted connections at the gusset plates have been replaced with high-strength bolts, a modification dating from 1973. The bridge is an example of a state highway department standard design riveted metal truss bridge that was used with great frequency beginning in the mid 1920s. It has no innovative or distinctive details. Approximately 150 riveted truss bridges built between 1925 and 1957 remain statewide. Neither it nor its setting is historically or technologically significant.''

column2: East Brady Bridge (Sergeant Carl F. Curran II Bridge)
column20: The new East Brady Bridge, the Sergeant Carl F. Curran II Bridge, was named after Sgt. Curran, who was killed near Fallujah, Iraq, in 2004. He was from East Brady, and he served in the Pennsylvania Army National Guard. The bridge is a high-strength weathering steel girder bridge, with a main span of 315 feet.

column15: Stone arch widened with steel stringers
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 3 span, 100'-long stone arch bridge built in 1904 is laid up in rusticated random ashlar and matched ring stones and was widened on both sides in 1933 with stringer extensions. The beams are supported at mid span on an ashlar pier. The bridge is finished with modern metal railings. Stone piers extend to the face of the sidewalks, supporting the fascia stringers. Metal fence railings enclose both sidewalks.''

column2: East Commerce Street San Antonio River Extension Bridge
column16: Only deck truss bridge in Bexar County
column18: Day & Zimmermann, Inc. (Project Manager), Manhattan Construction Company (Contractor), Ford, Powell & Carson, Inc. & K. M. Ng & Associates, Inc. (Architects and Engineers)
column20: In 1988, the Rivercenter mall was constructed, and the San Antonio River and River Walk were extended to meet the mall's food court. A bridge was built on East Commerce Street over this expansion. Rather than build a plain concrete bridge, a signature arched deck truss bridge was built to both beautify the extension and to maintain the historic appearance of the area. Decorative lighting is installed at the bottom of the truss lines.

column15: Concrete single tower with segmental concrete box girder approach
column20: The 1985 East Huntington Bridge (Frank 'Gunner' Gatski Bridge) was the second concrete cable-stayed bridge to be built in the United States. It was the first to be constructed in West Virginia and was built as a federal demonstration project. Discussions about a new Ohio River Bridge for East Huntington became controversial in the early 1970's. The Huntington Master Plan called for a bridge to be built about a mile upstream at Rome, Ohio. The bridge was to connect to a new road to be built through Lewis Hollow to Interstate 64. However, the location at the mouth of the Guyandotte River eventually was chosen. The Coast Guard was then unhappy since the design called for a central pier. As a result, the central pier was moved closer to the Ohio side, and a concrete segmental box beam was designed to connect the cable-stayed span and the West Virginia side. The West Virginia side was also to directly connect to US 60, but the ramp was never completed. The stub still exists. Frank 'Gunner' Gatski was Marshall University's first member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

column2: East Market Street San Antonio River Extension Bridge
column20: Completed in 1968, the San Antonio River was extended as part of the construction of the Henry Gonzales Convention Center and the 1968 World's Fair. This bridge was built as a part of this extension.
The bridge is the only steel girder frame bridge built specifically to cross a highway in Allegheny County.

column16: Last remaining bowstring truss in western Pennsylvania; eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Messerall Road Bridge is the last bowstring truss bridge still standing in all of western Pennsylvania. The only other example, the Beatty Mills Bridge of Armstrong County, was dismantled and stored in 2008. According to the Historic American Engineering Record (HAER), ''The bridge is an excellent example of a small wrought-iron bowstring truss. A prefabricated structure, it demonstrates the versatility of wrought iron and the speed with which it could be assembled. The segmented bowstring offered economy of material, simplicity of design, and ease of transport and assembly, the features important to the booming oil economy of 19th century northwestern Pennsylvania.''

The Travis Street Bridge was built in conjunction with the flood control project in the 1920's in which the San Antonio River was straightened and the bypass channel constructed. These bridges consist of concrete tee beams with ornamental balustrades.
The East Twenty-Fourth Street Bridge is a typical example of a 1950's concrete slab. The bridge is located within the campus of the University of Texas.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The two-span, 145'-long and 65' wide, elliptical concrete deck arch bridge is finished with paneled parapets and plain spandrel walls. There have been alterations to the ends of the parapets, but the bridge, built in 1909 by the county, is the oldest of the 21 examples of the technology in the county. It is a historically and technologically significant example of its type in the local context. The technology was used with great frequency by the Lawrence County engineer.''

column2: Eastbound US Route 30 Bridge over Norfolk Southern Railroad
column20: The Eastbound US Route 30 Bridge was originally built to carry a new alignment of US 30 over the Radebaugh Branch of the Pennsylvania Railroad. In 1959 the road was widened with a new bridge to the north. The 1936 bridge was converted to carry eastbound traffic only. According to the PAHBI (MEM Reviewer), ''The 130' long and 56.5' wide reinforced concrete deck arch bridge has Art Moderne-style vertical scoring flanking the arch barrel at the spring line and a cantilevered deck carried on Art Moderne-style brackets. The original railings were replaced in 1959 with standard design concrete barriers with tubular handrails. Safety shape barriers have been placed in front of them. A modern stringer bridge has been added to the west side of the arch span.''

column2: Eastbrook Neshannock Falls Hottenbaugh Run Bridge
column18: Thomas A. Gilkey, A. A. Sack (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 62'-long and 22' wide elliptical deck arch bridge built in 1913 has concrete parapets with posts defining the end of the span. The spandrel walls are plain. The bridge is one of 21 extant deck arch bridges built in the county between 1909 and 1930, and its detailing is typical of those designed by the county. It is not among the earliest.''

column2: Eastbrook Neshannock Falls Neshannock Creek Branch Bridge
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 65'-long and 18' wide elliptical deck arch bridge built in 1913 has concrete parapets with posts defining the end of the span. The spandrel walls are plain. There are repairs to the ends of the parapets. The bridge is one of 21 extant deck arch bridges built in the county between 1909 and 1930, and its detailing is typical of those designed by the county. It is not among the earliest. Neither the bridge nor its setting is historically or technologically significant.''

column2: Eastvale Bridge (John F. Kennedy Memorial Bridge)
column20: The Eastvale Bridge is known as the John F. Kennedy Memorial Bridge since it opened on November 22, 1963, the day John F. Kennedy was assassinated. Locals also call the bridge the Blue Bridge. It is one of the smallest thru cantilevers in Pennsylvania, since this type of bridge is usually built only for large crossings. The main span is just 360 feet. The bridge replaced a Whipple truss from 1879.

column15: Warren riveted supported by load-bearing stringers
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The single span, 42'-long bridge was built in 1913 as a riveted Warren with verticals pony truss bridge. In 1981 2 longitudinal beams and suspended floor beams were placed inside the truss lines. The truss bridge supports itself, not live loads. The truss bridge has no innovative or distinctive details, and it reflects the standardization of designs.''

column18: The Canton Bridge Company, B. M. French, County Engineer
column20: The Echo Dell Bridge is a late example of a pin-connected Pratt thru truss, built in 1909 by the Canton Bridge Company. The bridge is in a beautiful setting in Little Beaver Creek State Park. Even though the bridge had been closed to traffic for several years, it was rehabilitated and reopened in 2008. This bridge (as well as others in Columbiana County) serve as models as to what CAN be done to restore truss bridges.

The Echo Valley Bridge is an example of a state-standard concrete tee beam bridge. This type of bridge began to be used by the Pennsylvania Department of Highways in the late 1910's and was built through the 1950's. Many of these bridges, including Echo Valley, have severe spalling and are being replaced.

According to the PAHBI, ''The one span, pin connected, 63'-long, Pratt pony truss bridge built in 1895 is supported on ashlar abutments with flared wingwalls. It is an altered example of the standardized design that is common in the county. New eyes were welded onto the lower chord eye bars, and some of the rivets have been replaced by modern bolts at an unspecified date.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1895, pin connected, single span, 86'-long, Pratt thru truss is supported on ashlar abutments with flared wingwalls. The trusses traditionally composed, but the manner in which the floor beams are connected with Z-shaped straps at the lower panel points indicates that it was fabricated by Nelson & Buchanan. It is one of nine pin connected Pratt truss bridges in Armstrong County, and the bridge is historically and technologically significant as a complete example of the technology in the region. The bridge appears to be complete except for the cover plate welded to the floor beams.''

column15: Parker riveted with thru girder and floorbeam system approach spans
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Fort Pitt Bridge Works
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 4-span, 480'-long bridge built in 1936 consists of three, 70'-long, built-up thru girder approach spans and a 270'-long, riveted, Parker thru truss span over the river. The bridge is supported on concrete piers and concrete abutments with wingwalls. The trusses are traditionally composed, and there are no innovative or distinctive details. The cantilevered sidewalk is finished with standard design metal railings. The bridge was designed by the state highway department bridge division and fabricated by in state builder Fort Pitt Bridge Works.''

The Edith Barill Bridge was built to replace the former Star City Bridge in 2002 and 2004. Though the old bridge was open to unrestricted traffic, it was only two-lanes wide. WVDOH decided to replace it with a wider bridge, instead of constructing a new bridge next to it as a one-way pair. The westbound side of the bridge was built next to the former Star City Bridge. Once that side opened for temporary two-lane traffic, the old bridge was demolished. The eastbound side was built on the alignment of the old bridge, and opened to traffic in 2004. The photograph is from 2003, when the westbound side was open and the eastbound side under construction. The new Edith Barill Bridge is equipped with over 700 sensors in conjunction with West Virginia University of Morgantown. These sensors monitor the effects on the bridge of traffic, temperature, etc.

The Edith Barill Bridge was built to replace the former Star City Bridge in 2002 and 2004. Though the old bridge was open to unrestricted traffic, it was only two-lanes wide. WVDOH decided to replace it with a wider bridge, instead of constructing a new bridge next to it as a one-way pair. The westbound side of the bridge was built next to the former Star City Bridge. Once that side opened for temporary two-lane traffic, the old bridge was demolished. The eastbound side was built on the alignment of the old bridge, and opened to traffic in 2004. The photograph is from 2003, when the westbound side was open and the eastbound side under construction. The new Edith Barill Bridge is equipped with over 700 sensors in conjunction with West Virginia University of Morgantown. These sensors monitor the effects on the bridge of traffic, temperature, etc.

Edwin Land Boulevard is named after Edwin Land (5/7/1909 - 3/1/1991), an inventor known for polarizing light. He is best known for developing polarizing film and co-founding the Polaroid Corporation. He studied at Harvard University. The bridge is a modern steel beam with decorative concrete arched fascia panels.

column15: Parker pin-connected with deck girder approaches
column16: Tied for the oldest active truss bridge (on a public road) over the Susquehanna River in Pennsylvania (until late 2010)
column18: David A. Keefe (Engineer), Penn Bridge Company (Contractor)
column20: In 1950, all of the Susquehanna River Bridges (excluding the West Branch) in Pennsylvania were either thru trusses or concrete arches. Since then, all of the PennDOT-owned truss bridges have been demolished except for the Eighth Street Bridge and the Wyalusing Bridge. The Eighth Street Bridge will be the next to be demolished, scheduled for late 2010. The only truss bridges that will remain over the Susquehanna are two owned by Luzerne County and the Wyalusing Bridge. That's it. According to the PAHBI, ''The 5 span, 1016'-long steel pin-connected Parker thru truss bridge built in 1914 is traditionally composed of eye bar tension members and built-up compression members of standard sections. It is supported on stone piers and abutments with extensive concrete repairs including concrete caps, and encased or replaced cutwaters. The deck, stringers, and truss bearings were replaced in 1984. Welded repairs included plate welded to some diagonals at the lower panel points. Original railings have been replaced by W-beam guide rails at the roadway face of the trusses and a tubular metal railing at the cantilevered sidewalk. The altered bridge is a late example of the pin-connected truss bridge type/design that was introduced about 1870 by engineer Charles Parker. The Parker truss is a variation of the Pratt truss with a polygonal top chord. The type/design continued to be used for longer span crossings through the first decades of the 20th century because of economy of design, ease of erection, and pin connections, which were still considered a favorable means of handling secondary stresses in longer span trusses. The bridge was fabricated by the Penn Bridge Co., a prolific builder in the state since the 1870s.''

column15: Double intersection Pratt with a Pratt through truss approach on each side
column20: The earliest long-spanning railroad bridges were iron double intersection Pratt truss bridges. As trains became heavier, almost all of the bridges were replaced by steel Parker and Pennsylvania trusses for the longer spans, and Pratt, Baltimore, and Warren trusses for the smaller spans. For example, railroad bridges such as the ones at Parkersburg, Point Pleasant, and more were originally double intersection Pratt trusses. The superstructure was replaced, but the original piers still remain. Somehow, this bridge over the Elk River was never replaced. Eventually it will be converted to carry a rail trail (as part of Phase 2; the Kanawha River Bridge is Phase I). This conversion will allow many people to enjoy one of the most historic bridges in the state.

The historic Elkhurst Bridge is a rare example of a swinging suspension bridge. A swinging suspension bridge has no deck stiffening truss or girder. According to David Denenberg of bridgemeister.com, the local youth would drive quickly onto the bridge and slam on their brakes to feel the bridge sway. Hopefully there was no oncoming traffic! With a deck width of only 8 feet 4 inches, the bridge is probably the narrowest public-owned vehicular bridge on this site. The bridge was first constructed in 1930 with wooden towers and a completely wooden deck. The bridge was rehabilitated in 1941 when the wooden towers were replaced with steel ones and in 1984 when the wooden stringers were replaced with steel ones. The bridge was closed to vehicular traffic in March of 2003. Though there were probably other swinging suspension bridges in the area, most were demolished. One in nearby Gilmer County was bypassed.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: State Highway Commission, Gibb Gilchrist (Highway Engineer), G. G. Wickline (Bridge Engineer), J. G. Rollins, G. C. McKim (Resident Engineer), Uvalde Construction Company (Contractor)
column20: The Elliot Knox Boulevard is one of the largest concrete arch bridges in the region, consisting of five open spandrel spans. The bridge was built in 1934 as part of a new alignment of State Highway 2, the main road between Austin and San Antonio, bypassing the Faust Street Bridge. The Elliot Knox Boulevard Bridge was bypassed in 1965 by Interstate 35. While the two historic bridges remain, the Interstate 35 Bridge was replaced in 2002 - 2003.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, William E. Powers (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1937, 2 span, 206' long, riveted Parker pony truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls and a concrete pier. Built to a state highway department standard design, the bridge is an example of a common technology with no innovative or distinctive details. It was erected as part of the rebuilding efforts following the devastating 1936 St. Patrick's Day flood. Over 275 bridges, mostly in the western and central portions of Pennsylvania, were destroyed or damaged beyond repair. The department favored using heavy metal truss bridges to replace lost bridges because it was perceived that they could withstand future flood episodes.''
