column2: Elm Grove Stone Bridge (Monument Place Bridge)
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Elm Grove Stone Bridge is the oldest bridge in West Virginia. It was built for the National Road (Cumberland Road) in 1817. The builder, Moses Shepherd, was a friend of House Speaker Henry Clay at the time of the road's construction. Moses Shepherd was not only able to get the contracts to build the bridges on the road around Wheeling, but he even got the road to be realigned to pass his plantation, Shepherd Hall. This alignment caused an extra bridge to be constructed. In return, Shepherd built a now demolished monument to Henry Clay, so the area is known as Monument Place. The bridge was modernized in 1931 and again in 1958 when the bridge was faced with concrete. The West Virginia National Road Alliance proposes to restore the bridge and its past surroundings to their former glory.
The Emerald Pools Trail Bridge is one of several prefabricated lightweight truss bridges carrying trails in Zion National Park.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The single span, 50'-long, ribbed open spandrel reinforced concrete deck arch bridge dates stylistically to ca. 1910. It has plain spandrel columns. The concrete deck and beam guiderail railings date to ca. 1985. The bridge is technologically and historically significant representing the experimentation associated with the early days of reinforced concrete bridge technologies. It represents economy of both concrete and reinforcing steel for a short span.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The original Meadville Division Franklin Branch Erie Railway Bridge, a four-span Pratt truss, was destroyed by fire on November 4th, 1890. The bridge was replaced by the current two-span Pratt truss in 1892. 1892 was an eventful year in Oil City, since much of the city was destroyed in a flood and fire. Much of the city was immediately rebuilt. Much of the 1892 rebuilding, including the railroad bridge, has been designed the Oil City Downtown Commercial Historic District. At some point, a sidewalk was added to the bridge. The Justus Trail now uses the sidewalk.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1916, single span, 83'-long, reinforced concrete deck arch bridge is finished with raised panel parapets. In 1962 the substructure was widened, and two steel beams were placed on either side of the bridge to carry the sidewalks. The bridge is an example of a common type, and it has no innovative or distinctive details. It was built by the Ferro Concrete Company of Harrisburg which was for a short time around 1910 a representative for Daniel Luten's National Bridge Company, but the association ended prior to the construction of this bridge.''

column15: Queenpost, wooden covered on steel stringers
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1979
column20: The Erskine Covered Bridge is the oldest covered bridge and second oldest bridge of any type in Washington County, dating from 1845. It is a queen post wooden covered bridge. The bridge was rehabilitated in 2006, a year before the photo on this website was taken. A new support structure was added as part of the restoration and the supplementary intermediate supports were removed.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Estep Bridge is located near the end of a dead-end road in Washington County near the Allegheny County border. Note the unusual detail of the diagonal endpost connection with the top chord. The diagonal and the vertical are connected with separate pins. The top chord projects over the diagonal endpost. This is characteristic of Penn Bridge Company bridges from the 1870's through the 1880's. While there is no build date, and the National Bridge Inventory gives 1912 as the build date (which is clearly incorrect), the bridge stylistically dates from the 1880's based on its details. According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, ''The bridge is remarkably complete, and it represents the experimentation in design of the early days of metal truss bridges. The span is historically and technologically significant.'' The only obvious modifications to the bridge are new welded steel railings and load-bearing wooden bents below the floorbeams that help support the truss.

The Eugene Carter (Fort Hill Bridge) is an unusual example of a large-scale modern bowstring arch truss. It is the only one like it in in all of West Virginia and in surrounding states. Bowstring trusses were commonly built in the mid to late 1800's. The first examples date to the 1840's. With the advent of steel, bowstring trusses were no longer built. After World War II, a few modern examples have been constructed. Most are smaller, pre-fabricated trusses used on trails. The Eugene Carter Bridge has a main span of 465 feet and is eight lanes wide. Rather than being two parallel bridges, the bridge consists of three parallel lines bowstring arch trusses. Due to the curved ramps and weaving areas, the bridge in infamous for its high crash rate.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: Evans Bridge is one of five remaining pin-connected Pratt thru truss bridges in Washington County, though bridges are frequently being replaced with modern structures. Note the Evans Bridge's unusual detail of the diagonal endpost connection with the top chord. The diagonal and the vertical are connected with separate pins. The top chord projects over the diagonal endpost. This is characteristic of Penn Bridge Company bridges from the 1870's through the 1880's. The bridge stylistically dates to the 1880's, based on the details. The bridge is similar to the 1888 Coal Center Bridge. According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, ''The bridge is historically and technologically significant as an example of the technology prior to its becoming standardized.''

The Exchange Avenue Bridge is located in the Fort Worth Stockyards National Historic District. The stockyards were once the largest horse and mule market in the world, processing a peak of 5,277,496 head of livestock in a year. The bridge is an example of a segmental concrete arch. Such a design is comparatively rare in Texas. The bridge is unique in that not only does the bridge carry Exchange Avenue, but also the stores on both sides of the street! It is almost impossible to know where the bridge is from the street!

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1889, skewed, pin connected, single span, 73'-long, Pratt pony truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with flared wingwalls. The traditionally composed bridge is stylistically similar to 60 7217 0522 3041 [Dotter Road Bridge], a pony truss bridge that was built by the Smith Bridge Company. The built up floor beams are original.'' Nathan Holth of www.historicbridges.org identified the bridge as built by the Massillon Bridge Company, based on viewing a photo of a fragment of a plaque.

column18: The Ohio Bridge Corporation (U.S. Bridge Company)?
column20: The Fairplay-Seminary Road Bridge is a Warren welded polygonal pony from 1989. While the bridge is not as interesting as a historic truss bridge, it certainly is more interesting than a stringer or box beam!

Fallingwater is one of America's most famous houses, designed by Frank Lloyd Wright and built for the Kaufmann family. Unlike most houses which would have been constructed with a view of scenic waterfalls in Bear Run, Fallingwater was built directly over the waterfalls. The entrance to the house is therefore in the back, requiring a bridge over Bear Run for the driveway. The architecture of the concrete bridge matches that of the house.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Fallston Bridge is one of the most significant bridges in the area. It is a rare example of a two-span Whipple (double intersection Pratt) truss. There is only one other multi-span example in all of Western Pennsylvaniathe Mead Avenue Bridge in Meadvillealthough that bridge is to be replaced. The Fallston Bridge was built by the Penn Bridge Company, located just up the river in Beaver Falls. It exhibits the standard details of the company, such as the unusual top chord to vertical endpost connection, in which the diagonal is connected below the top chord with a separate pin as the adjacent vertical member. The bridge was repainted in 2005 and received minor repairs.

The Fannin Street Bridge is an example of a three span riveted Parker truss. Built in 1949, the bridge is a late example of a state-designed thru truss. Throughout the country, most state highway departments stopped building truss bridges after World War II.

The Farabee Drive Bridge, dating from 1904, is one of several remaining similar Nelson & Buchanan truss bridges. The comparable bridges are either three or four panels; the Farabee Drive Bridge is one of the longer four-panel designs. The Nelson & Buchanan bridges are noteworthy for being early riveted pony truss bridges in which each panel has an X shape. The bridge does not have an NBI number, so it may be privately owned.

column15: Whipple pin-connected with Pratt pin-connected approach spans
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: King Iron Bridge Company, W. R. Freeman (Engineer); rehabilitated by Thomas Hornseth (County Engineer), Law Engineering and Environmental Services, Inc. (Consulting Engineer), Jay-Reese Contractors, Inc. (Contractor)
column20: According to the Texas Historical Commission plaque, ''Caravans carrying supplies to Spanish missions in east Texas and other travelers crossed the Guadalupe River on El Camino Real (The King's Highway) near this site in the 18th century. It sometimes took weeks for floodwaters to subside so travelers could cross. In 1887, the Comal County Commissioners Court contracted with the King Iron Bridge Company of Ohio to build a high water bridge over the Guadalupe River. Among the last wrought iron bridges built in Texas and one of the first long-term toll-free structures completed over a major waterway in the state, this monumental truss structure extents more than 640 feet in length. It is comprised of two main spans, known as Pratt (Whipple) truss spans, flanked by two smaller spans. The Whipple was a variation on the more typical Pratt truss style bridge design which enjoyed brief but explosive popularity in the mid- to late-19th century. These trusses are connected by a pin-and-hanger system, which was the common method of the time. The spans are supported by oval-shaped masonry piers with rusticated stonework and pointed, or 'cut-water' ends. In 1917, the Texas Highway Department designed the Faust Street Bridge to serve as a major crossing for all traffic between Austin and San Antonio on State Highway 2, formerly the Austin-San Antonio Post Road. In 1934, a new concrete highway bridge was erected. The Faust Street Bridge continued to serve local traffic until it was damaged by fire in 1979. Its unique design, using a combination of Pratt and Whipple truss types, and its wrought iron construction place the Faust Street Bridge among the important historic bridges in the state.''

column15: Pennsylvania camelback thru truss with Pratt pony truss approaches
column18: Wrought Iron Bridge Company, Virginia Bridge and Iron Company
column20: The 1889 Fayette Station Bridge was the first vehicular bridge to cross the New River in Fayette County. In 1873, the C&O Railroad was completed through the New River Gorge. Not long after, Martin Blume founded the Fayette Coal and Coke Company. Fayette (east side) and South Fayette (west side) were built as company towns for the coal mines. In 1889, the Fayette Station Road was built to connect Fayetteville, the county seat of Fayette County, with Fayette and the C&O Railroad. The bridge was built as part of that road. Once the coal seam was exhausted, the towns were deserted. Nothing except for a few building foundations remain from the town. The bridge was allowed to deteriorate, and was closed to traffic in March of 1978, after the nearby New River Gorge Bridge was built. After almost 20 years, the bridge was dismantled and reconstructed. Though most of the bridge was replaced, as much original material was used as possible in the 1997 reconstruction. The bridge is an excellent example of how even a severely deteriorated bridge can be rebuilt and reopened to traffic.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: T. & S. White (New Brighton, PA) [Predecessor to the Penn Bridge Company]
column20: The 1876 Feed Mill Road Bridge is one of the oldest Whipple truss bridges in the entire state of Pennsylvania. As a result, it is a very important bridge. The bridge sits closed to traffic; its future is uncertain. According to the PAHBI, ''The one-span, 119'-long, wrought-iron, pin-connected, double-intersection Pratt thru truss bridge has built-up verticals and upper chord, and eye-bar diagonals, counters and lower chord. It is supported on stone abutments. The lattice portals are topped by builder's plaques that read ''T. & S. White, Builders, New Brighton, PA.'' Mounted at the top corners of the inclined end posts are cast-iron shields with the date ''1876.'' The bridge has been altered by replacement floorbeams, stringers, deck, railings, and welded repairs to the end-panel floorbeam hangers, but the trusses themselves are otherwise complete. It one of fewer than 10 identified double-intersection Pratt thru truss highway bridges dating from ca. 1870 to 1900 in the state, and one of no more than four from the 1870s. Builders T. & S. White began building bridges in 1868 and went on to incorporate the Penn Bridge Company in 1879. The bridge is technologically significant as an early, rare, and relatively complete example of the its type and design, fabricated by a noteworthy Pennsylvania builder. It would also contribute to a potential Williamson historic district.... The one-lane bridge over a tree-lined stream is currently closed to traffic. It has been closed since at least the mid 1980s. It is located in the rural village of Williamson. To the north of the bridge is a stone mill (ca. 1870) with machinery. Parallel to the bridge is an abandoned railroad bridge (pin-connected Pratt truss, ca. 1900), part of the former Pennsylvania Railroad branch line from Marion to Mercersburg. Williamson retains its railroad depot (ca. 1910) and 19th to early 20th century commercial and residential buildings located two to three blocks to the northwest of the bridge. The setting appears to have the integrity and cohesiveness of a potential historic district.''
The Fellowsville School Road Bridge is a tiny stringer with a wooden deck that serves a dead-end road, the only local street in Fellowsville, West Virginia.

The Fern Hollow Bridge of 1970 replaced a previous three-hinged deck arch. The bridge is a steel frame, most similar to the Chapline Hill Road Bridge over I-470 near Wheeling, West Virginia (Ohio County). It is one of three large steel frame bridges in Allegheny County, and is the only one to span a wooded ravine without any major roads. The design minimizes the impact to the park. The bridge won an AISC (American Institute of Steel Construction) upon completion.

The new 15th Avenue Bridge is an example of a weathering steel multi-beam bridge. It replaced a deteriorated steel truss that had been closed to traffic for approximately five years prior to demolition.

column15: Parker with Pratt thru truss approaches
column20: The 1926 Fifth Avenue Bridge was built just before the state standard truss bridges became common. It is of a visually pleasing configuration with a Parker truss center span with a Pratt truss approach span on each side. Since the bridge is not only a historical resource, but a gateway to the historic community of Guyandotte, the public is opposed to the bridge being replaced by a visually uninteresting girder bridge. Therefore, additional options were evaluated, such as rehabilitation and replacement with either a through truss or a faux suspension bridge (a girder bridge with non-load bearing elements to make it look like a suspension bridge). Though the public supported the faux suspension design, WVDOH decided to build a standard girder bridge. Due to many complaints, the new girder bridge will have decorative historic-looking street lights and railings. This is the typical response whenever the public complains about the replacement of a historic bridge -- a modern girder bridge is built with historic-looking railings, lampposts, and concrete textured to look like stonework. The bridge was closed in 2007, to be torn down in the winter of 2008-09, and the new bridge is to open in 2010.

column16: Last remaining rigid frame Turnpike overpass in Somerset County
column20: The Findlay Street Overpass is significant since it had stairs near each side of the bridge, allowing Turnpike motorists to attend St. John the Baptist Catholic Church. Unfortunately, the stairs were closed in 2009 and are to be removed as part of the reconstruction project that will also claim the bridge. The stairs will not be rebuilt. In 1940, the first stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike opened between Irwin and Somerset. The original mainline overpasses consisted of arched concrete rigid frames, steel thru girders, and concrete tee beams. The last of the tee beams were replaced in the 1990's. Beginning in the late 1990's and continuing through at least 2020, the entire original turnpike is being reconstructed and widened. Almost all original overpasses are being replaced as part of the project, including the Findlay Street Overpass.

The 1924 First Street Bridge is one of only a few single-leaf bascule bridges in eastern Massachusetts in which the counterweight is located above the road deck. In 1956, a parallel bridge was constructed to carry eastbound traffic, and the 1924 bridge was converted to carry westbound traffic. The 1956 bridge is a similar type.

column15: Single leaf bascule, thru girder and floorbeam system
column16: Possibly eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The 1924 First Street Bridge is one of only a few single-leaf bascule bridges in eastern Massachusetts in which the counterweight is located above the road deck. In 1956, a parallel bridge was constructed to carry eastbound traffic, and the 1924 bridge was converted to carry westbound traffic. The 1956 bridge is a similar type.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The one span, 228'-long, pin connected Parker thru truss bridge built in 1903 is supported on ashlar abutments. It is traditionally composed, but what stands out is its remarkable completeness. There are about 10 older Parker thru truss bridges throughout the state that are older than this example, including 3 in District 3-0, but the truss type is not common, this example is documented to a regional fabricator, and it has a long span length. The bridge is a historically and technologically significant example of the uncommon bridge type, which was used for longer spans because its design, developed in the 1870s, concentrates depth at the center of the span where forces are the greatest. Noteworthy features include the floorbeam framing, which reflects the transition from pinned to riveted field connections, and the railings.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1955, single span, 88'-long, steel stringer bridge with welded steel channel railings and diaphragms is supported on ashlar abutments with flared wingwalls dating from an earlier bridge. It is an example of the most common 20th century bridge type in the state, with no innovative or distinguishing details.'' According to the NBI, the wingwalls date from 1886. The masonry from the wingwalls extend above the approaches forming walls, indicating the original structure was a covered bridge.

According to the PAHBI, ''The riveted, single span, 54'-long, Warren with verticals pony truss bridge dates stylistically to ca. 1910. Ca. 1996 short steel angles were welded between the end posts and lower chords near the bearings, sections of the lower chords were replaced in kind, and the connections on a number of diagonals were changed from rivets to bolts. The bridge, an undistinguished example of its technology, has no innovative or distinctive details. Riveted truss bridges have been used in the state since ca. 1890.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 95'-long and 14' wide, pin-connected, 6 panel, Pratt thru truss bridge built in 1887 is supported on ashlar abutments with flared, stepped wingwalls. The deck and stringers are timber. The trusses are traditionally composed, but what is remarkable is how complete it is, including the original built up floor beams and the finials at the portals. The bridge is technologically and historically significant as a relatively early and complete example of the important bridge type. It is also documented to the Groton Bridge Company.''

By the 1950's the Warren truss design became the standard for Allegheny County truss bridges. The Fleming Park Bridge is noteworthy in that it is the only simple thru truss example. All others are either deck trusses or deck or thru cantilever trusses.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: The Oregonia Bridge Company, J. H. Sweetman (County Engineer)
column20: The Florence Bridge is a rare pre-World War I Warren thru truss. Comparable regional bridges, even ones constructed by the same company, are Pratt or Parker pin-connected trusses. The National Register eligible bridge is the only such example in the entire region. The bridge still retains its original architectural features such as cut-out Florence Bridge signs, decorative portal bracing, and railings.

The Footbridge in Sterrettania is an unusual private pedestrian suspension bridge. The staircase approaches to the bridge are perpendicular to the main suspension span. The towers are triangular, accommodating the angle in the walkway. The bridge is decorated with hanging flower baskets in the summer and pumpkins in the fall.

column2: Forbes Avenue Ramp to Boulevard of the Allies Bridge
column18: McClintic - Marshall Company / City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works
column20: The bridge was one of Pittsburgh's oldest bridges built to be a ramp. It was constructed to connect Forbes Ave with the inbound Boulevard of the Allies. The Boulevard of the Allies was one of several urban boulevards built in the 1920's to connect Downtown Pittsburgh with the city neighborhoods and suburbs. Since it was built to be a bypass for Forbes Avenue through Uptown, ramps were used to connect it with Forbes. The bridge was historically significant due to its association with the Boulevard. After being in a state of advanced deterioration for many years, the bridge was demolished in 2008. It was replaced by a new ramp without a bridge on a different alignment. In keeping with the tradition of the old bridge, the new bridge was painted a similar color, and decorative eagle reliefs were formed into the concrete abutments.

column15: High strength weathering steel continuous girder
column16: Most curved girder bridge in Pennsylvania
column20: The New Ford City Bridge is an example of a weathering steel girder bridge. High performance steel was used for the structure, eliminating the need for haunches. Upon construction in 2000, the western span became the most curved girder span in Pennsylvania.

column16: Last remaining Pennsylvania truss bridge on the Allegheny River in Pennsylvania north of Allegheny County
column18: E. K. Morse, Penn Bridge Company
column20: The Ford City Bridge was the last of several similar bridges in western Pennsylvania built by the Penn Bridge Company. The Pennsylvania trusses were distinctive in that the trusses formed Warren trusses at the ends of each span, since the diagonal members went in opposite directions in the first three panels from the endposts. Similar bridges included the now demolished Glenwood Bridge, Rankin Bridge, and Monongahela City Bridge over the Monongahela River and the State Street Bridge over the Allegheny River at Oil City. The only bridge still standing as of 2011 with a similar portal bracing is the main span of the Donora Webster Bridge over the Monongahela River, though that bridge may soon be demolished. The bridge was demolished in 2000, with a local resident bidding $1425 to push the plunger to demolish the bridge.

The Foresthill Bridge was completed in 1973 to span the planned Auburn Reservoir of the North Fork American River. The Auburn Dam and Reservoir was to be the final dam and lake system of the Central Valley Project. However, during preliminary construction of the dam, an earthquake occurred in a fault thought to be dormant near Oroville in 1977. Construction halted, and similar faults were found under the dam site. A redesign of the dam was found to be too costly, especially since dam was not crucial for flood control since Folsom Dam already existed downstream. As a result, construction of the dam never resumed. Therefore, with a height of 730 feet, the Foresthill Bridge will remain the fourth highest bridge in America, behind only the Royal Gorge Bridge, New River Gorge Bridge, and Hoover Dam Bypass Bridge. The bridge is also one of the largest cantilever truss bridges in America, with a main span of 862 feet. Due to its height, the bridge was used in the movie, xXx, in which Vin Diesel's character drove a Corvette off the bridge and parachuted away to escape pursuit. The bridge is also noteworthy that while it was designed to accommodate four lanes of traffic plus shoulders, only the two outside lanes were built, due to the relatively low traffic volume of Foresthill Road. Therefore, the center of the bridge has no deck. The inside lanes will only be added if warranted by increased traffic volumes.

column18: Richardson, Gordon and Associates (now HDR), Agnew-Joseph Company (Contractor), L. S. Coleman Company (Contractor)
column20: The bridge and new alignment for WV 39 was completed in 1964, in time for the flooding of the Gauley River due to the 1966 Summersville Reservoir. The new crossing replaced the Brocks Bridge. The bridge was a large example of a deck girder, with length of 1,230 feet and a height of 175 feet. The bridge cost $1,330,000. Upon opening, the bridge won an AISC Award of Merit for a medium span, high clearance bridge. The bridge was replaced in 2006 with another deck girder.
The bridge was originally built over the Intracoastal Waterway in Pompano Beach, Florida. It was moved to its current location in 1963. This is the only vehicular truss bridge in Southwest Florida.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways / Richardson Gordon & Associates, American Bridge
column20: Pittsburgh is famous for the confluence of the Monongahela River and Allegheny River at The Point, forming the Ohio River. In 1959 the Fort Pitt and Fort Duquesne Bridges were built; two similar double deck tied arch bridges on either side of the point. The Fort Duquesne Bridge has the shorter arch span, about 325 feet shorter than that of the Fort Pitt Bridge. The bridge was completed in 1963, except for all connections at the northern end. The bridge was nicknamed, ''The Bridge to Nowhere.'' College students supposedly drove a car off the end of the bridge and survived, though some think it to be a hoax. It was not until 1969 that the western half of the Y-shaped ramps was completed. These ramps are unusual in the region since they are welded double deck box girders on steel bents. The eastern ramps were finally built in 1986, completing the approaches to the bridge. The bridge was rehabilitated in 2010.

column15: Tied arch with deck girder approaches and spans over the back channel
column20: The Fort Henry Bridge opened to traffic in 1955 as an upgrade of US 40 between Wheeling Island and Wheeling. After the 1956 Interstate Highway Act was passed, it was decided that the new Fort Henry Bridge would be connected to an interstate, I-70. On the east side, the bridge ended at Mount Wood. Therefore, the 1966 Wheeling Tunnel (twin tubes, 1,518 feet long) was constructed to connect the bridge with I-70. On the west side, the bridge was extended by girder spans to cross Wheeling Island and the Back Channel of the Ohio River into Ohio. This project was completed in 1968. By looking at satellite imagery, you can get an idea of the original configuration of the Fort Henry Bridge. Due to reusing an older bridge, this section of I-70 is not up to interstate standards, and many wrecks occur on this stretch of the highway.
The Fort Hill Bridge is a state-standard example of a multi-beam (stringer).

column16: Oldest concrete arch bridge over the North Branch of the Susquehanna River in Pennsylvania
column18: Luzerne County, David A. Keefe (Engineer), Whittaker & Diehl Co. (Contractor)
column20: The bridge is named after Jenkins' Fort, which was John Jenkins' stockade home built in 1776. During the Revolutionary War, it was surrendered to the British under Major John Butler in 1778 and was burned. According to the PAHBI, ''The 11 span, 1,075'-long bridge built in 1924 consists of 7 open spandrel arch spans over the stream, and at its southeast end an encased steel deck girder span, 2 T beam spans and a slab span over local roads. The slab span replaced a T beam span in 1986. The 4 rib open spandrel arch spans have fasciae scored to appear like stone. The ribs have several generations of concrete and gunite patching and repairs, especially at the skewbacks. The original reticulated concrete parapet has been lost except at the exedrae (pedestrian refuges) on the downstream side and over the encased deck girder span. It has been replaced by a plain safety shape concrete parapet on the upstream side and by tubular metal railings on the downstream sidewalk side (1986).''

In 1940, the first stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike opened between Irwin and Somerset. The original mainline overpasses consisted of arched concrete rigid frames, steel thru girders, and concrete tee beams. The remaining tee beams were replaced in the 1990's. Beginning in the late 1990's and continuing through at least 2020, the entire original turnpike is being reconstructed and widened. Almost all original overpasses are being replaced as part of the project, including the Fort Littleton Interchange Bridge.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, George S. Richardson, American Bridge
column20: The Fort Pitt Bridge was the first double decked tied arch bridge and one of the first to be designed with computers. Pittsburgh is considered to be the only city with an entrance, since motorists do not see downtown until they drive through the Fort Pitt Tunnel and onto the bridge. It is the busiest river crossing in western Pennsylvania.

column15: Wire rope suspension with Warren pony stiffening truss
column20: In the late 1920's, four similar suspension bridges were built over the Ohio River along the Ohio Border. Two were eyebar chain suspension bridges in which the eyebar chains formed the top of the stiffening trusses at midspan and near the anchorages. The other two were unusual wire rope cable suspension bridges in which the suspenders were attached to the top of the stiffening truss. The main continuous cables were connected to eyebar chains at the ends of the bridge and ran to the anchorages. (Note that there is also a related 1930's cable suspension in Aberdeen, OH, but it is a more modern design). So what happened to these four interesting suspension bridges? In 1967, the 1928 Silver Bridge, an eyebar chain bridge, suddenly collapsed, killing 46 people. The other eyebar chain bridge at St. Marys (1928) was demolished in 1971 as a precaution. The 1927 U.S. Grant Bridge in Portsmouth, Ohio, one of the wire rope suspension bridges, was demolished in 2001. The last surviving bridge of the four is the 1928 Fort Steuben Bridge. It was bypassed in 1990, though allowed to remain open. ODOT eventually decided to let the bridge deteriorate until 2009, when it was to be demolished. Unfortunately, those plans are still on schedule. The bridge closed to traffic in January of 2009 due to a shifted slab of concrete and will be demolished later in the year. Local citizens are trying to organize a last-minute effort to save the bridge, with the hopes of utilizing the Fort Steuben Bridge to connect bike trails to Washington, D.C., and to Indianapolis. Even though no other suitable bridge exists in the area, it does not appear likely that the citizens will get their wish. Neither will anyone else who cares about a bypassed historic bridge.

Part of the Parkway East Squirrel Hill Interchange, westbound Beechwood Boulevard was realigned as part of a grade separation for Forward Avenue and some Parkway ramps. The lower westbound lane was relocated to the former path of Four Mile Run. Four Mile Run has been entirely enclosed. All original structures of the Penn Lincoln Parkway are considered to be historically significant, since the Parkway is an early example of a post-World War II urban highway.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1907, single span, 75'-long, reinforced concrete deck arch bridge has plain spandrel walls and is finished with modern beam guiderails and a cantilevered deck placed in 1974. Although an early example of its type, the bridge is an altered example of its technology.''

column16: Oldest active truss bridge in Cameron County
column20: The Fourth Street Bridge is an example of a state standard Parker thru truss. The portal bracing is composed of angles, typical of state standard bridges from ca. 1930. By the early 1930's, all state standard thru truss bridges have portal bracing composed of built-up members. According to the PAHBI (evaluated by JPH), 'The 1930, single span, 138'-long, rivet-connected Parker thru truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls. The upper chords are built up box sections; the lower chord, verticals, and diagonals are rolled sections. Rolled floorbeams support stringers and a stay-in-place deck with safety-shape parapets inside of the truss lines, placed in 1981. Also in 1981, the portal bracing was modified to provide greater vertical clearance. The bridge is an example of a state highway department standardized rivet-connected thru truss bridge with rolled verticals and diagonals.'

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 3-span stone arch bridge is listed in the National Register. Other than some minor repairs to repoint damaged end sections of the parapets, there has been no change in the bridge's status since the previous survey.''

The Fourth Street Bridge is an example of a state standard Parker thru truss. The portal bracing is composed of angles, typical of state standard bridges from ca. 1930. By the early 1930's, all state standard thru truss bridges have portal bracing composed of built-up members. According to the PAHBI (evaluated by JPH), 'The 1930, single span, 138'-long, rivet-connected Parker thru truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls. The upper chords are built up box sections; the lower chord, verticals, and diagonals are rolled sections. Rolled floorbeams support stringers and a stay-in-place deck with safety-shape parapets inside of the truss lines, placed in 1981. Also in 1981, the portal bracing was modified to provide greater vertical clearance. The bridge is an example of a state highway department standardized rivet-connected thru truss bridge with rolled verticals and diagonals.'

The first bridge on this site was built circa 1890 to carry a spur of the Turtle Creek Valley Railroad to the Pennsylvania Railroad and the Westinghouse Airbrake Company factories on the other side of Turtle Creek. The Turtle Creek Valley Railroad, also known as Westinghouse Road, was an interworks railroad serving various Westinghouse mines and factories. The railroad was operated by the Pennsylvania Railroad from the beginning of service in 1891. It was purchased by the Pennsylvania Railroad (which became Conrail) in 1903. Conrail abandoned the Turtle Creek Valley Railroad in 1982. The current bridge appears to have been constructed ca. 1960, when Turtle Creek was realigned and channelized for flood control. Though the bridge is wide enough for two tracks, it only contains one. The abandoned railroad tracks are still in place on the bridge. The bridge now carries the access road to the Wabtec factories.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Baltimore & Ohio Railroad, P. J. Lang (Engineer), A. C. Clard (Engineer), Bethlehem Steel (Contractor)
column20: The 1921 Foxburg Bridge was demolished in 2008. The abutments dated from 1883, when a wooden Howe truss was built at this location. The wooden bridge was built to carry railcars for the Pittsburgh and Western Railroad (which became the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad's Northern Subdivision) along the top deck and wagon and passenger traffic along the bottom deck. The article, ''Modern Engineering Accomplished Wonder,'' from the Oil City Derrick on August 23rd, 1921, provides an account of replacing the 1883 bridge with the 1921 bridge: ''Foxburg, Pa. Aug 22. The substitution of a new steel span, 180 feet long and weighing 400 tons, for a section of the old double locked wooden railroad bridge over the Allegheny at this point, the work of making the change occupying an actual period of only 10 minutes, was an engineering fete witnessed early today by practically all the inhabitants of this place. Placing of the new span was the first step in the reconstruction of the old bridge which is one of the last wooden railroad bridges left in the country. Two more spans of the same weight and dimensions as the first will be put in place, one on September 18 and the other October 16. The method employed by the engineers in making the substitution was apparently simple. The new steel structure was built alongside of the old wooden span, false work erected on the upstream side. Similar false work was built out on the down stream side. Both old and the new structures were set on several hundred small rollers and when all was ready cables which had been rigged from two railroad cranes were attached to the steel span and the signal to pull was given. As the new span rolled from its position it pushed the old structure from its place on the stone piers to a resting place on the false work on the down stream side. Both spans made the journey in less than 10 minutes and an hour later the bridge was ready for regular train service. The work was under the direction of P. J. Lang, bridge engineer for the Baltimore & Ohio railroad and A. C. Clark, district engineer of the same road.'' The last section of the bridge was erected on October 16, 1921. The bridge carried the railroad until 1964; the tracks were later removed. The bridge was demolished on July 24, 2008, to make room for the replacement bridge's sidewalk.
The new Foxburg Bridge is a four-span weathering steel girder bridge. The previous bridge stood where the sidewalk is now on the new bridge.

The Frankfort Road Bridge is an example of a Pennsylvania state-standard Parker truss bridge from the 1930's. There is only one other state-standard Parker truss in the entire county--the three-span Old Rochester Beaver Bridge over the Beaver River.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, W. L. Dunn Construction Company
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1948, skewed, single span, 50'-long T beam bridge with concrete balustrades is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls. It has no innovative or distinctive details. Beam guiderail railings have been placed in front of the railings. The bridge is an example of a very common bridge type that was used with great frequency beginning in the 1910s and continuing through the 1950s.''

column16: Rare closed spandrel arch with no fill
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The single span, 43' long and 16' wide reinforced concrete arch bridge was built in 1918. It has no fill, and the road follows the profile of the arch. The parapets are shaped correspondingly over the bridge and are finished with coping (partially lost). Lower parapets are atop the flared wingwalls.''

All original structures of the Penn Lincoln Parkway are considered to be historically significant, since the Parkway is an early example of a post-World War II urban highway. This bridge is the only truss bridge on the Parkway. It is actually two truss bridges in parallel, each carrying three lanes of traffic. Though not the longest bridge on the Parkway, the bridge is the longest that carries the highway over a valley.

column16: Largest cable-stayed bridge in Texas
column18: TxDOT; Leonhardt, Andra Und Partner, URS Dreiner (Designers); Woodward Clyde (Structural Engineer); Robert Scanlan (Consultant); Holger S. Svensson, DRC (Contractors)
column20: According to GlassSteelAndStone.com, ''An elegant misfit in the brutal world of Houston transportation, the Fred Hartman bridge gracefully carries traffic up and over the Houston Ship Channel between the cities of La Porte and Baytown. A recent addition to the area, it stands proudly on par with the great cable-stay bridges of the world including the more relaxed, but still pioneering, Erasmusbrug in Rotterdam.'' The bridge opened in 1995 to replace the Baytown Tunnel. Since the tunnel allowed a 40 foot depth for the ship channel, it had to be removed when the channel was deepened to 45 feet. The bridge is named after Fred Hartman, who was an editor and publisher of the Baytown Sun newspaper. The Hartman Bridge is the longest-spanning bridge in Texas with a main span of 1,250 feet. The towers are 440 feet tall, and the vertical clearance above the shipping channel is 178 feet.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 100'-long, closed spandrel concrete deck arch bridge, built in 1919, has a single sidewalk. Originally the bridge had sidewalks with ornamental concrete balustrades on each side. In 1983, one of the sidewalks was removed to allow placement of a widened roadway, and safety shape parapets were installed. The remaining sidewalk kept its balustrade. The reinforced concrete deck arch gained popularity quickly in the 1900s and was used with great frequency in Pennsylvania on local and county roads in the 1910s. Although a relatively early, long example, the significance of the bridge has been lost through alterations.''

column16: Bridge dedicated to Capt. Hill, Maj. Crew, Lt. Rein, and all other Pennsylvania POW-MIA's and veterans
column18: T. B. Dinsmore (Engineer), Pittsburgh Foundation Company (Contractor)
column20: The US 19 Tenmile Creek Bridge was renamed the Freedom Bridge in honor of Captain John Hill, Major James Crew, Lieutenant Charles Reign, and all other Pennsylvania POW-MIA's and war veterans. The decorative bridge is probably the best preserved concrete arch bridge in Greene County, retaining its original deck and balustrades. It is also one of the most ornate. The sidewalks are artfully cantilevered from the bridge, with shallow arch shapes between the floorbeams. The ornate balustrades, seen on a few other Greene County bridges, are of alternating droplet and diamond shapes. The bridge is the last remaining multiple-span concrete arch bridge in the county. The bridge is slated for replacement as part of a capacity improvement project.

According to the PAHBI, ''The one span, 90'-long, reinforced concrete deck arch bridge built in 1925 is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls and finished with concrete flat paneled parapets. The bridge has no innovative or distinctive details. The latest of 14 county-designed deck arch bridges...''

The Freeport Road Bridge over the Barge Basin is one of several Allegheny County designed and Fort Pitt Bridge Works built thru girders in the county. As part of the 1986 rehabilitation, concrete safety shape barrier has been placed inside the girders. As a result, most motorists do not notice they are crossing a bridge.

The Friendsville Bridge is a steel stringer in which the fascia girders are encased by concrete. This serves both for decorative and for protective purposes. This is a large stringer bridge for 1932; this type is more often seen for such crossings after World War II. Maryland commonly built state-standard truss bridges such as the US Route 40 Casselman River Bridge from the late 1920's though World War II.
The Frogtown Bridge is an example of a state-standard concrete arch bridge from the 1930's. Around 2005, the original concrete balustrades were removed and replaced with guide rail.

The Frye Station Bridge is an example of a state-standard Parker pony truss. Most similar state-standard bridges have seven or more panels; this bridge has six. As a result, the top chord is pointed in the center. The bridge is scheduled to be replaced with a wider bridge.

column15: Pratt pin-connected, full slope, retrofitted with I-beams
column20: The Galico Crossing Bridge is a full slope Pratt pin-connected pony truss bridge built by the York Bridge Company. According to the PAHBI (JPH Reviewer), 'The single-span, 82'-long, pin-connected, steel Pratt pony truss bridge built ca. 1905 has metal railings and ashlar abutments with wingwalls. It is traditionally composed of built-up compression members and eye-bar tension members. Rolled floorbeams with paired U-shaped hangers support steel stringers and a wood deck. The plaque lists the builder as the York Bridge Co. of York, PA , but the last digit of the date '190?' has been broken off. The company, which operated from ca. 1901 to 1916 built standard truss and girder bridges.' In 2004 the bridge was rehabilitated, in which I-beams were placed above the deck inside the truss lines and attached to the floorbeams.

The Galley Road Bridge was built in 1929 by the state to carry US 19 over Little Chartiers Creek. The bridge is a state-standard concrete elliptical arch with state-standard balustrades. US 19 was widened and realigned in 1948, and the old alignment was renamed Galley Road. At some point, possibly in 1950, ownership of the old road and bridge was turned over to North Strabane Township.

The bridge is an uncommon example of a concrete slab thru girder (instead of a concrete encased thru girder, in which the metal girder is encased with concrete). The bridge serves a dead end street in the Hays neighborhood of Pittsburgh.

column16: Last remaining multi-span truss bridge in Blair County
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, C. L. Johnson & Sons (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The skewed, riveted, 2 span, 314'-long, Pratt thru truss bridge built in 1936 is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls and a concrete cutwater pier. The bridge, built to a state highway department standard design developed in the mid 1920s, is an example of a common technology with no innovative or distinctive details. It was part of the rebuilding efforts following the devastating 1936 St. Patrick's Day flood. Over 275 bridges, mostly in the western and central portions of Pennsylvania, were destroyed or damaged beyond repair. Heavy metal truss bridges were favored because of their perceived ability to withstand future flood episodes.''

column18: A. P. Dise Company (Engineer), G. A. & F. M. Wagman Co. (Contractor)
column20: The Ganoga Bridge was demolished in 2010, a few months after the photograph was taken. According to the PAHBI, ''The 5 span, 419'-long reinforced concrete closed spandrel 4-ribbed arch bridge built in 1926 has standard concrete balustrades and it is supported on horizontally scored concrete piers and abutments. The bridge is accented with plain pilasters at each pier which extend upward to form balustrade posts topped by concrete light standards. Reinforced concrete arch bridges began appearing in numbers in Pennsylvania during the first decade of the 20th century, and by the early 1910s they were ubiquitous. The use of ribs is a savings of material but it requires extra formwork. An early example of a closed spandrel ribbed arch bridge is the 1907-1909 Mulberry St. viaduct in Harrisburg (22301200800233).''
This bridge replaced the 1926 Ganoga Bridge. It is an example of a skewed concrete beam bridge.
With the 1962 extension of the Parkway East to the Pennsylvania Turnpike, the Garden City Drive Bridge is the eastern-most bridge over the Parkway.

The Garrett Highway Bridge is the first noteworthy bridge over the Youghiogheny River. It is a tiny example of a closed spandrel concrete arch. The bridge was recently rehabilitated, in which the arch was faced with new concrete. The original parapets were removed and replaced with guide rail. The result is that motorists on US 219 do not even realize they are crossing the Youghiogheny River.

column18: T. J. Wilkerson, Beaver County Engineer; Penn Bridge Co. Contractor
column20: Garvins Bridge is the last remaining Warren pony truss bridge in Beaver County. It is similar to the now-demolished Concord Church Road Bridge. Garvins Bridge is distinctive for its concrete posts at the ends of the bridge. The posts serve both a decorative feature and as protection for the trusses.

Gaston's Mill was built in 1830 by Samuel Conkle and owned by Philander Gaston and others. The mill was adjacent to the Sandy and Beaver Canal, which was chartered in 1828 and completed in 1848. It connected the Ohio and Erie Canal at Bolivar, OH, to the Ohio River at Glasgow, PA. Though the mill remained in operation until the late 1920's, the canal was in operation only until 1852, when the Cold Run Reservoir outside Lisbon, OH, failed, destroying much of the canal. The Gaston's Mill Bridge was constructed to cross the canal ditch sometime after the canal was abandoned. A lock (with reconstructed wooden gates) is located close to the bridge.

According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1908, pin connected, single span, 102'-long, Pratt pony truss bridge with the floor beams above the lower chords is supported on ashlar abutments with flared wingwalls. The upper chords and verticals are built up members, and the lower chords and diagonals are eye bars.''

At Gauley Bridge, WV, the Gauley River and New River come together to form the Kanawha River. Here, US 60 crosses over the Gauley River. The first bridge on the site was a wooden covered bridge, of which the town was named. The current bridge dates from 1951. It is an example of a state-standard girder, complete with state-standard railings.

column16: Prior to its demolition, the bridge was the oldest truss in Blair County
column20: The Gaysport Bridge was the oldest truss bridge in Blair County since at least the 1990's prior to its demolition in 2010. According to the PAHBI, ''The pin connected, single span, 141'-long, Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on concrete-capped ashlar abutments. The 1895 date of construction is given in the inspection file but the builder is not documented in available records. Stylistically it could date to as late as the early 20th century. The trusses are traditionally composed with no innovative or distinctive details. It is an example of the standardized design that dominated the technology by about 1895.'' Despite the bridge not being classified as historically significant, PennDOT posted it on their bridge marketing site as early as 2002, 8 years prior to the replacement of the bridge.

The Geiring Road Bridge is an early example of a thru girder. It was built the same year as the nearby stone arch bridge. According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1905, single span, 43'-long, built up thru girder bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with flared wingwalls. The bridge is an undistinguished example of one of the most common bridge types in the state. It has no innovative or distinctive details, and its fabricator is not documented in available records.''

column15: Warren; Cantilever Main Span; Deck Truss Approach Spans
column20: The bridge was built as a U.S. Public works project in 1935. In 1966 it was converted to carry westbound traffic only, as the Little Bay Bridge was completed for eastbound traffic. The bridge was closed to traffic in 1984. It is undecided whether the bridge will be rehabilitated or replaced. It is eligible for the National Register.

The Rankin Bridge was constructed in 1951 and rehabilitated in 2008 - 2011. It replaced an 1897 steel truss bridge, one locals would call, ''Old Rickety.'' The bridge is one of the few large-scale Allegheny County designed bridges built after World War II. It is an example of a deck cantilever. When the bridge opened in 1951, it carried Pittsburgh Railways streetcars. That service lasted until 1965, when the route was converted to bus service. The bridge is used by many tourists to the area, since it is on the main route from Interstate 376 to the world famous amusement park, Kennywood.

The George Stuart Memorial Bridge is the only cantilever truss over the Allegheny River with two suspended spans. The 1952 bridge was the first on its site. It was originally a toll bridge, and it was the last state-owned toll bridge in Pennsylvania. Tolls were eliminated in 1961. The bridge was rehabilitated and widened in 1986 by framing members into the existing truss lines. It is named after George Stuart, who was the editor of the Valley News Dispatch and a member of the Pennsylvania State House of Representatives.

column18: Allegheny County, Vernon Covell, George S. Richardson
column20: This bridge, on the National Register, is one of the most famous and important bridges of the Pittsburgh region. Its 460 foot main span was the largest for a concrete arch in the world upon completion. Today, the bridge is the second tallest vehicular bridge in Pennsylvania and the 22nd tallest in America. The bridge towers above the site of the former Westinghouse Electric factories. The four entrance pylons have art deco reliefs by Frank Vittor. The subjects are: George Westinghouse, Electricity, Turtle Creek Valley History, and Steel.

column15: Load-bearing concrete I beams over an open spandrel concrete arch
column20: The Georgetown Bridge was an open spandrel concrete arch bridge. In 1997 the bridge was rehabilitated and widened. Rather than demolish the historic arch bridge, the piers were widened and new concrete I beams were placed spanning over the concrete arches. This solution effectively replaces the bridge while still maintaining its historic structure.

Dating from 1917, the Georgetown Road Bridge is an early example of a concrete tee beam. In fact, it is the oldest bridge of its type in Columbiana County. The earliest tee beams in neighboring Pennsylvania also date from around the same time. The bridge has been modified -- the original parapets were removed and replaced by guide rail.

column2: Gibsonia Road Bridge Over the Pennsylvania Turnpike East of Dorseyville
column20: The bridge was built as part of the 1951 Western Extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike. All mainline vehicular overpasses were either thru girders or deck girders in the extension. This bridge was an example of a thru girder. It will be replaced as part of the Turnpike widening, which will happen sometime after 2010. Note that PA 910 crosses the Turnpike four times. This bridge is one of three in close proximity.

column2: Gibsonia Road Bridge Over the Pennsylvania Turnpike Near Dorseyville
column20: The bridge was built as part of the 1951 Western Extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike. All mainline vehicular overpasses were either thru girders or deck girders in the extension. The bridge is one of four PA 910 crossings, and one of three in close proximity to each other. The bridge near Dorseyville is noted for being both skewed and steeply sloped. The bridge will be replaced as part of the Turnpike widening, which will happen sometime after 2010.

column2: Gibsonia Road Bridge Over the Pennsylvania Turnpike Near Gibsonia
column20: The bridge was built as part of the 1951 Western Extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike. All mainline vehicular overpasses were either thru girders or deck girders in the extension. This bridge was an example of a thru girder. It was one of the first to be demolished (2008) as part of the turnpike reconstruction and widening project.

column2: Gibsonia Road Bridge Over the Pennsylvania Turnpike West of Indianola
column20: The bridge was built as part of the 1951 Western Extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike. All mainline vehicular overpasses were either thru girders or deck girders in the extension. This PA 910 Bridge is an example of a thru girder. It is one of four PA 910 bridges over the Turnpike, three of which are all nearby. The bridge will be replaced as part of the Turnpike widening, which will happen sometime after 2010.
This is one of the last Allegheny County designed stone arch bridges. Within two years, Allegheny County replaced the type with stone-faced concrete arches.

column15: Tied arch, haunched deck girder back channel Ohio River spans
column18: George S. Richardson, Richardson Gordon & Associates
column20: The Glenfield Bridge is the longest continuous bridge in Allegheny County, with a length of 4,544 feet. It opened in 1976, the last missing link along Interstate 79 in Pennsylvania. At the ribbon-cutting ceremony, County Commissioner Jim Flaherty made the statement, ''It's a great pleasure to stand on a bridge and not have to worry about it failing.'' Ironically, five months later in the winter of 1977, a towboat operator discovered a 10 foot long crack in a girder over the Back Channel Ohio River. The crack was blamed on the electroslag weld. That process was banned due to the result of the investigation. Other minor cracks have been found in the bridge since. The bridge was rehabilitated in 2008.

The Glenn Fox Road Bridge was one of the original 1939 Pennsylvania Turnpike overpasses. Almost all of the original overpasses are being replaced as part of mainline reconstruction and widening which started around 2000.

The Glenwood Bridge is a very unusual continuous truss in which most of the superstructure is below the deck. At the mid-anchor span piers, the superstructure curves both downward to the piers and upwards over the deck as towers. The bridge and southern interchange were designed for a highway to connect Pittsburgh and the PA Turnpike at Irwin that was never built.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1922, single span, built up thru girder bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with wingwalls. The bridge is an example of a common type with no innovative or distinguishing detail. Girder bridges were first developed by the railroad industry in the 1850s, and they were used on vehicular roadways in Pennsylvania beginning in the late 19th century.''

column15: Burr arch truss, wooden covered bridge supported by steel stringers
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1980
column18: Built by Tobias Glessner; rehabilitated in 1998 by The Neilan Engineers, Inc. (Engineer), Lone Pine Construction, Inc. (Contractor)
column20: The Glessner Covered Bridge, like many in Somerset County, looks to have been built as a multiple kingpost and retrofitted with an arch to become a Burr arch-truss. The bridge was closed to traffic in 1995 and rehabilitated in 1998. As part of the rehabilitation, load-bearing steel stringers and an intermediate pier were added. The bridge is also noteworthy for being one of the few covered bridges crossing a river in Pennsylvania.

column15: Cable suspension with Warren deck stiffening truss and approaches
column16: Modern wonder of the world (ASCE), eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, one of America's most famous and most recognized bridges, the largest suspension bridge in the world when completed
column18: Charles Alton Ellis (Principal Engineer), Joseph Strauss (Engineer), Irving Morrow (Architect), Pacific Bridge Company, John Roebling's Sons Company, Bethlehem Steel Company
column20: Frommer's travel guide states that the Golden Gate Bridge is ''possibly the most beautiful, certainly the most photographed, bridge in the world.'' According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''Spanning one of the World's most spectacular channels, the Golden Gate Bridge is internationally renowned as a superb structural and aesthetic example of suspension bridge design.'' The bridge was proposed by an article in the San Francisco Bulletin in 1916. The bridge finally completed 21 years later. Answering the proposal, Joseph Strauss initially proposed a cantilever bridge to cross the Golden Gate (similar to the original East Spans of the San Francisco Oakland Bay Bridge). The design was changed to a suspension. Since Joseph Strauss had little experience with suspension bridges, senior engineer Charles Alton Ellis was the principal engineer for the project. Even after being fired in 1931, Ellis continued to work on the project, though he had to do so without pay. Construction began on January 5, 1933 and finished in April of 1937 at a cost of over $35 million. Eleven workers were killed during construction. Today the bridge is one of the most famous and most admired in the world. About 120,000 vehicles cross the bridge every day, and thousands more walk and bike across it. No visit to San Francisco is complete without a stop at the bridge!

column16: Was the last remaining pin-connected pony truss bridge in Indiana County
column20: The Goodville Road Bridge was the last remaining pin-connected pony truss bridge in Indiana County. According to the PAHBI, '''The 2 simple span, 178'-long, pin-connected Pratt pony truss bridge built in 1900 by Nelson & Buchanan is supported on an ashlar substructure. The floor beams are above the lower chords, and the trusses are traditionally composed. There are welded repairs to some verticals, and pin plates at the upper panel points now have bolts rather than rivets. The original lattice railings are inside the truss lines.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1935, 26'-long, closed spandrel concrete deck arch bridge is supported on concrete abutments with plain wingwalls and concrete parapets. The bridge also has pipe railings with plumber fittings. The far left wingwall was replaced in 1977.''

column16: Early Pennsylvania Department of Highways bridge
column20: According to the plaque, the 1917 bridge was designed by the Pennsylvania Department of Highways. If it was designed in-house, it is one of the oldest remaining state-designed bridges in all of Pennsylvania. State-designed truss bridges did not become widely used until 1930. The bridge is scheduled to be replaced by PennDOT. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1917, skewed, riveted, single span, 118'-long, Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls. The trusses are composed of built up members.''

column16: Oldest remaining bridge in Elk County, eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Grant Road Bridge is the oldest remaining bridge in Elk County. According to the PAHBI, ''The single span, 106'-long, pin-connected Pratt thru truss bridge, built in 1889 by the Wrought Iron Bridge Company of Canton, OH, is supported on ashlar abutments. The truss tension members are eyebars and rods. The top chords and verticals are built-up sections. Rolled floorbeams with U-shaped hangers support timber stringers and deck. The bridge has lattice portals and pipe railings. An original feature is the subtie from the top chord at the end panels through the midpoints of the verticals. The subtie is illustrated in Wrought Iron Bridge Co. catalogues, but it is not commonly found on surviving examples of the company's work. The bridge is historically and technologically significant as a long and complete example of its type and design by a prominent fabricator.''

The Grant Street Bridge was one of fewer than 50 Pennsylvania truss bridges in Pennsylvania at the time of its demolition. According to the PAHBI, ''The one-span, 245'-long and 46' wide, pin-connected, steel Pennsylvania thru truss built in 1914 is supported on stone abutments. The trusses are traditionally composed. All of the members are built up except for the eye bar tension diagonals. The built up floorbeams are framed into the verticals below the lower chords. The sidewalk is supported on built up brackets and is finished with a plain metal railing.''

column2: Great Allegheny Passage Casselman River Bridge at Confluence
column20: The Great Allegheny Passage Casselman River Bridge at Confluence was built to serve the Western Maryland Railway. It likely opened in 1912 along with the rest of the line. Abandoned since the 1970's, the bridge was converted to carry the Great Allegheny Passage Trail in 2001. The picture was taken in 2001, before the bridge was opened to trail users.

column2: Great Allegheny Passage Casselman River Bridge at Harnedsville
column20: The Great Allegheny Passage Casselman River Bridge at Harnedsville was built to serve the Western Maryland Railway. It likely opened in 1912 along with the rest of the line. Abandoned since the 1970's, the bridge was converted to carry the Great Allegheny Passage Trail in 2001.

column2: Great Allegheny Passage Ohiopyle High Bridge
column20: From 1906 to 1912, the Western Maryland Railroad built an extension from Cumberland, Maryland, to Connellsville, Pennsylvania, where it joined the P&LE Railroad. The Great Allegheny Passage Ohiopyle High Bridge over the Youghiogheny River near Ohiopyle was part of the extension. Though it is at the same level as the Low Crossing only a few hundred feet away, the Youghiogheny River drops over 100 feet in this stretch. In 1973, the Western Maryland Railroad became part of the Chessie System, which eventually became CSX. Under the new ownership, much of the Western Maryland line has been abandoned west of Big Pool, Maryland. The portion of the railroad from Cumberland to Connellsville (including the bridge) has been turned into the Great Allegheny Passage rail trail. This section opened in 1999.

column2: Great Allegheny Passage Ohiopyle Low Bridge
column20: From 1906 to 1912, the Western Maryland Railroad built an extension from Cumberland, Maryland to Connellsville, Pennsylvania, where it joined the P&LE Railroad. In 1973, the Western Maryland Railroad became part of the Chessie System, which eventually became CSX. Under the new ownership, much of the Western Maryland has been abandoned west of Big Pool, Maryland. The portion of the railroad from Cumberland to Connellsville has been turned into the Great Allegheny Passage rail trail. This modern bowstring truss, the Great Allegheny Passage Low Bridge, replaced the existing deck girder bridge in 1999. This bridge cost $2.1 million and is the longest of its kind in the state.

column2: Great Allegheny Passage over Dunbar Run
column20: From 1906 to 1912, the Western Maryland Railroad built an extension from Cumberland, Maryland to Connellsville, Pennsylvania, where it joined the P&LE Railroad. The Great Allegheny Passage bridge over Dunbar Run was part of the extension. The railroad called it Bridge No. 252.9, since it was 252.9 miles from Baltimore. The bridge is built on a curve of three degrees. In 1973, the Western Maryland became part of the Chessie System, which eventually became CSX. Under the new ownership, much of the Western Maryland has been abandoned west of Big Pool, Maryland. The portion of the railroad from Cumberland to Connellsville (including the bridge) has been turned into the Great Allegheny Passage rail trail in the 1990's and early 2000's. The bridge was converted to pedestrian use in 1994. For more information about the trail is found in Bill Metzger's book, ''The Great Allegheny Passage Companion.''

column2: Great Allegheny Passage over Riverside Drive
column15: Warren simple with deck girder approach spans
column20: From 1906 to 1912, the Western Maryland Railroad built an extension from Cumberland, Maryland to Connellsville, Pennsylvania, where it joined the P&LE Railroad. The Great Allegheny Passage bridge over Riverside Drive was part of the extension. The railroad called it Bridge No. 252.6, since it was 252.6 miles from Baltimore. Most of the bridge is a deck plate girder, with a thru truss over the former B&O railroad. The thru truss was needed for increased vertical clearance. In 1973, the Western Maryland became part of the Chessie System, which eventually became CSX. Under the new ownership, much of the Western Maryland has been abandoned west of Big Pool, Maryland. The portion of the railroad from Cumberland to Connellsville (including the bridge) has been turned into the Great Allegheny Passage rail trail in the 1990's and early 2000's. The bridge was converted to pedestrian use in 1994.

column2: Great Allegheny Passage Youghiogheny River Bridge at Confluence
column20: Until 1998, PA 281 crossed the Youghiogheny River in Confluence over an 1896 two-span Pratt thru truss bridge built by the King Bridge Company. In 1948, the truss bridge was rehabilitated, in which load-bearing continuous girders were added below the floorbeams. Two new piers were added. In 1998, the replacement bridge, a concrete girder, opened upstream. The trusses were removed, and rest of the bridge was rehabilitated and incorporated into the Great Allegheny Passage trail. Had the trusses been instead preserved, the historic bridge could have been an attraction in itself. However, this would have added to the project cost.

In 1940, the first stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike opened between Irwin and Somerset. The original mainline overpasses consisted of arched concrete rigid frames, steel thru girders, and concrete tee beams. The remaining tee beams were replaced in the 1990's. Beginning in the late 1990's and continuing through at least 2020, the entire original turnpike is being reconstructed and widened. Almost all original overpasses are being replaced as part of the project, including the Great Cove Road Overpass.

column16: Pennsylvania Historical Marker
column20: In the early 1800's, the National Road was built across southern Pennsylvania and northern Maryland. Most of the bridges were built as long-lasting stone arches instead of cheaper wooden bridges. This section of roadway consisted of two large crossings: The 1813 Little Crossings Bridge over the Casselman River and the 1818 Great Crossings Bridge over the Youghiogheny River. The Little Crossings Bridge (Casselman River Bridge) is a single-span arch which still survives today. The Great Crossings Bridge is longer, consisting of three shorter arches. Note that each stone was precisely chiseled to fit the adjoining stones. With most stone arch bridges, each stone is pre-cut to a standard size. The bridge opened with much fanfare on July 4th, 1818, and was dedicated by President James Monroe. After the devastation caused by the 1936 flood, the Army Corps of Engineers decided to build the Youghiogheny River Dam for flood control. The Great Crossings Bridge and adjacent town of Somerfield were flooded when the dam was completed in 1943. Today the bridge sits under 50 feet of water. However, once every 50 years or so, the water level drops due to a drought, and the bridge reappears. The last time this happened was in late 1998/early 1999 when this photograph was taken. The bridge will reappear again.

The bridge carries Greensburg Pike, which is the old alignment for the Lincoln Highway, US 30. The bridge connects to the Turtle Creek Valley, a once-prosperous area due to Westinghouse Electric and Westinghouse Air Brake factories. Due to congestion in the area, as well as the Pennsylvania Railroad needing to upgrade its lines, the new bridge was built in 1925. Only seven years alter, the Lincoln Highway was realigned to bypass the Turtle Creek Valley on a high bridge, the George Westinghouse Bridge. The 1925 Great Valley Bridge is historically significant in that it was built as a joint project between Allegheny County and the Pennsylvania Railroad, dating from a time where industrialization necessitated such transportation improvements. In 2012, the bridge is to be replaced.

column2: Greensburg Pike Bridge Over the Penn Lincoln Parkway East
column20: The 1981 Greensburg Pike bridge replaced an original 1952 rigid frame bridge over the Parkway East. The rigid frame was the easternmost bridge on the original Parkway, and was faced with sandstone. The replacement girder bridge was built to mimic the previous bridge, with sandstone-faced abutments and concrete encased fascia girders. Since the original bridge spanned only 98 feet, it needed to be replaced with the addition of a truck climbing lane in the Parkway reconstruction of 1981. In 2008 the bridge was rehabilitated, and the sandstone was replaced with formed concrete painted to look like stone.

In 1931, a new alignment of US 30 (Greensburg Pike) was built between North Versailles and East Pittsburgh. Old US 30 descended the hillside at a steep 9% grade, went through the congested boroughs of Turtle Creek and East Pittsburgh, and then towards Chalfant and Forest Hills via Electric Avenue to Ardmore Boulevard. The new alignment stayed along the top of the hill, crossed the Turtle Creek Valley over the 240 foot high Westinghouse Bridge, and descended to Ardmore Boulevard along the side of a hill. Thus, the new alignment bypassed the congested valley. This thru girder carried the old alignment of US 30 over the new alignment at the eastern interchange. It was an early example of a thru girder used for an interchange. This design became commonly used for freeway overpasses in the 1940's and 1950's. The bridge was replaced in 2010 with a wider structure that better accommodates the curve in the roadway.

The Greensburg Road Bridge was one of the original 1939 Pennsylvania Turnpike overpasses. Almost all of the original overpasses are being replaced as part of mainline reconstruction and widening which started around 2000.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: Grimm's Bridge is a beautifully restored example of a classic Wrought Iron Bridge Company Whipple truss. Back in the late 1800's, the WIBC built bridges such as this one all over the country. It was a common choice for 150 foot spans. However, the transition to steel caused Whipple truss bridges to become obsolete. Only a small number survive throughout the country. It is amazing that Columbiana County has two restored examples -- from two different companies! These two bridges as well as all the other restored truss bridges should make Columbiana County a great place to go for anyone who likes historic truss bridges.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1912, single span, 137'-long, reinforced concrete deck arch bridge has paneled parapets and concrete skewbacks. The bridge is significant as a contributing resource to the Chestnut Street potential historic district. It falls within the 1880-1930 period of significance of the district. With its aesthetic parapets and graceful lines, the bridge is in keeping with the character of the high-style architectural district and serves as a gateway to it. The bridge is a contributing resource to the identified historic district.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The two-span, simply supported, 212'-long, steel stringer bridge, built in 1950, is supported on a concrete substructure and has steel balustrades. It has no innovative or distinguishing details, and is an example of the most common 20th century bridge type in the state.'' In 2010, the bridge's superstructure was replaced using ARRA funding.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1980
column20: The Gudgeonville Bridge was the oldest covered of three covered bridges remaining in Erie County as of the mid 2000's. Just a few months after the photograph was taken in 2008 the bridge was destroyed by arson. The Gudgeonville Bridge was built in 1868 by William Sherman, who built other covered bridges in the area. A few sources site the date of construction as 1837. That may be the construction date of an older bridge at the same location. Supposedly the bridge is named after a mule named Gudgeon which was being delivered by Mr. Obadiah Will to Meadville in the mid 1800's. The mule was startled by passing canal boats playing ''My Old Kentucky Home'' and died. While some accounts state the mule dropped dead from fright, other accounts state that the mule refused to move and was beaten to death. Mr. Will buried the mule on the west bank of the creek and had the word ''Gudgeonville'' painted on the bridge. Some believe the mule still haunts the bridge area. There are also stories of other apparitions haunting the area, too. See the external links for more information.

According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1910, riveted, single span, 42'-long, 3 panel, Pratt pony truss bridge, is supported on ashlar abutments with wingwalls. The trusses are traditionally composed from built up members, and the bridge has no innovative or distinctive details.''

The Guthrie School Bridge is a two-span pin-connected Pratt half hip pony truss. The trusses are only three panels each. It is unusual that such a short bridge would consist of two pony spans instead of one larger pony or thru truss span. According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory (PAHBI), ''The 2 span, 84' long and 14' wide pin-connected Pratt pony truss bridge built in 1898 is supported on a substructure of ashlar abutments with wingwalls and a pier. Scour protection has been placed around the pier. The trusses are traditionally composed with built up box section upper chords and end posts. The verticals are angles with laced webs, and the diagonals and lower chords are eye bars. There are small welded repairs at the bearings. It is an example of the standardized design that was fabricated by many different bridge builders starting about 1885 and is very well represented in the county and region. The bridge is complete, but it has no innovative or distinctive details.''

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, W. L. Dunn Construction Company
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1955, skewed, single span, 75'-long steel stringer bridge is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls. It has standard design steel railings with concrete endposts with Art Moderne vertical scoring.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1904, pin connected, 61'-long, Pratt pony truss bridge with the floor beams above the lower chords is supported on ashlar abutments with flared wingwalls. The bridge has built up upper chords, and verticals. The lower chords and diagonals are eye bars.''

The bridge was built in 1942 as a three-lane wide bridge for a new alignment of US 22, the William Penn Highway. As such, the two ribs of trusses were 36 feet apart. In 1957, the bridge was widened by adding a third rib 18 feet to the south.

The Halls Road Bridge was built in 1912 by the Luten Bridge Company of York, PA. The bridge is similar to many other concrete arch bridges in West Virginia. It is likely the bridge was constructed for the old alignment of Harmon Creek Road (formerly Colliers Road). The bypassed Colliers Road Bridge is similar.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
