column20: The Hallton Bridge is one of only a few Horseheads Bridge Company bridges in the entire state. The builder is attributed to the distinctive built-up curved knee braces with twisted bars in a fan shape. Only one other similar thru truss has been documented by www.bridgemapper.com, though the bridge is closed awaiting replacement. With the upcoming demolition of the Hallton Bridge, this once common bridge type will become extinct in the state. The Hallton Bridge is for sale through the PennDOT bridge marketing program, though the responsible party to assume ownership must relocate the bridge. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1898, single span, 129'-long, pin-connected Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments. It has eye bars and rods for the tension members, and built-up compression members. Rolled floorbeams with U-shaped hangers support timber stringers and a wood deck. The stringers and deck in one panel are failed, accounting for the bridge's closure. The failure does not affect integrity of original design. [In 1997 the bridge was repaired and reopened to traffic]. The bridge is finished with lattice railings and lattice portals with built-up curved knee braces with twisted bars in a fan shape. According to the township supervisor, the 1898 date of construction was recorded from a bridge plaque before the plaque was lost. The builder is undocumented [but stylistically is attributed to the Horseheads Bridge Company]. The bridge is a long example of its type and design with it original decorative elements. Pin-connected truss bridges are increasingly rare, especially in this region of the state, with fewer than 20 documented examples from ca. 1880 to 1910 surviving in PADOT Dist. 2-0. This is one of the most complete and earliest to document the all standard details that came to characterize the pin-connected Pratt truss type/design in the 1890s. It is historically and technologically significant.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1900, pin connected, single span, 47'-long, Pratt pony truss bridge is supported on one concrete capped masonry abutment and one concrete abutment. The lower chords and floor beams are connected at the panel points with pin plates, a detail marking transition from pinned to field riveted connections. The trusses are significantly altered. New pin plates have been welded at the upper panel points and new coverplate was welded to the end posts.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The 60'-long, reinforced concrete deck arch bridge, built in 1923, has no innovative or distinctive details. It has paneled spandrels and is finished with two-high welded pipe railings. The east abutment has flared wingwalls. The west abutment is perpendicular to the long axis of the bridge. The reinforced concrete deck arch bridge gained popularity quickly in the Commonwealth in the 1900s and was common by 1910.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Harmon Creek Road Bridge is the only half-hip Pratt pony truss bridge in Washington County. Dating from 1889, it is one of the oldest truss bridges in the county. According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, ''The lower chords and diagonals are loop forged eyebars, and the upper chords are channels and lacing. The verticals are laced back to back angles. Original features include the built-up floor beams, pipe railings inside the truss lines and the outriggers. In a county and region with a deep and varied collection of metal truss bridges from the mid-1880s through the 1930s, this pony truss bridge stands out as an early and complete example.''
This concrete beam bridge replaced the former bridge on its site, a thru girder. The bridge typifies modern replacement bridges. The photograph was taken when the bridge was only a year old.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Whittaker & Diehl (Contractor)
column20: The photograph was taken about a year prior to the bridge's demolition. It was the only thru girder over the Casselman River. According to the PAHBI, '''The 1930, skewed, 2 simple span, built up thru girder bridge is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls and a concrete pier. The bridge has steel I beam floorbeams and a concrete deck. The bridge is an example of a common type with no innovative or distinguishing detail.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1895, pin connected, single span, 38'-long, Pratt pony truss bridge is stylistically similar to an 1894 truss bridge in the same township. The traditionally composed trusses are supported on one ashlar and one concrete abutment. The latter dates to 1985, when the stringers were replaced and the bearings were encased in concrete.''

column15: Multiple kingpost wooden covered supported by load-bearing stringers
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Harrington Covered Bridge is an example of a multiple kingpost covered bridge. It was built by William Sherman, who built other covered bridges in the area. In 1962 the bridge was heavily modified, in which a load-bearing steel support system was installed. The bridge no longer functions as a truss. The bridge is one of only two covered bridges remaining in Erie County.

column15: Open spandrel concrete arch with closed spandrel approaches
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1988
column18: City of Scranton, William A. Schunk (Chief Engineer), Chas F. Schroderer (Assistant Engineer), A. Burton Cohen (Consulting Engineer), Anthracite Bridge Co (Contractor)
column20: The photograph shows the closed spandrel approach arch over the Central Scranton Expressway. The large open spandrel arch is on the left, obscured by trees. In the summer, unobstructed views of the bridge are hard to find! According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''The bridge, a monumental structure spanning Roaring Brook between East and South Scranton, is a symbol of the city's progressive era in the early 20th century. A citizen's association formed to advocate for this connection between two neighborhoods originally of different economic character. Reinforced concrete engineer A. Burton Cohen, probably hired because of his affiliation with local railroads and the massive Tunkhannock Viaduct, designed the Harrison Avenue Bridge with a combination of filled- and open-spandrel forms. One of two Cohen-designed bridges in Scranton, this structure was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1988.''

In the 1920's, the Bureau of Public Roads worked to design and place rural roads in West Virginia. Many of the larger bridges were similar Pratt deck trusses. Unfortunately, most of these bridges have been replaced, such as the Cotton Hill Station Bridge over the New River and the Gypsy Bridge over the West Fork River. The Hartland Bridge is important as one of the few surviving examples.

column18: The Ohio Bridge Company (U.S. Bridge Company)
column20: The Hartley Road Bridge is the first bridge of interest over the Mahoning River. It is an early example of an Ohio Bridge Corporation welded Warren truss.

The original Harvard Bridge, named after John Harvard, was constructed in 1891. As with several of Boston's bridges, it was designed by William Jackson. The bridge was a haunched iron plate girder bridge with a swing span. Piers were built from granite. The swing span was converted to two fixed spans in 1924. The bridge was an early pioneering example of a long girder bridge with cantilevered spans. The alternating anchor and cantilever spans had lengths of 75 feet and 105 feet respectively, for a total length of 2,170 feet or 364.4 smoots (1 smoot = 5'-7''). In 1958, Oliver Smoot, the shortest pledge of Lambda Chi Alpha at MIT that year, was used by his fraternity brothers measure the bridge. The sidewalks was marked every 10 smoots. Due to deterioration, the superstructure of the bridge was replaced in the late 1980's through 1990. The new girders have the same proportions as the old ones. Not only are the smoot marks duplicated on the new bridge, the sidewalk slabs are each one smoot long.
The 1952 Harvison Road Bridge is one of the 1952 Western Extension bridges. The bridges consist of thru girders and stringers. Due to mainline widening, all original bridges are being replaced.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The 1902 Hawkins Bridge is the oldest Pennsylvania truss in the region and is eligible for listing in the National Register of Historic Places. The Pennsylvania truss was especially suited for long spans, so comparatively few were ever built. The only other examples in Greene and Washington counties are over the Monongahela River. The bridge was built by the Nelson & Buchanan Company after the agents split from the Pittsburgh Bridge Company. The bridge was closed to traffic sometime around 2007.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1978
column18: Rebuilt in 1974 by Carl E. Rexroth
column20: They Hays Bridge is a two-span stone arch built with semi-coursed rubble masonry. In 1978, the bridge and the surrounding area was designed the Hays Bridge Historic District. According to the PAHBI, ''The 2-span stone arch bridge built in 1820 is a listed resource in the Hays Bridge Historic District (7/31/78).''

column11: 1887 (Pratt span built); 1910 (relocated and widened) / 2010 (rehabilitated for pedestrians)
column15: Whipple with Phoenix Columns and a pin-connected Pratt approach span
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Hays Street Bridge was photographed in 2008, about a year before the rehabilitation project began. Sparks Engineering is the design consultant for the project. Patrick Sparks posted the following on Bridgehunter.com, ''The 1881/1910 Hays Street Bridge is a viaduct consisting of two wrought iron truss spans (one Phoenix Whipple 225-ft span, and one Pratt 130-ft span), and approximately 1000-LF of concrete approaches. In 1910, the City of San Antonio required the Galveston, Harrisburg & San Antonio Railway Co. (eventually part of Southern Pacific) to construct a viaduct over the railroad tracks at Hays Street. The railway company relocated the two truss spans from elsewhere on its lines. Records of the Phoenix Bridge Company archived at the Hagley Library in Wilmington, Delaware show that the Whipple truss dates from 1881 and was reconstructed from one or more salvaged spans over the Nueces River west of San Antonio. These records include entries in the company's customer index as well as copies of the 1910 repair shop drawings showing replacement joint blocks, bearing seats, and lateral bracing struts. The Whipple truss span is a Phoenix patent design using the now rare Phoenix segmental wrought iron columns with cast-iron joint blocks. The Pratt span has Phoenix-branded components, including the floor beams. Both spans were widened in 1910 from about 16-feet to the current 25-feet. The bridge is planned for rehabilitation as a bicycle and pedestrian facility by the City of San Antonio, using a Transportation Enhancement grant from the Texas Department of Transportation.''

In 1940, the first stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike opened between Irwin and Somerset. The original mainline overpasses consisted of arched concrete rigid frames, steel thru girders, and concrete tee beams. The remaining tee beams were replaced in the 1990's. Beginning in the late 1990's and continuing through at least 2020, the entire original turnpike is being reconstructed and widened. Almost all original overpasses are being replaced as part of the project. This will include the Hazelette Street Overpass. It is an example of a thru girder.
The Hecia Road Bridge is one of just a few steel frame bridges to span the mainline Pennsylvania Turnpike. The bridges are not original to the Turnpike.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, T Osborne & Co (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The two-span, simply supported, 146'-long, steel stringer bridge was built in 1948 as a replacement for a steel bowstring through truss bridge that collapsed three years earlier. It is supported on a concrete pier and abutments with wingwalls, and has a concrete filled steel grid deck with steel angle curbs and structure mounted steel railings. The superstructure is heavily corroded with several of the stringers exhibiting heavy section loss. The bridge has no innovative or distinguishing details and is an example of the most common 20th century bridge type in the state.''

column2: Henderson Avenue Canon Industrial Line Overpass
column15: Concrete encased thru girder and floorbeam system with tee beam approach spans
column18: Pennsylvania Railroad, Pennsylvania Department of Highways
column20: According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, ''The bridge carries a two-lane road and a sidewalk over an abandoned, former Pennsylvania Railroad right-of-way known as the Canon Ind. line from just southwest of the bridge to McKees Rocks and the steel mills along the Monongahela River. The tracks have been removed. The area is dominated by a mix of mid- to late-20th century residential and commercial development. The area does not appear to have historic district potential. The three-span, 115'-long and 32' wide bridge is composed of a concrete encased built-up thru girder main span and T beam approach spans. The girder encasement is finished plainly on the roadway face and with incised panels on the outside. The parapets on the approach spans are detailed the same way. The bridge is a late example of a common technology, and it is not historically or technologically significant. The rail line, now abandoned, was an industrial spur from Arden to the mills along the Monongahela River. It did not extend into Washington.''

According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, ''The single-span, 82'-long, built-up steel through girder bridge was constructed in 1938. It is supported on reinforced concrete abutments with wingwalls. Concrete posts at each of the bridge's corners serve to accept standard metal approach guiderails that were installed in 1981.''

column15: Open spandrel ribbed concrete arch with curved tee beam approaches
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Ira G. Hedrick, C. M. Thelin
column20: According to the Historic Bridge Foundation, ''Open spandrel concrete arch built in 1930. Spanning the Clear Fork of the Trinity River with a 124' long arch and 14 curved concrete girder approaches, the Henderson Street Bridge is a distinctive landmark in Fort Worth. The city erected this bridge in 1930, while developing the Jacksboro Highway to Lake Worth. To create a bridge fitting of the prospering city, engineers Ira G. Hedrick and C.M. Thelin, utilized a graceful open-spandrel arch form. An facet of the bridge is the curved concrete wall located between the arch rings; it was designed to act as a conduit for utility lines running across the river.'' In the early 2010's, the Trinity River is to be straightened in downtown Fort Worth, and the land in between to be redeveloped. A new bridge will be constructed on Henderson Street over the Bypass Channel. Eventually the area between the existing channel and the bypass channel will be redeveloped. Will this lead to the replacement of the National Register Eligible historic bridge?

The Hendricks Bridge was one of possibly only two thru girder bridges in the county. However, it was replaced by a single span deck girder in 2005. Even though the bridge only carried 300 vehicles per day, it was still replaced. The bridge was the last bridge over the Blackwater River before it joined the Dry Fork Cheat River to form the Black Fork Cheat River. Note that there is a pedestrian suspension bridge over the Black Fork Cheat River in Hendricks.

The 1968 Henry Gonzales Convention Center was enlarged in 2001. As part of this expansion, the San Antonio River was extended under the new part of the convention center, necessitating this steel and glass connector bridge.

column2: Henry Gonzales Convention Center Pedestrian Bridge
column20: The 1968 Henry Gonzales Convention Center was enlarged in 2001. As part of this expansion, the San Antonio River was extended under the new part of the convention center. This pre-fabricated pedestrian bridge was built to allow people to access both sides of the convention center from the river extension.
The Hermann Park Footbridge is an example of a prefabricated truss designed for pedestrian loadings.

The S Bridge in Hertford, NC, is the only historic bridge in the entire county. A new alignment of US 17 was built in 1965, bypassing the bridge, as well as the Town of Hertford. Hertford has not changed much over the years, and now is a National Register Historic District. According to Hertford's website, the bridge is the only S-shaped swing bridge in the country. The bridge is called an S-bridge, since the road is at a skew to the river and the center span of the bridge is perpendicular, the approaches are curved. The S Bridge can also be seen on tee shirts and other memorabilia from Hertford. It is nice to see a community embracing their historic bridge, using it to enhance the reasons for visiting the town. Unfortunately, due to deterioration, weight limits on the bridge have been reduced so that not even school buses can cross. It is unclear whether the bridge will be rehabilitated, replaced, or left alone.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Paul Construction Company
column20: The Heshbon Bridge is one of the last state-standard truss bridges built. Many were constructed across the state from the late 1920's through 1941. Note the difference in the portal bracing of the bridge as compared to others. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1941, skewed, 158'-long, riveted Parker thru truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with concrete caps. The trusses are traditionally composed with the upper and lower chords being built up box sections, and the verticals and diagonals rolled I sections. Lateral and sway bracing are laced channels. The deck is reinforced concrete, and the steel railings inside the truss lines are original.'' The bridge is scheduled for rehabilitation. This will include a deck replacement as well as structural steel repairs.

column18: City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works, T. J. Wilkerson, Cummings Structural Concrete, Co.
column20: The Heth's Run Bridge is the only one of the City of Pittsburgh neo-classical open spandrel concrete bridges that retains its original deck and a balustrade with decorative urns (the northern balustrade). As such the deck shows advanced deterioration, and the missing sections of the balustrades have been crudely repaired with wooden boards The southern balustrade has been replaced. In 1939 the City began to use the Heth's Run Ravine as a trash dump, eventually burying the bridge. The fill is at the same level as the southern sidewalk. While the bridge was originally to be replaced with fill, plans now call for daylighting the Heth's Run valley. Due to deterioration, the bridge will likely be replaced with a new structure.

column15: Prestressed concrete box beam with arch-shaped facade panels
column16: ACEC/PA Diamond Award
column20: The new Hickory Street Bridge is a prestressed concrete box beam bridge with arch facade panels to mimic the general shape of the previous truss bridge. According to www.smart-transportation.com, ''This unique project included replacement of an existing Closed Spandrel Earth filled arch structure over the Allegheny River in Downtown Warren, Pennsylvania. The bridge was identified as a contributing element to the adjacent historic district. During the preliminary engineering phase of the project, the existing structure was closed to traffic in March 2003 due to severe deterioration. This structure provided a direct link from the downtown and residential areas north of the bridge to the local hospital on the south side of the bridge. An intense public involvement effort and a dedicated design team culminated in a complete final design in less than a year and a bridge open to traffic by August 2005. The bridge design considered community context and dovetailed nicely with Downtown Warren's revitalization efforts. Today, the bridge is owned and maintained by the City and is a piece of civic infrastructure the community is truly proud of. Unique materials used in the project included pre-cast architectural arch facade panels and railings, alcoves above piers, period lighting, arch lighting, and an exposed aggregate finish.''

column16: Last remaining concrete arch bridge over the Allegheny River up until its demolition
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1917, 4 span, 500'-long (1 @ 113', 1 @ 124', 1 @ 131', 1 @ 133'), reinforced concrete deck arch bridge is supported on concrete abutments and concrete bullnosed piers. In 1963 the concrete parapets with tubular metal handrails replaced original Neo-Classical style balustrades. The bridge was designed by the Luten Engineering Company, but it is a late example of a Luten design, erected at a time when many of his patents were being voided.''

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, C L Johnson (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1937, riveted, single span, 108'-long, Parker pony truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with flared, stepped, wingwalls. The upper and lower chords are built up, and the vertical and diagonal members are rolled section. Built to a state highway department standard design used with great frequency since the mid 1920s, it has no innovative or distinctive details. It was erected as part of the rebuilding efforts following the devastating 1936 St. Patrick's Day flood. Over 275 bridges, mostly in the western and central portions of Pennsylvania, were destroyed or damaged beyond repair.''

Though the Highland Park Bridge was the next large Allegheny County deck cantilever truss to open after the Homestead High Level, it does not use the Wichert truss. The riveted truss bridge has pinned connections to attach the suspended spans with the anchor spans, like the Liberty Bridge over the Monongahela. The bridge has five main spans (with two anchor spans), thus the pinned connections are at spans 1, 3, and 5. The bridge is also unusual since the bridge has five, relatively short main spans. The advantage of cantilevering the trusses is to allow for a minimum number of long main spans.

According to the National Bridge Inventory, the Hillside Lane Bridge dates to 1893. That makes it one of the oldest riveted truss bridges in the region. It is also an early example of a Warren truss. (However, note that the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory estimates that the bridge dates to around 1910.) The light trusses are composed of angles. In 1995, the bridge was rehabilitated. The bridge was underpinned, steel plate was welded to the bottom chord, the deck, floorbeams, and stringers were replaced, and sliding steel bearings were installed. A similar 1893 bridge, the Swarts Hill Road Bridge, existed in Greene County until it was demolished in 2008.

The Hilltown Bridge consisted of two different pin-connected Pratt thru truss spans. The southern, larger span had a builder's plate reading, ''Thomas A. Gilkey, Engineer, 1913.'' The northern span appears to be older. It is possible it was reused from another location. It is also possible that both spans were originally identical, and that the southern span was damaged and replaced in 1913. The northern span appears to have been constructed in ca. 1900. Note that the compression members' V-lacing is perpendicular to the deck. Most truss bridges (including the southern span), have V-lacing parallel to the deck. Wrought Iron Bridge Company bridges are the exceptions, though this bridge does not have other matching details. The PAHBI gives the following description of the bridge: ''The 2-span, 282' long and 16' wide, pin connected Pratt thru truss bridge supported on an ashlar substructure was fabricated in 1914. The trusses are traditionally composed, and the floorbeams are framed into the verticals above the eye bar lower chords. The knee braces of the lattice portal braces have an elaborate scroll-design fill. The bridge appears to be complete, but it is an extremely late example of its technology. Mr. Gilkey designed pin connected bridges for the county through the 1920s.'' Note that the PAHBI does not evaluate the differences between the spans.

column15: Semicircular stone arch, widened by a closed spandrel concrete arch
column18: Widened by the Pennsylvania Department of Highways
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 2 span stone arch bridge was widened to both sides in 1927 by the Pennsylvania Department of Highways. Concrete balustrades were constructed at the same time, with little other architectural detailing.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, the 1889 Hodgen's Bridge ''stands out in a region with a deep and varied collection of metal truss bridges as one of the earliest. It also appears to be complete. The bridge is a historically and technologically significant example of its type and design based on its date of construction and completeness.'' Note the unusual detail of the diagonal endpost connection with the top chord. The diagonal and the vertical are connected with separate pins. The top chord projects over the diagonal endpost. This is characteristic of Penn Bridge Company bridges from the 1870's through the 1880's. The bridge is similar to the 1888 Coal Center Bridge and the Evans Bridge (build date not known).

column2: Homestead High Level Bridge (Homestead Grays Bridge)
column15: Wichert Truss; Deck Pratt Cantilever Truss; Deck Warren Truss
column18: Allegheny County, George S. Richardson, American Bridge
column20: The Homestead Grays Bridge is the longest bridge over the Monongahela River. It was the first bridge to use the ''Wichert Self-Adjusting Truss,'' which is a hinged open diamond shape that made each span of the continuous truss statically determinate. The structure was built without lacing, rare for a 1930's bridge. The bridge was named for the Homestead Grays baseball team in 2002. In 2006 - 2007 the bridge was rehabilitated and painted gray from blue.

The main truss span of the viaduct crosses the Union Railroad. The style of the bridge is similar to the 1951 Rankin Bridge (a deck truss though a cantilever), which was also designed by Allegheny County.

column18: City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works
column20: This small stone arch bridge culvert carries Homewood Trail in Frick Park over Nine Mile Run. Only a small number of stone arch bridges exist in Pittsburgh's Frick Park. The arch ring is likely concrete. The bridge is unusual for having a non-circular arch, and it is heavily skewed. Upon his death in 1919, industrialist Henry Clay Frick bequeathed Frick Park to the City of Pittsburgh. It opened in 1927.

column15: Concrete encased thru girder and floorbeam system
column16: Only thru girder over the Stonycreek River
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1914, 2 simple span, 166'-long (2 @ 83'), built up thru girder bridge is supported on concrete abutments and a concrete pier. The bridge, which has a camber, is completely encased in concrete.''

A suspension bridge was first built at Franklin Street over the Stonycreek River in 1907. It was destroyed in a flood and rebuilt in 1996. According to a plaque at the bridge, ''This bridge does more than connect two parts of Hooversville. It unites our citizens, out friends, and our past to our future. Our thanks to everyone, everywhere who enabled Hooversville to 'swing again' in '96.''

column16: Only truss bridge in Bedford County with more than three spans
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Pittsburgh Des Moines Steel Company
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1936, 3 span, 355'-long, riveted, Parker pony truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls and ashlar cutwater piers. Built to a state highway department standard design, the bridge is an example of a common technology with no innovative or distinctive details. It was erected as part of the rebuilding efforts following the devastating 1936 St. Patrick's Day flood. Over 275 bridges, mostly in the western and central portions of Pennsylvania, were destroyed or damaged beyond repair. Metal truss bridges were favored because of the perceived ability to withstand future flood episodes.''

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Joseph A. King (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1934, riveted, 2 span, 213'-long, Parker pony truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments and an ashlar pier. The trusses have rolled section verticals and diagonals and built up upper and lower chords. The bridge has no innovative or distinctive details.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 34'-long, stone arch bridge built in 1907 is laid up in rusticated ashlar, and it has flared, stepped wingwalls. The parapets are topped with flat coping stones and iron pipe railings with plumber fittings. One of 7 similar stone arch bridges built between ca. 1905 and ca. 1915 in the county, this is the oldest documented example. It retains its fine masonry that is the hallmark of the best stone arch bridges from the last quarter of the 19th century and early 20th century. The bridge is historically and technologically significant.''

The Horner Road Bridge is a common example of a small steel stringer bridge built prior to World War II. According to the PAHBI, ''The 32'-long steel stringer bridge built ca. 1930 is supported on concrete abutments, one of which was replaced in 1988. It has W-beam guiderails on each side of the timber deck.''

The Hot Metal Bridge was built to be rail connection carrying molten steel from the Eliza Furnace to the rolling mills of Jones & Laughlin Steel. In 1999, the southern deck girder and deck truss spans and the northern most thru truss span was removed. In 2007 the bridge was converted to connect to the Eliza Furnace trail.

According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1910, riveted, Pratt pony truss bridge with outriggers was altered in 1949 when built up stringers were placed below the existing floorbeams. The stringers carry much of the live load. The trusses have minor welded repairs, and they are a common design that is common throughout southwestern Pennsylvania.''

The Houston Street Bridge was built in conjunction with the flood control project in the 1920's in which the San Antonio River was straightened and the bypass channel constructed. These bridges consist of concrete tee beams with ornamental balustrades.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The bridge carries a 2 lane road over 1 track of Conrail. The line is the former Trenton Cut-off of the Pennsylvania RR. The line was constructed in 1902-04 as a bypass of Philadelphia for freight headed to and from New York. The Trenton Cut-off has been determined eligible by PHMC (9/14/93). The bridge is in a suburban setting of post-World War II residential and commercial development.... The one-span, 89'-long, pin-connected, wrought-iron Warren pony truss bridge is supported on stone abutments. The bridge has closely spaced wood floorbeams supporting a wood deck. The bridge was built in 1879 for the Northern Central Railway, a line operated by the Pennsylvania Railroad between Baltimore and Sunbury, PA. It was relocated over the PRR Trenton Cut-off ca. 1902-04. The bridge is a historically and technologically significant, rare and complete example of a pin-connected Warren truss bridge. It documents one of the many variations of iron truss bridges developed and used by the railroads from the 1860s to the 1880s. It is representative of the innovation and diversity that characterized metal truss bridge development during its golden age. In addition to its individual significance, the bridge crosses over a rail line that has historic significance and has been determined eligible by PHMC. It is contributing to the rail line.''

column15: Closed spandrel elliptical concrete arch, faced with ashlar
column20: The Howes Run Road Bridge is one of the Allegheny County stone-faced concrete arch bridges built under James Chalfant. According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory (1997), the bridge is one of six similar structures. It is one of the shortest examples.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1979
column20: The 1889 Hughes Covered Bridge is one of many covered bridges in Washington County, Pennsylvania. The bridge is an example of a queen post truss, though extra diagonal members are inside the truss lines. Around 1965, Interstate 79 was built nearby. Not only was Montgomery Run Road realigned to bypass the bridge, Montgomery Run itself was realigned, staying on the west side of the bridge. Therefore, the bridge carries a bypassed road alignment over a bypassed stream alignment. Without carrying traffic, the bridge still functions as a truss; it has not been strengthened with steel beams like most covered bridges.

column15: Pratt pin-connected with a Pratt pony truss approach span
column20: The Hull Drive Bridge was found to be eligible for the National Register of Historic Places in 1995 as part of its rehabilitation project. The bridge consists of a 151 foot pin-connected Pratt thru truss and a 70 foot pin-connected Pratt half-hip Pony truss. Note that the PAHBI lists the thru and pony trusses as separate bridges. The Hull Drive Bridge is attributed to the Wrought Iron Bridge Company due to the bolted connection details at the ends of the top chord of the pony truss and the A-frame portal bracing.

column15: Semicircular concrete (stone faced) arch with corrugated metal arch liner
column20: The stone-faced concrete arch bridge with a metal arch liner is one of a few similar arch bridges in Allegheny County's South Park. Many park bridges in Allegheny County were constructed in the late 1930's with Great Depression recovery funds.

column15: Pratt riveted half thru with deck Pratt and stringer approach spans
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, one of only two half thru trusses in Pennsylvania
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, P. I. Cox Construction Co.
column20: Beginning in the 1980's, PennDOT began an Upper Allegheny River Improvement Project (East Brady to New York) to replace or restore all of the bridges built before World War II. The bridges consisted of 12 trusses and 2 concrete arches. Thus far, 9 of the truss bridges and both of the concrete arch bridges have been replaced with concrete or steel beam bridges. Two state-standard truss bridges were rehabilitated. The last bridge to be ''improved'' is the Hunter Station Bridge. In will be replaced in the early 2010's. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1934, 6 span, 1050'-long bridge has 3, riveted Pratt half thru truss main spans (3 @ 276'), a riveted Warren with verticals deck truss span (1 @ 122'), and two steel stringer approach spans (2 @ 50'). The heavy trusses are composed of built up members. Designed by the state highway department, the bridge uses common technologies. The only unusual feature of the main span is the placement of the floorbeams at the midpoint of the verticals rather than at the lower panel points. The half thru truss type was used to keep the bridge deck above the flood stage of the river without having to construct high river piers. Although not technologically innovative for 1934, half-thru trusses are extremely rare. It seems to be the only one in the survey. The bridge should be eligible to present complete picture.''

The 1937 Hurricane - LaVerkin Bridge was completed in 1937 as a high-level Virgin River crossing. The original truss bridge still survives, though it is closed to traffic. The 1937 bridge is an example of a deck arch. Rather than replace the bridge, UDOT converted it to carry westbound traffic and built a twin bridge to carry eastbound traffic. The bridge was rehabilitated in which the deck was removed and the vertical members were removed, repaired, and reinstalled. The new bridge was built to similar dimensions. The project is an excellent example of historic bridge preservation.

The 1937 Hurricane - LaVerkin Bridge was completed in 1937 as a high-level Virgin River crossing. The original truss bridge still survives, though it is closed to traffic. The 1937 bridge is an example of a deck arch. Rather than replace the bridge, UDOT converted it to carry westbound traffic and built a twin bridge to carry eastbound traffic. The bridge was rehabilitated in which the deck was removed and the vertical members were removed, repaired, and reinstalled. The new bridge was built to similar dimensions. The project is an excellent example of historic bridge preservation.

column16: Utah Historic Site
column18: The Midland Bridge Company, Kansas City, MO
column20: According to the Utah Historic Site Plaque, ''In 1908 the Midland Bridge Company was awarded a contract in the amount of $3,299 to fabricate and erect the Hurricane / LaVerkin Bridge. The structure incorporates distinctive characteristics in its method of construction, is one of the earliest and longest surviving examples of a rigid Warren pony truss type bridge in the state of Utah, and retains its historical design, material, and workmanship. The Hurricane / LaVerkin Bridge's historical role was that of a vital transportation link that contributed to the development of southwestern Utah. Prior to the building of the bridge, traveling from LaVerkin to Hurricane required crossing of the stream bed of the LaVerkin Creek and the 'treacherous' Virgin River. On April 7, 1908, the Washington County News described the importance of this bridge when it stated that the 'steel bridge between LaVerkin and Hurricane is now being put up. When it is finished watch Hurricane grow . . . Come and walk on our steel bridge (the first one in the County), bathe in our Sulphur Springs, view our beautiful scenery, walk through our orchards and vineyards.''

column16: Last remaining multi-span thru girder over the Pennsylvania Turnpike
column20: In 1940, the first stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike opened between Irwin and Somerset. The original mainline overpasses consisted of arched concrete rigid frames, steel thru girders, and concrete tee beams. The remaining tee beams were replaced in the 1990's. Beginning in the late 1990's and continuing through at least 2020, the entire original turnpike is being reconstructed and widened. Almost all original overpasses are being replaced as part of the project, including the Husband Road Overpass. The bridge was one of only two thru girders with a center pier. The other, a PA 130 overpass, was replaced in 2002.

The Hutton Oakland Road Bridge is the longest concrete arch bridge in Garrett County. It is the only multiple span example. The bridge is also noteworthy for being one of two concrete arch bridges over the Youghiogheny River, the other being the 23-foot-long US 219 bridge. The Hutton Oakland Road Bridge has been rehabilitated, and the original parapets have been replaced by guide rail. Unfortunately, the bridge is not in very good condition.

column15: Cable suspension with Warren stiffening truss
column16: Longest bridge built as a pedestrian bridge in the region
column20: The 1955 suspension bridge was built on the piers of an 1886 railroad bridge. After the railroad bridge was destroyed by a flood in 1904, a pedestrian bridge was built on the surviving piers in 1920. That bridge was replaced in 1955 by the existing suspension bridge.

Andrew Ice started Ices Ferry, the first authorized ferry in western Virginia near the site of the bridge in 1785. In the 1840's, the town of Ices Ferry was the epicenter of West Virginia's iron production in the 1840's. In 1910 planning began to build a hydro-electric plant along the Cheat River in West Virginia just south of the Pennsylvania border. The project was stalled by World War I, completed in 1925, and dedicated in 1927. Not only would the lake created by the dam wipe out the town of Ices Ferry, it would also wipe out the existing crossing. Therefore, the current Ices Ferry Bridge was constructed to cross the new lake. After the bridge was completed, the dam was placed into service, and a lake was created beneath the bridge. The Ices Ferry Bridge is also significant for being one of the longest pin-connected truss bridges in West Virginia. It is the oldest truss bridge and the only pin-connected truss bridge in the county. The bridge is to be replaced by a new bridge on a different alignment. Once the new bridge is open, the existing bridge is to be demolished. This is unfortunate, especially since the bridge would be an ideal fishing pier over Cheat Lake.

The Idlewild Park People Bridge is one of the few historic truss bridges located in an amusement park anywhere. Idlewild Park began in 1878 and was greatly expanded in 1931. It is likely the bridge dates from this expansion.
The bridge widened in 1938 with the addition on two T beams to each side. New railings and a new deck were placed at that time.
In 2003, the bridge was built to replace the adjacent old Inks Lake Bridge. As part of the project, the TX 29 alignment was straightened and the road widened to two lanes in each direction.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Texas Highway Department, Austin Bridge Company (Contractor)
column20: In the 1930's, a series of lakes were created along the Colorado River for flood control and for hydroelectric power. In preparation for the lake, the Inks Lake Bridge was constructed in 1937 over the Colorado River for FM 29. The bridge is an example of a state-standard Parker truss. In 1938, the dam was completed and the lake formed. The lake was named after Roy Inks, one of the Lower Colorado River Authority's board members.

The Interstate 64 Bridge over the Big Sandy River was constructed in 1962 as a haunched deck girder. The superstructure was replaced in 1998, though the original piers remain. However, the new high strength steel girders are much shorter than the old haunched deck girders. Note the concrete extensions on the top of the piers in the photograph.

The Interstate 64 Bridge over the Big Sandy River was constructed in 1962 as a haunched deck girder. The superstructure was replaced in 1998, though the original piers remain. However, the new high strength steel girders are much shorter than the old haunched deck girders. Note the concrete extensions on the top of the piers in the photograph.

The 1959 Interstate 64 Guyandotte River Bridges are part of the first generation of interstate highway bridges, built soon after passage of the 1956 Interstate Highway Act. The bridges probably are the longest over the entire Guyandotte River.

The 1959 Interstate 64 Guyandotte River Bridges are part of the first generation of interstate highway bridges, built soon after passage of the 1956 Interstate Highway Act. The bridges probably are the longest over the entire Guyandotte River.

The Pennsylvania Department of Highways built a new limited access highway, Legislative Route 71, to connect the Pennsylvania Turnpike in New Stanton with US 40 in Washington in the late 1940's and early 1950's. After the Interstate Highway Act was signed, the freeway was extended to connect Wheeling, West Virginia, and beyond. The 1960 deck girder is an early interstate era bridge. As opposed to newer multi-beam girder bridges, this example is a fracture critical deck girder, in which perpendicular floorbeams support the deck on top of the two parallel main girders. A similar bridge over Jefferson Avenue (PA 18) was replaced in the early 1990's I-70 reconstruction.

The Pennsylvania Department of Highways built a new limited access highway, Legislative Route 71, to connect the Pennsylvania Turnpike in New Stanton with US 40 in Washington in the late 1940's and early 1950's. After the Interstate Highway Act was signed, the freeway was extended to connect Wheeling, West Virginia, and beyond. The 1960 deck girder is an early interstate era bridge. As opposed to newer multi-beam girder bridges, this example is a fracture critical deck girder, in which perpendicular floorbeams support the deck on top of the two parallel main girders. A similar bridge over Jefferson Avenue (PA 18) was replaced in the early 1990's I-70 reconstruction.

The Pennsylvania Department of Highways built a new limited access highway, Legislative Route 71, to connect the Pennsylvania Turnpike in New Stanton with US 40 in Washington in the late 1940's and early 1950's. After the Interstate Highway Act was signed, the freeway was extended to connect Wheeling, West Virginia, and beyond. The 1960 deck girder is an early interstate era bridge. It is one of the few surviving original bridges after the west Washington PA section of I-70 was rebuilt in the early 1990's.

The Pennsylvania Department of Highways built a new limited access highway, Legislative Route 71, to connect the Pennsylvania Turnpike in New Stanton with US 40 in Washington in the late 1940's and early 1950's. After the Interstate Highway Act was signed, the freeway was extended to connect Wheeling, West Virginia, and beyond. The 1960 deck girder is an early interstate era bridge. It is one of the few surviving original bridges after the west Washington PA section of I-70 was rebuilt in the early 1990's.

Dating from 1949, the stretch of Interstate 70 in the Bentleyville area is one of the oldest interstates in America. Designed and built by the state, the road opened as a new alignment of PA 71, modeled after the Pennsylvania Turnpike. The original road was to connect the Pennsylvania Turnpike in New Stanton with US 40 in Washington, Pa. The bridge over Pigeon Creek is one of the larger original bridges, and it still retains its original concrete balustrades. According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, ''The five-span simply supported, 385'-long, built-up steel stringer bridge, built in 1949, is supported on concrete bents and abutments, and has standard design concrete balustrades.''
The Interstate 79 Connoquenessing Creek Bridges are the longest I-79 bridges in Butler County. They are on an older stretch of road, dating from 1962. Interstate 79 was completed in 1976.
The Interstate 79 Connoquenessing Creek Bridges are the longest I-79 bridges in Butler County. They are on an older stretch of road, dating from 1962. Interstate 79 was completed in 1976.

column2: Interstate 80 Allegheny River Bridge at Emlenton
column16: Highest vehicular bridge in Pennsylvania
column18: Buchart-Horn (Consultant), Ted Andrzejewski (Chief Engineer), Broadhead Construction
column20: The Interstate 80 Allegheny River Bridge at Emlenton is the last remaining vehicular deck truss bridge over the Allegheny River north of the Allegheny County line (the river flows into the Ohio River at Pittsburgh, Allegheny County). The bridge is 270 feet high, making it the tallest vehicular bridge in Pennsylvania. As of 2010, the bridge is the 22nd tallest bridge in America and the fourth tallest on the interstate highway system. When the bridge opened to traffic, it was the tallest bridge carrying an interstate highway in America.

column16: Longest spanning Interstate 80 bridge in Pennsylvania
column20: The Interstate 80 Clarion River Bridge has the longest span of three interstate deck truss bridges in Clarion County. The bridge has a main span of 612 feet, making it the longest-spanning vehicular bridge in all of northern Pennsylvania. The bridge is also the only truss bridge spanning the main Clarion river.
The Interstate 80 Deer Creek Bridge is the shortest of three large Interstate 80 deck truss bridges in Clarion County. Built in 1965, the bridge is a late example of a deck truss with X-lacing.

column2: Interstate 80 North Fork Redbank Creek Bridges (Eastbound)
column15: Haunched continuous deck girder and floorbeam system
column20: The Interstate 80 North Fork Redbank Creek Bridges are examples of original Interstate 80 large deck girder bridges. Western Pennsylvania is an eroded plateau, necessitating several long, high interstate bridges over valleys. There are 5 large bridges on the 40 mile Emlenton to Brookville segment, consisting of three deck trusses and two haunched deck girder bridges.

column2: Interstate 80 North Fork Redbank Creek Bridges (Westbound)
column15: Haunched continuous deck girder and floorbeam system
column20: The Interstate 80 North Fork Redbank Creek Bridges are examples of original Interstate 80 large deck girder bridges. Western Pennsylvania is an eroded plateau, necessitating several long, high interstate bridges over valleys. There are 5 large bridges on the 40 mile Emlenton to Brookville segment, consisting of three deck trusses and two haunched deck girder bridges.

column16: Only deck truss bridge in Erie County, longest-spanning bridge in Erie County
column20: The Interstate 90 Six Mile Creek Bridge is an example of a first generation interstate bridge, built only a few years after the passage of the Interstate Highway Act. The bridge is noteworthy for being the longest-spanning bridge in Erie County. It is the only deck truss bridge in Erie County. It is also the highest bridge in the county. The bridge is to be replaced in 2010 (westbound) and in 2011 (eastbound).
In 2003, Wilmington Resident Ed Bried noticed a 7-foot crack in the bridge. The crack has since been repaired.

column18: Morse Bridge Company of Youngstown, OH, Reno (engineer)
column20: The Iron Bridge Lane Bridge is the oldest truss bridge in Allegheny County. According to www.pghbridges.com, it is the second oldest unaltered bridge in Allegheny County. It was built in 1878 by the Morse Bridge Company of Youngstown, Ohio. Since the Morse Bridge Company started in 1878, the bridge is extremely important! It is one of two pin-connected pony truss bridges in the county (the Dorrington Road Bridge is the other, which is to be replaced in 2009). Due to Pittsburgh's dominance in bridge building, few Morse/Youngstown Bridge Company Bridges were built in southwestern Pennsylvania. Only a handful of pre-1880 iron bridges exist anywhere, and that number is dropping fast. It is essential that the bridge is preserved. Since the bridge is privately owned, the bridge does not face the same imminent threat of demolition as the government owned bridges. However, it was damaged by flooding due to Hurricane Ivan in 2004.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1 span, 115'-long, pin-connected Pratt thru truss bridge built ca. 1890 is supported on stone abutments with concrete bridge seats added (1995). The lightly built trusses have lower chords and diagonals of eye bars, and upper chords, end posts, and verticals of channels with lacing. The bridge has lattice portal bracing and built-up upper laterals with an inverted fishbelly shape. The floorbeams, stringers and deck were replaced in 1995, but the floorbeams were reconnected to the trusses in the original manner with U-shaped hangers from the lower chord pins. The end panel lower chord members were post tensioned with rods placed to the inside of the eye bars. The bridge is among the early examples of its type/design in the region. The 1995 deck replacement was sensitive to the original fabric/appearance. The Variety Iron Works, a Cleveland, Ohio, fabricator, built bridges from ca. 1888-1907, but was most active in the 1890s. The bridge's date of construction is undocumented by available records but ca. 1890 is appropriate based on company history and style. The bridge is a historically and technologically significant example of its type/design with distinctive details like the lattice web end posts and the fact that is a rare instate example of the fabricator.'' According to historicbridges.org, ''The bridge displays several noteworthy, distinctive, or uncommon, details, many of them associated with the Variety Ironworks. The pedimented design of the struts is present on all known through trusses built by the company, and the design of the portal bracing is seen on nearly all of the known trusses built by the company. The use of lattice instead of cover plate, particularly on the top chord (except at the center two panels), is another design the company often used. This particular bridge also has lattice on the top of the endpost as well, which is an uncommon feature among highway truss bridges of this period in history. The hip verticals have up-set eyebars that have an uncommon shape (not circular) which is an unusual detail that has shown up on other Variety Ironworks spans.''

The Iron Bridge Trail Bridge once served a local road (McNay Ridge Road), which connected Bristoria Road with McClellan Road. In 1958 the land was acquired to create Ryerson Station State Park, which opened in 1967. The bridge and road became Iron Bridge Trail. The main attraction of the park is the Ronald Duke Lake, which was formed with the construction of a dam in 1960. After cracks were discovered in the dam, the water was drawn down in 2005. The lake will not be restored for several years. The bridge, however, was restored, sometime around 2007. At nearly 100 feet, it is a long example of a Pratt pony truss. Dating from 1914, it is a late example of a pin-connected truss.

column15: Warren/Baltimore cantilever truss with camelback thru truss approach
column20: The 1922 Ironton Russell Bridge was the first bridge over the Ohio River between Parkersburg, WV, and Cincinnati, OH. Today it is the oldest remaining cantilever truss over the entire Ohio River! However, it may not hold this distinction for much longer, as it is to be replaced. The bridge was to be replaced by a single tower cable-stayed bridge to open in 2008 or 2009. However, due to significant increases in construction prices between 2003 when final design began and 2006, the cost of the new bridge ballooned to $110 million, 30% over budget. As a result, the design for the new bridge was changed to a two tower cable-stayed bridge. Due to the delays from the redesign, the new bridge will not open until around 2015. In the meantime, ODOT spent $1.1 million in 2008 to make repairs to the Ironton Russell Bridge. The bridge was last rehabilitated in the 1970's, in which plates were welded onto the bridge, weakening the members. The welding violated welding codes. Today the bridge is closed when temperatures go below -5 degrees F. Only vehicles narrower than 7.5 feet are allowed to use the bridge. The bridge is also unusual in that ramps on both sides are perpendicular to the bridge, connecting streets that are parallel with the river. As the oldest cantilever over the Ohio River, would it not be wonderful if an organization could assume ownership of the bridge and restore it for pedestrian use? While such a conversion has been done in cities such as Cincinnati and Nashville, such conversions are few and far between.

column16: One of only two multi span concrete arch bridges in Blair County
column18: H. G. Hinkle (Engineer), Curwensville Construction Company (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 2 span, 166'-long, reinforced concrete deck arch bridge built in 1912 to plans developed by the county has raised paneled parapets, concrete abutments, and a concrete bullnosed pier. The bridge is one of 13 surviving deck arch bridges designed by the Blair County engineer and built between 1908 and 1913.''

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, H. B. Putnam (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1940, skewed, 2 span, 274'-long, rivet-connected Parker pony truss bridge is supported on a concrete pier and concrete abutments with wingwalls. The identical spans have built-up upper and lower chords and rolled I section verticals and diagonals. It has a cantilevered sidewalk and it is finished with standard metal railings.''

column2: Irwin Interchange Bridge over the Pennsylvania Turnpike
column20: The 1952 Irwin Interchange Bridge is one of the 1952 Western Extension bridges. The bridges consist of thru girders and stringers. Since the original 1940 Pennsylvania Turnpike ended at the Irwin Interchange, a new bridge was built over the mainline to accommodate the redesigned interchange as part of the extension.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, M Bennett & Sons (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1930, skewed, 29'-long, closed spandrel filled concrete deck arch bridge has concrete balustrades. It is a typical example of a common bridge type that was used frequently from the 1910s through the 1950s.'' Note the sharp skew of the arch in the photograph of the bridge.

column15: Parker with deck girder (stringer) northern approach
column18: Fabricated by Pan-American Bridge Co., New Castle, IN; Erected by E. R. Mills, Charleston, WV.
column20: The main span of the Ivydale Bridge is a state standard Parker thru truss. Note the one concrete pier in the photograph. The previous bridge had a longer main span than the current bridge. When West Virginia replaced the bridge, they built a new pier in the river for the end of the shorter truss. Instead of one approach span, the newer bridge has two.
The Jackson Street Bridge was a state-standard concrete tee beam bridge. The photograph was taken a few weeks before its demolition.

column15: Wichert deck continuous cantilever truss with Warren webbing
column20: The former James Rumsey Bridge was one of only five Wichert truss bridges in the world. Well, now there are only four left. The Wichert truss is an open hinged diamond-shaped structure that makes each span of the continuous truss statically determinate. The bridge was one of only two with Warren truss webbing. The other bridge, also located over the Potomac River in Washington County, Maryland, was built at the same time to the same design. That bridge was rehabilitated. The Rumsey Bridge was replaced by a haunched weathering steel deck girder in 2004. The bridge was named after James Rumsey, who successfully demonstrated his steamboat on the Potomac River on December 3 and 11, 1787. According to a report about the new bridge, the haunched girder design with a span exceeding than 400 feet (425 feet) is 'relatively rare.' Really?

The Jefferson Heights Road Bridge is the only structure built specifically to span the Parkway East mainline that has more than one span. The bridge was rehabilitated in 2009, in which the main girders were removed, repaired, and re-erected.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Designed by T. B. Dinsmore, built by Lippencott Brothers
column20: The Jefferson Road Bridge is the only concrete arch bridge listed on the National Register of Historic Places in Greene County. It was determined eligible in 1984. It is also the only open spandrel concrete arch bridge in the county. It was a rare surviving open spandrel concrete arch that retained its original road deck and balustrades. Despite its rarity and historical significance, the bridge was be replaced and demolished in 2009. Being one lane wide, the bridge was a bottleneck on PA 188. With the Point Marion Monongahela River Bridge which also was demolished in 2009, Greene County lost all of its National Register-Listed bridges (with the exception of covered bridges) the same year. Many of the covered bridges have recently been rehabilitated and retrofitted with steel support structures.

According to the PAHBI, ''The single-span, 180'-long, steel built-up through girder bridge, built in 1921, is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls. It has steel balustrade flanked sidewalks cantilevered from the bridge's sides. Girder bridges were first developed by the railroad industry in the 1850s, and they were used on roadways beginning in the late 19th century.''

column15: Pratt with deck girder approach spans
column20: The Jennings Randolph Memorial Bridge, with a main span of 745 feet, is the longest-spanning simple truss bridge in North America. It replaced an 1897 suspension bridge in 1977. The then-world's longest arch bridge, the New River Gorge Bridge, opened that same year in West Virginia.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Jennings Road Bridge is a closed spandrel concrete arch bridge that maintains excellent historic integrity. It is the only non-beam bridge over any of the two Casselman River branches. Dating from 1917, it ties with the smaller Chet Kelly Road Bridge as the oldest concrete arch bridge in the county.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 2 span, 44'-long, rusticated ashlar stone arch bridge has stepped, flared wingwalls and concrete scour protection. It dates stylistically to ca. 1910. The low parapets appear to have been rebuilt. The bridge has been insensitively repointed, but the original bonding pattern has been maintained. Stone arch bridges are not common in the region, and this example, which has integrity of design and workmanship is historically significant as a rare and complete regional example of the important bridge type.''

column18: Allegheny County, John F. LaBoon, Henry Hornbostel, Park Martin, George S. Richardson
column20: The Jerome Street Bridge is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. It is the only example of a thru arch bridge over the Youghiogheny River. The bridge was designed by Allegheny County and funded through the Federal Emergency Administration of Public Works. A plaque reads, ''This bridge was planned and designed during 1934-35 by the Allegheny County Authority. Construction work was commenced October 18, 1935. The bridge was completed in 1937 by the County Commissioners.'' As with Allegheny County-designed bridges at the time, much care was given to the overall appearance of the bridge. Henry Hornbostel was involved with the design of the bridge. The bridge is also similar to the railroad spans of the McKees Rocks Bridge in Allegheny County.

The 1933 Jersey Shore Bridge is one of the last remaining truss bridges on the West Branch Susquehanna River. Once the Shawville Bridge and the Arch Street Bridge are demolished, it will be one of only three two-span truss bridges on the West Branch. The bridge is an example of a state-standard Parker truss. The bridge was rehabilitated in 2000, and it has a sufficiency rating of 73.4% (2007).

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1884, pin connected, single span, 68'-long, Pratt pony truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments. The traditionally composed trusses have metal rod diagonals and hip verticals, built up upper chords and verticals, and eye bar diagonals. The beam guiderails were added ca. 1990. Crawford County is rich in pin connected, metal truss bridges. A total of 35 ranging in date from 1870 through the early 20th century remain in the county. This bridge stands out as an early, complete, documented example of a pin connected Pratt pony truss bridge. Adding to its significance is its documentation to the Morse Bridge Company, a short-lived but prolific regional bridge fabricator. The bridge is historically and technologically significant.''

column15: Steel continuous haunched girder and floorbeam system
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 610' long, 5-span viaduct is composed of 4 continuous welded deck girder spans and one stringer spans all supported on concrete column bents. It has metal railings. The columns supporting the stringers have been augmented with I section helper bents placed in 1976.''

column16: Only one of its type; Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1978
column18: Hocking Valley Bridge Works, Augustus Borneman
column20: The 1884 John Bright No. 1 Bridge (originally constructed on John Bright's property) is the only all-metal example of its type (a rigid suspension or inverted bowstring) in America. The bridge was constructed by a local company, The Hocking Valley Bridge Works of Lancaster, Ohio. The company was started by Augustus Borneman in 1881 and lasted until the early 1900's. The bridge is similar to a Berlin Iron Company lenticular truss bridge except that the top chord is flat rather than inclined. Prior to the all-metal example, Borneman had designed similar wood / iron hybrid bridges that were covered, such as the nearby John Bright No. 2 Bridge. Therefore, the bridge appears to be an experimental all-metal version of the covered hybrid bridge. It is not know if any more of these iron examples were built. In 1999, the bridge was moved to cross Fetters Run, connecting Ohio University - Lancaster Campus with Festival Hill. This is an excellent example of a restoration and reuse of a historic bridge.

column15: Covered wood/iron hybrid rigid suspension (or inverted bowstring)
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1975
column20: The 1881 John Bright No. 2 Bridge (originally constructed on John Bright's property) is a rare wood and metal hybrid covered bridge. As with early hybrid transitional bridges, the compression members are composed are wood and the tension members composed of are iron. The bridge is an unusual suspension / truss hybrid, known as either a rigid suspension or an inverted bowstring. The design is similar to that of a lenticular truss, except the top chord is flat rather than inclined. Beginning in the late 1870's, the patented lenticular design was marketed across the country by the Corrugated Metal Company of East Berlin, Connecticut (later known as the Berlin Iron Bridge Company). Perhaps Augustus Borneman tried to convert that design into a cheaper iron/steel hybrid version, which would explain the flat top chord. The bridge was modified with an addition of a wooden arch in 1913. The John Bright No. 2 Bridge was restored and relocated to Ohio University - Lancaster Campus in 1988 to connect Festival Hill with the campus. An all metal version of the bridge was relocated nearby in 1999.

column15: Bascule; Closed Spandrel Concrete Arch Approaches
column20: The bridge has been unofficially 'painted' by students at the adjacent University of Tampa. Historically, the bridge was known as the Lafayette Street Bridge.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: In the 1920's, Harvard University expanded by building their business school to the south of the Charles River. The traditional campus is north of the river in Cambridge. A pedestrian bridge was built to connect the two parts of campus. The 1927 bridge is an example of a concrete arch. To match Harvard University, the bridge was faced in red brick. Other aesthetic features include accented arch rings and keystones, seals of the university, concrete balustrades, and obelisks at the ends of the bridge. The bridge was renamed after John Weeks, a U.S. Representative and later Senator from Massachusetts. He served as the Secretary of War in the Harding / Coolidge administrations. The bridge also carries Harvard's steam, electrical, and communications networks.

The 1892 Johnson Hill Road Bridge is the third oldest truss bridge in Greene County. The Pumpkin Hill Road Bridge is possibly older, but its build date is not documented. Based on details, the Johnson Hill Road Bridge can be attributed to Nelson & Buchanan. The bridge has long been abandoned, and the road deck is gone.

column18: Chaney & Armstrong, Engineers; W. M. Pickett & Company (Contractor)
column20: The Johnson Road Bridge is one of the older concrete arch bridges in Washington County, dating from 1913. It was designed by Chaney & Armstrong, Engineers, before the company became the Chaney Engineering Company. The bridge is adorned with paneled parapets and spandrel walls. The bridge is rated to be in poor condition, and the arch is spalled.

In 1983, the Johnson Street Bridge was replaced by a welded prefabricated pedestrian truss bridge. The finials (towers) from the 1880's Crockett Street Bridge were placed as decorative features at the abutments.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1904, skewed, single span, 80'-long, pin connected Pratt pony truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments that date to 1927. The light trusses are traditionally composed, with built up box section upper chords, eye bar lower chords and diagonals, and steel angle verticals.'' According to PennDOT's website, the bridge is to be demolished in the fall of 2010.

column16: Last remaining concrete arch bridge in Forest County
column18: John Farris, Pennsylvania Board of Public Grounds & Buildings
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1919, three span, 291'-long (3 @ 97'), reinforced concrete deck arch bridge is supported on concrete skewbacks and two concrete cutwater piers. In 1996 the original flared, paneled parapets were replaced with plain parapets topped with one rail high aluminum railings.''

To many in the Pittsburgh area, the Hulton Bridge is known for lavender color (it was painted that shade from green in an early 1990's rehabilitation). The historic bridge is noteworthy for a lot more. It was the first County of Allegheny designed bridge over the Allegheny River. The bridge consists of 1,544 feet of trusses, longer than any other thru truss in the county. The bridge's main span is 505 feet, one of the longest in the country in 1910, is still in the top 50 of the longest simple truss spans in North America. The main span is also noteworthy in that it is skewed, though the rest of the surrounding trusses are not. Furthermore, the bridge is the oldest active multi-span vehicular bridge over the entire Allegheny River. Despite its historical significance and relatively good condition (the bridge is well-maintained and has no weight limit), it is scheduled for replacement. The narrow two-lane bridge is a bottleneck, and it is frequently congested. As seen on the map, the problem with the location of the bridge is that it has T intersections on each end. The narrow bridge cannot accommodate turn lanes. Many people live on the Oakmont side, and two different freeways have interchanges on the Harmar side. To alleviate congestion, a wider bridge is to be built. Depending on funding, the new steel girder will open as early as 2015.

The Bailey Truss was designed during the World War II as a light, prefabricated bridge consisting of standardized panels. The bridge could be quickly and easily erected to fit a variety of conditions. As such, the type is usually used as a temporary bridge. This is the only permanent example in Pennsylvania on this website.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: A. K. Nicolaysen (Design Engineer), Hans Helland (City Engineer), Chas M. Schoenfeld (Contractor)
column20: Commerce Street is one of the main east west roads through San Antonio. According to the State Historical Survey Committee, ''The main ford between San Fernando De Bexar (The City) and San Antonio De Valero (The Alamo), this river crossing has long been a focal point of history. At its footbridge on February 23, 1836, Alamo Emissary Albert Martin met to parley with Santa Anna's Aide, Juan Almonte, during the Texas War for Independence. . . . Present bridge replaces an 1880 iron structure, linking old and new, it spans 250 years of recorded history.'' The iron towers from the 1880's bridge were saved and relocated to the Johnson Street Pedestrian Bridge approach. According to the Historic Bridge Foundation, ''The Commerce Street Bridge consists of a 3-span continuous concrete T-beam superstructure resting on square pier columns. On the north side of the bridge are two curving flight of stairs that link with the River Walk below. The bridge is noted for its many decorative details including open concrete molded railing and architectural treatments to the outside pier columns and projecting spandrel walls. On the south side of the bridge is located a sculpture of an Indian brave created by noted Texas artist Waldine Tauch. Entitled '' The First Inhabitant,'' the sculpture consists of seven foot tall Native American in full, feathered headdress bordered by a background of corn. Carved onto each hand is a shallow Indian-patterned bowl, which once had drinking fountains concealed in each bowl. The sculpture was commissioned by the San Antonio Express, which offered Tauch $1,000 to complete the work. The bridge was most likely widened in 1929, and may have been subsequently widened again. Other alterations to the bridge may have occurred during the 1930s, with the creation of the San Antonio River Walk.''

column16: Oldest Pennsylvania truss in northwestern Pennsylvania, eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1900, pin connected, single span, 206'-long, Pennsylvania thru truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with wingwalls. The polygonal upper chords are built up box sections and the sub-ties are eye bars. The bridge is distinguished as an early example of its type and design. It is the oldest remaining Pennsylvania thru truss highway bridge in northwestern Pennsylvania, and only one other example in western Pennsylvania has an earlier construction date. The bridge is historically and technologically significant.''

The Judge J. Frank Graff Bridge is one of only a few deck truss bridges built in Pennsylvania during the 1970's. The bridge was built as part of the US 422 / PA 28 Kittanning Bypass. In the mid 1970's, many highway projects were cancelled. The Kittanning Bypass was not completed until 2001. Judge J. Frank Graff served on the Armstrong County Court of Common Pleas and the Pennsylvania Superior Court. In 2010 - 2012 the bridge was rehabilitated and repainted blue from the original green color shown in the 2005 photograph.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 5 span, 650'-long reinforced concrete deck arch bridge built in 1922 is supported on concrete piers and abutments. The spandrels are paneled to accent the arches. It has paneled parapets and paneled pilasters at the piers. A concrete railing separates the roadway from the sidewalk. Built as a joint-county project using a design prepared by the county engineers, the bridge is an example of a very common bridge type/design with no unusual or distinctive features.''

column2: Kanawha City Bridges (35th Street Bridge, 36th Street Bridge) (Northbound)
column20: The first bridge crossing the Kanawha River in Kanawha City was built in 1915 at 35th Street. It was demolished in 1975, and replaced by the twin 35th Street and 36th Street Bridges (Kanawha City Bridges). The 36th Street Bridge opened in 1975 and carried bidirectional traffic until the new 35th Street Bridge was completed the next year. The 35th Street Bridge serves southbound traffic and the 36th Street Bridge serves northbound traffic. The replacement bridges are both examples of haunched deck girders.

column2: Kanawha City Bridges (35th Street Bridge, 36th Street Bridge) (Southbound)
column20: The first bridge crossing the Kanawha River in Kanawha City was built in 1915 at 35th Street. It was demolished in 1975, and replaced by the twin 35th Street and 36th Street Bridges (Kanawha City Bridges). The 36th Street Bridge opened in 1975 and carried bidirectional traffic until the new 35th Street Bridge was completed the next year. The 35th Street Bridge serves southbound traffic and the 36th Street Bridge serves northbound traffic. The replacement bridges are both examples of haunched deck girders.

column15: Pennsylvania thru truss with camelback Pennsylvania approaches
column20: The 1928 National-Register eligible Kanawha Falls Bridge is the oldest remaining vehicular bridge over the entire Kanawha River. It is the very first bridge over the river, which is formed at the confluence of the Gauley and New rivers. The bridge is the only vehicular simple truss bridge over the entire Kanawha River that has multiple thru truss spans. It is one of the few Pennsylvania truss bridges in the state. The central Pennsylvania truss span is flanked by a camelback Pennsylvania truss span on each side. It is very rare to find a camelback Pennsylvania truss anywhere. The central span rests on trussed bents anchored into a low concrete pier. Though this bridge serving 500 vehicles per day is to be replaced, it should be preserved as one of the most unusual and historic bridges over the Kanawha River.

column15: Pennsylvania with Pratt thru truss approaches
column20: The former CSX Railroad Bridge is to undergo a $2.5 million dollar conversion to become a rail trail bridge. Senator Robert Byrd has secured $2 million in federal appropriations for the bridge. Once the bridge is converted, it will be the oldest bridge accessible to the public over the entire Kanawha River. It is likely that the bridge was originally a Whipple truss, and the superstructure was replaced around 1900. The Elk River Bridge is still the original Whipple truss. The bridge's conversion is an excellent example of creative reuse of a historic structure. The trail will eventually connect the Mound in South Charleston with the Capitol Complex and Coonskin Park. The conversion of the bridge is Phase I of the rail trail project.
The Kantner Bridge is an example of a state-standard multi-beam (stringer).

The Kantz Hill Road Bridge was a rare surviving pin-connected Pratt thru truss built by the King Bridge Company. It featured King Bridge Company standard details, such as lattice portal bracing above knee braces containing distinctive star shapes. The bridge was demolished in 2008 after its replacement was built on a different alignment. The replacement bridge cost $2,010,125. If the NBI ADT of 35 vehicles per day is correct, the replacement bridge cost about $57,500 per vehicle. The builders plaque was donated to the Clearfield County Historical Society.

column16: Only multi span truss bridge in Centre County
column20: The Karthaus Bridge is the last remaining multi-span bridge in Centre County. Once the Arch Street Bridge in Lycoming County is replaced, it will be one of only two truss bridges over the last 150 miles of the West Branch Susquehanna River. According to the PAHBI (JPH Reviewer), ''The two-span, 410'-long, riveted Parker thru truss bridge built in 1937 is supported on a horizontally scored concrete cutwater pier and concrete abutments with flared wingwalls. The bridge has built-up upper and lower chords, and rolled beam verticals and diagonals. Standard decorative lattice railings with attached W-beam guide railings are placed to the inside of the truss lines. The concrete deck was replaced in 1977.''

The Keating Summit Bridge is one of the most important surviving bridges in Pennsylvania. The 1891 bridge is one of the oldest rivet-connected bridges in all of Pennsylvania. The bridge has been determined to be historically and technologically significant. The bridge was originally built to span a branch of the Pennsylvania Railroad. Its large members give it the appearance of either a railroad bridge or a post-WWII truss. It is a rare surviving example of a bridge from the Union Bridge Company. It is also the oldest truss-supported bridge in Potter County.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
