column20: The Kellers Road Bridge is an unusual Pratt thru truss with V-laced diagonal endposts. The bridge looks to date from the 1890's. According to the PAHBI, ''The single span, 105'-long Pratt through truss bridge is supported on stone abutments. The pin-connected truss tension members are eyebars and rods, with built-up compression members. Built-up floorbeams and rolled stringers support a timber deck. Wire ropes provide the bridge railings. The bridge, built in 1927 according to Penn DOT records, is a late example of its type, and may have been moved to this location in 1927, but was probably built earlier. The bridge has been determined eligible by PHMC.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Pittsburgh Bridge Company, Nelson and Buchanan Agents
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The one span, 123'-long, pin connected Pratt thru truss bridge dated to 1892 is supported on a stone and a concrete abutment. The truss members are traditionally composed, but the floorbeams are framed into the lower ends of the verticals rather than suspended from the lower panel point pins. The eye bar lower chords are pin connected and connected to the verticals by pin plates. With the exception of the 1962 redoing for the stringers and deck, the bridge is complete, and it ranks as one of the good early examples of the important bridge type in the region. The bridge is historically and technologically significant.''

In the mid 1960's, the Shenango River Lake was created. Kelly Road became the only route to access the dam. The one-lane bridge was upgraded by a new parallel bridge to carry eastbound traffic. In the mid 2000's, the old westbound bridge was closed to vehicles. This bridge now carries bi-directional traffic. The bridges are to be replaced in the early 2010's.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Kelly Road (Westbound) Bridge is a rare pin-connected camelback truss. It is one of the only camelback trusses in western Pennsylvania. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1897, pin connected, single span, 187'-long, Parker thru truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with flared wingwalls. The polygonal upper chords are built up box sections, the verticals are toe-out channels with lacing, and the diagonals and lower chords are eye bars. The bridge is historically and technologically significant as an early and complete pin connected, Parker thru truss bridge. The technology is rare in Pennsylvania. Approximately 15 pin connected Parker truss highway bridges survive statewide [as of 1998, many have since been replaced], and only three date from before 1900. Adding to its significance is its association with the Penn Bridge Company, a prolific regional fabricator of metal truss bridges. '' According to www.mercercotrussbridges.com, ''The bridge now carries northbound traffic only, while a parallel, two-span, post-1956 stringer bridge carries southbound traffic. The bridge crosses the Shenango River at the east entrance to the Sharpsville Canal Lock Recreation Park, which has been created at the site of Lock No. 10 of the mid-19th century Erie Canal Extension. The abandoned and dewatered canal and stone canal lock chamber is located a short distance southwest of the bridge. The Penn Bridge Company of Beaver Falls, Pennsylvania, was organized in 1868 as T.B. White & Sons. At the time, the firm constructed wooden bridges. The plant was initially established in New Brighton; it was moved across the Beaver River to Beaver Falls in 1878. In 1887, the firm reorganized and incorporated as the Penn Bridge Company, producers of wrought iron, steel, and combination bridges; iron substructures, buildings, and roof trusses; and plate, box, and lattice girders and architectural ironwork. In the 1890s, the Penn Bridge Company's output averaged 5,000 long tons, ranking it as a small bridge fabricator. The Penn Bridge Company remained independent of the American Bridge Company, and continued to grow over the first two decades of the twentieth century, producing large and small structures and structural steel work. The company added new physical plant in 1902, reincorporated in 1905, and employed more than 500 workers in 1908. The Penn Bridge Company built bridges and structures in nearly all U.S. states and territories. It was particularly prominent in Pittsburgh, the City of Bridges. By 1908, the company had built four bridges over the Ohio River, five over the Monongahela River, and two over the Allegheny River, as well as the original Ohio River Dam Nos. 2, 4, 5, and 6.''

The Kemah Bridge is one of the longest bridges over a waterway in the Houston Area. It was completed in 1986, replacing a drawbridge. Located near the Kemah Boardwalk, the bridge is decorated with lights, including a neon Texas flag.

column16: Last remaining riveted pony truss bridge in Lawrence County
column20: The Kennedy Mill Bridge was the last remaining riveted pony truss bridge in Lawrence County. It was built in 1928 by Thomas Gilkey, the county engineer. The bridge was located in a popular recreational area with a spillway.

column15: Pennsylvania pin-connected with thru girder approaches
column16: Oldest vehicular Pennsylvania truss and second oldest vehicular truss over the Allegheny River in Pennsylvania
column18: E. C. Read, E. K. Morse, American Bridge Company
column20: The former Kennerdell Bridge was the second oldest truss bridge and oldest Pennsylvania truss bridge over the Allegheny River in Pennsylvania when it was demolished. The bridge was just one lane wide, and it had traffic signals on both sides. As of 2010, only one pre-World War I multi span truss bridge remains over the entire Allegheny River in Pennsylvania, and it is scheduled for replacement. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1907, 6 span, 905'-long bridge has a 3 pin connected, Pennsylvania thru truss spans (1 @ 200', 2 @ 260'), 2 thru girder approach spans (1 @ 75', 1 @ 80'), and a 1981 replacement steel stringer (1 @ 60'). The bridge is supported on concrete abutments, ashlar cutwater piers in the river channel, and steel bents.''

The New Kennerdell Bridge was built on the piers of the previous one-lane steel truss. It is a long-span example of a weathering steel continuous girder bridge. The bridge is the only crossing of the Allegheny River between Emlenton and Franklin. The bridge has no height or weight restrictions.

column15: Segmental stone arch widened by steel stringers
column18: J. M. Morse, Pennsylvania Department of Highways (widening)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The bridge was originally constructed as a 15'-wide stone deck arch bridge ca. 1900. In 1967 the bridge was widened to 29.5' by extending the abutments and adding 2 steel I beam stringers to each side. The bridge has also been redecked, with structure mounted guiderail railings added.''

The 1960 Kennywood Park Bridge is an early example of a large deck girder bridge built over a ravine. It replaced an earlier trestle. The bridge is located at the edge of the world famous amusement park Kennywood, which started as a trolley park in 1898. Kennywood is one of two amusement parks in America that are National Historic Landmarks. Famous for its roller coasters and historic rides, Kennywood is considered to be one of the best parks in the world. In 2000, the Travel Channel ranked Kennywood the 7th best thrill park. In 2004, it was ranked as the 2nd favorite amusement park in Theme Park Magazine's Reader's Choice Awards.

Ketchum Road used to connect SR 518 with SR 45 and Lake Cha-Vel. At some point the road was abandoned. The road deck of the Ketchem Road bridge has been removed and replaced with a pedestrian walkway. It appears that the right-of-way may have been sold, since a gate with a No Trespassing sign closes off the former road. The bridge is attributed to the Penn Bridge Company based on its details. It is similar to the Pancake Clarkson Road Bridge and the Culbertson's Mill Bridge. Unfortunately, there is so much section loss in the floorbeams at the pinned connections that you can see through them. Rope has been added to help strengthen the bridge. Without repair work, the bridge will likely collapse on its own in a few years.

In 1977, a new alignment of US 19 was completed between Mt Nebo (south of Summersville) and Beckley. The old alignment (now WV 41) went through the Meadow River Valley, and crossed over to the New River Valley near Prince. The new alignment crosses high above the Meadow River on the Ritchie Bridge and even higher across the New River Gorge Bridge. The Ritchie Bridge is an example of a Warren cantilever deck truss. US 19 was converted to an expressway (The Mountaineer Expressway) in 1995, and a new twin bridge was constructed. The photograph shows the newer bridge in the foreground.

In 1977, a new alignment of US 19 was completed between Mt Nebo (south of Summersville) and Beckley. The old alignment (now WV 41) went through the Meadow River Valley, and crossed over to the New River Valley near Prince. The new alignment crosses high above the Meadow River on the Ritchie Bridge and even higher across the New River Gorge Bridge. The Ritchie Bridge is an example of a Warren cantilever deck truss. US 19 was converted to an expressway (The Mountaineer Expressway) in 1995, and a new twin bridge was constructed. The photograph shows the newer bridge in the foreground.

The Keys Bridge, dating from 1903, is one of several remaining similar Nelson & Buchanan truss bridges. Comparable bridges are either three or four panels; the Keys Bridge is one of the longer four-panel designs. The Nelson & Buchanan bridges are noteworthy for being early riveted pony truss bridges in which each panel has an X shape. The Keys Bridge has X-laced guardrails instead of the V-laced guardrails seen on comparable bridges.

column15: Warren polygonal subdivided riveted, deck girder
column18: Western Maryland Railway, converted to rail-trail bridge and rehabilitated by DMJM+Harris (AECOM) and Brayman Construction
column20: As part of the 2003 rail-trail conversion, the spans carrying the former railroad over Flaugherty Creek and SR 2006 were replaced by longer, curved deck girder span. The bridge was built to accommodate two tracks, though one was ever used. The conversion contract cost $1.5 million. The project was one of the last to be completed on the Great Allegheny Passage Trail. The truss of the bridge is to be raised in 2011? as part of CSX's National Gateway clearance initiative.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1974
column18: Smith Bridge Company of Tipp City, Ohio
column20: According to Mercer County Engineer's Office's website, ''Mercer County Bridge No. 1801 is on the National Register of Historic Places. This is Mercer County's only remaining covered bridge. The bridge is located on Township Road 471, approximately one half-mile east of S.R. 18, in Pymatuning Township, Mercer County, Pennsylvania. The bridge is situated in a rural area and spans the Shenango River. The single-lane Mercer County Bridge 1801 consists of a single span, Smith Truss covered bridge on sandstone ashlars. The structure has a span of 122'-6'' backwall to backwall on a 90 degree skew. The roadway is 16'-7'' between the trusses. The bridge is 118'-7'' center to center of bearings. Two inch timber planking is laid diagonally over the floorbeams. Two inch timber planking is laid longitudinally for wheel paths, and these are nailed to the main flooring. The 2'' x 12'' floorbeams are spaced at 1'-9'' and are notched to rest on the lower chords. The timber truss diagonals are hand hewn timbers of various sizes. The upper chords are bolted 6'' x 10'' and the lower chords are bolted 6'' x 12'' timbers. These have spacer blocks to permit the diagonals to pass through forming a mortise and tenon connection. The structure was constructed in 1868 by the Smith Bridge Company of Tipp City, Ohio. Devised and patented in 1867 by Robert Smith, both tension and compression members were all wood. During the period of 1867 to 1870, Smith built 15 of these patented structures in Miami County, Ohio. Smith usually assembled the trusses in his home yard and shipped them by rail to the destination. Standard charges for a complete bridge put up by Smith's company was $18 per foot for a bridge span of 125 feet. The Kidds Mill bridge is the only one of Smith's patented bridges still standing east of Ohio.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1913, 2 simple span, 171'-long, riveted Warren pony truss with verticals bridge is supported on reinforced concrete abutments and a concrete pier. All truss members are composed of steel angles, with the exception of the floor beams, which are rolled I beams. The bridge has an open grid steel deck and structure mounted guiderail railings. It was built as part of the Manufacturers' Water Co. Quemahoning reservoir to supply water to Johnstown and the Bethlehem mill.''

The Kiger Hill Road Bridge is a tiny 39-foot pin-connected Pratt pony truss from 1909. It was rehabilitated in 1995, when the deck, stringers, floorbeams, and U-shaped hangers were all replaced. Some welding was performed for strengthening. While historic integrity was compromised, the superstructure condition is rated a 5 of 9, which is higher than many comparable bridges.

The Kingsdale Road Bridge is part of the old alignment of WV 2. It was bypassed in 2006 and is now closed to traffic. The photograph was taken in 2007. The bridge is attributed to the Luten Bridge Company of York, PA, since it is looks similar to the 1912 CR 7 Bridge in nearby Brooke County. That bridge was also built in 1912 by the Luten Bridge Company. The Kingsdale Road Bridge is one of three concrete arches in the county. It has been designated as possibly eligible for the National Register of Historic Places.

In West Virginia (as well as in other states with deep valleys), many people live on the opposite side of the creek from the main road. Therefore, many homes have driveways with a bridge over the creek. These people created a Kingpost truss, which is a rare type of truss bridge to find.

column15: Burr arch truss, wooden covered bridge
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Kings Bridge was built in the 1800's, probably around same time of the construction of the 1830 Barronvale Covered Bridge. The former identification signs of the Kings Covered Bridge used to give the year of 1802, though this is unlikely since America's first covered bridge is generally considered to be the 1805 Permanent Bridge. The bridge was rebuilt in 1906, in which the arch was likely added. The bridge was abandoned in 1934 when it was bypassed by the adjacent steel stringer bridge. The bridge was taken over by the Kings family, and it was retrofitted to serve as a livestock barn. In 1996, the Southern Alleghenies Conservancy and the Somerset Conservation District began to seek funds to rehabilitate the bridge. A temporary support structure was added to the bridge in 2000. The township took ownership the bridge and adjacent property in 2002, creating a bridge park. In 2008, the bridge was rehabilitated and opened to pedestrians. Thanks to the support of the community, the bridge is now a community asset and tourist attraction.
The Kingsley Road Bridge appears to have been built as a railroad bridge. There were several logging railroads in the region in the late 1800's and early 1900's.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Bechtel & Walters (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1927, 64'-long, reinforced concrete, closed spandrel deck arch bridge has flared concrete wingwalls. The bridge was widened by approximately 10' on the downstream side in 1958. In 1994 new safety shape parapets were placed on the bridge, replacing structure mounted beam guiderail railings attached at an unspecified date.''

column15: Trestle; steel deck girder on trussed bents
column16: Listed on the NRHP, 1977 - 2004, National Register of Historic Civil Engineering Landmarks, 1982
column20: The original Kinzua Bridge was constructed as an expansion of the New York, Lake Erie, and Western Railroad in 1882. It was designed by Octave Chanute and built by the Phoenix Iron Works using Phoenix columns, which are hollow iron tubes. The bridge was probably the largest built ever to use Phoenix columns. The entire structure was built in just 94 days. When the bridge was completed, it was the tallest and longest bridge in the world, with a height of 300 feet and length of 2100 feet. It was advertized as the 'Eighth Wonder of the World.' The bridge held the record until Gustave Eiffel's Garabit Viaduct in France opened in 1885. As railroad loads became heavier, the Erie Railroad (which merged with the NYLE&W) hired the Elmira Bridge Company to rebuild the structure, which was done from May through September of 1900. The bridge was rebuilt in which Howe truss 'timber travelers' were placed, starting at one tower, spanning over a second tower, and ending at a third tower. Therefore, the intermediate tower could be rebuilt. This process was repeated until the entire bridge was rebuilt. The anchor bolts which attached the base of the towers to the stone and concrete footings were reused from the previous bridge. The rebuilt Kinzua Viaduct was used by the Erie Railroad until 1959. It was to be torn down in the early 1960's. However, when Nick Kovalchick, the owner of the bridge's salvage company saw the bridge, he supposedly said, 'There will never be another bridge like this.' Kovalchick successfully worked together with preservation groups to convince the DCNR to buy the land to become the Kinzua Bridge State Park. The park was established in 1963 and opened in 1975. The bridge was refurbished in which sidewalks and railings were added for pedestrians. The bridge also continued to function as a railroad bridge for the Knox and Kane Railroad's sightseeing trips. In 2002, the bridge was closed to railroad and pedestrian traffic when an inspection revealed the anchor bolts (the original ones from the previous bridge) were badly rusted. A strong wind could blow the bridge off its footings, leading to catastrophic collapse. Construction began in early 2003 to repair the bridge. Unfortunately, time ran out. On July 21, 2003 the bridge was struck by an F1 tornado, with wind speeds of 94 miles per hour. Only the three northern towers and the six southern towers that had just been repaired withstood the storm. The rest lie as they fell on the valley floor below. The DCNR decided to leave the wreckage lie as-is, showing the forces of nature at work. The remaining portions of the bridge are to be strengthened, and glass bottomed observation platforms are to be extended from the ends of the bridge.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1988
column18: Charles A. Williams (Engineer),  William Wagner and Brothers of Dallastown, Pennsylvania (Contractors)
column20: According to PennDOT's publication, Historic Highway Bridges in Pennsylvania: ''This small, single span arch bridge was built in 1915 in a style patterned after that of nineteenth century highway bridges. Built of random-coursed ruble, the Kise Mill Bridge is a single-span camelback arch, with a very narrow wall above the crown. The name, 'camelback', is derived from the hump created mid-span by the incline of the roadway. Two earlier bridges preceded the Kise Mill stone arch bridge at this site. A date stone set into the inner parapet wall identified this bridge's builders: Charles A. Williams, Engineer, and William Wagner and Brothers of Dallastown, Pennsylvania, Contractors. The Kise Mill Bridge is part of the Kise Mill Bridge Historic District listed on the National Register of Historic Places.''

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, McClintic-Marshall Co. (Contractor)
column20: The Kittanning Citizens Bridge was featured in the movie, The Mothman Prophecies, in which it played the Silver Bridge in Point Pleasant, West Virginia. The Silver Bridge collapsed in 1967, taking the lives of 46 people. In the movie, the bridge was modified to be a suspension bridge. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1932, riveted, 4 span, 949'-long bridge is composed of 3 Parker thru truss main spans (1 @ 409', 2 @ 240') and one steel stringer approach span. Parker thru truss span with 400' lengths are not technologically challenging or significant. They are composed of larger dimensioned members. The substructure is concrete abutments and piers. It has no innovative or distinctive details. The bridge, the fourth at this location, was built to a State Highway Department standard design. The granite piers flanking the sidewalks at the portals are topped with Neo-Classical style luminaires.'' The bridge replaced a bowstring truss.

Knoebels Amusement Resort started as a swimming hole near a wooden covered bridge. In 1940, the bridge was replaced with the current thru girder bridge. As Knoebels Amusement Resort continued to expand, the road and bridge were purchased and used as a pedestrian walkway and service road in the amusement park.

The Koppel Bridge is the oldest deck truss in Beaver County. It was constructed in 1915 and rehabilitated in 1994, receiving a new deck. Despite this modernization work and although the bridge is not weight restricted, its sufficiency rating is only 8.4%. The bridge has the most truss spans of any bridge entirely in Beaver County, consisting of 7 truss spans and 5 stringer spans. It is important to note that the bridge is not continuous, despite its long length. Most continuous truss bridges were not built until after World War II. The truss design is unusual in that the center panel of each of the larger spans consists of an X, although the bridge is a Warren truss. The bridge is scheduled for rehabilitation.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, John Swanger (Contractor)
column20: Built in 1949, the Kreamer Bridge is a late example of a state standard truss bridge. Few were constructed after World War II. According to the PAHBI, ''The 2-span, rivet-connected Parker pony truss bridge built in 1949 is composed of built-up chords and rolled section diagonals, verticals, and floorbeams. It has standard metal railings to the inside of the truss lines, concrete deck, and is supported on concrete abutments and piers. The bridge is a standard design rivet-connected truss of a type used extensively by the state highway department from the late 1920s through the 1940s.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1895, pin connected, single span, 93'-long, Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls. The only modifications to the traditionally composed bridge appears to be the ca. 1985 placement of beam guiderails, steel curbs, and an asphalt-filled steel pan deck. Crawford County is rich in pin connected, metal truss bridges. A total of 35 ranging in date from 1870 through the early 20th century remain in the county population. This bridge, one of three in the county fabricated by the Penn Bridge Company or its predecessor, stands out as a complete, documented example of its type and design. It is historically and technologically significant.''

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1979
column20: The Krepps Covered Bridge is an example of a king post truss. It was built in 1887 and relocated to its current site in the 1950's when a replacement bridge was built. An intermediate wooden pier was added to help support the bridge, since as of 2006 the bridge has not been retrofitted with steel beams. Since the bridge is to be restored, steel beams will probably be added and the intermediate support removed. The Annual Covered Bridge Festival is held next to the bridge the third weekend of September.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Guy Trimpey (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 2 simple span, 213'-long and 26' wide, Parker pony truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls and a concrete pier. A sidewalk with a metal railing is cantilevered from one side. The bridge is an example of a commonly used state standard design. The trusses are traditionally composed with built up box section upper chords and inclined end posts and rolled section for the web members.''

In 1950, the Vesta Coal Company built a coal processing plant, the Labelle Preparation Plant, directly across the Monongahela River from the company town, Vestaburg. Vesta Coal built a suspension bridge to support a coal conveyor belt to carry coal from the mines at Vestaburg to the coal processing plant on the other side of the river. In the 1970's, Vesta mines No. 4 and No. 5 were depleted, although the Labelle Preparation Plant continued under different companies (Castradale Coal Co. is the most recent operator). The bridge is no longer used to carry coal. The abandoned bridge was removed in 2011.

column16: Most arch spans of any concrete arch bridge in the region
column18: James H. Fuertes, Evitts Creek Water Company
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1916, 11 span, 223'-long (2 @ 20'-7'', 9 @ 20'), reinforced concrete deck arch bridge is supported on concrete abutments and piers. It is finished with paneled parapets. The bridge was built in association with the Lake Gordon dam and reservoir built to supplement the water supply for Cumberland, MD. The project is not historically significant. The cyclopean masonry, gravity dam was not technologically noteworthy, and the reservoir's 1,400 million gallon capacity proved to be inadequate just 25 years after it was built.''

column2: Lake Lynn Power House and Dam Suspension Bridge
column20: According to F. Curry, P.E., and J. Bowie of the Historic American Engineering Record: "When built, the Lake Lynn power house and dam reflected the state of the art in American hydroelectric power technology and developed a very substantial portion of West Virginia's hydrologic resources. This utility helped provide electricity in much of northern West Virginia and southern Pennsylvania and encouraged economic development in these areas. The reservoir created by the dam also permits the Monongahela River (into which the Cheat River flows) to run normally during dry, late summer months." The suspension bridge carries an access walkway from the dam's power house to the switchyards.

According to the PAHBI, ''The skewed, 22'-long and 17.8' wide steel stringer bridge with a concrete jack arch deck is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls. The plain concrete parapets are integral with the fascia beam encasement. Arched, corrugated metal liners were placed between the bottom flange of the stringers and the jack arch deck was poured in place. It was a common period detail for a stronger deck, and this example is not an early one.''

The Lake Road Bridge is a representative example of a state-standard stringer with concrete balustrades. According to the PAHBI, ''The single-span, 44'-long steel stringer bridge built in 1937 is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls and has standard design concrete balustrades. It has no innovative or distinguishing details, and is an example of the most common 20th century bridge type in the state.''

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Louis Wiscott (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1955, single span, 53'-long steel stringer bridge is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls. It has standard design steel railings with Art Moderne style concrete endposts.''

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1994
column20: The Lamar Boulevard Bridge is one of Austin's two concrete arch bridges over the Colorado River (Lady Bird Lake). However, the Congress Avenue Bridge was modified with load-bearing beams, so those arches are decorative. Therefore, the Lamar Boulevard Bridge is the last remaining concrete arch bridge over the Colorado River in the region. The bridge has narrow sidewalks, and was the source of several collisions involving bicycles and pedestrians. In 2001, the James Pfluger pedestrian bridge opened adjacent to the bridge to solve this dangerous situation.

Until 1960, vehicles on US 40 (the National Road) had to descend steep grades to go through the narrow and busy town of Brownsville, cross the river on a narrow bridge, and travel up the steep hill on the other side of the river. In 1960 a new expressway was built, bypassing Brownsville on the Lane Bane Bridge, a new high-level bridge. The structure is an example of a deck cantilever continuous truss. The Warren trusses point downward over the piers instead of upward as in most comparable bridges. On the west side of Brownsville, the expressway used to end at a partial interchange with PA 160. The road under the PA 160 overpass was never constructed. However, in 2008 the overpass was demolished, and Redstone Way opened on the never-used alignment to connect US 40 with the new Mon-Fayette Expressway. On the east side of Brownsville the road was extended in 1977 and again in 1990 with the opening of a segment of the Mon-Fayette expressway to the north. Interestingly, with connections to the new Mon-Fayette expressway on both sides, the 1960 expressway and bridge have become obsolete. A segment of the Mon-Fayette will be constructed to make a continuous connection with the other expressway segments, bypassing the 1960 Brownsville Bypass and Lane Bane Bridge. The Lane Bane Bridge will remain open to traffic.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, last remaining pin-connected truss bridge in Bedford County
column20: Unlike the vast majority of pin-connected truss bridges in Pennsylvania, the Langdons Drive Bridge is to be rehabilitated. This is a very important project, since the bridge is the last pin-connected truss bridge of any time in Bedford County. The project will involve the replacement of the floorbeams (which have previously been modified). According to the PAHBI, '''The 104' long, pin connected Pratt thru truss bridge fabricated in 1889 by the King Iron Bridge Co. of Cleveland is supported on ashlar abutments with wingwalls. The light trusses are traditionally composed, but they are complete. The lower chords were post tensioned to strengthen the bridge and add redundancy at an unknown date. The bridge is historically and technologically significant as an early and complete example of the important bridge type. It is also the work of an important early national bridge building company.''

column18: City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works, T. J. Wilkerson, John F. Casey Co.
column20: The Larimer Avenue Bridge was America's longest-spanning concrete arch bridge when it opened in 1912. Like the other Pittsburgh bridges from the time period, it was built in the City Beautiful style. The deck as well as most of the ornamentation was removed in the rehabilitation of 1981. The bridge is the oldest remaining of the City of Pittsburgh open spandrel concrete arches. The bridge is named after General William Larimer was a prominent businessman in the Pittsburgh area in the mid 1800's. He eventually moved west, becoming one of the founders of the City of Denver.

According to the PAHBI (MEM Reviewer), ''The 1937, skewed, single span, 147' long and 52' wide, riveted, Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with wingwalls. The trusses are traditionally composed with built up box section upper chords and inclined end posts and rolled section for the web members. The original lattice railings remain in place. The bridge is neither historically nor technologically significant. It was built as part of the rebuilding effort following the devastating 1936 St. Patrick's Day flood when over 275 bridges, mostly in the western and central portions of Pennsylvania, were destroyed or damaged beyond repair. Following the flood, the department turned to established technologies like standard-design riveted steel truss bridges to replace lost spans.'' In 2010, PennDOT rehabilitated the bridge. Work included replacing the deck and repainting the bridge yellow-orange.

column16: Largest arch bridge in Lycoming County
column20: The 1938 US 220 Larrys Creek Bridge is the largest concrete arch bridge in the county. It has a main span of 90 feet. According to EPV from the PAHBI, ''The single span, 90'-long reinforced concrete closed spandrel deck arch bridge built in 1938 was widened in 1970. Concrete parapets with metal tube railings were constructed at that time.'' The bridge was widened as part of the creation of the Susquehanna Beltway to connect Williamsport with I-80. The bridge is on one of the only stretches of the beltway not upgraded to a limited access divided highway.

column2: Laurel Street / East Busway / Edgewood Avenue Bridge
column15: Concrete rigid frame (Laurel St & Edgewood Ave), haunched girder frame (East Busway & Norfolk Southern), deck girder (not in use)
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways / John F. Casey Co. Contractors
column20: The bridge consists of eight separate bridges built next to each other. Due to the uniform appearance the concrete rigid frame bridges at each end (Laurel St to the west, Edgewood Ave to the east) the structure looks to be one bridge. Five rigid frame haunched girder spans are to the west of Edgewood Ave, each built to carry one track of the Pennsylvania Railroad (now Norfolk Southern). The eastern two bridges now carry the Martin Luther King East Busway, which is a bus-only highway owned and operated by the Port Authority of Allegheny County. The steel deck girder span between Norfolk Southern and Laurel St was built to accommodate a sixth railroad track if needed. Laurel St has been closed to the south of the bridge. All original structures of the Penn Lincoln Parkway are considered to be historically significant, since the Parkway is an early example of a post-World War II urban highway.
This is a very rare regional example of a bascule pony truss. Tampa may replace the Laurel Street Bridge if funding becomes available.

column15: Pin-connected Pratt half-thru truss with stringer and thru girder approaches
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: A&P Roberts Co., Pencoyd Iron Works
column20: The Layton Bridge is the only National Register Listed bridge over the Youghiogheny River outside Allegheny County, PA. The bridge is noteworthy as a rare pin-connected half thru truss, in which the road runs through the middle of the bridge. The bridge is also unusual in that it runs directly into a tunnel. It was originally built for the Washington Run Railroad, which connected Layton to coal mines and coke ovens at Star Junction. In 1931 the line was abandoned, and the bridge was purchased by what is now PennDOT and converted to vehicular use. The bridge is one of the few National Register Listed bridges in the area still standing, though it is deteriorated and is slated for replacement.

The bridge is a rare example of a skewed concrete arch in which the five ribbed arches are ''stepped'' or offset from each other. The bridge is structurally deficient and is to be replaced. It is located near an Allegheny County Airport runway.

The Lee Avenue Bridge is a thru girder over Weirton Mittal Steel's railroad. Thru girders were often built as railroad overpasses, since they provide more clearance than deck girders. The bridge, which was open during a 2004 visit, was closed during a December 2007 visit. It is not clear if the bridge has reopened.

column15: Parker riveted with thru girder approaches
column20: According to the PAHBI (MEM Reviewer), ''The 5 span bridge consists of a 334'-8'' long Parker thru truss main span and 4 simply supported thru girder approach spans ((1 @ 81'-5'', 1 @ 80'-7'', 1 @ 67'-6'', 1 @ 63'-3''). The trusses are traditionally composed with built up members, and while the truss span is long, it has no innovative or distinctive details.''

The 1927 pony truss bridge was moved from Lowville in Erie County in 1990. According to the PAHBI, ''The Leesburg Road Bridge, a steel, riveted, 5 panel pony truss structure, is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls placed in 1990, as was the new concrete deck. The bridge was moved to its present location in 1990.''

The Leet Street Bridge is the second oldest thru truss bridge in Allegheny County (behind the southbound Smithfield Street Bridge). It was originally part of the Pittsburgh, Youngstown, and Ashtabula Railroad Bridge No. 20 in Lawrence Junction, PA, near New Castle. In 1904, the Pennsylvania Railroad moved the bridge to its current location to carry Leet Street over the mainline, where it was widened and re-erected by the Pittsburgh Steel Construction Co. The bridge is considered historically significant in the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Survey (1997) since is complete with the unusual Z section in the hip panel floorbeam hangers and bottom chords. This is a feature of early truss bridges by the Morse Bridge Co. of Youngstown, OH.

column2: Leger Road Bridge over Brush Creek
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI (MEM Reviewer), ''The 65' long and 15.8' wide reinforced concrete deck arch bridge was built in 1909 and is finished with paneled parapets and concrete wingwalls. Toe walls for scour protection have been placed. The bridge is one of the earliest complete examples of its technology in the region, and it is historically and technologically significant.''

column2: Leger Road Bridge over Norfolk Southern Railroad
column15: Warren riveted on trussed bents with girder approaches
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI (MEM Reviewer), ''The 3 simple span bridge consists of a 62' long riveted, Warren with verticals pony truss main span and 28' long built up deck girder approach spans. The substructure consists of ashlar abutments topped with concrete seats and built up 2 column bents. The truss is a standard PRR design composed of angles and plate. The design was used since the late 19th century. The bridge, which appears to be complete, is finished with three-high pipe railings with cast iron end posts. The stringers and deck are wood. The bridge is historically significant in association with the Pennsylvania RR main line. It is a complete example of their commonly used grade crossing elimination bridge of the period. American Bridge Co. fabricated many bridges for the railroad company.'' The bridge was closed to traffic around 2010 and is to be replaced.

column16: Last remaining double intersection Warren truss bridge in region; possibly eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Leonard Street Bridge is the last remaining double intersection Warren truss bridge in the entire region. The PAHBI did not evaluate the bridge, citing it to be in an inaccessible location. This is no longer the case, since a senior center was built near the bridge. The PAHBI evaluated a similar (now demolished) bridge as follows: ''The 1904, skewed, single span, 55'-long, rivet-connected, double intersection Warren pony truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments. The 6 panel, lightly built structure has built-up upper and lower chords, angle diagonals, and original outriggers. The double intersection Warren truss design is identified by two superimposed sets of equal sized diagonals, and it is a variation of the much more common (single intersection) Warren truss design, patented in 1848. The double-intersection Warren truss design was developed in the mid-19th century, and it enjoyed its greatest period of popularity from about 1895 to 1905 when advances in field pneumatic riveting led to a rapid shift from pinned to riveted (rigid) connections. This example, built by the New York Central RR, is historically and technologically significant as a complete example of the uncommon truss design. It documents the diversity of design that characterized the historical development of the metal truss bridge technology.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The single span, 80'-long reinforced concrete closed spandrel deck arch bridge is finished with W-beam guiderails on both sides. The plain bridge, built in 1911, is representative of the early application of the technology in the county in the 1910s.''

column15: Pratt pin-connected, half-hip; deck supported by load-bearing stringers
column20: The Lesher Road Bridge is an excellent example of a historic bridge rehabilitation in which a new load bearing structure was built inside the existing bridge. As a result, the old bridge still remains intact and the new bridge is capable of carrying unrestricted loading. According to the PAHBI, ''The bridge was rebuilt in 1997 with a steel stringer superstructure placed between the 1897 pin connected pony truss bridge, which remains in place. The new stringer carry the live loads while the trusses support themselves.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, was the last remaining pin-connected thru truss bridge in Indiana County
column18: Pittsburgh Bridge Company, Nelson & Buchanan Agents
column20: The Lewis Bridge was the last remaining pin-connected thru truss bridge in Indiana County. The bridge had all the characteristic features of a late 1800's Nelson & Buchanan truss bridge. The bridge was determined to be eligible for listing on the National Register of Historic Places as part of the Section 106 process in 1999. The bridge was not structurally deficient and scored a fair or better rating in all categories according to 2009 National Bridge Inventory data.

column15: Pratt deck cantilever; Pratt deck truss approach
column20: The Liberty Bridge connects the Liberty Tunnels to Crosstown Blvd (I-579) and downtown Pittsburgh. The Liberty Tunnels are some of the longest in the country, with a length of 5,889 feet. The Liberty Bridge has riveted connections, though the suspended spans are attached with pin connections. The bridge used to have architectural features such as concrete towers extending above the deck at the piers and decorative railings and lightposts. There was a landscaped traffic circle between the bridge and tunnel. Beauty ended up being sacrificed for safety and efficiency, since the traffic circle was removed and the deck was widened in the 1983 rehabilitation. As part of the widening, the decorative railings and lightposts were removed, and the concrete towers at the piers were cut off below the deck.
The Liberty Street Bridge is part of a 1960 realignment of PA Route 18. The former state-standard truss bridge is still in existence, as of 2011.

The Liberty Street Bridge is a rare rainbow arch bridge in the region, the only one that exists in several neighboring counties. There are no examples in the West Virginia panhandle or in western Pennsylvania. Thankfully the bridge was rehabilitated and restored in 2000.

While the Liberty Bridge on the north side of the Liberty Tunnels is well known, the bridge immediately to the south is almost unknown. In the 1980's rehabilitation, the original balustrades were replaced with safety shape barriers which run continuously through the tunnel. Therefore, motorists can hardly tell that they are crossing the bridge on the south end of the tunnel.

column15: Semicircular stone arch, concrete rigid frame parallel span
column20: In 1940, Liberty Way was realigned. An 85 foot rigid frame culvert was built from the old bridge to the south for the new alignment. The old bridge remains as a pull-off area.

column2: Library Road Bridge No. 1 Over Piney Fork Creek
column20: The stone arch bridge probably dates to around 1900, since the arch is made from stone instead of concrete. A sidewalk was added parallel to the bridge on the east side. Since the bridge spans less than 20 feet, it does not need to be inspected. It was probably built at a different year than the stone arch bridge about 1,000 feet to the north on Library Road, since this bridge has flat parapets.

column2: Library Road Bridge No. 2 Over Branch of Piney Fork Creek
column20: The stone arch bridge probably dates to around 1900, since the arch is made from stone instead of concrete. A sidewalk was added parallel to the bridge on the east side. Since the bridge spans less than 20 feet, it does not need to be inspected. The bridge was probably built at a different year than the stone arch bridge about 1,000 feet to the south on Library Road, since this bridge has curved parapets.

column18: City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works
column20: The Lincoln Avenue Bridge is the largest vehicular stone arch bridge in the region. Built in 1906, it predates the open spandrel concrete arch crossings. The bridge crosses under a thru girder span of the perpendicular 1903 Pennsylvania Railroad Brilliant Cutoff Viaduct. Silver Lake, a popular ice skating location, used to be below the corner of the intersecting bridges. The image of the lake and the bridges could be seen in many postcards. The lake eventually was replaced by a drive-in which is now a car wash. Only the bridges survive as a reminder of the once beautiful, park-like valley

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The bridge is eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, likely due to its association with the railroad.
The bridge is a state-standard example of a concrete tee beam. It is the only multiple span tee beam over the Stonycreek River.

The 1905 Lindsay Bridge is one of several remaining similar pony trusses. The comparable bridges are either three or four panels; the Lindsay Bridge is one of the longer four-panel designs. The bridge is attributed to the Nelson & Buchanan Company, which was responsible for the other bridges. The Nelson & Buchanan bridges are noteworthy for being early riveted pony truss bridges in which each panel has an X shape. The Lindsay Bridge sits on flared ashlar wingwalls that have been reinforced with additional concrete walls. The bridge has been better maintained than some of the other similar bridges.

The Linesville Spillway Bridge crosses a spillway channel in the Pymatuning Reservoir. Thousands of car are attracted to the area around the spillway. As a result, it is a popular tourist attraction to feed the fish, often from the sidewalk on this bridge. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1934, 40'-long, single span, T beam bridge has concrete balustrades and concrete abutments with flared wingwalls. Modern beam guiderails have been placed in front of the balustrades. The bridge was built to a state highway department standard design when the highway was relocated as a result of the development of the Pymatuning dam and reservoir. The bridge is not historically significant in association with the project. The 17,000 acre lake was developed by another state agency. The bridge is a standard design and is not a unique design developed for the project, and it is well north of the dam.''

From 1939 to early 2007, the Links Bridge carried Hookstown Grade Road over Raccoon Creek. It was a riveted Pratt thru truss with an extra diagonal member connecting the bottom chord with the midpoint of the diagonal endpost.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1-span, 29'-long brick arch bridge has stone spandrel walls and abutments. The bridge, which dates in style from ca. 1900, has lost its historic integrity because of removal of the parapets and upper portions of the spandrel walls. W-beam guiderails have been added with posts embedded in concrete curbs (ca. 1980). Better examples of early 20th century brick arch bridges have been identified in the county and region (50722104664004). The builder of this bridge is undocumented in state records.''

The Lisbon Bridge is one of the most significant historic bridges in the region. It is a large example of a Massillon Bridge Company bowstring truss arch. The bowstring truss arch is the oldest truss type. Nationally, very few remain. It is the predecessor to the modern tied arch bridge. While several companies built bowstring bridges, the Massillon Bridge Company's bridges were distinctive in that their arch was composed of trusses. The bridge used to span the Middle Fork Little Beaver Creek near where it currently sits. It was bypassed in 1966 by a stringer bridge (also shown on this website). Luckily, Columbiana County moved the bridge instead of demolishing it. However, the bridge is in danger because there is a tree lying on the arch. Hopefully Columbiana County will relocate and preserve this significant and rare bridge.

The Lisbon Street Bridge is a beautiful concrete elliptical arch. It features decorative balustrades and lampposts, decorations that on other concrete bridges are usually allowed to deteriorate until they are removed. The bridge also has a plaque to 'Red' Lloyd Householder, who was 'a friend to all passers-by, his gentle nod and friendly 'hello' will be forever in our memories.'
Due to traffic congestion, the bridge will either be widened or replaced. The bridge will either be widened to 6 lanes, widened to 8 lanes, or replaced by an 8 lane structure.
Due to traffic congestion, the bridge will either be widened or replaced. The bridge will either be widened to 6 lanes, widened to 8 lanes, or replaced by an 8 lane structure.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places; Feature of Casselman River Bridge State Park
column20: The National Road (Cumberland Road) was the first federally funded highway, built through northern Maryland in the early 1800's. It was an upgrade of Braddock's Road. The road needed to cross the Youghiogheny River and the smaller Casselman River (known then as Castleman's River or the Little Youghiogheny River). Two stone arch bridges were built: The Great Crossings Bridge (Youghiogheny) and the Little Crossings Bridge (Casselman). Construction began on the Little Crossings Bridge in 1813. With a main span of 80 feet and a height of 30 feet, it was America's longest-spanning stone arch bridge when it opened. Supposedly, the large arch was built to accommodate a potential C&O Canal extension to Pittsburgh that was never built. In the 1930's, much of the National Road (also known as the Cumberland Road) was widened and realigned. The Little Crossings Bridge was bypassed in 1933 by a Pratt truss on a realignment of the National Road. In the mid-1950's, the Little Crossings Bridge was restored. Maryland bought the land around the bridge and turned it into Casselman River Bridge State Park. This is an excellent example of Maryland preserving and promoting one of its most historic bridges.

column2: Little Deer Creek Valley Road Bridge
column20: The Little Deer Creek Road Bridge is one of only a few Allegheny County-designed multi-span rigid frame bridges. Dating from 1940, it is a late example of the type, which was introduced by Allegheny County Department of Public Works in 1929.

column16: Last remaining non-beam bridge over Loyalhanna Creek
column20: According to the PAHBI (MEM Reviewer), ''The 3 span, 216' long and 49' wide reinforced concrete deck arch bridge built in 1918 is finished with incised spandrel panels. The main span has 96'-long clear span, and the 2 flanking spans are each 50'-long. The original reticulated-pattern concrete balustrades were removed and replaced with steel railings in 1954.''

column2: Lone Pine Road Bridge Over Little Tenmile Creek
column20: According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, ''The skewed, 60'-long and 22' wide, single-span, reinforced concrete deck arch bridge was built in 1908. It is finished with plain spandrel walls and low parapets that are also atop the flared wingwalls. The spandrel walls are spalled, with significant loss of original fabric. The bridge is the earliest example of the technology in the county, but it is not among the earliest in the region and state. It is also very plain and has lost original fabric. Earlier, more architectonic, and complete examples represent the significance of the technology.''

column2: Lone Pine Road Bridge Over Redd Run
column20: According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, ''The single-span, 33'-long, concrete encased steel stringer bridge, built in 1930, is supported on a concrete substructure, and has standard design concrete balustrades and incised fasciae. Concrete encasement was favored in the state because it provided protection for the steel and eliminated the need to periodically paint the beams. A representative example of one of the most common mid-20th century bridge types and designs in the state, it has no innovative or distinguishing details.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: In 1793, the West Chamberlin Bridge (West Boston Bridge) was constructed at this location. The bridge was made famous by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow's 1845 poem, ''The Bridge.'' The bridge was rebuilt in 1854 and began to carry horsecar (streetcars pulled by horses) traffic 1856. By the late 1800's, the old bridge was overwhelmed by traffic congestion and newer electric streetcars. In 1894, legislation was passed authorizing the Boston Transit Commission, the new Cambridge Bridge (Longfellow Bridge), the Charlestown Bridge, and the Tremont Subway. The Cambridge Bridge Commission was organized in 1898 to design and build the bridge. The commission chose William Jackson as Chief Engineer and Edmund Wheelwright as Architect. They traveled to Europe to find inspiration for the new Cambridge Bridge by studying similar bridges. According to Massachusetts and War Department regulations, the new bridge had to either provide sufficient vertical clearance for navigation or be a moveable bridge. The Cambridge Bridge Commission successfully lobbied both agencies to permit the new bridge to be a stationary bridge, since a moveable span would not be consistent in appearance with the other stationary spans, and it would add to the cost of the bridge. Note the bridge was designed with towers flanking the center span, a design typically used in drawbridges. For moveable bridges, a tower provides an operations room for the bridge tender. The design of a stationary bridge set a precedent for all bridges upstream of the Longfellow Bridge. In choosing a steel arch bridge, the commissioners wrote that the bridge would ''furnish the eastern boundary of a great park system along 18 miles of river...destined to be the most beautiful park in the country. It is the present purpose, to make the new Cambridge Bridge one of the finest and most beautiful structures in the world.'' The towers are ornamented with granite sculptures to depict a hypothetical voyage of Leif Eriksson up the Charles River. The bridge is also decorated with the city seals of Boston and Cambridge. Construction began in 1900, the bridge was completed in 1906, and rail service began in 1912. It was renamed the Longfellow Bridge in 1927. In service for over 100 years, the bridge still stands as one of the longest steel arch bridges in America (in total length). The bridge is to receive its first major rehabilitation in 2012 - 2015.
Completed in 1968, the San Antonio River was extended as part of the construction of the Henry Gonzales Convention Center and the 1968 World's Fair. This bridge was built as a part of this extension.

On average, only 25 vehicles per day used the unimproved gravel road to cross the Lovers Leap Bridge. That might have been a high estimate. The PAHBI attributes the bridge to the Farris Engineering Company of Pittsburgh since it is similar to another bridge, a now-demolished SR 3003 bridge over the same creek. At the time of the PAHBI in 1997, the state was responsible for six old pony truss bridges in Fayette County. All were upgraded to modern beam bridges in under 10 years, leaving only County and Township bridges. On November 1, 2009, a propane truck driver disobeyed the 5 ton posting and crossed the Lovers Leap Bridge. Engineers post weight limits for good reason. Not surprisingly, the truck (as well as the bridge) ended up in the creek. It is possible the bridge will not be replaced.

The National Bridge Inventory dates the Lovi Road Bridge to 1930. Since it is unusual for a stone arch bridge to be built after World War I and before the New Deal, it is likely that the 1930 date is either an error or the date of a modification. The Lovi Road Bridge is one of only three stone arch bridges in Beaver County, not counting the Pennsylvania Avenue Bridge, which is officially a brick arch.

column15: Pin-connected braced eyebar chain suspension truss
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1988
column20: In 1890, a flood destroyed all the bridges in the English Center area, which was a regional logging and tanning center. Two replacement bridges were completed in 1891. Only the Lower Bridge survives. The bridge is an unusual suspension truss hybrid, possibly the only one like it in the entire country. It is also one of only a few short-span suspension bridges in the state. In a conventional suspension bridge design, the deck is stiffened by deck, pony, or thru trusses. Vertical suspender cables (or eyebars) connect the deck in tension with the main continuous cables or eyebar chains. In the design of the Lower Bridge, the web of the bridge is comprised of a pin-connected truss. Vertical members are built up compression members; the diagonal eyebars between the panels support the bridge in tension. The entire webbing acts as bracing, eliminating the need for the stiffening truss. With possibly no other bridges like it remaining anywhere, it is paramount that the bridge is preserved.

column15: Haunched continuous box girder (two parallel girders)
column20: Until the Lower Buffalo Bridge's opening in 1998, there was a gap of 32 miles between bridges over the Kanawha River. As part of infrastructure improvements for a new Toyota manufacturing plant, the Lower Buffalo Bridge was constructed. In that way, trucks could cross the bridge to take US 35 to WV 34 to get to I-64. To open for traffic in time for the completion of the Toyota plant, the entire design and construction timeframe was compressed to only 30 months. Components of the river span were erected on barges and hoisted to connect with the rest of the bridge. The bridge is noteworthy for being one of the longest continuous steel box girders in the country. When the bridge opened, the main span of 525 feet was the third longest comparable span in the United States.

column15: Burr arch truss, wooden covered bridge supported by steel stringers
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1980
column20: The Lower Humbert Bridge is an example of a Burr arch-truss. The bridge was rehabilitated in 1991 in which load-bearing steel beams and an intermediate pier were added. In 2006, someone detonated an explosive device on the bridge, causing minor damage. The Upper Humbert Bridge no longer exists.

Despite its location near the popular Ohiopyle State Park, few people know about the Lower Meadow Run Bridge. Of course, only 55 vehicles cross the bridge on an average day. The bridge is an example of a pin-connected Pratt pony in which the stringers are wooden. The original rectangular railings remain on the bridge.

The Lower Portage Road Bridge is an example of a riveted pony truss. The bridge was rebuilt in 1990 in which a new stringer bridge was built over the truss bridge. The trusses now function only as railings. The bridge exhibits a method of replacing the bridge while retaining its original appearance.

The bridge over Lower Twomile Run is an example of a semicircular stone arch. The build date is estimated to be around 1895, since other stone arch bridges were built around the same time in Venango County.

column15: Steel stringers supporting a Queenpost, wooden covered
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1979
column20: The Lyle Covered Bridge was originally a queen post truss built in 1887. As the bridge aged and loads increased, supports were added below the bridge at the ends of the panels, resulting in a three-span bridge. The main span became only 13 feet long. In 1998, a new steel stringer bridge was built to support the bridge, and the intermediate supports were removed.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, last pin-connected truss bridge in Forest County
column20: According to the PennDOT bridge marketing page, ''The Lynch Village Bridge is a 205-foot long, 19-foot wide, pin-connected single-span Parker Through Truss bridge that carries the two-lane SR 1003 (Blue Jay Road) over Tionesta Creek. The ten-panel truss design features four vertical posts on either side of a king post, reinforced by diagonal ties that slope toward the center of the bridge The Eyre Construction Company, a Philadelphia concern, originally fabricated the bridge in 1905 on another site. In 1946, an earlier truss bridge on the site collapsed under the weight of a heavy delivery truck. Rather than construct an entirely new structure, township and county officials worked with the state highway department to relocate the well-built Parker Through Truss Bridge to the site in 1948. The Parker Through Truss became widely popular just prior to the turn of the century, due to its reputation as a durable design for single span bridges over 200 feet in length. PENNDOT and the Pennsylvania Historical and Museum Commission agree that the bridge is eligible for inclusion on the National Register of Historic Places for its technological significance.''
There are plans to put a streetcar line on the bridge.
The bridge is illuminated at night with magenta lights by Brilliant Lighting Design. There are plans to put a streetcar line on the bridge.
The bridge is illuminated at night with magenta lights by Brilliant Lighting Design. There are plans to put a streetcar line on the bridge.

column15: Pennsylvania pin-connected, with a Parker pin-connected and deck girder approach spans
column16: Last remaining Pennsylvania truss over the Shenango River
column18: John Farris (Engineer), Thomas A. Gilkey (County Engineer), Independent Bridge Company (Contractor)
column20: The Mahoning Avenue Viaduct is an unusual skewed structure. The bridge has two curves, in which one truss endpost is inclined and the alternate endpost is vertical. According to the PAHBI, ''The 11-span, 1,195'-long, Mahoning Avenue Viaduct built in 1923 consists of 3, pin-connected, Pennsylvania truss main spans of 307', 306', and 227' lengths and 8 built up deck girder approach spans. The substructure consists of concrete abutments and piers with the approaches supported on steel bents on concrete pads. The cantilevered sidewalk is finished with a period metal railing. The bridge was built for the county and the state, and it was designed by Thomas Gilkey who did a great deal of bridge design work for Lawrence County. As a design preference, Mr. Gilkey used pinned connections for his truss bridges through the 1920s.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1918, 29'-long, reinforced concrete, closed spandrel arch low has capped parapet walls and concrete wingwalls. One wall is angled to provide clearance for a curved approach.''

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1918, 29'-long, reinforced concrete, closed spandrel arch low has capped parapet walls and concrete wingwalls. One wall is angled to provide clearance for a curved approach.''

column15: Pratt riveted with stringer approach span
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1918, 29'-long, reinforced concrete, closed spandrel arch low has capped parapet walls and concrete wingwalls. One wall is angled to provide clearance for a curved approach.''

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, M Bennett & Sons (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1918, 29'-long, reinforced concrete, closed spandrel arch low has capped parapet walls and concrete wingwalls. One wall is angled to provide clearance for a curved approach.''
According to the PAHBI, ''The 81'-long, single span, concrete deck arch bridge built in 1916 is finished with bush hammer spandrel panels and concrete flat paneled parapets.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The single span, 88'-long, rivet-connected Warren with verticals pony truss bridge built between 1907 and 1911 is supported on one stone abutment and one concrete abutment, placed ca. 1925. The truss has all built-up members of standard steel sections. Rolled floorbeams and stringers support a timber deck. Stock lattice railings are set to the interior faces of the trusses. The Warren truss type/design, patented in 1848, emerged as one of the most commonly used truss designs after 1895 because of advances in metallurgy and improvements in field pneumatic riveting. Over 125 examples from the late 1870s to 1950s have been identified in the state. This 1907-11 example has no noteworthy or unusual features or details. It is not an early or significant example of the work of the Penn Bridge Co., which was very active in the eastern United States from the 1870s to 1930s. Nor is it significant for its historic association with the 1895 state bridge act, a relatively ineffective law that provided funding for rebuilding county-owned bridges from 1895 to 1923.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1918, 29'-long, reinforced concrete, closed spandrel arch low has capped parapet walls and concrete wingwalls. One wall is angled to provide clearance for a curved approach.''

column16: Only example of its type in America
column18: Dr. Spiro Pollalis (Designer), DLZ Ohio (Project Manager), HNTB (Structural Design), Kokosing Construction Company (Contractor), Jansen & Spaans (Construction Engineer)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1918, 29'-long, reinforced concrete, closed spandrel arch low has capped parapet walls and concrete wingwalls. One wall is angled to provide clearance for a curved approach.''

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Fort Pitt Bridge Company (Fabricator)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1936, skewed, 2 span, 300'-long, riveted Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments and piers. In 1980 a number of verticals and diagonals had rusted areas removed and steel plate welded in their place. The bridge, built to a state highway department standard design, is an example of a common technology used since ca. 1895. It has no innovative or distinctive details. It was part of the rebuilding efforts following the devastating 1936 St. Patrick's Day flood when over 275 bridges were destroyed or damaged beyond repair. The bridge is neither historically nor technologically significant. Nor is the highway historically significant. Although now designated US 6, it was not a part of the original highway developed across Pennsylvania's northern tier. In the 1910s and 1920s it was part of SR 5, promoted as the Lakes to the Sea Highway, one of the many tourist trails in the state. Following the adoption of the federal numbering system in 1926 it was renumbered SR 19. Its was redesignated as part of US 6 following WW II.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The 52'-long closed spandrel concrete elliptical arch bridge, built in 1918, has a sidewalk cantilevered off one side supported on reinforced concrete brackets. Ca. 1985 its concrete parapets were removed and replaced with standard W-beam guiderail railings. The reinforced concrete deck arch gained popularity quickly in the 1900s and was used with great frequency in Pennsylvania on local and county roads in the 1910s.''

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: S. W. Bowen, Brenneke and Fay (Consulting Engineers); Hannan-Hickey Brothers Construction Company (General Contractor); Virginia Bridge and Iron Company (Steel Subcontractor)
column20: According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''The Main Street Viaduct was the first concrete arch bridge in the United States to employ self-supporting reinforcing steel. . . . The Main Street Viaduct was built to connect the Fort Worth CBD with the North Side, an area that had experienced explosive growth since the incorporation of the Town of North Fort Worth and the reorganization of the Fort Worth Stock Yards Company in 1902. The first bridge crossing the Trinity River at Main Street was a metal deck truss erected in 1889. This structure was replaced by a two-lane wire suspension bridge which proved to be inadequate to handle the increased traffic. The principal constraints facing Bowen in the design of the Main Street Viaduct were related to the unstable soil conditions of the site and to the unpredictable nature of the Trinity River. . . . The three-hinged arch was selected because it would not be strained by unequal settlement. Also, the three-hinged arch is a statically determinate form, meaning that stresses can be easily computed for design and secondary temperature stresses are eliminated. Ribbed construction was adopted because it is light and best adapted to the use of hinges, and also because no waterproofing would be required. . . . The Main Street Viaduct has been altered from its original construction by removal of the original railings. However, the basic structure of the bridge remains unchanged. As one of the oldest reinforced concrete viaducts in Texas, it remains an excellent example of early twentieth-century concrete bridge building practice, and continues to serve its original function as the main crossing of the Trinity River between the Fort Worth CBD and neighborhoods to the north.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Majorsville Road Bridge is a classic example of a pin-connected Pratt thru truss. The 1901 pin-connected bridge exhibits an unusual detail that reflects the transition to riveted truss bridges which was going on at the time the bridge was constructed. The built-up floorbeams are connected with pin plates, riveted to their outer edge. According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, "The bridge is historically and technologically significant because of its completeness, relative rareness of the type, date of construction, and non-standard detailing." However, state-owned bridges are aggressively being replaced with wider, modern structures, so it is likely the bridge will soon be demolished.

In 1955, US 290 (now I-35) was upgraded to a freeway though Austin, with two lanes in each direction. The road was only about 80 feet wide, including shoulders. Several rigid frame bridges were built over the freeway, including this one on Manor Road. I-35 soon became congested, and this section of road was widened in 1972. Since there was insufficient room to widen the road along the shoulders, northbound and southbound express lanes were built over the highway. As a result, this stretch of I-35 is an unusual three-level highway in which express lanes, frontage roads, and local lanes are all on different levels.

column15: Bascule (Warren pony riveted); pin-connected Parker main span
column16: Only pin-connected truss in county
column20: The bridge was built to carry Route 120 between Tracy and Stockton. As the road became busier, a twin span was constructed in 1949, and the bridge was converted to carry westbound traffic. When Interstate 5 was constructed in 1971, the bridge was returned to bi-directional use. A pedestrian bridge was later built parallel to the bridge. The Manthey Road Bridge is noteworthy for being one of the only pin-connected truss bridges in the region.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Maple Grove Road Bridge is the first bridge over the main body of the Casselman River. The historic bridge is the only concrete arch bridge over the main body of the river.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: By only one foot, the Maple Street Bridge has the second-longest concrete arch in Garrett County. The bridge maintains excellent historical integrity and is eligible for the National Register of Historic Places. It is attributed to the Luten Bridge Company since the style of the balustrade matches that of other Luten Bridge Company bridges, such as the Crellin Underwood Road Bridge. The bridge is near the similar Old Selbysport Road Bridge.

The Marble Falls Bridge is an example of a deck truss, a rare type in Texas. Since the bridge is a bottleneck, it is to be replaced by a dual bridges, accommodating two lanes of traffic in each direction. This is in contrast to the TX 71 Bridge over the Pedernales River in Travis County, in which the deck truss bridge was widened from two to four lanes by the addition of a steel multi-beam bridge for the southbound lanes.

column16: Only remaining deck truss bridge in Jefferson County
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 7 span, 727'-long viaduct built in 1937 is composed of 3, 173' long Pratt deck truss main spans. In 1984 the original T beam approach spans were replaced with 45' long adjacent box beam spans on new concrete column and cap beam bents. The floorbeams and deck of the main span was replaced, and it was widened with cantilevered deck sections.''

Marianna, Pa, was built in 1907 by the Pittsburgh Buffalo Company as a coal mining community. It was considered a model patch town, since nicer company homes and amenities were provided to the workers. This bridge was built for the railroad that served the mines at Marianna. The railroad was eventually abandoned, and the bridge was rehabilitated for vehicular use.

column15: Wire rope suspension with Warren through stiffening truss and double intersection Warren through approach
column20: According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''The 1929 Market Street Bridge, the fourth and grandest structure to cross the Susquehanna River at this location, reflects the evolution of Wilkes-Barre from an 18th-century agricultural settlement into a thriving metropolis built upon the coal industry. Anthracite fostered urban growth and prosperity, fueling significant early-20th-century civic improvements such as this new bridge. Architecturally, the monumental Beaux Arts-style bridge, designed by nationally prominent New York architects Carrere & Hastings, stands as a gateway to downtown Wilkes-Barre and as one of Pennsylvania's most outstanding concrete bridges.''

According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''The 1929 Market Street Bridge, the fourth and grandest structure to cross the Susquehanna River at this location, reflects the evolution of Wilkes-Barre from an 18th-century agricultural settlement into a thriving metropolis built upon the coal industry. Anthracite fostered urban growth and prosperity, fueling significant early-20th-century civic improvements such as this new bridge. Architecturally, the monumental Beaux Arts-style bridge, designed by nationally prominent New York architects Carrere & Hastings, stands as a gateway to downtown Wilkes-Barre and as one of Pennsylvania's most outstanding concrete bridges.''

column15: Open spandrel elliptical concrete arch with closed spandrel approaches
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1988; considered one of Pennsylvania's most outstanding concrete arch bridges
column18: Carrere & Hastings (Architect), Benjamin H. Davis & David A. Keefe, Walter S. Rae, Carol A. Benenson & Associates (Contractor)
column20: According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''The 1929 Market Street Bridge, the fourth and grandest structure to cross the Susquehanna River at this location, reflects the evolution of Wilkes-Barre from an 18th-century agricultural settlement into a thriving metropolis built upon the coal industry. Anthracite fostered urban growth and prosperity, fueling significant early-20th-century civic improvements such as this new bridge. Architecturally, the monumental Beaux Arts-style bridge, designed by nationally prominent New York architects Carrere & Hastings, stands as a gateway to downtown Wilkes-Barre and as one of Pennsylvania's most outstanding concrete bridges.''

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Clyde Thomson (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The skewed, 2 span, 322'-long, rivet-connected Pratt thru truss bridge built in 1938 is supported on concrete-capped ashlar abutments and an ashlar pier that appear to date to the previous bridge. The traditionally composed bridge has built-up upper and lower chords and rolled I-section verticals and diagonals. The concrete bridge deck and the bearings were replaced in 1994.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The one-span, 158'-long, rivet-connected Parker thru truss bridge built in 1933 has built-up chords, rolled section diagonals and verticals, cantilevered sidewalks with lattice railings, and concrete abutments with flared wingwalls. The concrete deck was replaced in 1981. The bridge is a late example of the Parker truss type, a variation of the Pratt truss with polygonal top chord, developed in the 1870s and patented by engineer Charles H. Parker. The truss type was adopted by the state highway department in the late 1920s as a standard design for long-span crossings.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: Milford Street used to be the main thoroughfare connecting Port Royal with the covered bridge over the Juniata River. As both vehicular and railroad traffic grew, a bridge was needed to carry the road over the Pennsylvania Railroad mainline. Since there was insufficient room to build ramps for the overpass at Milford Street, the bridge was built a block south at Market Street, with an inclined approach to connect the to roads on the east side of the railroad. When the covered bridge was replaced in 1937, the new bridge was built as an extension of the Market Street Overpass. According to the PAHBI, ''The bridge carries a 2 lane road and a sidewalk over 2 active railroad tracks of Conrail's/Amtrak's Pittsburgh-Philadelphia main line. The railroad is the historically significant PRR Main Line that has been determined eligible by PHMC (9/14/93). The bridge is located in Port Royal, in a mixed-use commercial and residential setting of 19th- and early 20th century buildings. The buildings in the immediate setting have significant alterations including replacement windows, enclosed porches, and the addition of modern storefronts and siding. The railroad station at the bridge's northwest quadrant has been lost. The bridge is the westernmost span in a viaduct that carries SR 75 over the railroad, First Street and the Juniata River. The slab, steel stringer, thru girder and Parker thru truss spans to the east of the arch were placed in 1937 by the state highway department as part of a project to replace a covered bridge, once located on an alignment approximately 250' north of the present crossing. The 1937 sections of the viaduct are not historically or technologically significant.... The one-span, 87'-long, reinforced concrete arch bridge is supported on concrete abutments with paneled pilasters at the corners. The bridge has concrete parapets and paneled spandrel walls to accent the arch. The date ''1910'' is inscribed at the crown. As part of the extension of the viaduct in 1937, the parapets and posts over the east wingwalls were removed. The arch bridge is historically significant in association with the PRR Main Line.
