It dates from a period when the PRR concentrated on eliminating dangerous at-grade crossings in cities and towns. The bridge is complete except for the loss of two sections of parapet over the east wingwalls. Although not individually distinguished, it contributes to the historic railroad line.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1890, pin connected, single span, 74'-long, Pratt pony truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with wingwalls. It is traditionally composed with built up upper chords, eye bar diagonals and lower chords, and back-to-back angles with laced web verticals. The bridge, one of three in the county fabricated by the Penn Bridge Company or its predecessor, stands out as an early, complete, and documented example of its type and design. It is historically and technologically significant.''

column15: Whipple (Double Intersection Pratt) with Pratt thru truss approaches
column18: Wrought Iron Bridge Company of Canton, Ohio
column20: Despite assurances that the 1882 Martha Bridge would be preserved next to its replacement, the historic bridge was demolished in 2008. The Martha Bridge was one of only a few remaining multiple-span Whipple truss bridges left in the country, with a total length of 470 feet. The bridge consisted of four thru truss spans, with two central Whipple spans and an approach Pratt span on each side. It was a classic Wrought Iron Bridge Company of Canton, Ohio, design. The bridge such a rare structure, it was listed on the WVDOH state historic bridge register and was eligible for the National Register of Historic Places. When the bridge was bypassed, the plan, approved by the SHPO, was to restore the old bridge and to create a riverside park at one end. However, later in the year the new bridge was completed, a local resident noticed that the deck of the bridge was being removed. WVDOH decided to demolish the structure without proper approval; the workers did not even have a valid contract. After a three-year battle with preservationists, WVDOH got their way and the irreplaceable bridge became just a memory. It is interesting to note that some nearby church members also advocated its replacement, claiming the bridge was an eyesore. Apparently members must not have liked the idea of having a riverside park and historic bridge for their picnics. However, according to the Huntington News Network, the church's construction plans near the site could be the real reason for the opposition to the bridge's preservation.

column2: Martin Luther King, Jr. East Busway Bridge over Dahlem Street
column20: The Pennsylvania Railroad (now Norfolk Southern) constructed three parallel closed spandrel concrete arch bridges in 1904 to carry the mainline over Dahlem Street in the East Liberty section of Pittsburgh. Separating the bridges were stairs that descended to Dahlem Street. In the late 1970's, the Port Authority of Allegheny County constructed the East Busway along part of the railroad right-of-way. The bridges were renovated in 1978 as part of the project. The railroad was moved to the northern structures and the busway was constructed on the southern structure. Steel stringers were added to fill in the gaps between the parallel bridges, and the stairways were removed. The bridge is noteworthy since it is the oldest reinforced concrete arch bridge in Allegheny County used by vehicles (buses).

The Martin Street Bridge is one of several San Antonio bridges built at the same time as the late 1920's flood control project. The south side of the bridge (pictured) was widened at an angle as part of construction of an adjacent office building.

The Marwin Drive Bridge is at an unusual location where it crosses a creek at the intersection of a straight county line. The 1960 girder replaced a previous truss bridge, reusing the abutments and piers. Since the girder spans are not as long, uncommon metal cylindrical piers were added halfway between the abutments and the center pier. Though this bridge has been at the site for about 50 years, it retains the look of a temporary bridge.

column16: One of the last remaining lattice girders in America, eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The single span, 47'-long, lattice thru girder bridge built in 1894 is supported on rubble stone abutments. The girders are composed of built-up sections for the upper and lower flanges and webs with rolled T-section and plate. The rolled floorbeams (ca. 1950) are set directly on the girder flanges. The bridge has rolled stringers and wood plank deck. Built-up girders, to make an I-beam section of sufficient depth to span greater distances than possible with the available rolled beams, were developed by the railroads in the late 1840s, and the technology proved to be the only serious competitor to the metal truss for railroad use in the 19th century. Taking advantage of the tensile strength of wrought iron and later steel, the built-up girder, which could be fabricated off site and easily transported and then hoisted into position, proved to be a boon to the railroads. Literally thousands of built-up deck and thru girder bridges were built for the railroads during the 19th and early 20th centuries, but surviving pre-1900 examples are not common. Some early examples have lattice webs rather than solid webs. The bridge is historically and technologically significant as among the earliest surviving examples of its type/design in Pennsylvania. The 1-lane bridge over a single active railroad track in a cut is closed to traffic. Woods are to all quadrants, although the area has scattered 19th to late 20th century buildings. The setting does not have the cohesiveness or integrity of a historic district. The rail line is the former Central RR of NJ main line from Easton to Wilkes-Barre, completed in 1866. The line was primarily an anthracite coal hauler.''

column15: Pennsylvania with Parker thru, Warren polygonal pony, and thru girder approaches
column18: Farris Engineering Company (designer), Independent Bridge Company (contractor)
column20: The Masontown Bridge is one of a diminishing number of large multi-span truss bridges in both the region and in the country. In 2000 there were seven thru truss bridges over the entire Monongahela River outside of Allegheny County (not counting the arched Speers-Belle Vernon Bridge). By 2011, only three will remain. This number will likely drop to one, the Old Brownsville Bridge, by the mid-2010's. The Masontown Bridge was supposed to be demolished in 2005, although the project was pushed back to the early 2010's due to lack of funding. With the Masontown Bridge project, PA Route 21 is to be widened and realigned (again), and a new four-lane bridge is to be built over the Monongahela River. Eventually this will permit a four-lane highway from PA 88 all the way to Uniontown. The new bridge is to be constructed in stages, with a two lane section to be built next to the existing bridge. Then the existing bridge will be demolished and the other two lanes of the new bridge built. According to the PAHBI, ''The 11 span, 1,458' long and 25' wide bridge is composed of three built up thru girder spans at each end, one 127' long Warren with verticals and polygonal top chord pony truss, three 187' long Parker thru truss spans and one 402' long Pennsylvania thru truss river span. The bridge is 25' wide. The truss members of the thru trusses are built up, and the upper panel point connections are riveted, but the intermediate connections of the Pennsylvania truss and the lower panel point connections throughout are pinned. The combination of connections is not common for 1925, but it is not technologically significant. The main span is long, but the bridge has no innovative details. It was designed by Farris Engineering Co. of Pittsburgh for Greene and Fayette counties. The firm was established in 1910, and their designs are not uncommon in the region.''

The Mauch Chunk Street Bridge is an example of a two-span segmental stone arch. The bridge was likely widened at some point. The Mauch Chunk Street Bridge was rehabilitated in 1997, in which the parapets were replaced.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Groton Bridge Company, Walker Brothers Contractor, Charleston, WV
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 8 panel, pin-connected, Pratt thru truss is supported on ashlar abutments with concrete capped flared wingwalls. The trusses are traditionally composed, but some uncommon details include the use of punched plate rather than eye bars for the lower chords and loop forged connections for the hip floor beam hangers and lower sway bracing. The bridge was fabricated by the Walker Brothers of Charleston, WVa in 1900, well after the standardization of the bridge type. It is historically and technologically significant as a complete example of a non-standard design pin connected truss bridge.''

column15: Pratt pin-connected with Pratt riveted pony approaches
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Pittsburg Bridge Company, Nelson & Buchanan Agents
column20: Many considered the Maxwell Run Bridge to be one of the finest historic bridges in the state prior to its 2004 demolition. The bridge featured two long pin-connected thru trusses from 1891 and riveted Pratt pony trusses from 1905 on each side of the thru trusses. It is not known why the pony trusses are newer. All spans are distinctive Nelson & Buchanan styles. The spans had excellent historic integrity. In 2004 the bridge was replaced at a cost of $2.1 million. The bridge was estimated to carry 80 cars per day. Therefore, the replacement bridge cost $26,250 per vehicle. According to the PAHBI, ''The 344'-long bridge consists of a pin connected, 2 span, Pratt thru truss main span and 1 riveted Pratt pony truss approach span at each end. The traditionally composed bridge is supported on ashlar abutments and ashlar cutwater piers. The bridge is historically and technologically significant as a complete example of an increasingly rare type and design. Adding to its significance is its documentation to the Pittsburgh Bridge Company and its agents, Nelson & Buchanan Company, regionally prominent and prolific fabricators of highway bridges in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.''
The Mayport Road Bridge is a state-standard steel stringer bridge. It was built on the substructure of the previous bridge from 1895.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1912, riveted, single span, 75'-long, Pratt pony truss bridge with the floor beams above the lower chords is supported on ashlar abutments with flared wingwalls. The 6 panel trusses have built up box section upper chords and toe-out angle lower chords and diagonals. Built to a standard design, the bridge has no innovative or distinctive details.''

These standard PA Department of Highways tee beam bridges are located at the location where the North Branch of Montour Run joins Montour Run. The separate bridges are connected by a triangular-shaped abutment. Therefore, they look like one two-span bridge on the south side and two separate bridges on the north side. Officially, they are two separate bridges.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, T. J. Foley (Contractor)
column20: The 1930 McClintock Bridge is an early example state-standard example of a Pratt thru truss. The portal bracing consists of just two x shapes, which is the least common state standard design. According to the PAHBI, '''The 1930, riveted, skewed, 2 span, 312'-long (2 @ 156'), Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls and a concrete pier. The trusses have built up upper and lower chords and rolled I section verticals and diagonals. Built to a state highway department standard design that was used with great frequency since in the mid 1920s, the bridge has no innovative or distinctive details. SR 8 traversed the west side of the state from Waynesburg (Greene County) to Erie, passing through Pittsburgh. One of more than a half dozen north-south, trans-state routes, its traffic was mostly local in nature.''

column15: Semicircular concrete (stone faced) arch with corrugated metal arch liner
column20: The stone-faced concrete arch bridge with a metal arch liner is one of a few similar arch bridges in Allegheny County's South Park. Many park bridges in Allegheny County were constructed in the late 1930's with Great Depression recovery funds.

column15: Howe truss supported by load-bearing steel stringers
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Rehabilitated by Frank B. Taylor Engineering
column20: In 1875, Thomas McConnell bought Daniel Kennedy's gristmill along Slippery Rock Creek. In 1875, the existing covered bridge was constructed just downstream of the mill. The mill closed in 1928, and the property was conveyed to the Western Pennsylvania Conservancy in 1942. In 1957, McConnells Mill State Park was dedicated. The covered bridge is an example of a Howe truss, a transitional structure composed of wooden compression members and metal tension members. In 1998 the bridge was rehabilitated, and load-bearing stringers were installed beneath the deck. According to the National Register of Historic Places nomination, ''The McConnell's Mill Bridge is another of the less commonly used trussing systems. Built in 1874, the McConnell's Mill Bridge used the Howe truss developed and patented by William Howe in 1840. Only four bridges suing the Howe truss exist in Pennsylvania today.''

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Johnson Drake & Piper (Contractor)
column20: The McConnells Mills Bridge is an uncommon example of a single-span haunched stringer bridge. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1949, single-span, 99'-long built up, haunched steel stringer bridge is supported on concrete abutments and has concrete balustrades with Art Moderne-style endposts.'' Dating from 1949, it is an early example of a state-designed grade separation bridge. The bridge's replacement project starts in the summer of 2010 and ends in 2011.

column18: The Ohio Bridge Company (U.S. Bridge Company)
column20: The McCormick Run Road Bridge is a modern welded Warren polygonal truss built by The Ohio Bridge Corporation. It is constructed out of weathering steel.

column15: Warren riveted with deck girder main and approach spans
column20: The 962-foot long McDonald Viaduct is the Montour Trail's longest bridge. On July 1, 1913, the Pennsylvania Railroad granted the Montour Railroad the overhead crossing rights above its Panhandle Division Railroad. The Warren thru truss span was used to carry the Montour Railroad over the Panhandle due to greater ground clearances for the truss as opposed to a deck girder. In World War II the bridge was thought to be crucial for the transport of coal into Pittsburgh. Meanwhile, if it was blown up, it could interfere with Panhandle Division traffic below. Therefore the bridge was illuminated at night and even guarded. Interestingly, both railroads are not in use today. In 2003, the viaduct was converted to carry the Montour Trail.

column15: Burr arch truss on load-bearing wooden stringers
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, last remaining covered bridge on the West Branch Susquehanna River
column20: According to the National Register of Historic Places nomination form, ''The McGees Mills Covered Bridge is a single span of 109', with horizontal siding, a shingle covered gable roof, and cut stone abutments. Interior has been encased with protective wooden walls. Floor boards are narrow, horizontally laid. Eave level windows as well as two centrally placed, square windows are present. The Susquehanna River watershed once had the most covered bridges in Pa. At one time, 30 covered bridges crossed the main Susquehanna River itself but they as well as many on the West Branch, the North Branch, and the Juniata River are now gone. The West Branch of the Susquehanna starts far to the west and passes through five counties before joining the main river. At one time six covered bridges crossed the West Branch at Clearfield, Lock Haven, Williamsport, Muncy, Lewisburg and McGee's Mills. Today only the McGee's Mills Bridge remains. Several smaller covered bridges crossing small streams still remain in the five counties the West Branch passes through. However the McGee's Mill Bridge is the only remaining covered bridge in Clearfield County today as well as being the last covered bridge spanning the West Branch itself. The village of McGee's Mill began with the settlement of James McGee in 1826 and the erection of a gristmill and sawmill. Bell Township remains basically agricultural to the present. The McGee's Mill covered bridge continues to serve this rural agricultural community as transportation across the West Branch of the Susquehanna.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The 1908 McGrath Highway Bridge is a rare example of a skewed camelback truss with three truss lines. The bridge consists of built-up, V-laced members. Though the Boston area used to have many thru truss bridges over railroads, the McGrath Highway Bridge and the nearby Cross Street Bridge are the only ones left.

In 2005, the fascia beam of the Lakeview Drive Bridge collapsed over Interstate 70. The bridge was an example of a concrete adjacent box beam with a bituminous deck. The bituminous deck allowed water to pass through, which eventually entered the box beam causing the rebar to rust. Several similar concrete box beam overpasses were replaced as a precaution; the McIlvane Road was one of the last to remain. In 2010, the bridge was struck by an overheight truck, and subsequently demolished. The bridge was similar to the now-demolished overpass adjacent to the Wright Covered Bridge.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 2002; Only example of type in Texas
column18: J. M. Nagle (City Engineer), J. G. McKenzie (Bridge Engineer), L. C. Wagner (Assistant Engineer), Don Hall Constructor, Inc. (Contractor)
column20: According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''Spanning Buffalo Bayou in Houston Texas, the carnival-colored McKee Street Bridge is one of the few examples of a structure in which cantilever and anchor members form a true continuous girder. The bridge is also distinguished by cantilevered concrete sidewalks and steel picket and pipe railings, highlighted by a ''ring'' motif - a common decorative feature of the 1930s.'' According to FrostTownHistoricSite.org, ''The unique design of the McKee Street Bridge was a response to the challenge of creating a bridge that could provide adequate clearance for small craft navigating Buffalo Bayou. The sharp angle of the bayou at this location created an additional obstacle in building a bridge. After considering several spanning technologies, city bridge engineer, J.G. McKenzie utilized a continuous through-girder configuration. The selected design provided adequate horizontal clearance with a 120' span over the main channel of the bayou. To compensate for the angle of the crossing, the bridge was build on a skew with the piers and abutments laid out with their downstream footings offset by arranging the floor beams over the supports at perpendicular angles. The unusual appearance of the bridge is a result of designing the girders to follow the calculated bending moment curve. The two curves that rise as waves above the roadway represent the reverse curve created by the intersection of two simple parabolas at a point of tangency 15' out from the center of each support.''

column18: Allegheny County, Vernon Covell, George S. Richardson, Fort Pitt Bridge Works
column20: The McKees Rocks Bridge refers to a string of structures almost 1.5 miles in length connecting PA 51 to PA 65 over the Ohio River Valley and parts of McKees Rocks. The ''McKees Rocks Bottoms'' area is a former island in the Ohio River, in which the former back channel is above river level and thus no longer carries water (though the railroads built their lines through the former channel). The section of the bridge over the old island is built up on terra firma with rigid frame underpasses. The bridge over Helen Street is one such underpass.

column18: Allegheny County, Vernon Covell, George S. Richardson, Fort Pitt Bridge Works
column20: The McKees Rocks Bridge refers to a string of structures almost 1.5 miles in length connecting PA 51 to PA 65 over the Ohio River Valley and parts of McKees Rocks. The ''McKees Rocks Bottoms'' area is a former island in the Ohio River, in which the former back channel is above river level and thus no longer carries water. The railroads built their lines through the former channel, thus separating ''The Island.'' The section of the bridge over the old island is built up on terra firma with rigid frame underpasses. Officially, the portion of the bridge from PA 65 over the Ohio to the start of the terra firma is a separate bridge. The monumental two-hinged thru arch was designed by Allegheny County to be a replica of New York's Hell Gate Bridge. The Hell Gate Bridge was designed by Gustav Lindenthal, engineer of the Smithfield St. Bridge, and was the largest bridge entirely built of Carnegie Steel at the time. The approach spans for the replica McKees Rocks Bridge include spandrel-braced arches and deck Warren trusses.

column18: Allegheny County, Vernon Covell, George S. Richardson, Fort Pitt Bridge Works
column20: The McKees Rocks Bridge refers to a string of structures almost 1.5 miles in length connecting PA 51 to PA 65 over the Ohio River Valley and parts of McKees Rocks. The ''McKees Rocks Bottoms'' area is a former island in the Ohio River, in which the former back channel is above river level and thus no longer carries water (though the railroads built their lines through the former channel). The section of the bridge over the old island is built up on terra firma with rigid frame underpasses. The southern arches are over the railroad (the former back channel). The crescent thru arches are similar only to the Jerome Street Bridge over the Youghiogheny River, though the arches do not extend below the deck.

The McKeesport Duquesne Bridge is one of only three remaining active pin-connected truss bridges over the Monongahela River, originally built as a vehicular bridge. From north to south, the bridge consists of the following spans: 62' deck girder, 196' Pratt thru, 194' Pratt thru, 382' Parker thru, 382' Parker thru, 382' Parker thru, 250' Pratt thru, 199' Pratt thru, and 205' Pratt thru. The trusses are pin-connected. The first truss span and northern end of the second truss spans are skewed.

column18: Allegheny County, Charles Davis, King Bridge Company
column20: Under the direction of Charles Davis, many stone arch bridges were erected in Allegheny County around 1900. In some cases, however, thru girders with stone abutments were erected. It is not known what prompted thru girders to be built. It is likely that the thru girder was cheaper to build than the arch. Girders also allow a larger volume of water to flow under the bridge, so possibly they were built over shallower channels with a greater chance of flooding. The McLaughlin Run Road Bridge is an excellent example of an Allegheny County thru girder. Due to deterioration, the bridge was replaced in 2011.

column16: Highest vehicular bridge in Cambria and Somerset counties, longest vehicular bridge in Somerset County
column20: The McNally Bridge is a continuous deck girder that carries US 219 high over the Stonycreek River. The 1,388 foot long bridge is the tallest vehicular bridge in either Cambria or Somerset counties and is the longest in Somerset County.

column15: Whipple pin-connected with riveted Baltimore supplemental trusses
column16: Rare surviving iron Whipple thru truss with Keystone Columns; Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Penn Bridge Works (Penn Bridge Company) (1872 bridge), Rodgers Brothers Co (1912 bridge)
column20: The Mead Avenue Bridge is one of the most significant bridges in the entire state of Pennsylvania. It is considered by many to be nationally significant. The bridge consists of a two 1872 cast and wrought iron Whipple trusses built with Keystone Columns supplemented by two 1912 Baltimore trusses. In 1907, the Northwestern Pennsylvania Trolley Company began running street cars across the bridge. It soon became apparent that the bridge was not strong enough to carry the trolley cars, and temporary wooden supports were added. These supports had to be removed each winter and reinstalled each spring. As a permanent solution, the trolley company and the county commissioners agreed to split the cost of a new bridge in 1911. It was to be a three-span concrete arch, though the Meadville Chamber of Commerce wanted an 'impressive' 200 foot single-span arch. As the debate dragged on, the court eventually decided that the Chamber of Commerce could no longer continue an injunction to hold construction. The next day, the local newspaper ran an article about a similar concrete bridge that cracked a short time after construction and needed to be replaced. As a result, public opinion swayed away from building a concrete bridge at all. John Dick, president of the committee of city businessmen, suggested that for 10 percent of the cost of a new structure, the existing bridge could be strengthened. Not wanting to let this opportunity pass up, the commissioners and the trolley company agreed on this solution, and work began shortly thereafter. Installation of the trusses took less than a week and was completed in January of 1912. This solution had the unintended benefit of retaining what has become one of the oldest through truss bridges in America! It its modified form, the bridge carried traffic until its closure in 2007. The bridge is to be demolished sometime around 2012 or 2013. The majority of the community supports demolition, though many outside groups are promoting its preservation. According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''Mead Avenue, formerly Dock Street, bears the unusual distinction of having two bridges on the same site at one time. Grafted to the original double-intersection Whipple truss built by Penn Bridge Works, external Baltimore trusses help this 1872 structure carry modern traffic loads. This compromise, born of economizing impulse and public turmoil, has allowed the bridge a longer life than might otherwise have been possible.'' The bridge is definitely one to visit prior to its demolition. Retaining its 1872 look, the bridge takes you back to the long lost days of Whipple trusses, Keystone Columns and vertical endposts, decades before bridges were designed for automobiles!

column15: Open spandrel concrete arch with steel deck supports
column18: City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works
column20: The Meadow Street Bridge was one of several City of Pittsburgh open spandrel concrete arch bridges with ornate classical architectural details. The entire bridge except for the arch ribs was demolished in 1962, replaced by a new steel deck and deck support system.

According to the PAHBI, ''The one span, 64'-long, riveted, Warren with polygonal top chords pony truss bridge built in 1913 is supported on concrete abutments. There are parapets atop the wingwalls at the approaches. The trusses are traditionally composed, and bolts were used for the field connections. Rolled floorbeams support stringers and a concrete jack arch deck. It is not known if the deck is original. The original lattice railings are inside the truss lines. . . . Stylistically it appears to be the product of the Owego Bridge Company, which is documented to have used the shaped gusset plates at the upper panel points.''

column18: Chaney Engineering Company, Colonial Construction Company
column20: In the 1910's and 1920's, Chaney & Armstrong, Engineers (later Chaney Engineering Company) built about 15 concrete arch bridges in Washington County. The Meadowcroft Road Bridge, one of these bridges, has plain spandrel walls and incised paneled parapets. The Meadowcroft Road Bridge is one of the larger examples. Due to the bridge's narrow width and spalling arch, it is to be replaced.

column18: The Ohio Bridge Company (U.S. Bridge Company)
column20: The Mechanicstown Road Bridge replaced a 1917 bridge over the Norfolk Southern Railroad (formerly the Penn Central Railroad). The new bridge is a welded Warren truss from the Ohio Bridge Corporation. The new bridge is a less common camelback.

column18: Design of rehabilitation by AECOM in 2009 - 2010
column20: The Memorial Bridge was built in 1952 as a realignment and Connellsville bypass of US 119, the road that connects Uniontown and Greensburg. It is an early post-World War II example of a continuous deck girder with spans over 150 feet. The bridge was rehabilitated in 2009 - 2011.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The 1940 Memorial Drive Bridge is an example of a steel thru girder, built as a grade separation to handle increasing traffic volumes along the enlarged Memorial Drive at the Boston University Bridge intersection. The bridge is faced with brick and topped with stone coping, and it has decorative brick pylons with crests.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Mercer Pike Bridge is a rare surviving thru truss from the Morse Bridge Company. Mercer Pike is an old alignment of US 19, connecting Mercer with Meadville. According to the PAHBI, ''The single-span, 83'-long and 17' wide, pin-connected, Pratt through truss bridge built in 1888 is supported on concrete abutments that were reportedly rebuilt in 1938 and 1944. The solid web portal braces has an ''MBC'' cypher in them, but research failed to identify the name of the fabricator. The floor beams have been replaced, and there are minor repairs to the truss members, but otherwise the bridge appears to be complete and a historically and technologically significant example of the important technology.''

The Mercer Street Bridge is an example of a county-owned state-standard truss bridge. Mercer Street (Mercer Pike) is the old alignment of US 19, connecting Mercer with Meadville. In 1953, US 19 was realigned with a new, larger French Creek crossing, and the Mercer Street Bridge was turned back over to Crawford County. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1936, riveted, single span, 221'-long, Parker thru truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with flared, stepped wingwalls. Built to a state highway department standard design, the bridge is an example of a common technology with no innovative or distinctive details. It was part of the rebuilding efforts following the devastating 1936 St. Patrick's Day flood. Over 275 bridges, mostly in the western and central portions of Pennsylvania, were destroyed or damaged beyond repair. To replace them the department turned to established technologies like riveted metal truss bridges, which had been used in the state since about 1900.'' The bridge was repainted dark blue in 2004.

The Mercer Street Extension Bridge previously carried Mercer Street Extension over Connoquenessing Creek. Connoquenessing Creek is the largest body of water in Butler County. The land on the west side of the bridge was purchased by the Indian Brave Campground (IBC). It appears the campground purchased the bridge as well, since the bridge is fenced off with a No Trespassing on IBC Property sign. In the mid 1990's, there were at least five public owned truss bridges over the Connoquenessing Creek in Butler County and three in neighboring Beaver County (where the large creek flows into the Beaver River). All eight were replaced by the mid 2000's. Due to private ownership, the Mercer Street Extension Bridge is the last remaining truss over the creek in Butler County.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1955, single span, 47'-long steel stringer bridge is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls. In 1975 the bridge received a new open grid steel deck and structure mounted guiderail railings.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Metz Road Bridge crosses the Venango / Clarion county line. According to the PAHBI, ''The one span, 40' long rusticated ashlar stone arch bridge with a high rise was built in 1910, and it is finished with pipe railings set in the stone curbs. The bridge appears to be complete, including its crisp mortar joints. It is a short and late example of it technology, but it is one of only three stone arch bridges in the district, and it is a fine example of high quality late-19th and early 20th century masonry. The bridge is historically significant.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 46'-long and 16' wide, reinforced concrete deck arch bridge built in 1912 has plain concrete parapets and spandrel walls. The parapets continue over the flared wingwalls. The spalling at the arch ring has resulted in the loss of original fabric. The reinforced concrete deck arch bridge gained popularity quickly after 1905. Somerset County used the technology frequently starting after 1907, and there are over 20 extant examples. . . . While not the earliest example, this bridge is a well-preserved example of the type with local significance as the work of a prolific county engineer.''

The bridge was built as part of the 1951 Western Extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike. All mainline vehicular overpasses were either thru girders or deck girders in the extension. The bridge will be replaced as part of the Turnpike widening, which will happen sometime after 2010. The Middle Road Bridge is an example of the Turnpike's thru girder design.
The Middle Street Bridge is an unremarkable concrete slab bridge located on a local street in Homesworth, Ohio.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Whitaker & Diehl (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The bridge carries a 2-lane highway and sidewalk over the Juniata River between the towns of Mifflin and Mifflintown. A potential Mifflin commercial historic district has been identified by PHMC (DOE 3/27/90), but no exact boundaries or period of significance are established by the available information in the file. The bridge would not be within the district's boundaries, which would extend no further east than the street fronting the river adjacent to the bridge's southwest quadrant and to the 19th-century residence at its northwest quadrant. The west end of the bridge in Mifflintown is adjacent to a parking lot at its southeastern quadrant and a brick vernacular residence (1833) at its northeastern quadrant. Mifflintown is the county seat. The courthouse and square are located two blocks east of the bridge. The area surrounding the courthouse is dominated by mid-19th to early 20th century brick commercial and civic buildings. It appears to have historic district potential. Further research would be needed to establish the potential Mifflintown district's significance and boundaries. It may include the residence at the bridge's northeast quadrant, but it would not extend to the bridge or parking lot to its southeast.... The 690'-long, steel, Parker thru truss bridge, built in 1936, is composed of four equal spans of approximately 172.5' long each. The trusses are rivet-connected and composed of standard steel members, including built-up chords and rolled-beam verticals and diagonals. The bridge is supported on concrete piers and stone abutments. A sidewalk is cantilevered off of the north side of the bridge. The concrete deck was replaced in 1972, but no other major alterations are noted. The Parker truss design dates to the 1870s and is a variation of the Pratt with a polygonal top chord. The design was used by the state highway department throughout the early to mid-20th-century as an economical alternative to other long span bridge types and designs.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1880, pin connected, single span, 80'-long, Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with flared wingwalls. The bridge has a number of distinctive details associated with the builder, the Wrought Iron Bridge Company, including diagonals with four-prong ends and cast guide blocks at the hip panels. The bridge is historically and technologically significant as a complete, early example of a pin connected, metal truss bridge. Adding to the significance is its association with the Wrought Iron Bridge Company, a prominent fabricator of metal truss bridges.'' According to www.mercercotrussbridges.com, ''The Pratt Through Truss bridge has a number of distinctive details associated with the builder, the Wrought Iron Bridge Company of Canton, Ohio, including cast guide blocks at the lower chords of the hip panels. This bridge is slated to be removed. The Wrought Iron Bridge Company was organized in 1866 and incorporated in 1871 by David Hammond, a carpenter-turned-bridge builder. The company ''immediately took its place in the forefront of the country's bridge builders,'' manufacturing and distributing an impressive variety of metal bridges, including bowstring trusses and an assortment of single and multiple intersection trusses, girder, and swing bridges, most from patented designs. Its 1874 Designs of Wrought Iron Bridges contained articles on the strength, durability, resistance to corrosion, and working loads for iron bridges. The company, with agents spread across the nation, built bridges throughout the continental United States. By 1880, it had purportedly built more highway bridges than any other bridge company in the country. A large company with a capacity of approximately 10,000 tons per year, it was absorbed into the American Bridge Company in 1901.''

The Milesburg Bridge is an example of an early state standard Parker thru truss. The bridge exhibits portal bracing composed of angles, a feature only used on ca. 1930 state standard bridges. The design was revised by the early 1930's with taller portal bracing with built-up members. According to the PAHBI (JPH Reviewer), ''The one-span, 138'-long, riveted Parker thru truss bridge built in 1930 is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls. The bridge has built-up upper and lower chords and rolled beam verticals and diagonals. The cantilevered sidewalks are finished with decorative lattice railings. The deck was replaced with a concrete-filled steel deck in 1982. Some welded repairs were made at the time including plates welded to the webs of the verticals at the lower panel points.''

column16: Possibly Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Milford Bridge is an unusual pin-connected Pratt pony truss. The built up members have V-lacing on the top face, as well as the bottom. The diagonal members penetrate the top chord and are bolted to the top, like horizontal bracing of some truss bridges. Typically, diagonal members are connected at the pins. Furthermore, the bridge has outriggers with star-shaped rods, comparable to older bowstring trusses. If you plan to visit the bridge, note that it is located on private property. Do not walk up to the bridge without permission from the landowner. The picture used on this site was taken from the nearby public road.

column2: Military Order of the Purple Heart Bridge (Bridgeport Bridge)
column20: This is the girder bridge that replaced the historic Wheeling and Belmont Bridge. Unlike the old bridge, the replacement has no unique or distinguishing features.

According to the PAHBI, ''The single span, 108'-long, rivet-connected Warren with verticals pony truss bridge built between 1907 and 1911 is supported on stone abutments. The 10 panel truss has built-up members of standard steel sections. Rolled floorbeams and stringers support a timber deck. Stock lattice railings are set to the interior faces of the trusses. The Warren truss type/design, patented in 1848, emerged as one of the most commonly used truss designs after 1895 because of advances in metallurgy and improvements in field pneumatic riveting. Over 125 examples from the late 1870s to 1950s have been identified in the state. This 1907-11 example has no noteworthy or unusual features or details. It is not an early or significant example of the work of the Penn Bridge Co., which was very active in the eastern United States from the 1870s to 1930s. Nor is it significant for its historic association with the 1895 state bridge act, a relatively ineffective law that provided funding for rebuilding county-owned bridges from 1895 to 1923.''

column2: Mill Mountain Road Nescopeck Creek Bridge
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The single span, 63'-long, pin connected, wrought iron, Pratt pony truss bridge is supported on stone abutments. The bridge is composed of built-up sections for the compression members, and eye bars and rods for the tension members. It has an uncommon double pin connection at the end post-upper chord connections, and an unusual adjustable eye bolt detail at the hip vertical-lower chord connection. Both details are associated with the Penn Bridge Co. of Beaver Falls, one of the earliest and most prolific metal truss bridge fabricators in Pennsylvania. The bridge is an early example of its type/design with proprietary details by an important in-state fabricator. It has minor alterations, such as strengthening of one of the end posts with a welded box section sleeve, but these have not had a significant impact on the over all integrity of original design. The bridge is historically and technologically significant.'' Luzerne County, recognizing the historic nature of the bridge, rehabilitated the bridge in-house in late 2010. According to the Luzerne County Reporter, ''County Engineer Joe Gibbons said the bridge was recommended for closure through the federal bridge inspection process because the structure's floor system was deteriorating. Gibbons, assistant county engineer Chris Belleman and county bridge foreman Kenneth McDaniels examined the bridge and designed a new floor system replicating the one used when the bridge was built about 100 years ago, Gibbons said. If the county had opted to tear down the old bridge, the new one would have to be two lanes and cost an estimated $1.5 million due to federal design requirements, Gibbons said. Because the county was repairing an existing bridge, the single-lane structure could remain, he said. The steel needed for the repairs was bid out and cost about $30,000, and the county spent another $5,000 on other materials, Gibbons said. The county road and bridge crew ripped out the old flooring and installed the new material in sections while making other repairs, Gibbons said.''

column2: Mill Mountain Road Nescopeck Creek Tributary Bridge

column16: Oldest surviving truss bridge in Mercer County (as of 2010), Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1885, single span, 82'-long, Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with flared wingwalls. The traditionally composed trusses have built up box section upper chords, channels with lacing verticals, and eye bar lower chords and diagonals. The bridge is historically and technologically significant as a complete, early example of a pin connected, metal thru truss bridge. The bridge is one of the two oldest surviving truss bridges in the county [The older bridge, the Milburn Road Bridge, was demolished in 2007]. Adding to its significance is its association with the Penn Bridge Company, a prolific regional fabricator of metal truss bridges.''

column2: Mill Road Little Valley Creek Bridge
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Nathan R. Rambo, Co. (Engineer); P. J. McCormick & Sons (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The one-span, 30'-long stone arch bridge, built 1912, has voussoirs with keystone, fieldstone spandrel walls, and parapets with slate coping. It is supported on stone abutments. The intrados is pargetted and the bridge has grapevine repointing. It is a short and undistinguished example of a bridge type that is common from the first two decades of the 20th century in Chester County. The county-built traditional stone arch bridges were favored by the county engineer, and at least 19 similar bridges from 1908 to 1919 have been identified. Stone arch bridges have been in use in Pennsylvania since the late 17th century, and over 350 examples have been identified statewide, with more than two-thirds dating to before 1900.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Denithorne Brothers, Phoenixville, PA; Wrought Iron Bridge Company?
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The one-span, 37'-long, wrought-iron, pony truss bridge built in 1882 is supported on stone abutments. The bridge has built-up upper chords and verticals, and eye bar lower chords and diagonals. Cast-iron connecting pieces are used at the end post-upper chord connections, but all other connections are pinned. U-shaped hangers support built-up fishbelly floorbeams. Channel railings (ca. 1950) are welded to the inside of the truss lines. U-shaped stone wingwalls with parapets enclose the approach roadways. The wingwalls have been repaired and buttressed by concrete walls faced with stone (1997). The bridge is an early and complete example of its type and design with uncommon cast-iron connecting piece details. These type of cast-iron connections were used during a period of transition from the all cast- and wrought-iron truss bridges of the mid-19th century, to the all pin-connected truss bridges of the late 1880s and 1890s. Surviving examples with the cast-iron connecting pieces are rare. The bridge was built by Denithorne Brothers, a leading fabricator of metal truss highway bridges in the county and region. It is the oldest of ten identified Denithorne-built bridges in Chester County from 1882 to 1905.''

The Mill Run Bridge is an example of a state-standard Parker truss. Note the portal-bracing composed of angles, typical of only the bridges built in 1930. It is the only state-standard truss or single-span Parker truss bridge in Fayette County.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Mill Street Bridge is the old alignment of Route 88 crossing the former PRR Monongahela Railroad (now Norfolk Southern). The bridge, a Warren pony truss, is a standard Pennsylvania Railroad design for railroad crossings. This design consists of Warren trusses composed of back-to-back angles. Gusset plates for the connections are placed between the angles. The design has been used by the railroad since at least 1897. According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, ''This example is complete, and it is historically significant in association with the Monongahela Railway, which PHMC has determined to be a historic district.'' The bridge is also noteworthy for its skew.

The Mill Street Bridge was a rare pin-connected Parker truss over the Shenango River in Sharon, Pennsylvania. The design of the Parker truss was unusual, since the top chord was inclined only at the ends and flat in the center. The bridge was abandoned in the mid 1900's when the factory on the east side of the river expanded over the former road. The bridge was demolished around 2008.

column2: Mill Street Bridge (American Veterans Memorial Bridge)
column20: The Mill Street Bridge is an unusual skewed truss bridge in which one endpost is diagonal and the opposite is vertical. According to the PAHBI, ''The one-span, 221'-long and 36' wide, pin connected Parker thru truss bridge built in 1917 is supported on ashlar abutments. The bridge is skewed on one side only. The trusses are traditionally composed of built up members and eye bars for the verticals and lower chords. There are bolted and welded repairs to various members. The cantilevered sidewalks are finished with period metal railings.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The 1888 Miller Farm Road Bridge is one of the oldest bridges in Venango County. Located in Oil Creek State Park, it was built during the peak of the first oil boom in the world in the late 1880's. In 1865, the world's first oil pipeline was constructed from the short-lived oil boomtown of Pithole to Miller's Farm along Oil Creek. The Miller Farm area became an important point where the oil could be shipped along Oil Creek to the Allegheny River. Today the area around the bridge is undeveloped, with a few miles of unpaved road leading to the bridge. These factors led to the bridge being repaired in 2000. A plaque reads, ''Through cooperative efforts of Venango County, PennDOT District 1-5, and Oil Creek State Park Maintenance Crew this 112-year old landmark was restored - October 2000.'' As of the bridge's 2007 inspection, it is not classified as structurally deficient. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1888, pin connected, single span, 154'-long, Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with flared wingwalls. The traditionally composed trusses have built up upper chords and verticals. The lower chords and diagonals are eye bars are historically and technologically significant as an early example of its technology (Criterion C). One of 16 surviving pin connected truss bridges in Venango County, the bridge stands out as a complete example of its type and design. Adding to its significance is the documentation to the Massillon Bridge Company of Massillon Ohio, a regional fabricator of metal truss bridges. The bridge is historically and technologically significant.'' Despite the bridge's relatively good condition and historical significance, it is now scheduled for replacement.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The 1887 Miller Station Bridge is a rare example of a wrought iron Whipple (double intersection Pratt) truss bridge. The bridge has been listed on the National Register of Historic Places since 1988. The bridge is not a typical Wrought Iron Bridge Company Whipple truss. The portals feature ornate iron work. While the ends of the top chord project over the ends of the diagonal endposts like a Penn Bridge Company Bridge, only one pin is used at that connection (unlike the Penn bridges that have two). Despite the bridge's historic significance, it is to be replaced in 2011 or 2012. The bridge is advertised for relocation as part of PennDOT's Bridge Marketing Program.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Bethlehem Steel Fabricating and Erection Division
column20: The Millville Road Bridge from 1930 is an early example of a state-standard Parker truss bridge. According to the PAHBI, ''The single span, 166'-long riveted Parker thru truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls. The truss members are built-up sections. The concrete safety shape barriers were placed in 1977.''
The bridge is the only girder bridge built to cross an Interstate in Allegheny County that is haunched over two piers. The entire low chord is curved, which is uncommon in such a bridge.
The Miner Slough Bridge is an early example of a thru truss in which all members are rolled H-section steel beams.

The Mingo Junction Wabash Railroad Bridge is one of America's most significant railroad bridges (which is why it is one of the few railroad bridges to be on this website). In the early 1900's, the Wabash-Pittsburg Terminal Railroad was built by Jay Gould to compete with the Pennsylvania Railroad. To reach Pittsburgh, two similar cantilever bridges were built over the Ohio and Monongahela rivers. According to a New York Times article from 1901, they were the two longest-spanning cantilever bridges in America (behind only the Firth of Fourth Bridge in Scotland). The bridge in Pittsburgh had a main span of 812 feet and the one at Mingo Junction, 700 feet. The bridge in Pittsburgh was demolished in 1948. It was prominent in many old postcards and photographs of Pittsburgh. Few people know, however, that its sister bridge still survives in Mingo Junction!

The Moffett Mill Road Bridge was a Beaver County-designed Pratt thru truss. It was built on the abutments of the previous 1875 bridge. The only comparable remaining Beaver County-designed thru truss, the Links Bridge, was demolished in 2007. The Moffett Mill Road Bridge became deteriorated, failing inspection and being closed to traffic November 2007. The bridge was demolished in 2011, with the new structure to be completed in 2012.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Mohr Road Bridge is one of two similar riveted Parker pony truss bridges in Greene County, though the other one is scheduled for replacement. The Mohr Road Bridge, at only 40 feet, is the shortest of the three. The trusses come up only to the lattice railing. According to the National Bridge Inventory, the Mohr Road Bridge was built in 1904, about 10 years before the other two comparable bridges. If the 1904 date is correct, the bridge is an early example of a riveted truss. However, it is possible the date is incorrect and should be 1914. The bridge is attributed to the Penn Bridge Company, which built the similar Rudolph Run Bridge.

The Monaca-East Rochester Bridge is one of the few major river crossings in Western Pennsylvania to be built in the 1950's. It was originally a toll bridge, although it became a free bridge in 1973. The bridge is unusual because the towers of the cantilever are relatively short. Compare the proportions to that of the Ambridge-Aliquippa Bridge or the Sewickley Bridge (in Allegheny County). The Monaca East Rochester was painted silver (aluminum paint) until its 1993 rehabilitation.

column15: Continuous haunched deck girder; steel stringer approach spans
column20: The bridge consists of three parallel girders. The approach spans are steel stringers. The bridge replaced the previous 1910 three-span Pennsylvania thru truss, built by the Fort Pitt Bridge works. When the bridge was built, it was one of the longest-spanning girder bridges in the country.

column2: Monongahela Connecting Railroad Bridge (Hot Metal Street Bridge)
column15: Pennsylvania, Parker, Pratt, and deck Pratt approaches
column20: The Monongahela Connecting Railroad Bridge is often incorrectly called the Hot Metal Bridge, since the other bridge sharing the piers actually carried hot metal. The bridge was converted to vehicular use in 2000, and the northern Pratt through truss span was removed. Decorative lighting was added to the portals on June 12, 2008 and ''turned on'' by Governor Ed Rendell. The lighting project was made possible through the work Pittsburgh History and Landmarks Foundation and other sponsors. The bridge is a rare pin-connected truss over a navigable waterway.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1-span, 34'-long brick arch bridge has fieldstone spandrel walls and parapets. Two sections of stone parapet have been lost and replaced with concrete. The spandrel walls and parapets have been inappropriately pargetted and repointed. The builder and date of construction are undocumented by available township records, but the bridge dates by style to ca. 1890. Brick arch highway bridges date primarily in the last quarter of the 19th century, and are not a common highway bridge type in Pennsylvania. This example, one of approximately 25 identified, has lost integrity of original design due to the pargetted and repaired spandrel walls and parapets.''

column18: Wrought Iron Bridge Company of Canton, Ohio
column20: Around 1960, Montour Park Road was widened and realigned (now called Montour Run Road), cutting into the hillside to remain along the west side of Montour Run. The old alignment crossed the Montour Railroad (now Montour Trail) and then Montour Run, continuing to the north on the east side of the stream to meet with Beaver Grade Road. The old alignment and bridge has long been abandoned. The bridge is long-forgotten, since there are not even bridge closed signs or barricades to prevent bridge access (though there are rotted holes in the wooden deck). Though the bridge lacks plaques, there are interesting decorative eight-pointed stars on the floorbeams that can be used to indentify the builder. A Wrought Iron Bridge Company (WIBC) bowstring in Iowa from 1873 and a WIBC Pratt pony in Michigan with a plaque giving an 1874 patent date contain similar decorations. If this bridge was built in the early to mid 1870's, then it is the oldest truss bridge in Allegheny County and one of the oldest in all of Western Pennsylvania. Adding to its significance is its association with a prolific bridge company. The bridge has an unusual end post / top chord connection. It looks to be a repair of the original WIBC connection.

column2: Montour Trail Bridge Near Montour Park Road
column20: The Montour Railroad was organized in 1877 to connect the Imperial Coal Company with Montour Junction along the Ohio River. The railroad was realigned in the early 1920's, with most bridges dating from 1926 by the McClintic Marshall Company. This is one of many of these similar bridges. The Montour Trail was abandoned by 1986. Three years later the Montour Trail Council was organized, and the alignment has since been converted to carry the Montour Trail.

column2: Montour Trail Bridge Over Beagle Club Road
column20: The Montour Railroad was organized in 1877 to connect the Imperial Coal Company with Montour Junction along the Ohio River. The railroad was extended to the south in 1912 through 1917 to reach additional coal mines. The bridge over Beagle Club Road was built for this expansion. The Montour line was abandoned by 1986. Three years later the Montour Trail Council was organized, and the alignment and bridge have since been converted to carry the Montour Trail.

column2: Montour Trail Bridge Over Donaldson Road
column20: The Montour Railroad was organized in 1877 to connect the Imperial Coal Company with Montour Junction along the Ohio River. The railroad was extended to the south in 1912 through 1917 to reach additional coal mines. The bridge over Donaldson Road was built for this expansion. The Montour line was abandoned by 1986. Three years later the Montour Trail Council was organized, and the alignment and bridge have since been converted to carry the Montour Trail.

The 1931 Montoursville Bridge is a three-span state-standard Parker truss. The bridge was rehabilitated in 1994, and it is not structurally deficient. With a sufficiency rating of 81.8%, the bridge is an excellent example of a well-maintained truss bridge.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: In 1935, a devastating flood destroyed the Montropolis Bridge. The 1938 replacement is a state-standard Parker through truss. The historic bridge is one of the largest truss bridges in the region, consisting of five truss spans. In 1963 a new bridge was built to the east to carry northbound US 183 traffic, and the 1938 bridge was converted to carry southbound traffic. In 1994, a new alignment of US 183 was built to bypass Austin. A new high-speed southbound bridge was constructed, and the 1938 bridge was converted to serve as the southbound frontage road. Construction also began on a northbound high-speed bridge. Plans apparently changed, and the northbound bridge was never completed. The piers still exist, with no beams resting on them.

column2: Moores Crossing Bridge (Old Congress Avenue Bridge)
column15: Whipple pin-connected with a riveted Pratt pony approach span
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: C. Q. Horton, King Iron Bridge Company, rebuilt by the Austin Bridge Company
column20: Moore's Crossing Bridge is one of the longest Whipple truss bridges in America. According to the Texas Historical Commission plaque, ''This structure was originally part of a six-span bridge across the Colorado River at Congress Avenue in Austin. Constructed there in 1884, it was designed by the King Iron Bridge and Manufacturing Co. of Cleveland, Ohio. In 1910 it was dismantled and placed in storage. Five years later three spans were rebuilt here by destroyed the same year in a flood. The current bridge, comprised of the remaining spans, was completed in 1922.'' The northern riveted Pratt pony truss dates from the reconstruction in 1922.

The Morganza Road Bridge, with a main span of 90 feet, is one of the largest concrete arch bridges in Washington County. The bridge has plain spandrel walls. It was rehabilitated in 1983, and the original parapets were replaced with concrete barrier. It is likely the bridge was built by the Chaney Engineering Company, since most concrete arch bridges in Washington County built around the same time were built by that company. Later examples such as this bridge have plain spandrel walls.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1935, skewed, 3 span, 160'-long bridge has an 88' long riveted Warren with verticals pony truss main span and deck girder approach spans (1 @ 32', 1 @ 36') supported on concrete abutments and battered concrete columns. The heavy trusses have no innovative or distinctive details.''

The bridge was determined to be eligible for listing in the National Register of Historic Places, since it was an early example of a thru girder with a cantilevered (drop-in) main span. The drop-in span had shiplap connections. This construction allowed the main span to be among the longest in the state when the bridge opened. The bridge was also historically significant for its association with the Pennsylvania Railroad mainline. It was replaced by twin bridges, increasing traffic capacity in the area.
This bridge was built as an approach span over a railroad to the historically significant Mosside Boulevard Bridge. It was replaced by a concrete culvert beneath fill underneath the bridge.
The Mostoller Bridge is a state-standard example of a multi-beam bridge.

Moundsville Bridge is a tied arch bridge with a main span of 912 feet, the longest tied arch span in all of Ohio, West Virginia, and Pennsylvania. The bridge opened in 1986 and is the first bridge on the site. Moundsville is named after Grave Creek Mound, an Adena Native American burial mound, which is the largest conical mound in the United States.

column16: Austin Landmark
column20: The Mount Bonnell Road Bridge is an example of a riveted polygonal Warren truss. Instead of replacing the bridge, the city's new 1995 beam bridge was built next to the historic truss bridge. The bridge was restored and converted for pedestrian use. The bridge serves as an excellent example of historic preservation.

According to the PAHBI, ''The two-span, 278'-long, steel Pratt through truss bridge, built in 1924, consists of two identical 8-panel spans. It was determined not eligible as a result of the Section 106 consultation process.'' The bridge possibly designed by county engineer Thomas Gilkey, though it could also have been an early state design.
The Mount Jackson Road Bridge is a typical example of a modern steel beam bridge.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1940 skewed, one-span, 190'-long, riveted Pratt through truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls. The trusses are traditionally composed with rolled section web members, and there are no innovative or distinctive details. The original lattice traffic railings remain in place.'' The bridge has a plaque dedicated to the memory of Scott Wilson and Anthony Murdick, two firefighters from Unionville who laid down their lives in the line of duty on April 8, 2001.
The Mt Davis Road Bridge represents a state-standard concrete tee beam bridge.

The Mt Storm Bridge is the last bridge over the Stony River. It is a 1930's state-standard example of a Pratt thru truss. Though this type was built frequently in the 1930's, few still remain, especially in the region. The last similar bridge in Tucker County (to the west) was demolished in 2007. There are no similar bridges in Mineral County (to the east). With the planned demolition of the Bayard Bridge, the Mt Storm Bridge will be the last historic truss bridge in the region! (At least until it is also demolished).

In the early 1800's, the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania built the Pennsylvania Canal to connect Pittsburgh and Philadelphia and to compete with the Erie Canal and the C&O Canal. Since it was not practical to construct a canal over the Allegheny Mountain, the original Portage Railroad was built. It was a 36 mile mule and horse pulled railroad, which operated from 1834 to 1854. In ten locations, canal boat carrying rail cars were pulled up and down the mountains by steam-powered inclined planes. The Pennsylvania Canal became obsolete soon after construction, with the advent of the steam-powered locomotive. In 1854, the Pennsylvania Railroad was completed, connecting Johnstown and Altoona. To compete with the railroad, the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania constructed a replacement for the Portage Railroad, bypassing the inclines. The New Portage Railroad was completed in 1856 and sold to the Pennsylvania Railroad in 1857. The Pennsylvania Railroad became famous for the large U-shaped Horseshoe Curve alignment up the side of the Allegheny Mountain. The New Portage Railroad had a much smaller comparable curve, therefore called the Mule Shoe Curve. While the Pennsylvania Railroad initially abandoned the New Portage Railroad, the segment from Gallitzin to Hollidaysburg was brought back into service in 1904. Some sources state the bridge was built in 1902 for the Pennsylvania Railroad. The line was used until the 1960's. Today the Mule Shoe Bridge is abandoned. Some of the old alignment is a rail trail.

The Murray Avenue Bridge is one of only three large frame bridges in Allegheny County. It replaced one of Pittsburgh's grand open spandrel concrete arches, built ca. 1910. The railing sculptures and plaques were saved from the original bridge and placed at the intersection of PA 8 and PA 130 along the Allegheny River.

The Nallen Bridge was an ornate 2-span concrete arch. Given its location in the center of Nallen, it was most likely originally constructed to carry US 19 across the Elk River. A new US 19 bridge (a girder) was constructed to the south. The old bridge was abandoned, and deteriorated until it was removed around 2006.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1988; Association for Bridge Construction and Design, Susquehanna Chapter Award, Best Rehabilitated Bridge, 2007
column18: Pittsburgh Construction Company, rehabilitated by Gannett Fleming
column20: According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''The bridge is an early example of a concrete arch bridge built on a curving, skewed alignment. This open-spandrel reinforced concrete bridge is the most recent of several at this important crossing, which was on the Bedford-Chambersburg Turnpike before it became part of the Lincoln Highway in 1916.'' By the late 1990's, the bridge suffered from severe concrete spalling. It was also too narrow to accommodate two lanes in each direction of US 30. Rather than replace the historic bridge, a new concrete multi-beam bridge was built to carry eastbound traffic in 2005. The historic bridge was rehabilitated and converted to carry westbound traffic. During the rehabilitation project, the deck and spandrel columns were replaced. Only the arch ribs and the substructure were retained. The rehabilitation and widening project is an excellent example of a historic bridge rehabilitation.
The abutments of the Nashua Road Bridge date from 1878. The current steel beams were placed in 1981 when the original superstructure was removed.

column2: National Road Bridge over Branch of Buffalo Creek
column20: In 1929, a new wider, straighter alignment of the National Road was built. This alignment involved the bypass of the original S-bridge over a branch of Buffalo Creek. The newer 1929 bridge is an example of a state-standard concrete tee beam. Due to deterioration, the original state-standard balustrade was replaced by a solid concrete parapet on the northern side (pictured). The entire bridge was replaced in 2009. The adjacent historic S-bridge has been turned into a park.

column18: The Terrell Bartlett Engineers, D. D. Harrigan (City Engineer), Elder Construction Company (Concrete), Virginia Bridge & Iron Company (Steel)
column20: The Navarro Street North Bridge is one of a few similar Warren polygonal pony trusses in San Antonio. The bridges are unusual in that while the ends of the truss are inclined, the center section has a flat top chord. The bridge also retains its original decorative lampposts on both ends.

The Navarro Street South Bridge is the only concrete arch over the downtown section of the San Antonio River. The bridge is noteworthy for its architectural features such as ornamental concrete designs and patterns, decorative balustrades, and ornate lampposts.

column16: To be the last remaining truss bridge in Forest County (around 2015)
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Ortale Construction Company of Pittsburgh
column20: Nebraska was a logging town along the banks of Tionesta Creek. After the 1936 St. Patrick's Day Flood caused widespread damage throughout Pennsylvania, Flood Control Acts of 1936 and 1938 were enacted authorizing the construction of flood control dams. In 1940, the Tionesta Dam was completed four miles downstream from Nebraska. Since the bridge and town were in the impoundment area for the lake, the town was razed. The bridge remains, though it is flooded for much of the year. The bridge was rehabilitated in 1999 in which the deck was replaced and the sidewalk was removed. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1933, riveted, single span, 187'-long, Parker thru truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls. The trusses have built up upper and lower chords and rolled section verticals and diagonals. A portion of the sidewalk has been lost, and its lattice railing has been significantly damaged. The bridge, built to a state highway department standard design used with great frequency since the mid 1920s, has no innovative or distinctive details.''

column15: Wooden covered Queenpost on load-bearing steel stringers
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Neddie Woods Covered Bridge was built in 1889 and retrofitted with load-bearing steel stringers in 1979. The bridge was named after Edward (Neddie) Wood, a Civil War veteran and owner of the land around the bridge. The bridge was extensively rehabilitated in 2005, in which much of the original wood was replaced. As with all remaining covered bridges, the bridge is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. Greene County sells puzzles of some of their covered bridges, including this one. Note that the description of the bridge is incorrect; it is NOT the oldest bridge remaining in Greene County. A few iron bridges are older.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Neff Bridge is a historically significant Pratt truss bridge on Alexandria Pike, the old alignment of US 22. The bridge dates from 1899, exhibiting the distinctive details of a bridge built by the Pittsburg Bridge Company, Nelson & Buchanan Agents. Despite a superstructure condition rating of critical (2 out of 9) and a deck and substructure condition rating of serious (3 of 9), the bridge is scheduled to be rehabilitated. The repaired historic bridge will serve the area for many years to come!

column16: Third longest bridge in use in the Florida Keys, longest concrete multi-beam example
column20: After the completion of the Overseas Highway in 1938, the Florida Keys began to experience rapid population growth and development. By the 1960's, it was apparent that the converted railroad bridges were too narrow to handle the volume of traffic they experienced. Furthermore, the converted railroad bridges lacked shoulders. As a result, the Florida Department of Transportation decided to replace all of the bridges, starting with the Bahia Honda Bridge. The old Bahia Honda Bridge was the most dangerous, since the road, built over thru trusses, had a vertical curve in the middle of the bridge. The dual replacement bridges were wide concrete multi-beam bridges, each with two lanes plus shoulders. Due to the high cost of such a bridge, later replacements (such as the Seven Mile Bridge and the Long Key Bridge) were single-lane concrete segmental girders with narrow shoulders. The new Bahia Honda Bridge is the only example of a concrete multi-beam longer than a mile, and it is the third longest active bridge in the Keys.

column16: Fourth longest bridge in use in the Florida Keys
column20: The Channel No. 5 Bridge is one of three large concrete segmental bridges in the Florida Keys, and the fourth longest in use. The precast, post-tensioned box girder design was used since it was cheaper than traditional concrete beam designs.

The New Davis Bridge is a weathering steel deck girder, similar to many other historic bridge replacement structures in West Virginia. Note the simulated stonework along the abutment and parapet. Many new bridges incorporate architectural features as such in an attempt to add decoration to make up for the loss of the old bridge.

The New Dundon Bridge replaced the Dundon Truss Bridge in 2008. It is a common example of a weathering steel continuous deck girder. Most historic bridges are replaced with bridges such as these. The New Dundon Bridge is the longest bridge in all of Clay County.

column16: Last remaining pin-connected pony truss bridge in Huntingdon County
column20: The New Fording Bridge was rehabilitated around 2007. As such, the County's only pin-connected pony truss will serve the area for years to come. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1889, single span, 63'-long, Pratt pony truss bridge with the floor beams above the lower chords is supported on ashlar abutments with concrete wingwalls. The light trusses have laced webs rather than built up box sections at the inclined end posts and end panels of the upper chords. The bridge is one of three pin connected trusses in the county dating to 1889. The other two, which are more complete, have been listed in the National Register (31 7220 0373 3009) or determined eligible by PHMC (31 4005 0120 0000). This example is altered (original diagonal and two counters have been removed and replaced with steel cable in 1978).''

This bridge is the replacement for the historic 1882 Martha Bridge. It is a common weathering steel deck girder. Across the country (as well as the world), the historic bridges are being demolished and replaced with bridges such as this one.

The McClaren Bridge was a 1901 half-hip pin-connected Pratt pony truss. According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, ''The inclined end posts and outside panels of the upper chords are channels with laced webs. The interior panels have cover plate. The verticals are back to back angles with a lattice web, and the diagonals and lower chords are small sized eye bars. The built up floor beams are placed above the lower chord and riveted to the sides of the verticals.'' The bridge was replaced in 2000 with a prefabricated welded Warren polygonal pony truss. This is a standard type of bridge from the U.S. Bridge Company of Ohio. The silver finish indicates the bridge is galvanized.

column18: Eagle Bridge Company of Sidney, Ohio (Contractor)
column20: The $4.1 million, 271 foot-long haunched deck girder was built to replace the historic Orange Avenue Bridge. The bridge features context sensitive solutions such as stamped concrete (to simulate masonry) since it is replacing a historic bridge. Interestingly, though built at a comparable elevation, the bridge is almost 100 feet longer than its predecessor. It is located 200 feet north of the existing bridge, and will tie in with OH 315 and Carriage Road with a roundabout.

column2: New Point Marion Cheat River Bridge
column20: The New Point Marion Cheat River Bridge replaced a 1908 camelback truss built by the Penn Bridge Company. The new bridge uses cylindrical piers. In that way the piers can be rotated so the top is perpendicular to the skewed deck without affecting the hydraulic performance of the Cheat River. The new bridge is built on a skewed alignment to eliminate a sharp bend at the end of the old bridge.

The New River Gorge Bridge is one of the most famous and impressive bridges in North America. An image of it is seen by millions of people daily, as it depicted on the back of the West Virginia quarter. The 1,700 foot arch was the largest in the world when completed and is still the largest in the Western Hemisphere. The 876 foot high bridge is the tallest in the Western Hemisphere that carries an expressway. It is second only to the Royal Gorge Bridge of 1,118 feet which was built as a tourist attraction. The next large arch to be completed is the Hoover Dam Bypass Bridge. Some sources say the bridge will be 840 feet high, others say it will be 890 feet high. Therefore, the Hoover Dam Bypass Bridge may eclipse the New River Gorge Bridge as the highest vehicular bridge in America.

column16: Longest segmental bridge in the world when completed, longest bridge in use in the Florida Keys
column20: The Seven Mile Bridge is the longest bridge in use in the Florida Keys. The original Seven Mile Bridge was longer, though it is now discontinuous since short intermediate sections have been removed. The new bridge opened on May 24, 1982 as final US 1 bridge to be replaced in the keys, just as the old bridge was the final railroad bridge to be completed. The new bridge was the longest segmental bridge in the world when completed. It has a vertical curve to give boaters a clearance of 65 feet. This is the highest road elevation in all of the keys. Several movies have been filmed on the bridge. The bridge is closed for traffic for 2.5 hours on one Saturday each April to allow runners to cross the bridge. According to FIGG's website, ''At the time of its completion in 1982, Seven Mile Bridge (35,867' long) in the Florida Keys was the longest continuous concrete segmental bridge in the world. The bridge utilizes a precast, post-tensioned box girder superstructure and hollow precast segmental piers, which increased the speed of erection. The structure was completed six months ahead of schedule and has earned eight awards, including an Exceptional Award for Cost Savings Innovation from the Federal Highway Administration. The bridge's 264 spans carry the Overseas Highway. FIGG's segmental alternate saved $7 million when bid against an alternate design.''

column15: Semicircular stone arch with brick fascia arch rings and corrugated steel arch liners
column20: The New Somerset Road Bridge is a late example of a stone arch from 1935 that has a corrugated steel arch liner. A few 1930's stone arches in Allegheny County, Pennsylvania, also have the liners. This was a cheaper and easier way to build a stone arch bridge. The New Somerset Road Bridge has brick fascia arch rings, enhancing the appearance of the bridge. It is likely the bridge was built with WPA or other New Deal funds.

column2: New York Central Railroad Clarks Mills Bridge
