column20: The bridge carried a branch of the New York Central Railroad, which primarily hauled coal and manufactured goods. The bridge is long abandoned, and the right of way is used as an unofficial trail.

column2: New York Central Railroad Little Shenango River Bridge West of Hadley
column20: The bridge carried a branch of the New York Central Railroad, which primarily hauled coal and manufactured goods. The bridge is long abandoned, and the right of way is used as an unofficial trail. It is a less common example of a small pinned railroad thru truss.

column15: Wire rope suspension with a double intersection Warren stiffening truss
column20: The Newell Bridge, built in 1905, is among the oldest bridges over the Ohio River. The first bridge to be built, the 1849 Wheeling Suspension Bridge, was a suspension. So was the next one, the 1866 Roebling Suspension Bridge in Cincinnati. Many of the succeeding vehicular bridges over the Ohio River also were suspension bridges. The next oldest bridges that remain in existence are the 1904 Market Street Bridge (located 25 miles south of the Newell Bridge) and the 1905 Newell Bridge. They are also 3rd and 4th oldest among any type over the Ohio River. Both are also significant for being two of the oldest all-steel suspension bridges. There is, however, an important distinction between the two bridges. The privately owned Newell Bridge is still a toll bridge, one of only two left over the Ohio River in West Virginia or Ohio. As such, it has been constantly maintained and still retains its original appearance. The Market Street Bridge has had some significant alterations, such as the replacement of the stiffening truss. Thanks to private ownership, the Newell Bridge remains a fine example of our transportation heritage.

column16: Last remaining thru truss in Perry County
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 4-span, 691'-long thru truss bridge built in 1934 to a standard state highway department design has typical mid-20th-century details such as built-up upper and lower chords, rolled steel beam verticals and diagonals, and riveted connections. It is supported on concrete abutments and piers. The cantilevered sidewalk has standard metal railings. In 1966 the original concrete deck was replaced by an open steel grid deck. The rivet-connected Parker truss bridge was adopted by the state highway department as a standard in the 1920s. The department turned to the well-established technology of riveted steel truss bridges, which had been in use since the 1890s, because truss bridges offered an economic alternative to other long-span bridge types.'' The bridge is the last remaining thru truss bridge in Perry County.

A 2118 foot long bridge with nine thru truss spans must certainly cross a river, right? Not in the case of the Nine Span Bridge. The bridge was built to carry Indianapolis Boulevard (connecting Indianapolis and Chicago) across the once sprawling Gibson Railroad Yard, located near the steel towns of Gary and East Chicago. As the railroad only goes under two spans today, most of the bridge is no longer needed. Due to escalating maintenance costs, INDOT decided to replace the bridge. It is offered to interested parties on their bridge marketing page. If there are no takers, one span will be stored for ten years, and the rest of the bridge will be demolished. Without this bridge, what other tourist attraction is in this area? INDOT should use the money, instead of for demolition, for restoration of the National Register Eligible bridge, marketing it as a tourist attraction.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The No Hands Bridge was completed in 1912 by the Pacific Portland Cement Company to serve the Mountain Quarries Railroad that connected their limestone quarry with the Southern Pacific mainline in Auburn. The bridge was noteworthy upon construction for being one of the longest concrete arch bridges in the west when completed (supposedly the longest in the world at the time). In the early 1940's the railroad shut down, and the steel and some other materials from the line were removed and used in the war effort. The abandoned railroad grade was used by horsemen, including rider Ina Robinson. She was famous for dropping her reins to cross the bridge (which had no railings at the time), which is why the bridge is now known as the No Hands Bridge. The durable bridge withstood several floods, and even temporarily carried automobiles when the other bridges were washed away. Today the bride is part of the Western States Pioneer Express Recreation Trail, and it is the final American River Crossing of the famous Western States 100 Mile Endurance Ride and Run.

column15: Closed spandrel elliptical concrete arch, faced with ashlar
column20: In Oakdale there are two similar stone-faced concrete arches at the intersection of Noblestown Road and Union Avenue. The Noblestown Road Bridge is the older of the two, dating from 1921. Allegheny County chief engineer Charles Davis designed many stone arch bridges for small crossings. After his death in 1907, his successor, James Chalfant, modernized the design using stone-faced concrete arches. Rather than rusticated ashlar, his arches were faced with coursed ashlar and stepped voussoirs along the arch ring. The State Street Bridge is one such design. It is one of the last of Charles Davis's arch bridges, since he died the year after completion. His successor, Vernon Covell, did not continue the type, with one notable exception: The perpendicular Union Avenue Bridge of 1925.

The North 17th Street Bridge was a Pennsylvania Railroad standard design, a riveted Warren truss composed of angles and plates. The bridge was originally over ten spans long, with a ramp to the Pennsylvania Railroad roundhouse and a curved S-bend eastern ramp. It was likely built in conjunction with the construction of the 1905 East Altoona Round House (East Altoona Enginehouse), which was located just to the north of the bridge. The roundhouse was 395 feet in diameter, one of the largest in the world when it was built. By the late 1960's, parts of the eastern end of the bridge between the roundhouse and the S ramp were removed. The roundhouse and the east half of the bridge were demolished in the 1970's or 1980's. In 2010 the rest of the bridge was removed. The photograph from late 2010 shows only the western most span remaining, with the deck and floor stringers removed.

column15: Dual cantilevered steel girder (fascia girders are encased)
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, unusual dual cantilevered design for a non-moveable bridge
column18: Harrington, Howard, and Ash (Consulting Engineers), Charles E. Grubb (County Engineer), Frederick Snare Corporation (Contractor)
column20: According to the HAER report by P.A.C. Spero & Company with Kidde Consultants, ''State Bridge Number 575 is a 213 feet long steel girder bridge with a clear span of 150 feet. The girders are cantilevered from the abutments with counterweight pockets extending 29 feet into the abutments. The fascia girders are concrete encased. All girders are curved giving the bridge the appearance of an arch in elevation. The substructure is concrete and the railing is a concrete balustrade. End posts at the portals are concrete and highly ornamented. . . . The specifications for the present Bridge 575 describe a double cantilever steel deck girder structure with a single span of 150 feet supported upon two concrete abutments. It provides a paved roadway 60 feet wide accommodating double street car tracks, and two 10 feet sidewalks. The steel girders will be encased, in part with poured concrete and in part [sic) cement mortar placed with the cement gun.... Each cantilever arm has nine parallel deck girders which extend back across the supporting abutment and are anchored down at the rear. The pairs of cantilever arms are connected by shear locks in the center of the span. Eight combined trolley and light poles were to be erected along the bridge, -- and water pipes, gas pipes, electrical conduits and other utilities were incorporated into the structure. This extensive project also involved the construction of a stone retaining wall and a concrete comfort station, alterations to the street grades, and the raising of the railroad track at the north end of the bridge. Due to the high volume of traffic at this location, the specifications required the builder to construct the western half of the new bridge while traffic continued to use the previous bridge. . . . Unlike the majority of historic steel girder bridges surveyed in Delaware, which are simple spans, this bridge is a cantilevered structure. It is also located within the Brandywine Village Historic District.''

column16: Brandywine Creek Park is listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The concrete slab bridge carries North Park Road over a channelized tributary of Brandywine Creek in Brandywine Park. Much of the tributary's valley was filled in by I-95 in the 1960's. Designed by Frederick Law Olmstead, Brandywine Creek Park was acquired and developed in the late 1800's and early 1900's.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: The Terrell Bartlett Engineers, Inc., I. Ewig (City Engineer), McKenzie Construction Co. (Concrete), Houston Structural Steel Co. (Steel)
column20: The North Presa Street North Bridge is one of a few similar Warren polygonal pony trusses in San Antonio. The bridges are unusual in that while the ends of the truss are inclined, the center section has a flat top chord. Since North Presa Street crosses the river at a river bend, the bridge is skewed and has an approach thru girder span. The bridge is also unusual that the road deck does not fill the space between the truss lines. There is no deck along the east side of the bridge! Usually it is the case that the trusses are too close together! It is not known if the deck was ever wider, though historical photographs seem to indicate the deck was always narrower than the trusses.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1911, riveted, single span, 48'-long, Warren with verticals pony truss bridge is supported on abutments constructed from rail piles with steel plate breast walls. The trusses of the 4 panel bridge are composed of built up members. An undistinguished example of a common technology, the bridge has no innovative or distinctive details. Nor was the fabricator a prolific or prominent builder of metal truss bridges. Riveted truss bridges have been used in the state since ca. 1890.''

column2: North St Mary's Street Center Bridge
column20: In 1890, a lenticular thru truss was built at this location. In 1925, it was moved to Brackenridge Park where it still stands. The replacement bridge, built in conjunction with the flood control project, is an example of a tee beam. As part of the project, the river was straightened and a channel was dug bypassing the U-shaped bend in the river downtown.

column2: North St Mary's Street North Bridge
column20: The North St Mary's Street North Bridge is a decorative example of a concrete tee beam. Note the ornate balustrades.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The North Street Bridge is a 7 panel, pin-connected, traditionally composed Pratt thru truss bridge supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls. The trusses are traditionally composed, and the bridge appears to be complete. It was built within the ca. 1870-1930 period of significance of the determined eligible historic district, and it is thus a contributing resource. The bridge is similar to 55 7411 8142 3038 and may have been fabricated by the Groton Bridge Co.''

The North Vine Street Bridge is a plain closed spandrel concrete arch, designed by Greene County. It once had paneled parapets, but they were replaced with guide rail over the arch. The narrow bridge is to be replaced with a wider structure.

The Northern Canal Walkway Bridge was constructed to provide access to the Northern Canal system (including the Pawtucket Dam). The Northern Canal was finished in 1848, completing the city's canal system. The Northern Canal and feeder were built to increase and regulate hydropower for the canal system to power Lowell's mills. The bridge is an example of a riveted Warren truss composed of angles. It is off limits to all but authorized personnel. Occasionally, the National Parks Service conducts tours of the canal system, using the bridge.

column15: Steel stringer main span; concrete tee beam approach spans
column20: Between Murrysville and Churchill, there were two alternate alignments of what is now US 22. Old William Penn Highway (near current I-376) ran to the north, and Northern Pike (near current Business 22) ran to the south. The Northern Pike Bridge was built to carry old Northern Pike over a new three-lane alignment of US 22, which opened in 1941. US 22 was widened to five lanes in 1957, though the Northern Pike Bridge constrained the road to only four lanes. The steel bridge had concrete haunched fascia girders and concrete balustrades.

column2: Northern Pike Bridge over the Pennsylvania Turnpike
column20: The bridge was built as part of the 1951 Western Extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike. All mainline vehicular overpasses were either thru girders or deck girders in the extension. Spanning four lanes and two ramps, this bridge is one of the longest thru girders over the mainline on the Pennsylvania Turnpike. As a result, the bridge was rehabilitated instead of replaced.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1926, skewed, single span T beam bridge with paneled parapets is supported on a concrete substructure. It is an example of a very common bridge type that was used with great frequency from the 1910s through the 1940s.''

column18: Chaney & Armstrong Engineers, Nelson & Buchanan Company?
column20: The 1913 Oak Ridge Road Bridge is a tiny 40-foot riveted Pratt pony truss. It can also be classified as a queen post, since there is only one panel between the inclined endposts. Stylistically the bridge is one of several similar Nelson & Buchanan truss bridges in the county. The builder's plaque states ''Chaney & Armstrong Engineers,'' the consulting engineers responsible for many bridges in Washington County at that time. The Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory lists this bridge as being the work of the Penn Bridge Company according to its plaque. Since this plaque was not found during bridgemapper.com's field visit, and since the bridge is very similar to other Nelson & Buchanan Bridges, it is possible this listing is an error. The Oak Ridge Road Bridge's superstructure is rated critical, with a score of only 2 of 9. This indicates that the bridge will be replaced.

The Oak Street Bridge is noteworthy for being the oldest bridge over the Little Youghiogheny River. It is also the only arch bridge over the river. The parapets of the bridge were removed and replaced by guide rail in a renovation project. The builder's plates were also removed with this alteration.

In Oakland, Maryland, the Oakland Pedestrian Bridge, a new welded truss bridge, was built to carry a trail over the Little Youghiogheny River. The bridge is supported by welded warren pony trusses. However, decorative trusses were added in the top center part of the bridge to make it look like a thru truss. There are no piers below the end of the 'thru' section, giving the bridge an unrealistic appearance. Decorative luminaires were also added to the bridge in an attempt to make it historic. It is unfortunate that though many historic bridges are destroyed every year, a new bridge was built to try to simulate a historic one. Why not relocate a real historic bridge? Meanwhile, the last pin-connected truss in the county will soon be demolished.

The Oakland Rosedale Road Bridge is one of several modern pre-fabricated welded Warren pony truss bridges in the state. It is the only vehicular truss bridge over the entire Little Youghiogheny River. It is gratifying to see that Garrett County is choosing to build new truss bridges. The bridge is galvanized, meaning it is hot-dipped in zinc, which gives the steel a shiny silver color. This process prevents rust and is a more cost-effective alternative to painted steel.

column2: Ohio and Baltimore Short Line Bridge
column20: In 1873 and again in 1881, John Garrett, president of the B&O Railroad, planned to build an extension of the railroad from Connellsville to Washington to Wheeling to bypass Pittsburgh. Only three miles of the railroad were completed, though grading was done in various locations in Fayette and Washington counties. The three-mile Ohio & Baltimore Short Line featured this bridge, a deck truss with a stone arch approach. Only the stone arch approach remains. The line was abandoned in 1941, and the rest of the bridge was removed at some point later. The bridge is visible from the Great Allegheny Passage. For more information about the trail, refer to Bill Metzger's book, ''The Great Allegheny Passage Companion.''

column2: Ohio River Boulevard Bridge over Dilworth Run
column18: Allegheny County, Norman Brown, Vernon Covell, Booth & Flinn Company
column20: The bridge is one of five remaining Ohio River Boulevard open spandrel concrete arch bridges. The original Ohio River Boulevard was completed in its entirety in 1931 as a new highway to connect the municipalities along the northern side of the Ohio River to Pittsburgh. The new route involved the construction of six major open spandrel concrete arch bridges, as well as several other smaller bridges. The largest of the arches, the Jacks Run Bridge, was demolished in 1984. The smallest, the bridge over Dillworth Run survives, though the deck was replaced in 1980. The main span is only 135 feet and the bridge is only 225 feet long.

column2: Ohio River Boulevard Bridge over Eckert Street
column20: The bridge is the eastern most of the Ohio River Boulevard concrete arch bridges. Ohio River Boulevard was completed in its entirety in 1931 as a new highway to connect the municipalities along the northern side of the Ohio River to Pittsburgh. The new route involved the construction of six major open spandrel concrete arch bridges, as well as several other smaller bridges. The largest of the arches, the Jacks Run Bridge with a 400 foot main span was demolished in 1984. The bridge over Eckert Street has the largest span of the remaining five bridges at 270 feet. The deck was replaced in 1994, and all ornamentation was removed. However, the widened deck with concrete barriers improves the bridge's safety.

column2: Ohio River Boulevard Bridge over Ferry Street
column20: The stone arch bridge was built for the Pittsburgh, Fort Wayne, & Chicago Railroad, part of the Pennsylvania Railroad system, to near the now non-extant Roseburg station around 1875. The railroad was moved closer to the river, and the alignment including the bridge abandoned. During the project to extend Ohio River Boulevard along the river from Emsworth to Beaver County, the abandoned railroad alignment and bridge were incorporated into the roadway. The bridge is one of the oldest stone arch bridges still in use in Allegheny County.

column2: Ohio River Boulevard Bridge over Forest Avenue
column18: Allegheny County, Norman Brown, Vernon Covell, Booth & Flinn Company
column20: The original Ohio River Boulevard, which opened in 1931, was a new highway to connect the municipalities along the northern side of the Ohio River to Pittsburgh. The original route was from the Manchester neighborhood of Pittsburgh to Emsworth. The bridge over Forest Avenue is one of six surviving arch bridges, and is the only closed spandrel arch. While the National Bridge Inventory lists the bridge as an arch, the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory of 1997 lists the bridge as a rigid frame. As such, the bridge would be among the oldest rigid frame bridges in Pennsylvania. Unlike the other Ohio River Boulevard concrete arch bridges, the Forest Avenue Bridge retains its original deck and decorative railings. These are likely to be removed in its 2011 rehabilitation.

column2: Ohio River Boulevard Bridge over Lowries Run
column18: Allegheny County, Norman Brown, Vernon Covell, Booth & Flinn Company
column20: The Ohio River Boulevard Bridge over Lowries Run in Emsworth marks the eastbound beginning of the original Ohio River Boulevard, a highway opened in 1931 to connect the municipalities along the northern side of the Ohio River to Pittsburgh. Boulevard entrance pylons are to the east of the structure. The bridge has been mostly unaltered, retaining its original deck and railings. By the early 2000's, the bridge became structurally deficient with a low sufficiency rating. As a result, the bridge was replaced in 2010 and 2011.

column2: Ohio River Boulevard Bridge over South Fremont Avenue
column18: Allegheny County, Norman Brown, Vernon Covell, Booth & Flinn Company
column20: The bridge is one of five remaining Ohio River Boulevard open spandrel concrete arch bridges. The original Ohio River Boulevard was completed in its entirety in 1931 as a new highway to connect the municipalities along the northern side of the Ohio River to Pittsburgh. The new route involved the construction of six major open spandrel concrete arch bridges, as well as several other smaller bridges. The largest of the arches, the Jacks Run Bridge, was demolished in 1984. The bridge over South Fremont Avenue is the second smallest, with a main span of 180 ft. As part of the bridge rehabilitation around 1980, the deck was replaced and all ornamentation was removed. This improved the bridge's safety, with a wider deck and concrete barrier parapets.

column2: Ohio River Boulevard Bridge over Spruce Run
column18: Allegheny County, Norman Brown, Vernon Covell, Booth & Flinn Company
column20: The bridge is the western most of the Ohio River Boulevard open spandrel concrete arch bridges. The original Ohio River Boulevard was completed in its entirety in 1931 as a new highway to connect the municipalities along the northern side of the Ohio River to Pittsburgh. The new route involved the construction of six major open spandrel concrete arch bridges, as well as several other smaller bridges. The largest of the arches, the Jacks Run Bridge, was demolished in 1984. All other open spandrel arch bridges were rehabilitated. The bridge over Spruce Run is the longest remaining bridge, with a length of 650 feet. Consisting of three arches, it is the only one to have multiple arch spans. However, only the bridge over Dilworth Run has a smaller arch (15 feet shorter; the Spruce Run Bridge arches are 150 ft). The deck was replaced circa 1986.

column2: Ohio River Boulevard Bridge over Verner Avenue
column20: The bridge is one of five remaining Ohio River Boulevard open spandrel concrete arch bridges. Ohio River Boulevard was completed in its entirety in 1931 as a new highway to connect the municipalities along the northern side of the Ohio River to Pittsburgh. The new route involved the construction of six major open spandrel concrete arch bridges, as well as several other smaller bridges. The largest of the arches, the Jacks Run Bridge, was demolished in 1984. Of the remaining bridge, the bridge over Verner Avenue has the second largest main span at 210 feet. The deck was replaced in 1989.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Ohl Street Bridge is the last remaining Pratt thru truss bridge over the Shenango River. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1909, pin connected, two span, 256'-long (2 @ 128'), Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments and an ashlar cutwater pier. The bridge is a complete, handsome example of a pin connected, metal truss bridge with aesthetic details, including cresting and decorative sidewalk railings. It was built by the Canton Bridge Company, a regional fabricator of metal truss bridges. Modifications have been minor, limited to the replacement in 1980 of some floorbeams and stringers, and the strengthening of some truss members by adding cover plate. The bridge also contributes to a potential historic district consisting of the NR-eligible Bessemer & Lake Erie Railroad shops to its east and a working class residential neighborhood to its west.'' According to www.mercercotrussbridges.com, ''The construction of the Ohl Street Bridge, located on the Greenville Borough-Hempfield Township line, illustrates the planning and construction process of a metal truss bridge. As the area's industrial center, Greenville expanded south in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, and formerly vacant or agricultural land became valued for industrial and residential development. In 1876, E.W. Hodge established the Hodge Manufacturing Company on New Street. Other industries soon joined it. The largest was the Bessemer & Lake Erie Railroad, which established a major rail yard, repair shops, and a roundhouse in South Greenville. Residential neighborhoods sprang up to house the employees of these plants. A footbridge was erected to allow those living on the west side of the Shenango River to reach these facilities. In September 1907, ''not less than twenty-four resident taxpayers'' of Greenville and Hempfield Township petitioned the Court of Quarter Sessions for a road bridge to replace the footbridge. The six viewers appointed to appraise the crossing agreed that a bridge was necessary and took the somewhat unusual step of recommending details, including type of bridge (single span steel truss), its length (150 ft) and width (40 ft), the need for a sidewalk, and the width of the approach roads leading to the structure. In all likelihood, this indicated that the Mercer County Engineer already knew what type of truss bridge he planned to design. The viewers presented the report to the Grand Jury on October 21, 1907. It was approved two days later. In November, the County Commissioners agreed to pay for the bridge. The Commissioners selected the Canton Bridge Company of Canton, Ohio to construct the bridge. The Pratt through truss bridge constructed by the company was two spans rather than one and, at 256 ft, much longer than the viewers recommended. A contract between Mercer County and the Canton Bridge Company carefully detailed erection specifications. Structural steel was to be used throughout, with the exception of cast steel for shoes and bearings and cast iron for decorative elements such as the bridge nameplates, portal cresting, and railing ornaments. The bridge deck was specified as built up arched corrugated steel plates resting on the lower flanges of the steel stringers to be filled and surfaced with concrete. The center section of the deck was to be much heavier than the rest, in order to support a proposed streetcar line that was never built. This also accounts for the bridge's width. The contract also detailed the dead and live loads the bridge had to accommodate; the degree of workmanship with which it must be erected; and even the approved methods by which it must be assembled. Notably, bridge members were to be erected using rivets driven with pneumatic hammers rather than hammered by hand. However, on-site construction specified the use of pinned connections at the panel points, not rivets. Since the bridge was replacing a footbridge, a broad cantilevered sidewalk was built on the north side of the bridge with provisions made for the possible later addition of a second sidewalk on the south side of the bridge. The Canton Bridge Company completed the Ohl Street Bridge in October 1909. The bridge featured decorative details designed to enhance the bridge's aesthetic appeal. The portal struts were embellished with quarter round sunburst cresting and spherical finials, and the sidewalk railing was artfully composed of overlapping strips of metal and decorated with rosettes. Inspectors appointed by the court to insure that the bridge was built as designed called the Ohl Street Bridge 'first class in every respect.'''

column15: Warren riveted with concrete beam approaches
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Rollen J. Windrow (State Highway Engineer), S. J. Treadaway (Consulting Engineer), Mosher Steel & Machinery Co. (Steel Contractor), A. C. Buchanan & Son (General Contractors)
column20: The Old 81 Bridge served the main route between Waco and Austin before I-35 was built. The bridge is an example of a riveted Warren truss. The style of bridge was often built for comparable crossings on long distance routes in the 1920's, though only a few still survive.

column15: Pratt pin-connected with steel stringer approaches
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Old Airport Road Bridge is an example of a pin-connected Pratt thru truss. The National Bridge Inventory gives the bridge a build date of 1922, which is very unlikely since the bridge is pin-connected. The bridge appears to date from about 1900. It was probably either rehabilitated or relocated in 1922. The bridge was bypassed in 1987. Rather than demolish the old bridge, it was allowed to stand as a relic of turn of the century transportation.

column2: Old Austin Highway Three Mile Creek Bridge
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: J. B. Fauntleroy (State Highway Engineer), C. C. Wickline (Bridge Engineer), El Paso Bridge & Iron Company (Contractor)
column20: The Old Austin Highway Three Mile Creek Bridge is the last remaining historic bridge of any time in Gillespie County. The Old Austin Highway (US 290) was the main road connecting Austin to the west. In 1955, the road was realigned, and the bridge was bypassed. The bridge is an example of a state-standard Warren pony truss.

column15: Parker pin-connected with Pratt pin-connected/riveted and deck girder approach spans
column16: America's longest pin-connected truss bridge, Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: William Krome, Joseph Meredith, Florida East Coast Railway, American Bridge (Steel Fabricator); rebuilt by B. M. Duncan (Chief Engineer)
column20: Out of all channels to be crossed by Henry Flagler's Florida East Cost Railway in the Florida Keys, the Bahia Honda Channel was the deepest, with a maximum depth of 24 feet. As a result a truss bridge was constructed, since the truss can span longer distances than concrete arches. Most of the concrete arch bridges had 35 foot spans, though the Long Key Bridge had some arches with 50 foot spans. The steel girder spans were 80 feet (60 feet over Pigeon Key). The Bahia Honda Channel Bridge's spans varied on channel depth. The center span is a Parker truss with a span of 247 feet. 13 larger Pratt thru truss spans on either side of the Parker truss have 186 foot spans. 13 smaller Pratt thru trusses with 128 foot spans are on either side of the larger Pratt trusses. Finally, the bridge has 9 deck girder spans at its west end. While the smaller Pratt spans have riveted connections, the larger Pratt and Parker truss spans have pinned connections in the center area of the low chord, making the bridge the longest pin-connected truss bridge in America, if not the world! After the 1935 Hurricane when the railroad was sold to the Overseas Road and Toll Bridge District, the bridge was converted to vehicular use. Instead of widening the trusses, a wider bridge deck was built over the trusses! Therefore, the bridge became a deck truss. Its Parker span might be the only such deck truss in the country if not the world! In 1972, the bridge was the first of the major Florida Keys bridges to be bypassed. One truss span at the east side and one deck girder span at the west side was removed. While most of the bridge has be abandoned, the remaining west approach was opened for pedestrian use in Bahia Honda State Park.

According to the PAHBI (MEM Reviewer), ''The one span, 66' long and 18.3'' wide reinforced concrete deck arch bridge built in 1920 as a joint-county bridge is finished with plain spandrel walls and paneled parapets. The ashlar wingwalls probably date from an earlier bridge. A section of one parapet has been lost, and the bridge has been coated with shotcrete.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: William Krome, Joseph Meredith, Florida East Coast Railway; rebuilt by B. M. Duncan (Chief Engineer)
column20: Henry Flagler made his fortune by establishing the Standard Oil Company in 1870, though he is best known for developing Florida by building the Florida East Coast Railway. In the late 1800's, Key West was the largest city in Florida. Furthermore, it was the only city with a deep water port. In anticipation of the opening of the Panama Canal, Flagler decided to extend his railroad to Key West. Starting in 1905, the railroad and its miles and miles of bridges and fill sections was finally completed in 1912. Most bridges, such as this one, were closed spandrel concrete arch causeways. While the railroad initially led to boom years, the competition from newer Florida cities and ports such as Miami and Tampa as well as the loss of the cigar and sponging industries exacerbated the effects of the Great Depression in the 1930's. The railroad filed for bankruptcy in 1932. On Labor Day, 1935, ''The Storm of the Century'' as it was later known, struck the keys. The Category Five hurricane destroyed much of the railroad, washing out miles of fill sections. A rescue locomotive carrying hundreds of veterans working on building an auto route for the Overseas Road and Toll Bridge District (ORTB) through the keys was lost. In all, 428 people were killed. The bridges survived. The railroad could not afford to rebuild its line and went bankrupt. The Public Works Administration loaned the ORTB funding to build a highway through the keys, utilizing the railroad right-of-way and bridges. The concrete bridges, such as this one, were widened in by placing steel beams across the bridge and encasing them with concrete. The highway was opened for traffic in 1938, though modernized and dedicated in 1944. From 1972 to 1982, new bridges replaced all of the former railroad bridges. Many of the old bridges were converted to carry trails or serve as fishing piers. Sections of many were removed to allow boat passage. Some were demolished entirely. Bridgemapper.com has documented all of the remaining 23 bridges.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Geo. Porter, Hermann Laub, Chaney & Armstrong (Engineers) Crossan Construction Co., Fort Pitt Bridge Works (Contractors)
column20: The 1914 Old Brownsville Bridge has a main span of 520 feet, which is the longest vehicular simple truss span in the entire state of Pennsylvania! The height of the truss ranges from 51 feet to 80 feet. Most bridges built around the same time had multiple smaller truss spans. For example, the Masontown Bridge to the south has a main span of about 400 feet and five truss spans. The Charleroi-Monessen Bridge to the north has two main spans of about 400 feet plus another truss approach span. The Old Brownsville Bridge, however, has one monumental truss span and thru girder approaches. The bridge was constructed to replace an 1833 covered bridge that carried the National Road across the river. Because of the National Road, this is the site of the first Monongahela River crossing in the region. The National Road in Brownsville has another important bridge on it: the Dunlap's Creek Bridge, America's first cast iron bridge, located near the Fayette County end of the Old Brownsville Bridge over Dunlaps Creek. The Old Brownsville Bridge, Dunlap's Creek Bridge, and adjacent Lane Bane Bridge (a 1960's deck cantilever truss) make Brownsville one of the best places to visit in the country for bridges! Maintenance on the bridge was performed in 2010.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: William Krome, Joseph Meredith, Florida East Coast Railway; rebuilt by B. M. Duncan (Chief Engineer)
column20: Henry Flagler made his fortune by establishing the Standard Oil Company in 1870, though he is best known for developing Florida by building the Florida East Coast Railway. In the late 1800's, Key West was the largest city in Florida. Furthermore, it was the only city with a deep water port. In anticipation of the opening of the Panama Canal, Flagler decided to extend his railroad to Key West. Starting in 1905, the railroad and its miles and miles of bridges and fill sections was finally completed in 1912. Most bridges, such as this one, were closed spandrel concrete arch causeways. While the railroad initially led to boom years, the competition from newer Florida cities and ports such as Miami and Tampa as well as the loss of the cigar and sponging industries exacerbated the effects of the Great Depression in the 1930's. The railroad filed for bankruptcy in 1932. On Labor Day, 1935, ''The Storm of the Century'' as it was later known, struck the keys. The Category Five hurricane destroyed much of the railroad, washing out miles of fill sections. A rescue locomotive carrying hundreds of veterans working on building an auto route for the Overseas Road and Toll Bridge District (ORTB) through the keys was lost. In all, 428 people were killed. The bridges survived. The railroad could not afford to rebuild its line and went bankrupt. The Public Works Administration loaned the ORTB funding to build a highway through the keys, utilizing the railroad right-of-way and bridges. The concrete bridges, such as this one, were widened in by placing steel beams across the bridge and encasing them with concrete. The highway was opened for traffic in 1938, though modernized and dedicated in 1944. From 1972 to 1982, new bridges replaced all of the former railroad bridges. Many of the old bridges were converted to carry trails or serve as fishing piers. Sections of many were removed to allow boat passage. Some were demolished entirely. Bridgemapper.com has documented all of the remaining 23 bridges.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: William Krome, Joseph Meredith, Florida East Coast Railway; rebuilt by B. M. Duncan (Chief Engineer)
column20: Henry Flagler made his fortune by establishing the Standard Oil Company in 1870, though he is best known for developing Florida by building the Florida East Coast Railway. In the late 1800's, Key West was the largest city in Florida. Furthermore, it was the only city with a deep water port. In anticipation of the opening of the Panama Canal, Flagler decided to extend his railroad to Key West. Starting in 1905, the railroad and its miles and miles of bridges and fill sections was finally completed in 1912. Most bridges, such as this one, were closed spandrel concrete arch causeways. The concrete bridges, such as this one, were widened in by placing steel beams across the bridge and encasing them with concrete. The highway was opened for traffic in 1938, though modernized and dedicated in 1944. From 1972 to 1982, new bridges replaced all of the former railroad bridges. Many of the old bridges were converted to carry trails or serve as fishing piers. Sections of many were removed to allow boat passage. Some were demolished entirely. Bridgemapper.com has documented all of the remaining 23 bridges.

The Old Crisman Road Bridge is the last remaining truss bridge in Porter County (not including a modern bike trail bridge). Since the bridge has been bypassed but not replaced, INDOT recognizes the historic value of the bridge. Hopefully INDOT will eventually repair the bridge and open it up for pedestrians.

The bridge was determined to be historically significant due to the rare detailing of the floorbeam connections to the trusses. The railroad line it crossed was chartered by the Pittsburgh Southern in 1876 and taken over by the Baltimore and Ohio in 1883. The bridge was reportedly built as an improvement to the B&O. An alternate source dates the bridge to ca. 1875.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The historic Old Clifton Mills Road Bridge is a classic example of an 1880's Wrought Iron Bridge Company Pratt truss. Clifton Mills Road was realigned and built on the opposite side of the creek. Old Clifton Mills Road is no longer a through road and ends just after the bridge. The bridge is essentially a driveway, since it serves two houses. It can be hard to find the road to the bridge; the only sign is for the entrance to a private club.

column18: Union Bridge Company, Theodore Cooper, re-erected by The Foundation Company, pony trusses by the Farris Engineering Company and fabricated by American Bridge
column20: In 1892, a two-span Pennsylvania truss was built to span the Allegheny River connecting Sixth Street with Federal Street between the cities of Pittsburgh and Allegheny (now Pittsburgh's North Side). Built as an important link between two then prosperous cities, the bridge was fitted with architectural decorations, such as peaked portals with decorative ironwork. Structurally the bridge was impressive, with two spans of 439 feet that were among the longest in the country for a simple truss. An alternate design for the bridge was an unusual configuration of thru arches with lenticular truss lower chords. The bridge was also significant for being the last surviving structure entirely designed by nationally-significant engineer Theodore Cooper. Only a few Union Bridge Company structures still exist anywhere in Pennsylvania. In 1917, Secretary of War Newton Baker issued a mandate that Pittsburgh's Allegheny River bridges must have a minimum clearance of 47 to provide clearance for navigation. In 1927 the bridge was replaced with the current Roberto Clemente Bridge. Instead of demolishing the old bridge, it was separated into four sections, placed on barges, and was moved to cross the Back Channel of the Ohio River in Coraopolis. Two Warren pony approach trusses were added to the Coraopolis approach to span the former P&LE Railroad. By the 1980's the bridge's steel became so brittle that the structure had to be closed whenever the temperature was below 30 degrees F. This caused great inconvenience to anyone who depended on the bridge. As a result, the National Register-Listed bridge was demolished in 1994 to make way for its modern replacement.
The bascule span is permanently in the open position. The bridge is used as a fishing pier.

column15: Pennsylvania half thru truss (river span), Warren deck truss, Warren thru truss (railroad span)
column18: McKeesport and Port Vue Bridge Company
column20: The bridge was a very rare, unusual example of a Pennsylvania half thru truss. From east to west the bridge consisted of a thru girder, deck Warren trusses, a Pennsylvania half thru truss, deck Warren trusses, and a thru Warren truss (over CSX). The bridge was closed to traffic in 1989 and demolished on January 15, 1994.

The Old Forbes Road Bridge was rehabilitated in 2003 in which the deck and parapets were replaced. The upper courses of stone were encased with concrete. According to the PAHBI, ''The 40'-long and 15' wide stone arch bridge built in 1914 is laid up in rusticated ashlar. The corresponding parapets step down over the flared wingwalls.''

The Old Kane Road Bridge was demolished a few months after it was photographed. According to the PAHBI, '''The 2 span, 72'-long T beam bridge built in 1924 is simply supported on a reinforced concrete pier and abutments with wingwalls. It is finished with concrete safety shape parapets from ca. 1980.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: William Krome, Joseph Meredith, Florida East Coast Railway; rebuilt by B. M. Duncan (Chief Engineer)
column20: Henry Flagler made his fortune by establishing the Standard Oil Company in 1870, though he is best known for developing Florida by building the Florida East Coast Railway. In the late 1800's, Key West was the largest city in Florida. Furthermore, it was the only city with a deep water port. In anticipation of the opening of the Panama Canal, Flagler decided to extend his railroad to Key West. Starting in 1905, the railroad and its miles and miles of bridges and fill sections was finally completed in 1912. Most bridges, such as this one, were closed spandrel concrete arch causeways. While the railroad initially led to boom years, the competition from newer Florida cities and ports such as Miami and Tampa as well as the loss of the cigar and sponging industries exacerbated the effects of the Great Depression in the 1930's. The railroad filed for bankruptcy in 1932. On Labor Day, 1935, ''The Storm of the Century'' as it was later known, struck the keys. The Category Five hurricane destroyed much of the railroad, washing out miles of fill sections. A rescue locomotive carrying hundreds of veterans working on building an auto route for the Overseas Road and Toll Bridge District (ORTB) through the keys was lost. In all, 428 people were killed. The bridges survived. The railroad could not afford to rebuild its line and went bankrupt. The Public Works Administration loaned the ORTB funding to build a highway through the keys, utilizing the railroad right-of-way and bridges. The concrete bridges, such as this one, were widened in by placing steel beams across the bridge and encasing them with concrete. The highway was opened for traffic in 1938, though modernized and dedicated in 1944. From 1972 to 1982, new bridges replaced all of the former railroad bridges. Many of the old bridges were converted to carry trails or serve as fishing piers. Sections of many were removed to allow boat passage. Some were demolished entirely. Bridgemapper.com has documented all of the remaining 23 bridges.

column2: Old Lakes to the Sea Highway Bridge
column20: The bridge was originally built as a realignment of local roads for the Lakes to the Sea Highway, now US 322. It is a state standard example of an arch culvert. The bridge was possibly constructed around 1960 as part of the highway's realignment, bypassing an existing stone arch bridge. In 1981 the highway was realigned again, and the bridge was bypassed. It remains open to traffic as a westbound ramp from US 322 to Deep Hollow Road. According to the PAHBI, ''The department used the arch culvert for many years starting in the late 1910s. It was favored for its economy of design and maintenance, ease of construction, and pleasing appearance. The type is common throughout the Commonwealth.''

column2: Old Lincoln Highway Shobers Run Bridge
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, S. J. Brotemarkle Co. (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The bridge was originally constructed in 1936 as a skewed, reinforced concrete, closed spandrel, deck arch bridge with concrete balustrades. In 1970 the bridge was widened to one side by the addition of a precast, prestressed concrete bridge that more than doubled the bridge width. The concrete balustrades were replaced with low concrete parapets topped with tubular hand rails. The alterations have compromised integrity of design, materials, setting, and context.''

column2: Old Little Duck Missouri Channel Bridge
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: William Krome, Joseph Meredith, Florida East Coast Railway; rebuilt by B. M. Duncan (Chief Engineer)
column20: Henry Flagler made his fortune by establishing the Standard Oil Company in 1870, though he is best known for developing Florida by building the Florida East Coast Railway. column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: William Krome, Joseph Meredith, Florida East Coast Railway; rebuilt by B. M. Duncan (Chief Engineer)
column20: While extending the Florida East Coast Railway was Henry Flagler's ultimate goal, the intermediate milestone in construction of the railroad in the Key's was to reach Knight's Key Dock in Marathon. The largest bridge to be built in this section was the Long Key Bridge. Due to the depth of the water, the central and eastern arches were enlarged to span 50 feet. The western approach arches (pictured) are the standard 35 feet. In all, there are 180 50 foot arches and 42 35 foot arches. While under construction, a hurricane struck the work site on October 17, 1906. About 130 workers were killed. The bridge was finally completed in 1908. After being widened and converted to vehicular use in 1938, the bridge was bypassed in 1982. Since then the bridge was converted to a pedestrian bridge with fishing platforms. The widened deck was removed.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: William Krome, Joseph Meredith, Florida East Coast Railway; rebuilt by B. M. Duncan (Chief Engineer)
column20: Henry Flagler made his fortune by establishing the Standard Oil Company in 1870, though he is best known for developing Florida by building the Florida East Coast Railway. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1922, riveted, single span, 104'-long, Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with concrete caps. The heavy trusses, designed to handle to high load capacity, are composed of built up members.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, oldest of three remaining truss bridges in county
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1 span, 93'-long, wrought iron, pin-connected Pratt thru truss bridge was built in 1889 according to BMS records, but the bridge plaques documenting the date and builder have been lost. The trusses are traditionally composed with the lower chords and diagonals being eye bars, the upper chords being built up box sections, and the verticals being channels with lacing. The bridge has lattice portals with lattice brackets, and pipe railings that appear to be original are attached to the interior faces of the trusses. The built up floorbeams have U-shaped hangers. The wood stringers and deck were replaced in kind in 1994. The bridge is supported on fieldstone abutments. The bridge is an early and notably complete example of its type/design in a region with more than 120 truss bridges from the 1880s to 1940s. It is an early example of the all standard details that came to characterize the pin-connected Pratt truss type/design by the mid 1890s. It is historically and technologically significant.''

column2: Old Ohio Bahia Honda Channel Bridge
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: William Krome, Joseph Meredith, Florida East Coast Railway; rebuilt by B. M. Duncan (Chief Engineer)
column20: Henry Flagler made his fortune by establishing the Standard Oil Company in 1870, though he is best known for developing Florida by building the Florida East Coast Railway. Bridgemapper.com has documented all of the remaining 23 bridges.

The Old Ohiopyle Road Bridge was built as an early Pennsylvania Department of Highways truss bridge (according to the PAHBI). At some point in the latter portion of the 1900's, the bridge was retrofitted with load-bearing stringers below the floorbeams of the bridge. In 1996 the bridge was replaced by a culvert on a different alignment. The old bridge was left in place to be used as a trail. However, the truss superstructure was cut above the railings and removed. Only the original bearings, ends of the diagonal endposts, and the grate deck remain from the truss bridge. This is a lost example of preservation, since the truss bridge could have been an interesting landmark along the trail.

column15: Warren riveted with stringer approach spans
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Old Pecan Grove Road Bridge is an excellent example of a 1930's Warren thru truss. Note that unlike the tension members, the vertical members are built-up with X-lacing. Typically, 1930's bridges use standardized members all of the same size for both tension and compression members.

column2: Old Point Marion Cheat River Bridge
column20: The 1908 Point Marion Cheat River Bridge was a rare three-span camelback truss bridge built by the Penn Bridge Company. Though the bridge had no weight restriction on US 119, trucks frequently got stuck at the T-intersection at the northern end of the bridge. The replacement bridge was built on a new alignment at an angle, eliminating this sharp turn. Once the new bridge was opened to traffic, the truss bridge was demolished. Today there are only three (soon to be two by 2012) pre-World War II truss bridges remaining on the Cheat River (not counting the forks and branches).

The Old Ridge Road Bridge is the largest concrete arch bridge in Erie County. The bridge consists of three 60 foot closed spandrel arches. Architectural treatments included accented arch rings and paneled parapets. According to the PAHBI, ''According to PennDOT records, this bridge has been closed since before 1985. It is in reportedly bad condition and the files have no pictures of the bridge itself.'' Note that the bridge is closed to pedestrians and is overgrown. Visit in winter to get the best photographs.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: William Krome, Joseph Meredith, Florida East Coast Railway; rebuilt by B. M. Duncan (Chief Engineer)

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, last remaining concrete thru arch in western Pennsylvania
column18: George B. Zahniser (County Engineer), Harrington, Howard & Ash (HNTB) (Consulting Engineer), John A. Byers (Contractor)
column20: The Old Route 18 Hickory Run Bridge is the last remaining concrete thru arch in all of western Pennsylvania. Visit the bridge soon, since it is to be torn down. According to the PAHBI, ''The single-span, 112'-long, reinforced concrete thru arch bridge was designed by Harrington Howard & Ash, successors to HNTB. It is a complete example of a design the consulting engineers also used in Delaware in 1942. The bridge is not a Marsh arch. Rather, it uses the same principles of a reinforced concrete open spandrel arch, and it represents an economical and pleasing use of both steel and reinforced concrete. It is historically and technologically significant because of the rareness of its design, its date of construction, association with prominent consulting engineers, and its completeness.''

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Clark Brothers (Contractor)
column20: The Old Route 22 bridge over Blair Gap Run was built underneath the former New Portage Railroad / Pennsylvania Railroad Mule Shoe Bridge, a stone arch. According to the PAHBI, ''The bridge carries a two-lane section of old US 22 with shoulders over a stream in a wooded setting. The roadway and bridge pass through the opening of the Muleshoe bridge, a stone arch railroad bridge constructed in 1902. The railroad line carried by the bridge has been abandoned since the 1970s. The skewed, 39'-long, reinforced concrete, slab bridge is supported on concrete abutments and is finished with standard design concrete balustrades. There is a shear detail at the ends of the slab. The 1930 bridge is an undistinguished example of the technology that was used throughout the state with great frequency by 1920. The bridge was built during a widening and realignment of this section of US 22, the William Penn Highway, which was one of the over 50 tourist trails in Pennsylvania during the 1910s and 1920s. Redesignated US 22 in 1928, the road had negligible significance as a cross-state route, with the more southerly US 1/US 30 and, after 1940, the Pennsylvania Turnpike, the more heavily traveled routes. This section of US 22 has itself been bypassed.''

The highway was opened for traffic in 1938, though modernized and dedicated in 1944. From 1972 to 1982, new bridges replaced all of the former railroad bridges. Many of the old bridges were converted to carry trails or serve as fishing piers. Sections of many were removed to allow boat passage. Some were demolished entirely. Bridgemapper.com has documented all of the remaining 23 bridges.
The bridge was photographed about a month before its permanent closure, on June 28, 2007. The bascule piers were imploded on October 30, 2007.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Old Selbysport Road Bridge is the longest-spanning concrete arch bridge in Garrett County. The concrete balustrade was recently repaired. Unfortunately the builder's plaque was located in a repaired section of balustrade, so now it is missing. Since this bridge is similar to the Crellin Underwood Road Bridge, it was likely built by the Luten Bridge Company.

column2: Old Seven Mile Bridge (Knights Key-Pigeon Key Bridge )
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: William Krome, Joseph Meredith, Florida East Coast Railway, American Bridge (Steel Fabricator), Terry and Tench Company (Contractor); rebuilt by B. M. Duncan (Chief Engineer)
column20: The Old Seven Mile Bridge (Knights Key-Pigeon Key-Moser Channel-Pacet Channel Bridge) is the longest of the original Florida East Coast Railway (FECR) Bridges. The bridge was designed and built in four sections: Knight's Key Bridge, Pigeon Key Bridge, Moser Channel Bridge, and Pacet Channel Viaduct. Unlike most of the FECR bridges in the keys, only the Pacet Channel Viaduct consists of concrete arches, as seen in the picture. The rest of the bridge is composed of steel deck girders spans. Steel girders were more economical for most of this crossing, due to a deeper channel that makes longer spans more efficient. As with the other keys bridges, the bridge's deck was widened when it was converted to vehicular use in 1938. The rails from the railroad were used as railings. Once the replacement bridge opened in 1982, several spans of the old bridge were demolished, including the one to the west of the Pigeon Key ramp. Since the new bridge does not cross Pigeon Key, the Knight's Key-Pigeon Key Bridge and ramp were retained to provide vehicular access to the island. Therefore, the bridge was divided into two sections. The Knights Key-Pigeon Key Bridge continued to provide vehicular access to Pigeon Key until 2008, when it was closed to traffic. It may be rehabilitated in the future. Currently (2009) it is just open to pedestrians. According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''At the time the Florida East Coast Railway constructed this bridge it was acclaimed as the longest bridge in the world, an engineering marvel. It was the most costly of all Flagler's bridges in the Key West Extension. Since the beginning it has served as the one and only vital link between Miami and Key West. The logistics of assembling labor and materials and overcoming the difficulties presented by deep water, normal tides and hurricanes attest to the engineering and management skills of those connected with its construction.''

column2: Old Seven Mile Bridge (Moser Channel-Pacet Channel Bridge)
column15: Steel deck girder with concrete closed spandrel semicircular arch approaches
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: William Krome, Joseph Meredith, Florida East Coast Railway, American Bridge (Steel Fabricator), Terry and Tench Company (Contractor); rebuilt by B. M. Duncan (Chief Engineer)
column20: The Old Seven Mile Bridge (Knights Key-Pigeon Key-Moser Channel-Pacet Channel Bridge) is the longest of the original Florida East Coast Railway (FECR) Bridges. The bridge was designed and built in four sections: Knight's Key Bridge, Pigeon Key Bridge, Moser Channel Bridge, and Pacet Channel Viaduct. Unlike most of the FECR bridges in the keys, only the Pacet Channel Viaduct consists of concrete arches, as seen in the picture. The rest of the bridge is composed of steel deck girders spans. Steel girders were more economical for most of this crossing, due to a deeper channel that makes longer spans more efficient. The bridge also had a 253 foot thru truss swing span over Moser Channel, though it was damaged in 1981 by an over height truck carrying a backhoe. As a result, the span was demolished. As with the other keys bridges, the bridge's deck was widened when it was converted to vehicular use in 1938. The swing span was widened. The rails from the railroad were used as railings. Once the replacement bridge opened in 1982, several spans of the old bridge were demolished, including the one to the west of the Pigeon Key ramp. Since the new bridge does not cross Pigeon Key, the Knight's Key-Pigeon Key Bridge and ramp were retained to provide vehicular access to the island. Therefore, the bridge was divided into two sections. Most of the Moser Channel-Pacet Channel Bridge is abandoned, though the western end has been converted to a fishing pier. According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''At the time the Florida East Coast Railway constructed this bridge it was acclaimed as the longest bridge in the world, an engineering marvel. It was the most costly of all Flagler's bridges in the Key West Extension. Since the beginning it has served as the one and only vital link between Miami and Key West. The logistics of assembling labor and materials and overcoming the difficulties presented by deep water, normal tides and hurricanes attest to the engineering and management skills of those connected with its construction.''

column15: Trestle, deck girder on trusses bents
column20: The first of the Pittsburgh area bridges spanning large ravines were trestles, or girders or trusses supported on trussed bents. By the 1930's, most were replaced by arches or trusses capable of spanning longer distances without intermediate supports. The former Shadeland Avenue Bridge was the last of these large trestles, though a few smaller examples still exist in the area. The bridge was replaced by a deck girder, which opened in 1993.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: William Krome, Joseph Meredith, Florida East Coast Railway; rebuilt by B. M. Duncan (Chief Engineer)
column20: Henry Flagler made his fortune by establishing the Standard Oil Company in 1870, though he is best known for developing Florida by building the Florida East Coast Railway. In the late 1800's, Key West was the largest city in Florida. Furthermore, it was the only city with a deep water port. In anticipation of the opening of the Panama Canal, Flagler decided to extend his railroad to Key West. Starting in 1905, the railroad and its miles and miles of bridges and fill sections was finally completed in 1912. Most bridges, such as this one, were closed spandrel concrete arch causeways. While the railroad initially led to boom years, the competition from newer Florida cities and ports such as Miami and Tampa as well as the loss of the cigar and sponging industries exacerbated the effects of the Great Depression in the 1930's. The railroad filed for bankruptcy in 1932. On Labor Day, 1935, ''The Storm of the Century'' as it was later known, struck the keys. The Category Five hurricane destroyed much of the railroad, washing out miles of fill sections. A rescue locomotive carrying hundreds of veterans working on building an auto route for the Overseas Road and Toll Bridge District (ORTB) through the keys was lost. In all, 428 people were killed. The bridges survived. The railroad could not afford to rebuild its line and went bankrupt. The Public Works Administration loaned the ORTB funding to build a highway through the keys, utilizing the railroad right-of-way and bridges. The concrete bridges, such as this one, were widened in by placing steel beams across the bridge and encasing them with concrete. The highway was opened for traffic in 1938, though modernized and dedicated in 1944. From 1972 to 1982, new bridges replaced all of the former railroad bridges. Many of the old bridges were converted to carry trails or serve as fishing piers. Sections of many were removed to allow boat passage. Some were demolished entirely. Bridgemapper.com has documented all of the remaining 23 bridges.

column15: Pratt pin-connected, full slope, Phoenix columns
column20: The Old Smokey Train Bridge is a rare example of a truss bridge with Phoenix columns. It is perhaps the only example of a historic truss bridge being reused for an amusement park ride. According to Harry Deitz Book, ''Knoebels an Amusement Park with a Heart,'' Lawrence Knoebel purchased two bridges for the park in 1936. One was the Lawrence Knoebel Covered Bridge, which is still located at the park. According to the book, ''Along with his purchase of the Benton covered bridge, Lawrence Knoebel was the successful bidder at a purchase price of $75 for another bridge that spanned Fishing Creek in Sugarloaf Township. There is no report anywhere on what happened to that bridge, whether it became part of the Knoebel scenery or if it was sold by Lawrence to another interested individual or firm.'' Since the date of the Old Smokey Train Bridge (ca. 1890) predates the park, the bridge was relocated from elsewhere. It is possible that this is the other bridge Lawrence Knoebel purchased. The Old Smokey Train and the Pioneer Train were purchased in 1960, initially running on the same track. According to the Knoebels book, ''Marion Vought, an Elysburg contractor who also was employed by the park, was hired to drain a swamp area, clear trees, construct a tunnel and bridge and lay the one-and-one-half miles of track.'' It is possible that Vought either reused the former Fishing Creek Bridge for the train or relocated a different bridge. The routes of the trains have been modified and separated, so the bridge could have also been relocated during one of the train's track realignments. Knoebels Amusement Resort is one of the premier parks in the nation for historic rides. It is fitting that it also has a historic bridge, one of only a few with Phoenix columns in Pennsylvania.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: William Krome, Joseph Meredith, Florida East Coast Railway; rebuilt by B. M. Duncan (Chief Engineer)
column20: Henry Flagler made his fortune by establishing the Standard Oil Company in 1870, though he is best known for developing Florida by building the Florida East Coast Railway. The railroad filed for bankruptcy in 1932. On Labor Day, 1935, ''The Storm of the Century'' as it was later known, struck the keys. The Category Five hurricane destroyed much of the railroad, washing out miles of fill sections. Many of the old bridges were converted to carry trails or serve as fishing piers. Sections of many were removed to allow boat passage. Some were demolished entirely. Bridgemapper.com has documented all of the remaining 23 bridges.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: William Krome, Joseph Meredith, Florida East Coast Railway; rebuilt by B. M. Duncan (Chief Engineer)
column20: Henry Flagler made his fortune by establishing the Standard Oil Company in 1870, though he is best known for developing Florida by building the Florida East Coast Railway. Many of the old bridges were converted to carry trails or serve as fishing piers. Sections of many were removed to allow boat passage. Some were demolished entirely. Bridgemapper.com has documented all of the remaining 23 bridges.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1922, 83'-long, reinforced concrete closed spandrel deck arch bridge has an elliptical arch, a cantilevered deck and modern structure mounted guiderail railings which replaced paneled parapets ca. 1975. The bridge is spalled, and steel channels have been bolted to the spandrel walls as reinforcement.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: William Krome, Joseph Meredith, Florida East Coast Railway; rebuilt by B. M. Duncan (Chief Engineer)
column20: Henry Flagler made his fortune by establishing the Standard Oil Company in 1870, though he is best known for developing Florida by building the Florida East Coast Railway. column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: William Krome, Joseph Meredith, Florida East Coast Railway; rebuilt by B. M. Duncan (Chief Engineer)
column20: Henry Flagler made his fortune by establishing the Standard Oil Company in 1870, though he is best known for developing Florida by building the Florida East Coast Railway. In the late 1800's, Key West was the largest city in Florida. Furthermore, it was the only city with a deep water port. In anticipation of the opening of the Panama Canal, Flagler decided to extend his railroad to Key West. Starting in 1905, the railroad and its miles and miles of bridges and fill sections was finally completed in 1912. Most bridges, such as this one, were closed spandrel concrete arch causeways. While the railroad initially led to boom years, the competition from newer Florida cities and ports such as Miami and Tampa as well as the loss of the cigar and sponging industries exacerbated the effects of the Great Depression in the 1930's. The railroad filed for bankruptcy in 1932. On Labor Day, 1935, ''The Storm of the Century'' as it was later known, struck the keys. The Category Five hurricane destroyed much of the railroad, washing out miles of fill sections. A rescue locomotive carrying hundreds of veterans working on building an auto route for the Overseas Road and Toll Bridge District (ORTB) through the keys was lost. In all, 428 people were killed. The bridges survived. The railroad could not afford to rebuild its line and went bankrupt. The Public Works Administration loaned the ORTB funding to build a highway through the keys, utilizing the railroad right-of-way and bridges. The concrete bridges, such as this one, were widened in by placing steel beams across the bridge and encasing them with concrete. Many of the old bridges were converted to carry trails or serve as fishing piers. Sections of many were removed to allow boat passage. Some were demolished entirely. Bridgemapper.com has documented all of the remaining 23 bridges.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1916, 2 span, 210'-long, closed spandrel filled concrete deck arch bridge with concrete balustrades is supported on concrete abutments. Although it is a relatively large example of its bridge type, it is not considered significant because its integrity was compromised when the bridge was widened on one side in 1953.''

column2: Old US 62 Cool Spring Creek Bridge
column15: Curved chord concrete thru girder and floorbeam system
column16: One of the only remaining examples of its type in Pennsylvania
column20: The Old US 62 bridge over Cool Spring Creek is a rare example of a curved chord concrete thru girder, in which the girder is curved to be thicker at midspan. While this type of bridge was common in Michigan, only a few examples were ever built in Pennsylvania. The only other known example in Pennsylvania is a few miles away on the old alignment of US 62 over Yellow Creek. Another example in western Pennsylvania (Lawrence County) was demolished in 2009. In 1948 US 62 was realigned and straightened, and the curved chord girder bridge was bypassed.

column15: Curved chord concrete thru girder and floorbeam system
column16: One of the only remaining examples of its type in Pennsylvania
column20: The Old US 62 bridge over Yellow Creek is a rare example of a curved chord concrete thru girder, in which the girder is curved to be thicker at midspan. While this type of bridge was common in Michigan, only a few examples were ever built in Pennsylvania. The only other known surviving example in Pennsylvania is a few miles away on the old alignment of US 62 over Cool Spring Creek. The only other known example in western Pennsylvania (Lawrence County) was demolished in 2009. In 1948 US 62 was realigned and straightened, and the curved chord girder bridge was bypassed.

The arch is skewed, having stepped ribs. When Walnut Street (PA 48) was realigned in 1934 and 1963, an arch culvert was built over Long Run. The culvert extends from the northeast side of the bridge. Vegetation covers the Old Walnut Street Bridge and extends to the realigned PA 48.

In 1985, PA 995 Warm Spring Road was realigned and the historic arch bridge bypassed. The adjacent landowners took over the old road, so the bridge is now privately owned. The old road functions as a driveway. The arch bridge dates from 1851. The bridge is built with semi-coursed rubble masonry. Shotcrete was applied to the arch intrados.

column2: Old William Penn Highway Lost Creek Bridge
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, A. G. Andrew Engineering Company (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The bridge carries a three-lane road with shoulders over a stream in an area dominated by a mix of mid- to late-20th century residential and commercial development. The road is a bypassed section of old US 22/US 322, the William Penn Highway, one of several early automobile tourist trails and cross-state highways established in the 1910s. The area does not appear to have historic district potential.... The 1-span, 60'-long, reinforced concrete, closed spandrel arch bridge has been altered by removal of the original standard concrete balustrades. In 1980, the left side concrete balustrade was removed and replaced by a concrete parapet, and in 1989 the right side balustrade was removed and replaced by W-beam guide railings. Constructed in 1930, the bridge is a late and altered example of the concrete arch technology that became popular in the 1900s and 1910s. It is not technologically distinguished. The bridge does not date from the late 1910s and early 1920s period of significance of the old William Penn Highway (old US 22), and is thus not historically significant in association with the history of the early tourist trail. The bridge was built in 1930 as part of the campaign to improve and widen the route.''

column2: Old William Penn Highway Thompson Run Bridge
column20: The bridge does not have a file on the National Bridge Inventory, so it is probably less than 20 feet long. It is on the Old William Penn Highway, which is an old alignment of US 22 constructed in the early 1800s (note the original Forbes Road is now Frankstown Road). The current bridge appears to be a state-standard concrete Tee Beam. The state did not build this type of bridge until around 1920. A similar bridge on Old William Penn Highway over Thompson Run dates from 1926, so this bridge may date from the same time. The bridge ends at a right angle with the 1916 Thompson Run Road Leak Run Bridge.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Oldham Bridge is located near the ghost town of Crumb, PA. The bridge is attributed to the Penn Bridge Company due to similar structures in Greene County. According to the PAHBI, ''The 49'-long and 12' wide riveted Parker pony truss built in 1908 is supported on ashlar abutments with flared wingwalls. The upper chords and inclined end posts are angles with cover plate, and the verticals are angles with battens. The field connections are bolted, a common 1900s detail for light truss bridges. The original lattice railings are inside the truss lines. The bridge appears to be complete, but it has no innovative or distinctive details.''

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 2002
column20: The 1898 Orange Road Bridge is a rare long-span pin-connected Pratt thru truss. The main span is 180 feet, which is a much more common length for a Whipple truss or a Parker truss. As such, the bridge represents the transition from iron to stronger steel trusses, since the extra trusses are no longer needed. The bridge is also unusual since the eyebars along the bottom chord are at deck level; the tops of the circular ends of the eyebars are above the level of the deck. The bridge is also the last remaining publicly-owned pin-connected truss of any type in Delaware County. The Orange Road Bridge was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 2002. It was closed to traffic in 2007, and the replacement bridge opened on a new alignment 200 feet to the north. The project cost for the new bridge is $4.1 million (or about $1,100 per average daily car). While there is still a chance the bridge may be rehabilitated and/or relocated for pedestrians, it is much more likely the historic structure will be demolished.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Trimpey and Whipkey (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1922, 3 simple span, 125'-long, T beam bridge (3 @ 41') with standard concrete balustrades is supported on concrete abutments with parallel wingwalls and solid piers. It has no innovative or distinctive details and is an example of a very common bridge type that was used with great frequency beginning in the 1910s and continuing through the 1950s. It is however, contiguous to the area of West Salisbury that is a potential historic district. The east side of the river would be the boundary, so the 1922 bridge is within and a contributing resource to the potential historic district.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: Nathan Holth of www.historicbridges.org describes the Orient Bridge as a 'glorious structure,' with its beautiful Victorian portals. It is one of the most ornate rural bridges in the entire state. The bridge is one of only a few (if not the only) surviving examples built by The Cleveland Bridge & Iron Company. It is one of the oldest bridges in the region and the last remaining Whipple truss in Pickaway County.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Minns Brothers (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1940, single-span, 67'-long steel stringer bridge with standard concrete balustrades is supported on ashlar abutments with flared wingwalls. Sections of the balustrades are damaged from weathering and collisions. The bridge has a concrete deck and steel angle welded cross-braced diaphragms. It has no innovative or distinguishing details and is an example of the most common 20th century bridge type in the state.''

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Bailey Construction Company
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The one-span, 113'-long, riveted Parker pony truss bridge built in 1932 is supported on ashlar abutments with concrete caps. The bridge has built-up upper and lower chords, and rolled beam verticals and diagonals. The cantilevered sidewalks have standard decorative lattice railings. The concrete deck was replaced in 1975. The Parker truss bridge is a late and undistinguished example of its type and design built to a state highway department standard. The truss bridge type and design was developed in the late-19th century and used as a standard by the department in the 1920s and 1930s.''

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Bethlehem Steel Company (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1939, single span, 158'-long, rivet-connected Parker thru truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments that have been capped with concrete. It has built up upper and lower chords, and rolled I section verticals and diagonals. The bridge is a state highway department standard design truss bridge that was used with great frequency [over 75 examples were built] beginning in the mid 1920s [and ending in the early 1940's]. It has no innovative or distinctive details.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The 36'-long, reinforced concrete closed spandrel deck arch bridge built in 1914 has parapets that are plain on the roadway faces and incised on the fasciae.
