The spandrel walls have been stabilized by four large tie rods that were inserted through the bridge in 1991. The reinforced concrete deck arch bridge gained popularity quickly after 1905. Somerset County used the technology frequently starting after 1907.''

column2: P. J. McArdle Roadway Viaduct No. 1
column15: Riveted Parker thru truss with 11 girder spans on trussed bents
column18: City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works
column20: The bridge was built as part of P. J. McArdle Roadway, which was built as a sloped hillside road to connect Mount Washington with the SouthSide (and Downtown Pittsburgh). The bridge is severely deteriorated, with a weight limit of 3 tons. Viaduct No. 2 (similar steel girders on trussed bents) was rehabilitated and reconstructed in 2003, and Viaduct No. 3 (an open spandrel concrete arch) was replaced in the 1980's.

Until the opening of the Mon-Fayette Expressway, PA Route 51 was the main connection between Pittsburgh and Uniontown. The PA Route 201 Interchange Bridge is an early example of a post-World War II grade separation. Allegheny County and the Pennsylvania Turnpike pioneered the use of this type for roadway crossings around 1940.

The Route 28 Barge Basin Bridges are twin girder bridges built in 1971. They are noteworthy for the deepness of their girders, allowing for a span length of 306 feet. As a comparison, the main cantilever truss spans of the nearby Highland Park Bridge over the Allegheny River are only 278 feet in length.

The Route 28 Barge Basin Bridges are twin girder bridges built in 1971. They are noteworthy for the deepness of their girders, allowing for a span length of 306 feet. As a comparison, the main cantilever truss spans of the nearby Highland Park Bridge over the Allegheny River are only 278 feet in length.

column2: PA 8 Bridge over the Pennsylvania Turnpike
column20: The bridge was built as part of the 1951 Western Extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike. All mainline vehicular overpasses were either thru girders or deck girders in the extension. The bridge was rehabilitated and repainted ca. 2005 and is one of the few that was not replaced when the section of roadway was reconstructed

The PA Route 51 Pennsylvania Avenue Bridge is built at an extreme skew in order to carry the road over the former P&LE railroad. The bridge is a state-standard Pratt thru truss (the only one in the county), though it has a stronger design of the portal bracing to accommodate the skew. It was replaced in 2011 with a modern bridge.

column18: United Construction Company of Albany, New York
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The single span, 127'-long steel riveted Pratt thru truss bridge dating stylistically to ca. 1910 is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls. The truss members are built up of angle and channel sections, with plates on the top chord. Rolled floorbeams, stringers and riser beams support an open grid steel deck that was placed in 1962. Pipe railings are attached to the inside face of each truss.''

The Palm Garden Bridge was built as part of the PAT South Busway project to carry the Busway and the T (the light rail) over Route 51 and Saw Mill Run. It replaced a previous trolley trestle. At the end of the bridge is a perpendicular similar structure that carries the Busway over US 19 (West Liberty Avenue).

The 142-foot Pancake Clarkson Road Bridge is a long example of a pin-connected Pratt thru truss. In the late 1800's, bridges with span lengths of around 150 feet were usually Whipple trusses or Parker trusses instead of Pratt trusses. Since the bridge is steel, not iron, it seems the Penn Bridge Company designed it to take advantage of the strength of steel.

The Panhandle Trail Harmon Creek Bridge was on a rail line built by the Pittsburgh, Cincinnati, Chicago & St. Louis Railroad. The rail line was taken over by the Pennsylvania Railroad and the bridge renamed the Panhandle Railroad Bridge. It is possible that the stone arch bridge was rebuilt by the Pennsylvania Railroad, since it appears to match other Pennsylvania Railroad bridges. The bridge was widened on the upstream side with concrete arches. By the 1980's the line was abandoned. In the late 1990's the right of way was turned over to the West Virginia Rails-to-Trails Council. The West Virginia section of the trail opened in 2000.

column2: Panhandle Trail Robinson Run Bridge Near Primrose
column15: Closed spandrel stone and concrete arch
column20: The bridge was built as part of the railroad that became the Pittsburgh, Cincinnati, Chicago, & St. Louis Railway, commonly known as the Panhandle Railroad. The railroad opened in 1865 from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, to Weirton, West Virginia. Circa 1900, the railroad was expanded, and the stone arch bridge was widened with concrete arches.

column15: Spandrel braced deck arch with Pratt webbing
column18: City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works, Henry Rust
column20: The burning of the Schenley Casino and damage to the adjacent trestle over Junction Hollow in 1896 led to the construction of both the Panther Hollow Bridge and the Schenley Bridge. The bridges are rare surviving three-hinged arch bridges from the 19th century. While very similar, the Panther Hollow Bridge's arch is made up of four ribs, with two stone approach arches on each side. The Schenley Bridge's arch is made up of six ribs with only one larger stone arch approach on each side. The Panther Hollow Bridge is the more famous of the two, probably due to the Giuseppe Moretti panther sculptures at the ends of the stone balustrades. The image of the bridge crossing above the once-beautiful Panther Hollow Lake was a popular in postcards in the early 1900's. After falling into disrepair in the 1990's, the bridge was restored in 1999.

column18: City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works, Works Progress Administration
column20: The WPA constructed the Schenley Park Bridle Path (as well as other trails in the park) in 1939. The bridges built for the trail consist of stone arches with corrugated metal arch liners. Bridge No. 4 is the largest of the WPA stone arches.

column15: Concrete T beam with a prestressed concrete I beam span
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 11 span, 551'-long T beam and prestressed beam viaduct built in 1934 and altered in 1960 is supported on a reinforced concrete substructure. It is finished with unique concrete balustrades with 2 sizes of holes on the railing. The original structure was a 12-span T beam structure. In 1960, the end 2 spans were removed and replaced with a single span of prestressed concrete I beams and a new, horizontally scored abutment. The original styled parapets were duplicated in 1960.'' The prestressed concrete I beam span is pictured.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, McClintic-Marshall Co. (Contractor)
column20: The Parker Bridge is one of three pre-World War II Allegheny River bridges north of Allegheny County that was rehabilitated. All others were replaced (except for the Hunter Bridge which is scheduled for replacement). According to the PAHBI, ''The inclined, 4 span, 1,140'-long (2 @ 252', 1 @ 390', 1 @ 225') riveted Parker thru truss bridge built in 1934 is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls and concrete column and cap beam bents on concrete pedestals. The heavy trusses are traditionally composed and were built to a state standard design. They have no innovative or distinctive details. Riveted metal truss bridges, common in the state by the early 20th century, were extensively built in Pennsylvania by the state highway department in the 1920s and 1930s.'' The bridge has one of the longest main spans ever built for a state-standard 1930's truss bridge.

Parolari Road is the old alignment of PA 153. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1916, single span, 49'-long, reinforced concrete deck arch bridge has flat paneled concrete parapets with paneled posts and incised spandrels. Built for the township, the bridge is an example of a bridge type and design that was common by 1916. It has no innovative or distinctive details. Nor is the builder, the Farris Engineering Company, noteworthy. The prolific firm was known for standard design reinforced concrete and steel bridges. Reinforced concrete deck arch bridges were introduced into the region during the first decade of the 20th century.''

column15: Warren polygonal thru truss with Pratt deck truss approaches
column20: The 1930 Patrick Street Bridge is the oldest vehicular bridge over the Kanawha River in Kanawha County and is the second oldest bridge (as of 2009) over the entire river. It is eligible for the National Register of Historic Places. Out of the three main spans over the river, the southern two are deck Pratt trusses and the northern one is a Warren thru trusses. Both the Warren thru truss and the Pratt deck truss were both standard designs of the State Road Commission. To the west of the bridge is an island, with the main channel on the north side. Therefore, it is logical that the thru truss would be the northern river span.

The Pawtucket Street Bridge is an example of a deck plate girder bridge. It appears to date from the same time as the Aiken Street Bridge over the canal, which was completed in 1897. Unfortunately, the bridge is structurally deficient.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The 1919 Paxton Bridge is a riveted Warren truss in which the top chord and diagonal endposts are composed of rolled H-section members. The other compression members are V-laced, and the tension members (including the bottom chord) are laced with battens. According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, this bridge is one of the first, if not the very first, bridge ever to use H-section members. As such, the bridge is historically and technologically significant. Due to deterioration, the bridge was closed to traffic in either late 2006 or early 2007.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The one span, 34'-long and 17' wide reinforced concrete deck arch bridge built in 1909 is supported on concrete abutments and finished with concrete flat paneled parapets. The bridge ranks as one of the earliest complete examples of the technology in the region, and it is historically and technologically significant based on its date of construction, and completeness. Reinforced concrete was first used for bridges in Pennsylvania in the mid 1900s, and it quickly became a popular material. Complete deck arch bridges from before 1910 are not common in this region of the state. This example is representative of the detailing typical of the earliest examples.''

The Pecan Street Bridge was built in conjunction with the flood control project in the 1920's in which the San Antonio River was straightened and the bypass channel constructed. These bridges consist of concrete tee beams with ornamental balustrades.

Ohio University - Lancaster Campus moved to its current site in the late 1960's, with the opening of John Brasee Hall in the fall of 1968. The university expanded significantly in the 1970's. At some point, this pedestrian bridge was constructed across Fetters Run to connect Festival Hill with the campus. The bridge is an unusual design, probably built by a local craftsman rather than an established company. The bridge is comprised of two intersecting kingpost-like trusses connected at the top by a horizontal member. All members are welded pipe. In 1989, the John Bright No. 2 Bridge was relocated next to the bridge to provide a larger, wider crossing. In 1999, the John Bright No. 1 Bridge was also relocated nearby.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, N. B. Putnam (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1936, skewed, 2 simple span, 88'-long, T beam bridge with standard concrete balustrades is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls and a concrete pier. It has no innovative or distinctive details.'' Contrary to the HBI, the abutments are masonry, dating from the previous bridge.

column2: Penn Lincoln Parkway East Bridge over Ardmore Blvd
column20: All original structures of the Penn Lincoln Parkway are considered to be historically significant, since the Parkway is an early example of a post-World War II urban highway. The arch was chosen for this location for the economy of materials and the desire to keep the superstructure below deck level (according to department records).

column2: Penn Lincoln Parkway East Bridge Over Ramp A
column20: All original structures of the Penn Lincoln Parkway are considered to be historically significant, since the Parkway is an early example of a post-World War II urban highway. As with most Parkway East rigid frame bridges, the fascia of the span is scored to accent the curved profile.

column2: Penn Lincoln Parkway East Bridge Over Ramp G
column15: Thru/deck girder and floorbeam system / stringer
column20: All original structures of the Penn Lincoln Parkway are considered to be historically significant, since the Parkway is an early example of a post-World War II urban highway. The bridge is unusual in that the northern girder is a thru girder and the original southern girder is a deck girder. Two stringers were added to the south (EB) for the 1981 addition of a truck climbing lane.

column2: Penn Lincoln Parkway East Lougeay Run Bridge
column15: Deck haunched girder and floorbeam system
column20: The Penn Lincoln Parkway East Thompson Run Bridge is one of the larger bridges on the 1962 Parkway East extension between Churchill and the Pennsylvania Turnpike. It is comprised of two girder bridges next to each other, one carrying eastbound traffic and the other carrying westbound traffic. The girders are haunched (meaning the girders come to a point over the piers). Since there are only two parallel girders per structure, they are classified as fracture critical (meaning that a failure of one girder would lead to a collapse of the bridge). The bridge is similar to the nearby bridge over Thompson Run, except that this bridge has 3 main spans instead of 4.

column2: Penn Lincoln Parkway East Ramp A Bridge Over Ardmore Blvd
column20: All original structures of the Penn Lincoln Parkway are considered to be historically significant, since the Parkway is an early example of a post-World War II urban highway. The arch was chosen for this location for the economy of materials and the desire to keep the superstructure below deck level (according to department records).

column2: Penn Lincoln Parkway East Ramp A Bridge Over Ramp FG
column20: All original structures of the Penn Lincoln Parkway are considered to be historically significant, since the Parkway is an early example of a post-World War II urban highway. As with most Parkway East rigid frame bridges, the fascia of the span is scored to accent the curved profile.

column2: Penn Lincoln Parkway East Ramp D Bridge Over Ardmore Blvd
column20: All original structures of the Penn Lincoln Parkway are considered to be historically significant, since the Parkway is an early example of a post-World War II urban highway. The arch was chosen for this location for the economy of materials and the desire to keep the superstructure below deck level (according to department records).

column2: Penn Lincoln Parkway East Ramp D Bridge Over Parkway East
column20: All original structures of the Penn Lincoln Parkway are considered to be historically significant, since the Parkway is an early example of a post-World War II urban highway. The bridge is unusual that the deck girders carry a curved, inclined ramp.

column2: Penn Lincoln Parkway East Ramp D Bridge Over Ramp A
column20: All original structures of the Penn Lincoln Parkway are considered to be historically significant, since the Parkway is an early example of a post-World War II urban highway. As with most Parkway East rigid frame bridges, the fascia of the span is scored to accent the curved profile.

column2: Penn Lincoln Parkway East Thompson Run Bridge
column15: Deck haunched girder and floorbeam system
column20: The Penn Lincoln Parkway East Thompson Run Bridge is the largest bridge on the 1962 Parkway East extension between Churchill and the Pennsylvania Turnpike. It is comprised of two girder bridges next to each other, one carrying eastbound traffic and the other carrying westbound traffic. The girders are haunched (meaning the girders come to a point over the piers). Since there are only two parallel girders per structure, they are classified as fracture critical (meaning that a failure of one girder would lead to a collapse of the bridge). The freeway was built as a bypass of the 1942 William Penn Highway, which also featured a long bridge over the Thompson Run Valley. However, the William Penn Highway Bridge, the Hall Station Bridge, was a cantilever deck truss. The Penn Lincoln Parkway East Thompson Run Bridge shows how far girder bridges have progressed in 20 years. The bridge is also the only girder bridge in Allegheny County where the girders are haunched over three piers.

column18: Luten Engineering Company, J Murray Africa
column20: Penn Street is the old alignment of US 22, which was rerouted around Huntingdon Borough in 1948. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1918, 2 span, 128'-long reinforced concrete deck arch bridge is supported on concrete abutments and a concrete pier with a brick bullnose and footer. The cantilevered sidewalk and steel railings date from 1948. The bridge was designed by the Luten Engineering Company, founded by Daniel Luten, an influential early 20th century designer of reinforced concrete arch bridges. This bridge is a late and altered example of a Luten design, erected at a time when many of his patents were being voided. Early and complete examples represent the contribution made by Luten in the development of reinforced concrete bridge technology.''

column2: PennDOT Maintenance Yard Tributary Little Pike Run Bridge
column20: The PennDOT Maintenance Yard Driveway Bridge was originally built as a larger bridge. Stylistically, it looks to date from around 1920. At some point the bridge was replaced. Instead of demolishing the entire bridge, PennDOT salvaged a portion of it and moved it to its current location to serve as access to a maintenance yard. In the photograph, note the trusses are cut from what was once a larger span.

column18: Penn Bridge Company, H. G. Hinkle (Engineer), W. H. Herr (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The one span, 82'-long and 39' wide, reinforced concrete deck arch bridge built in 1910 is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls. It is finished with plain spandrels, and the original railings were removed and replaced with plain concrete barriers ca. 1990. The bridge is one of 13 surviving reinforced concrete deck arch bridges built by the Blair County engineer, 1908-1913.''

column18: Thomas A. Gilkey, Farris Bridge Company
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 77'-long and 22' wide elliptical deck arch bridge built in 1912 has concrete parapets with posts defining the end of the span. The spandrel walls are plain. The bridge is one of 21 extant deck arch bridges built in the county between 1909 and 1930, and its detailing is typical of those designed by the county.''

column2: Pennsylvania Avenue Bridge Over McKinley Run
column15: Closed spandrel segmental brick arch (with ashlar spandrel walls)
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Pennsylvania Avenue Bridge over McKinley Run is one of only two brick arch bridges in western Pennsylvania. The structure is very unusual since it consists of a brick arch with stone spandrel walls. Thus it is eligible for the National Register of Historic Places. A similar (though two-span) example in New Brighton was recently replaced, adding to the rarity of the Pennsylvania Avenue Bridge.

column2: Pennsylvania Railroad Old Bridge Over Standing Stone Creek Bridge
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the Historic American Engineering Record (HAER), ''This abandoned railroad bridge, one of the few original PRR main line bridges still extant, consists of four semi-circular stone arches, each approximately 25' in length. This early structure parallels a highway bridge and a railroad bridge presently used by Conrail. All three bridges span [Standing] Stone Creek. The voussoirs and keystones are smooth-faced, while the remainder of the stone work is rock faced. The top courses of stone are gone, and the top of the bridge is planted with forsythia and small shrubs. The Pennsylvania Railroad constructed this stone bridge over [Standing] Stone Creek, at the eastern end of Huntingdon Borough, in 1848 and 1849, and the first train passed through to Huntingdon on June 6, 1850. In 1892 when the main line was relocated to the former Pennsylvania Canal Bed, just south of the original railroad alignment, this bridge was abandoned. A layer of soil gradually formed on top of the structure, and about ten years ago it was planted with flowering shrubs. Huntingdon borough keeps the area mowed and trimmed.''

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The original alignment for the Pennsylvania Railroad was through Newport along 3rd Street. Since the Pennsylvania Canal was built before the railroad, the canal originally occupied the prime land along the river. The railroad bridge was probably either widened or replaced with the existing stone arch in the late 1800's when the rest of the line was improved. After the Pennsylvania Canal shut down around 1900, the railroad was relocated onto the former canal right-of-way. The former railroad bridge was eventually converted to pedestrian use. Note the railroad used more expensive ashlar construction for the bridge, as compared to the rubble masonry used in the nearby vehicular stone arch bridges.

column15: Steel stringer with cantilevered main span
column20: The 1952 Pennsylvania Route 130 Overpass is one of the 1952 Western Extension bridges. The bridges consist of thru girders and stringers. Due to the vertical curve in the road and the cantilevered main span, the bridge has the appearance that is sagging. This bridge will be replaced due to future mainline widening.

column2: Pennsylvania Route 150 Bald Eagle Creek Bridge
column16: Only Parker truss in Clinton County
column20: The Pennsylvania Route 150 Bald Eagle Creek Bridge is an example of a state standard Parker thru truss. It is the only Parker truss that remains in Clinton County. According to the PAHBI (JPH Reviewer), '''The 1933, single span, 205'-long, 8 panel, rivet-connected, Parker thru truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls. The polygonal upper chords are built up box sections, the lower chords consist of channels with battens, and the verticals and diagonals are rolled sections. The bridge is an example of a state highway department standard design rivet-connected truss bridge with rolled section verticals and diagonals.''

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Thomas A. Mekis (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The three-span, continuous 301'-long steel stringer bridge built in 1953 is supported on a concrete substructure and has standard W-beam guiderails mounted to the original steel balustrades. The continuous span bridge consists of a 112'-long center span and two 89'-6'' end spans.''

column2: Pennsylvania Route 21 North Fork Dunkard Fork Wheeling Creek
column20: At Ryerson Station, the north and south forks of the Dunkard Fork of Wheeling Creek converge. Pennsylvania Route 21 crosses over the forks only about 1,000 feet southeast of the confluence on twin state standard concrete arch bridges. Both retain their original state-standard balustrades.

column2: Pennsylvania Route 21 South Fork Dunkard Fork Wheeling Creek
column20: At Ryerson Station, the north and south forks of the Dunkard Fork of Wheeling Creek converge. Pennsylvania Route 21 crosses over the forks only about 1,000 feet southeast of the confluence on twin state standard concrete arch bridges. Both retain their original state-standard balustrades.

column2: Pennsylvania Route 210 Little Mahoning Creek Bridge (Gahagan Bridge)
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Williamson Construction Company
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1931, 2 span, closed spandrel deck arch bridge has a reinforced concrete pier with scour protection. The original concrete balustrades were replaced in 1982 with modern metal guiderail railings, compromising integrity.''

column18: Chaney & Armstrong, Engineers, W. M. Pickett & Company, Contractor
column20: The Pennsylvania Route 231 Brush Creek Bridge is a less common type of segmental concrete arch. The parapets are integrated with the spandrel walls of the bridge. The engineers were Chaney & Armstrong, who designed many Washington County bridges.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 3-span, 214'-long bridge built in 1934 consists of a 150'-long, rivet-connected, Parker thru truss span flanked by two 32'-long T beam spans. It is supported on concrete piers and abutments. The truss is composed of built-up members for the chords and rolled beams for the verticals and diagonals. The cantilevered sidewalks are finished with standard metal railings. The concrete deck with parapets inside of the trusses was placed ca. 1985. The Parker truss design was developed in the 1870s. Rivet-connected examples have been in common use on Pennsylvania roads since 1900. The design with rolled beam diagonals and verticals was a frequently used state standard from the 1920s to the 1940s.''

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, J. H. Bradley Construction Company
column20: The bridge is one of only two thru girder bridges in Elk County. According to the PAHBI, ''The single span, 78'-long built-up thru girder bridge is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls. Rolled floorbeams support the concrete deck.''
The Pennsylvania Route 75 Overpass is an example of a steel delta frame overpass, used infrequently in the 1960's and 1970's.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 7 span, 450' long, reinforced concrete ribbed rigid frame bridge built in 1942 is composed of 3 continuous girders with hinged joints to allow for expansion and cantilevered end spans. Expansion and rotation at the joint is accomplished by providing a hinge composed of an eyebar with two pins fastened to channels embedded and anchored in the ends of the concrete girders at the joint location. The bridge is supported on 3-column concrete piers and stub abutments. In 1991 steel beams were placed between and connected to the original girders as was a new concrete deck finished with cantilevered sections and safety-shape barriers. PennDOT built at least 3 examples of this unusual design.''

The Pennsylvania Route 88 Maple Creek Bridge is an altered concrete arch bridge. A sidewalk was added to the west side of the bridge, separated by the original parapet. The parapet on the east side was replaced. Due to the paneled parapet, the bridge is attributed to Washington County engineers, Cheney & Armstrong.

The Pennsylvania Route 88 Whiteley Creek Bridge is one of the longest closed spandrel arch bridges in Greene County. In 1966, the 1930 bridge was widened with a stringer extension on the east side (the west side of the bridge is shown in the photograph). The original parapets were replaced with Pennsylvania standard guardrail. Since the bridge was built in 1930 on a state road, it was likely built by the Pennsylvania Department of Highways.

column15: Haunched thru girder and floorbeam system
column20: The Pennsylvania Route 917 Bridge is an unusual example of a haunched thru girder bridge. It is only one of a few such bridges in the entire state. The bridge was built as an overpass to Legislative Route 71, which was redesignated I-70. Constructed by the Pennsylvania Department of Highways, LR 71 is one of the few freeways in America to built by the state prior to the passage of the Interstate Highway Act. The bridge will likely be replaced due to planned widening of the interstate in the area.

column2: Pennsylvania Routes 18 and 21 South Fork Tenmile Creek Bridge East of Rogersville
column20: The Pennsylvania Routes 18 and 21 South Fork Tenmile Creek Bridge east of Rogersville is a state-standard concrete arch from 1930. In 1991 the bridge was rehabilitated, and the state-standard balustrade was removed and replaced with guide rail on the southern side.

column2: Pennsylvania Routes 18 and 21 South Fork Tenmile Creek Bridge North of Eastview
column20: The Pennsylvania Routes 18 and 21 South Fork Tenmile Creek Bridge north of Eastview is similar to the Freedom Bridge. The bridge was built with the same balustrades featuring alternating droplet and diamond patterns. The bridge was rehabilitated in 1995, and the south spandrel wall was rebuilt. The balustrade on that side was removed and replaced with a plain barrier parapet.

column2: Pennsylvania Routes 18 and 21 South Fork Tenmile Creek Bridge South of Eastview
column20: The Pennsylvania Routes 18 and 21 South Fork Tenmile Creek Bridge south of Eastview is an example of a state-standard stringer. It is representative of the first generation of stringer bridges built by the state after World War II. The bridge retained its original appearance, complete with its original railings. The bridge was replaced in 2009.

column2: Pennsylvania Routes 56 and 711 Norfolk Southern Railroad Overpass
column15: Riveted Warren polygonal pony with stringer approaches
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, last remaining Warren polygonal pony in Westmoreland County
column18: Pennsylvania Railroad, Pennsylvania Department of Highways, American Bridge (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI (MEM Reviewer), ''The skewed, 417'-long bridge consists of a 106' long riveted Warren pony truss with a polygonal upper chord span and 7 rolled stringer approach spans (2 @ 35.6', 1 @ 49', 1 @ 51.9', 1@ 52.11', and 1 @ 54.11'); 6 to the west of the truss span and 1 to the east. The trusses are traditionally composed with built up members. The substructure consists of concrete abutments and concrete column and cap beam bents. The safety shape barriers date to ca. 1985. The bridge is an example of common technologies and is not technologically significant, but it appears to be significant in association with the Pennsylvania RR main line. The bridge was designed and built by the railroad on the eve of its long period of decline.'' The deteriorated bridge is to be replaced in 2012 to 2013 as a design-build project.

column18: FIGG, The Walsh Group, McTish Kunkel
column20: The new Pennsylvania Turnpike Allegheny River Bridges are the first new bridge in Allegheny County to completely cross one of the three rivers (Monongahela, Allegheny, and Ohio) in over twenty years. The last major bridge built was the 1988 Monongahela Bridge. The new bridges are the second concrete segmental bridge in Pennsylvania, and the first that is cast-in-place (the first was precast) using balanced cantilever construction. The first bridge, the Pennsylvania Turnpike Susquehanna River Bridge, opened in 2007. The Pennsylvania Turnpike Allegheny River Bridges consist of two parallel bridges, each carrying three lanes. The structures contain nearly 50,000 cubic yards of concrete and 3,000 tons of reinforcing steel. Aesthetic features in the new bridge will include variable depth girders, and concave piers with a stone pattern. The cost was $190 million. These bridges represent the future of bridge design and construction in Pennsylvania.

column18: Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission, Modjeski and Masters
column20: The old Pennsylvania Turnpike Allegheny River Bridge was built as part of the turnpike's Western Extension in 1951. It is one of a few large bridges serving an interstate dating from before the Interstate Highway Act of 1956. The bridge is the longest deck truss on the Pennsylvania Turnpike, and it is third longest overall behind the Susquehanna River Bridge and Delaware River Bridge. The bridge features three cantilevered spans, due to its crossing of an island in the Allegheny River. The main channel span is an impressive 534 feet long. The bridge was replaced with wider structures in 2010.

The Pennsylvania Turnpike Beaver River Bridge is the fifth longest bridge on the Pennsylvania Turnpike mainline. At a height of 170 feet, it is the tallest mainline Turnpike bridge, though shorter than some on the Mon-Fayette extension. It opened as part of the Western Extension (between Irwin and Ohio) in December 1951. With the 2009 replacement of the Allegheny River Bridge, the Beaver River Bridge will be the only deck truss on the Pennsylvania Turnpike system. As of 2005, the bridge is not considered to be structurally deficient. However, since the bridge has no shoulders, the Pennsylvania Turnpike is studying whether to upgrade or replace the bridge.

In 1940, the first stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike opened between Irwin and Somerset. The original mainline overpasses as well as some mainline bridges consisted of arched concrete rigid frames, steel thru girders, steel deck girders, concrete tee beams, and arched culverts. Beginning in the late 1990's and continuing through at least 2020, the entire original turnpike is being reconstructed and widened. Almost all of the mainline bridges are being replaced as part of the project. This will include the Bedford Interchange Bridge. It is an example of an arched concrete rigid frame. The bridge is the alternate Turnpike rigid frame design with scored abutments, no columns, a recessed plain spandrel span, and closed parapets.

column15: Steel multi-beam with encased fascia girders
column20: The Pennsylvania Turnpike Business US 220 Overpass is an example of a steel deck girder. The bridge has aesthetic details such as encased fascia beams, decorative columns at the end of the span, and concrete balustrades. The bridge will likely be replaced when the Pennsylvania Turnpike is reconstructed.

column2: Pennsylvania Turnpike Clear Ridge Road Bridge (Cathedral Bridge)
column20: During construction of the Pennsylvania Turnpike, one of the largest road cuts ever constructed at that time was excavated through Clear Ridge. The excavated material was used to create a fill section over the Clear Creek Valley, including Clear Ridge Road. Therefore, a parabolic arched culvert was used as the overpass. The bridge is also known as the Cathedral Bridge, since its tall arched profile reminds some of a cathedral.

column15: Haunched deck girder and floorbeam system, widened by haunched girders
column20: The Pennsylvania Turnpike Dunnings Creek Bridge is the third longest original Pennsylvania Turnpike bridge. It is an example of a haunched deck girder and floorbeam system bridge, one of the largest of such bridges in Pennsylvania when built. In 1997 the bridge was widened by additional beams added alongside the original girders. The new fascia beams have the same profile as the original beams.

column2: Pennsylvania Turnpike Northeast Extension Lehigh River Bridge
column20: The Pennsylvania Turnpike Northeast Extension Lehigh River Bridge is one of the longest bridges on the Northeast Extension. It is an example of a deck girder. The bridge is to be replaced by wider structures in 2011.

column2: Pennsylvania Turnpike Northeast Extension Pohopoco Creek Bridge
column20: The Pennsylvania Turnpike Pohopoco Creek Bridge was one of only two truss bridges built for the Pennsylvania Turnpike Northeast Extension. The bridge is to be replaced in 2011 by wider twin girder bridges.

column2: Pennsylvania Turnpike Raystown Branch Juniata River Bridge East of Bedford
column15: Haunched deck girder and floorbeam system, widened by haunched girders
column16: Longest remaining original Pennsylvania Turnpike bridge
column20: The Pennsylvania Turnpike Raystown Branch Juniata River Bridge east of Bedford is the longest remaining original Pennsylvania Turnpike Bridge. It used to be second longest, behind the New Stanton Viaduct. The bridge is an example of a haunched deck girder and floorbeam system bridge, one of the largest of such bridges in Pennsylvania when built. In 1997 the bridge was widened by additional beams added alongside the original girders. The new fascia beams have the same profile as the original beams.
The Pentress Bridge is the longest and newest of seven concrete tee beam bridges in Monongalia County.

column2: Percy V. Pennybacker Jr. Bridge (360 Bridge)
column16: First Place - FHWA Excellence in Highway Design Competition (1984); Most innovative example of Austin architecture by the Consulting Engineers Council of Texas (1992)
column18: David McDonnold (Design Engineer), Buddy Johnson (Project Supervisor), Hyundai Heavy Industries (Steel Fabrication), Bristol Steel (Erection), Clearwater Constructors (Construction Management)
column20: The Percy V. Pennybacker Jr. Bridge is named after a Texas Highway Department bridge engineer who was a pioneer in welded bridge technology. The Pennybacker Bridge is noteworthy that it is a two-hinged arch, not a tied arch. Note the thinness of the supports under the road deck as compared to that of a tied arch. Built during the period of form-follows-function structures, the bridge is a rare example of a bridge designed to fit the context of its setting. Spanning a recreational lake with a lot of boaters and water skiers, the arch design allows the bridge to span Lake Austin of the Colorado River without piers. For aesthetics, the weathering steel was sandblasted upon completion to ensure the amber patina would weather evenly.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1885, pin connected, single span, 130'-long, Pratt thru truss bridge has several early and non-standard details. The floor beams are above the lower chords. The pins frame into the box-shaped verticals. There are minor welded and bolted repairs, the but the bridge is historically and technologically significant reflecting early thinking about design and connection details.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, oldest unaltered bridge in Venango County.
column20: The Petroleum Center Bridge was built as part of transportation improvements as result of Venango County's oil boom in the late 1800's. It is the oldest unaltered historic bridge in Venango County. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1884, pin connected, 2 span, 239'-long (2 @ 115'), Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on an ashlar substructure. The portal is detailed with corner brackets with pierced decoration and a lattice-filled pedimented top brace. The original floorbeams were built up sections, but a number of them and their hangers were replaced with rolled I sections in 1984. There are limited repairs to the verticals. The steel channel railings inside the truss lines were placed in 1947 as was the open grid steel deck. The bridge is historically and technologically significant as an early and fairly complete example of the important bridge type and as an example of the work of the Morse Bridge Company of Youngstown, OH.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 43'-long, 3 panel, pin-connected, Pratt pony truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with stepped wingwalls. The trusses are traditionally composed, but the design of the lower panel points is not common. Instead of suspending the floor beam from a U-shaped hanger, they are riveted to the bottom of the verticals, which are punched for the pin connection of the eye bar diagonals and lower chords. The verticals are toe out channels with laced webs to accommodate the connection design. The fabricator of the bridge is not documented, but the bridge reflects period thinking about connections and overall economy of material. The bridge appears to be complete and it dates stylistically to 1900 or before. It is a historically and technologically significant as an example of a non-standard design metal truss bridge.''

column2: Phipps Run Trail Bridge Below Tufa Bridge
column15: Closed spandrel concrete arch, faced with ashlar
column20: The tiny stone-faced concrete arch is eclipsed by the much larger tufa-faced arch above. The bridge connects the trail along Phipps Run with a trail that climbs up the ravine to the Schenley Park Visitor Center and Phipps Conservatory. In the 1980's or so, the trail along Phipps Run was washed out. A temporary wooden bridge was constructed to connect the stone bridge with the remnants of the trail (as seen on pghbridges.com). The temporary bridge was removed when the trail was reconstructed.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1988; oldest lenticular truss bridge in Pennsylvania; last remaining Corrugated Metal Company lenticular truss bridge in Pennsylvania
column18: Corrugated Metal Company (Predecessor to the Berlin Iron Bridge Company)
column20: The 1881 Pierceville Bridge is the oldest of four lenticular truss bridges in Pennsylvania. Rather than give the build date, the bridge plaque gives the patent date of 1878, indicating that the bridge an early example of a Corrugated Metal Company lenticular truss. The bridge has been listed on the National Register of Historic Places since 1988. Unfortunately, the bridge was damaged by flooding. Despite being one of the most significant historic bridges in the state, it is to be demolished by PennDOT. According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''The Nicholson Township Lenticular Bridge is a well-preserved example of a truss fabricated by the Corrugated Metal Company. Of special interest is how the company fabricated the pin connections at the end-posts and on the top chord. These connections on the Nicholson Bridge are not mitered--a more expensive procedure that the Corrugated Metal Company's successor firm, the Berlin Iron Bridge Company, would employ.'' It is essential that anyone interested contact their legislators to save this important historic bridge.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: Pigeon Key, only two to three acres in area (depending on the tides), was developed as a work camp during construction of the original Seven Mile Bridge. Once construction was completed, the island became a bridge tender / maintenance camp. The swing span of the Seven Mile Bridge was nearby. After the Great Hurricane of 1935, the Florida East Cost Railroad throughout the keys was converted to a toll highway run by the Overseas Toll and Bridge District (OTBD). OTBD took ownership of Pigeon Key, converting the key to its headquarters. The conversion, completed in 1938, included this wooden ramp to the island. Tolls were removed in 1954 and the OTBD was dissolved. After various other uses, Pigeon Key is now operated as a museum and historical site. Due to deterioration in the Old Seven Mile Bridge to Knights Key (Marathon), the Pigeon Key Ramp was closed to vehicular traffic in 2008. It is still open to pedestrians.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1988
column20: The Pine Creek Bridge is one of the most significant bridges in Pennsylvania. A remark in the PAHBI reads, ''This could be the best bridge in the state!'' It is a rare example of a Pauli truss, a lenticular truss variant. Augustus J. Du Bois states ''The form of the Pauli truss is so arranged that the maximum strains in the flanges shall be constant (see the History Cooperative link for more information).'' The bridge is one of about 50 surviving lenticular trusses in the country. The type was built almost exclusively by the Berlin Iron Bridge Company (Corrugated Metal Company) from 1878 to 1900. The Pine Creek Bridge is an especially rare example since Warren trusses rather than Pratt trusses are used as webbing. PennDOT, recognizing the significance of the bridge, is rehabilitating the structure for 2011. The bridge was disassembled in 2008 and will be re-erected in 2010. About 50 percent of the members will be replaced. The bridge is one of only a few non-urban metal bridges to ever be restored by PennDOT! PennDOT should be applauded for their work. Hopefully the project can serve as a model for future bridge projects. Note that another one of the few successful preservation bridge projects was Waterville Bridge, which used to span Little Pine Creek only 12 miles upstream. The bridge was also a lenticular Warren thru truss, dating from 1890. The bridge was relocated to Swatara State Park in Lebanon County when replaced.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1910, single span, 23'-long, reinforced concrete deck arch bridge has a high rise to achieve vertical clearance over the track. The abutments and wingwalls are concrete. The bridge is finished with one spalling concrete flat paneled parapet and one modern beam guiderailing placed at an unknown date. An example of a type and design that was commonplace by 1910, the bridge is short and undistinguished, and it has no innovative or distinctive details. The railroad line, a minor hauler of coal that served no major industrial centers, is not historically noteworthy.''

column18: Ohio Department of Highways, Bellefontaine Bridge & Steel Company
column20: The Pine Lake Road Bridge is a polygonal riveted Warren truss. It is the forerunner to all of the polygonal Warren welded truss bridges seen in Ohio. The bridge has been closed to traffic for several years. The Columbiana/Mahoning county line runs through the bridge.

The New Hampshire and Maine Turnpikes were completed (Maine, 1947; New Hampshire, 1957) and incorporated into I-95 in 1960. Since both turnpikes tied into the US 1 Bypass, there was a gap at the Piscataqua River crossing until this bridge was completed in 1972.

The Pitcairn Railroad Yard Bridge used to connect Pitcairn (at Wall Avenue) with the Pennsylvania Railroad Yard on the other side of Turtle Creek. The Pennsylvania Railroad station was also located just across the bridge. The station, as well as the bridge, was closed in the late 1970's with the demise of the PATrain. The pay office for the Pitcairn Yard was also immediately across the bridge at the entrance to the yard. The bridge looks similar to two existing Warren pony trusses built over the former Pennsylvania Railroad nearby in Westmoreland County. Those bridges were built by the railroad in 1902 and 1906.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: President and Cornplanter Townships, Venango County, Richard A. Bigley (Contractor)
column20: According to HAER, ''It is significant as a late 19th century example of a rural masonry bridge constructed at a time when most of its counterparts were built in the more common metal truss types. Although considered substandard at the time of its construction, this bridge's short span and low rise contribute make its engineering compensation by the construction of massive abutments an outstanding and enduring example of 19th century craftsmanship.''

column2: Pittsburgh & Lake Erie Railroad Ohio River Bridge
column15: Cantilever with a thru Pennsylvania camelback approach
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Albert Lucius, McClintic-Marshall Company, Dravo Contracting Company
column20: In general, this website does not cover railroad bridges. However, an exception must be made for the Pittsburgh & Lake Erie Railroad Ohio River Bridge. This massive cantilever bridge is one of the most famous railroad bridges in America, seen in many books about bridges. It has also become the symbol for Beaver County. In 1907, the Quebec Cantilever Bridge collapsed while under construction. Though many similar projects were cancelled, the P&LE Railroad continued with the design and construction of the similar bridge between Beaver and Monaca. The design was carefully reviewed and checked, and strict quality control procedures were implemented. The bridge incorporated many innovative structural details and designs, such as concrete pier caissons. After 100 years, the bridge still serves mainline rail traffic for CSX.

column15: Thru girder and floorbeam system with T beam and deck girder approach spans
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Welsh Construction Company
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The Pittsburg & Shawmut Railroad Viaduct carries a 2 lane street and 1 sidewalk on a reverse curve over a deep cut, 2 tracks and a small railroad yard of the P&S RR outside of the borough of Kittanning. The street parallels the Allegheny River. Just north of the viaduct is the Kittanning Bridge (03103800600080). The P&S was formed in the early 1900s, primarily to haul coal and timber. The 1931, 398'-long viaduct is composed of a 98'-long steel thru girder main span, 6 reinforced concrete T beam spans (3 @ 48', 1 @ 46.6', and 1 @ 32.6'), and a 75.6'-long deck girder span, all simply supported. The substructure is reinforced concrete column and cap beam bents and, beneath the main span, reinforced concrete arches. The T beam spans have paneled parapets on the river side and standard concrete balustrades on the other side. Jersey wall barriers have been placed in front of the deteriorating balustrade. Intersecting the main span at the end of the bridge is a concrete culvert carrying an access road to the yard over the railroad tracks (BMS #03402500100032).''

The bridge was built as part of the 1951 Western Extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike. All mainline vehicular overpasses were either thru girders or deck girders in the extension. The bridge will be replaced as part of the Turnpike widening, which will happen sometime after 2010. The bridge is part of a trumpet interchange with I-376 and US 22.

The 1920 Pittsburgh Street Bridge is an early example of an Allegheny County-designed concrete arch without stone facing. This type of bridge became the standard after Vernon Covell succeeded James Chalfant as County Engineer in 1922. Only the smallest of the Allegheny County arches did not receive ashlar facing, such as this one and the 1916 Thompson Run Road Leak Run Bridge.

column2: Pittsburgh-McKeesport Boulevard Bridge over Maple Ave
column20: The rigid frame bridge was built as an approach to the W. D. Mansfield Memorial Bridge over the Monongahela River. The bridge incorporates the period Allegheny County design features.

column16: Only Baltimore truss in Luzerne County, early example of a state-standard truss
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The skewed, 4 span, 355'-long bridge is composed of a single rivet-connected Baltimore steel thru truss span built in 1929 and 3 spread prestressed concrete box beam approach spans built in 1985 to replace T beam spans. The truss is composed of all built-up members of standard steel sections. Rivets have been replaced by bolts in some vertical, diagonal, and lower chord members. W-beam guide rails have been set to the inside faces of the trusses. The cantilevered sidewalk has a standard metal lattice railing. The Baltimore truss design, a variation of the Pratt design with subties and substruts, was used nationally from the 1870s through the 1950s. It was developed about 1871 by engineers of the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad. The subdivided panels more evenly distribute the loads in longer span bridges. Early examples were pin connected but like all major metal truss designs rivet connections dominated by 1900. This late altered example with all standard features was designed by the state highway department bridge unit, which commonly used Pratt and Pratt variation rivet-connected trusses from the 1920s to 1950s.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The pin connected, single span, 41'-long, Pratt pony truss bridge built ca. 1895 is supported on ashlar abutments with flared wingwalls. The traditionally composed trusses have no innovative or distinctive details. The upper chords and end posts are built up, the lower chords and diagonals are eye bars to facilitate the pinned field connections, and the verticals are laced angles. The fabricator and construction date are not documented in available records.'' The bridge was retrofitted with modern steel beams placed in the truss lines, turning the bridge into a thru girder. These beams are connected to the floorbeams. This low-cost solution extends the life of the old bridge.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Michael Perrish (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The skewed, single span, 53'-long, reinforced concrete rigid frame bridge built by the state in 1936 is composed of nine ribs. It is finished in the Moderne taste with severe blocky pilasters that extend into posts for the plain parapets. The bridge is historically and technologically significant as a rare example of its type and design. It crosses the Bessemer & Lake Erie RR, which is historically significant. This bridge however, was built by and for the state highway department.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The single-span, 51'-long, deck arch bridge is a Melan arch by evidence of a spall revealing a steel beam arch rib. The Melan system consists of curved steel beams imbedded in the concrete arch ring. In actual structural action, it is more like a steel arch than a true reinforced concrete arch. The bridge has paneled concrete parapets and it is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls. The Melan system was introduced in the United States in 1893, and although eclipsed by other arch reinforcing systems in the first years of the 20th century, it was an important step in the evolution of the technology. The builder and date of construction of this example are undocumented by available state and local records. It dates stylistically to ca. 1905. Fewer than 10 confirmed Melan arch bridges from 1900 to 1910 have been identified statewide, and this is the only identified example in District 2-0. Others may exist that cannot be identified because of lack of documentation or physical evidence from spalling. The bridge is a historically and technologically significant example of its type/design.''

Lebanon Church Rd was built in the 1930's to connect PA 51 (an arterial that connects to Pittsburgh) with the 1931 Allegheny County Airport. The interchange was built to address congestion an the important intersection. The bridge is an early example of a rigid frame over a highway. It was done in the moderne style, and features the Allegheny County fleur-de-lis railings. The bridge was designated the Grade Separation Bridge, reflecting the rarity of a grade separated intersection in the 1930's. Great Depression funding was used to construct this bridge (Federal Emergency Administration of Public Works).

column16: Last remaining Parker truss in Blair County
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The one span, 235'-long and 47' wide, heavy, riveted Parker thru truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls. The trusses are composed from built up members dimensioned to reflect the high capacity of the span. Built to a state highway department standard design, it has no innovative or distinctive details. It is not technologically significant. The bridge is not significant in association with the Pennsylvania Railroad main line. It was built by the state highway department as part of a reconstruction of US 220. Its purpose was to improve vehicular traffic flow, not to increase the efficiency of railroad operations.''

The Plumb Street Bridge is an abandoned bridge on an old alignment of Plumb Street in Darlington. It appears that Plumb Road is the alignment of PA 551, since PA 551 is now offset one block to the west along 2nd Street through Darlington. Perhaps rather than replacing the bridge, PennDOT rerouted the road to bypass the bridge. The new PA 551/PA 168 bridge dates from 1985. The Plumb Street Bridge is a riveted Pratt pony truss with large members. It most likely dates from the 1920's or 1930's.

column2: Point Marion Monongahela River Bridge (Demolished) (Albert Gallatin Memorial Bridge)
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Point Marion Bridge Company; Engineers:  Harrington and Cortelyou, T. J. Cambern, Resident Engineer; Contractors:  Pittsburgh Des Moines Steel Company, General Contracting Corporation
column20: The 1930 Point Marion Monongahela River Bridge was one of only three pre-World War II cantilevers left in Pennsylvania. The bridge was listed on the National Register of Historic Places due to its historic significance. Unfortunately, the bridge was in poor condition by the 1990's. It was imploded in November of 2009. The new bridge is a steel truss.

column15: Parker with steel stringer approach spans
column18: HDR (Engineer), TWE (Engineer), McCormick Taylor (Engineer), SWANK Associated Companies, Inc. (Contractor), American Bridge (Contractor)
column20: The Point Marion Bridge is a 21st century simple thru truss bridge, a design rarely built anymore. Built alongside the previous bridge, the through truss design was selected since the bridge was required to tie in with the existing roads on each side of the bridge while maintaining navigational clearances (400 foot clear span, 47 foot elevation). A girder bridge was not feasible considering these constraints. With the support structure above the road deck, the maximum floor system depth is only 5.5 feet. While most truss bridges are fracture critical, this bridge was required to have redundancy. As a result, the bottom chord was constructed of box sections consisting of web and cover plates bolted together with angles. Therefore, if an individual plate component failed, the bottom chord would not. The bridge was also designed with an extra wide sidewalk to accommodate pedestrians and bicycles. Once the new bridge was opened to traffic, the National Register-listed Albert Gallatin Point Marion Bridge was demolished.

column16: Last remaining Parker truss in Erie County
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, H. T. Osburn & Co. (Contractor)
column20: The 1928 Pollocks Bridge was an early example of a state-standard thru truss. Pennsylvania state standard truss bridges were commonly built from 1930 - 1941. The bridge was the last remaining Parker truss in Erie County when it was demolished in 2006. Though the bridge was not weight restricted, it's deck width was only 19.4 feet, narrow for a US highway. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1928, 2 span, 180'-long bridge consists of a 150'-long, riveted Parker thru truss main span and a 30'-long reinforced concrete T beam approach span. It is supported on concrete abutments and a concrete cutwater pier. The bridge, a late example of a common technology, has no innovative or distinctive details. Riveted truss bridges were used in Pennsylvania since ca. 1895 and were erected with great frequency by both county and state bridge builders in the 20th century. This bridge is one of approximately 90 riveted Parker truss bridges statewide dating from after 1925. The highway is not historically significant. Although now a part of US 6, at the time the bridge was built the highway was designated SR 79, a secondary road connecting Union City (Erie County) with the Pennsylvania-Ohio state line. It was redesignated US 6 following WW II.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The 1878 Pollocks Mill Bridge is the oldest active truss bridge in Greene County. It is a rare example of a Massillon Iron Whipple (double intersection Pratt) truss in which the diagonals pass through the verticals. The portals are comprised of characteristic Massillon Bridge company webbing. The trusses are noteworthy for containing many early details, such as chafing guides for the diagonals and rolled I sections with cover plates riveted to the flanges. The bridge was repaired in 1990, when the floor and floorbeams were replaced. As the oldest active truss bridge in the entire region and eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, it is one of the most significant remaining bridges in Greene County. With the Massillon Bridge Company's decorative ironwork, it is possibly the most beautiful.

column16: Oldest remaining truss bridge over the Ohio River in use between Ohio and West Virginia
column20: The Pomeroy-Mason Bridge was one of a few similar 1920's cantilever bridges over the Ohio River built by the Mt Vernon Bridge Company. One by one, all of the bridges are being demolished. The Pomeroy-Mason Bridge was demolished in 2009, replaced by a cable-stayed bridge. As of 2010, the other two remaining similar bridges are the 1922 Ironton Russell Bridge and the 1926 Bellaire Bridge. Both are to be replaced as early as 2012. The Ohio River's other 1920's cantilever, the Milton-Madison Bridge between Kentucky and Indiana, is also to be replaced around then. The Pomeroy-Mason Bridge was built as a toll bridge, and it eventually became a free bridge owned by Ohio. The bridge carried US 33, until the road was rerouted over the Ravenswood Bridge in 2003.

column15: Parker riveted with thru girder approaches
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, J. H. Wickersham (Contractor)
column20: Milford Street used to be the main thoroughfare connecting Port Royal with the covered bridge over the Juniata River. As both vehicular and railroad traffic grew, a bridge was needed to carry the road over the Pennsylvania Railroad mainline. Since there was insufficient room to build ramps for the overpass at Milford Street, the bridge was built a block south at Market Street, with an inclined approach to connect the to roads on the east side of the railroad. When the covered bridge was replaced in 1937, the new bridge was built as an extension of the Market Street Railroad Overpass. According to the PAHBI, ''The bridge carries a 2-lane highway and sidewalk over the Juniata River and a 2-lane street in Port Royal. The bridge is part of a viaduct that includes a reinforced concrete arch bridge, built in 1910, that spans over the Pennsylvania RR Main Line. The arch bridge is evaluated significant in association with the historic rail line (DOE 9/14/93). A 2-span, 80'-long, steel stringer bridge serves as a ramp between the viaduct and First Street at the bridge's northwest end. At the viaduct's western quadrants on First Street in Port Royal are a row of residences dating from the 19th century. While the residences at the northwest quadrant of the bridge have architectural integrity, those at the southwest quadrant are altered with replacement siding and windows, additions, and conversions to apartments. The immediate setting does not have the over all continuity or integrity of a historic district.... The 8-span, 1087'-long bridge, built in 1937, is composed of four Parker thru truss spans over the river, measuring approximately 222'-long each, a steel thru girder span over the street, and two steel stringer and a reinforced concrete slab approach spans. The deck was replaced in 1975 and the slab span replaced a steel stringer span in 1982. The rivet-connected trusses are composed of standard built-up chords and rolled steel section verticals and diagonals. The bridge is a late and undistinguished example of a truss design developed in the 1870s and used by the state highway department as a standard beginning in the 1920s. It has no noteworthy details. More than 75 examples from the 1920s to 1940s have been identified [though many have since been demolished]. The bridge is not distinguished by its setting, nor is it significant in association with the development of Port Royal. The town grew in association with the railroad as a local commercial and transportation center for the countryside from the late 1840s to about 1910. The bridge was built as a standard state highway department replacement project for a covered bridge.''

Milford Street used to be the main thoroughfare connecting Port Royal with the covered bridge over the Juniata River. As both vehicular and railroad traffic grew, a bridge was needed to carry the road over the Pennsylvania Railroad mainline. Since there was insufficient room to build ramps for the overpass at Milford Street, the bridge was built a block south at Market Street, with an inclined approach to connect the to roads on the east side of the railroad. When the covered bridge was replaced in 1937, the new bridge was built as an extension of the Market Street Railroad Overpass. Since the new bridge was built at a higher elevation than the end of the Market Street Overpass, this steel stringer ramp was built over the original approach. According to the PAHBI, ''The bridge carries a 2-lane ramp from First Street to the SR 75 steel truss viaduct over the Juniata River in Port Royal. To the bridge's east are a row of residences dating from the mid-19th to late-19th century. While the residence immediately northeast of the ramp has over all architectural integrity, those to the southeast of the viaduct are very altered with replacement siding and windows, additions, and conversions to apartments. The immediate setting does not have the continuity or integrity of a historic district. The reinforced concrete arch bridge adjoining the west end of the ramp spans over the Pennsylvania RR Main Line. The line has been evaluated historically significant by PHMC (DOE 8/11/94). The arch bridge, built 27 years prior to the steel truss viaduct as a grade-crossing elimination project, is recommended historically significant in association with the line.... The two-span, 80'-long, steel stringer bridge is composed of rolled steel section stringers with steel diaphragms and a concrete deck. It is supported on concrete-filled, fluted steel pile bents with concrete caps, and is finished with welded metal railings with concrete posts. The bridge is a historically and technologically undistinguished example of the state's most common 20th-century highway bridge type, with over 4,300 pre-1957 examples, many dating to before 1910. It has no noteworthy details. The bridge is not distinguished by its setting, nor is it significant in association with the development of Port Royal or the construction of the SR 75 viaduct. The town grew in association with the railroad as a local commercial and transportation center from the late 1840s to about 1910. A covered bridge spanned the Juniata River at Port Royal at least as early as 1875. The 1937 SR 75 viaduct and ramp is a later improvement, initiated by the state highway department as one of many such projects throughout the state to replace older bridges incorporated into the state highway system during the 1910s and 1920s.''

column15: 3-hinged ribbed closed spandrel segmental concrete arch, 3 vaults
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, George S. Richardson
column20: The Portal Bridge is one of the most innovative in Pittsburgh. It is an unusual three-hinged, post-tensioned concrete arch. The process of post-tensioning allows the bridge to be unusually long and shallow, with a length of 160 feet and a height of only 23 feet. The crest is only 2 feet thick. The bridge consists of four ribs. The ribs are covered by a concrete shell forming three decorative vaults, which are illuminated at night. Beneath the bridge is a pedestrian bridge over a reflecting pool. The shallow arch is an attractive solution for connecting Point State Park and fountain with Downtown Pittsburgh between the Interstate.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Brown Davis & White (Contractor)
column20: The Port-Emporium Road Bridge is an example of a state-standard 1950's stringer. The continuous stringers have riveted splice plates. The bridge retains excellent historic integrity, including its original railings.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1904, pin connected, single span, 127'-long, Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with flared wingwalls. The light, traditionally composed trusses were strengthened in 1991 by filling the lower portions of the end posts with concrete.'' The bridge is attributed to the Canton Bridge Company due to its details.

According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1895, single span, 25'-long, stone arch bridge is laid up with ashlar spandrel walls and matched ring stones. The flared wingwalls that have been reinforced with stone rip-rap. The pipe railings are not original, but were salvaged from another structure. The bridge has been extensively repointed.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The skewed, two-span, 310'-long, riveted Pratt thru truss bridge built in 1932 is supported on an ashlar substructure with concrete caps. The upper chords and end posts are built up box sections, and the diagonal members are rolled section. Lower chords are toe in channels with stay plates. The cantilevered sidewalk is finished with a metal lattice railing. Safety shape barriers were placed inside the truss lines in 1984.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The 1881 Potter Bridge is one of the most rare and unusual truss bridges in Western Pennsylvania. The bridge is an archaic Pratt truss with vertical endposts. The trusses are hung from the top of the endposts, meaning that the bottom chord is discontinuous with the endposts. Diagonals connect the bottom chord with the endposts. The end panels are without a true low chord! This unusual design reflects experimentation in early truss bridge design. The superstructure has been rated a 3 (serious), so the future does not look good for this historically significant bridge. Due to deterioration, it was closed to traffic sometime around 2011. There are no other similar bridges in the region.

column18: Owen and Plummer, Troutman and Flockler
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1920, single span, 63'-long, reinforced concrete deck arch bridge is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls. It is finished with concrete raised panel parapets with pyramidal-topped posts.''

column16: Possibly Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: Preachers Road is an old alignment of the Roy Furman Highway (PA 18/PA 21). The Preachers Road Bridge was built in 1915 on the stone abutments of the previous bridge. It is the second oldest thru girder in the county (the oldest is 1914) and is the only concrete encased thru girder. Such bridges were encased with concrete not only to protect the steel but also to make the structure aesthetically pleasing. The bridge was bypassed in 1954 when the new alignment of the highway was built. Due to deterioration, the Preachers Road Bridge is closed to traffic. It is doubtful the bridge will be restored.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, L R Owens (Contractor)
column20: Built in 1940, the Presqueisle Street Bridge is a late example of a state standard Parker pony truss. After World War II, stringers were constructed in such locations. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1940, single span, 128'-long, rivet-connected Parker pony truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls. The bridge has built-up chords and rolled I-section verticals and diagonals. It has a cantilevered sidewalk and it is finished with standard metal railings. The bridge is a late example of a state highway department standard design truss bridge that was used with great frequency beginning in the mid 1920s.''

In western Allegheny County, there are several islands in the Ohio River. The McKees Rocks / Stowe Township ''Island'' is unusual since the former back channel is dry. Railroads took advantage of the channel for their lines. Only one bridge, The McKees Rocks Bridge, crosses the dry channel in the center of the former island. The only other road crosses the railroad tracks at the southern point. In the northern part of ''The Island,'' this pedestrian bridge was built, extending from Kennedy Lane, to allow workers to access the factories on the island. The bridge consists of three tall Pratt thru truss spans and one short Warren thru truss (between two Pratt spans). The Warren span is likely a replacement. All truss spans have riveted connections. The bridge has been closed to pedestrians. It is to be demolished.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1896, pin connected, single span, 86'-long, Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on concrete-filled steel caisson abutments. Although the bridge is traditionally composed, it stands out in the county population of over 35 metal truss bridges because of its completeness and details that are associated with fabricator the Youngstown Bridge Co. These include the lattice web portal brace with a radiating pattern in the knee braces. The verticals and top lateral bracing have laced webs. The documented bridge is a historically and technologically significant example of its type and design.''

The Primrose Road Bridge is one of the oldest concrete arch bridges in Washington County, dating to 1913. According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, the arch bridge with a ''bush hammered finish has a vertical curvature that gives the bridge an almost peaked appearance. The unadorned, plain parapets are spalling, particularly at the base of the spandrel wall and in the arch barrel. The spandrel walls also have large cracks.'' Due to being in such poor condition, the bridge is likely to be replaced.

column16: Possibly the only one of its type in Pennsylvania
column20: The Prison Road Bridge is a rare example of a riveted Howe truss. In a Pratt or Parker truss, the diagonals are tension members (thin rods) and the verticals are compression members (thick built-up members, often with V lacing). Howe trusses are the reverse. Note the thickness of the diagonal members and the thinness of the vertical members in the bridge. In addition, the diagonals are parallel to the inclined endposts in a Howe, as opposed to perpendicular in a Pratt. The Howe truss is one of the oldest truss types, originally used as a wood and iron hybrid with wooden diagonals and iron verticals. Some early Howe truss bridges are covered. With the transition to all metal bridges, the advantages of the Pratt truss soon became clear; Howe trusses were very rarely built after that, while pin-connected Parker and camelback trusses were still being built until the 1930's. The Prison Road Bridge is the only example of a metal Howe truss bridge in Pennsylvania on this website. It is also an early example of a riveted truss bridge with an inclined top chord. Perhaps the Prison Road Bridge is a Howe truss due to early experimentation with riveted truss bridges with inclined top chords. Today the bridge sits mostly abandoned and forgotten. The bridge is closed and has been taken over by the adjacent property owner; the road on the southern side no longer exists.

This unidentified private road bridge over Rush Run is a nice elliptical concrete arch bridge with decorative paneled parapets. The bridge is unusual in that the road curves, following the arch ring. The private road, which is shown on maps but not identified, serves a few houses. The bridge was probably built by the county and eventually turned over to the landowners.

column2: Private Bridge Over Sinnemahoning Portage Creek
column16: Oldest known truss bridge in Cameron County, oldest vehicular bridge in Cameron County
column20: This private bridge is used for a driveway along the west side of Sinnemahoning Portage Creek from PA 155. It is possible the bridge carried the original alignment of PA 155. Based on the bolted connection details at the top of the diagonal endposts, the bridge is attributed to the Wrought Iron Bridge Company of Canton, Ohio. The bridge is the oldest surviving vehicular bridge in Cameron County, and it is the only pin-connected truss bridge. The bridge is probably eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, though no formal evaluation has been performed. Thankfully, the private owners seem to be keeping the bridge in good repair.

column2: Private Driveway Bridge at April Street
column20: This bridge at April Street looks as though the main span was built as a light girder for a driveway. It could almost be called a thru girder, since the small girders form the curb of the bridge. Since the bridge is riveted, it dates from before 1960. The approach span is really interesting. It appears to be recycled from either the endposts of a thru truss or the legs of a bedstead.

As of 2009, this is the only lattice girder bridge example on bridgemapper.com! This extremely significant and rare bridge is one of only two or three remaining in Ohio. The lattice girder was a standard catalogue bridge from the Canton Bridge Company. It was suitable only for short spans (too short for a pony truss). With the advent of steel stringers, this type of bridge quickly became obsolete. This example looks to have served a local road in Dillonvalle. Google Maps identifies the road as TR 1195, though this may be an error. Today the bridge functions as a driveway and is owned by the adjacent landowner.

Until approximately 2007, the Prosser Hollow Road Bridge was a pony truss, supported by stringers added in 1967. Despite the alteration, the bridge serving 50 vehicles per day was replaced. The new structure is a concrete arch culvert, which is a bit more visually pleasing than the standard modern beam bridge. It is also the first non-beam bridge over the Allegheny River.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Pumpkin Run Road Bridge is possibly the only surviving bridge built by the Wrought Iron Bridge Company in Greene County. The bridge stylistically dates to the late 1800's. It has standard WIBC details, such as rolled I beam verticals, pronged floor beam hangers and lattice-filled portal braces. The National Bridge Inventory dates the bridge to 1919. This is probably an error, although it is possible the bridge was moved to its current location that year. At some point girders were built on separate abutments below the floorbeams to help support the load.

The Pursley Creek Bridge serves a driveway that used to be an old road. The light Pratt Queenpost truss is composed entirely of angles, riveted together. The bridge retains its original laced railings.

column18: T. B. Dinsmore (Engineer), Lippencott Bros. (Contractors & Builders)
column20: The Pursley Creek Road Bridge, with a main span of 120 feet, is one of the largest closed spandrel arches in Greene County. It retains its original deck and its original neoclassical balustrades. Unfortunately, the balustrades are in bad shape, with several panels missing.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1932, three span, 124'-long, T beam bridge with standard design concrete balustrades is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls. The fascia beams are haunched. The bridge was built as part of the development of Pymatuning Lake, a 17,000 acre reservoir created to provide an adequate water supply for the Shenango and Beaver valleys, and a recreational attraction for the region.'' According to the 1913 Pymatuning Act, ''... the primary purpose of the Pymatuning Reservoir shall be for the conservation of waters entering the Pymatuning Swamp and for regulating the flow of water in the Shenango and Beaver rivers.
