A secondary purpose is to use the dam and lake as a reservoir to impound flood water during periods of excessive runoff from the 158 square miles of drainage area above the dam.''

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1998
column18: Cleveland Bridge Company? J. R. Gemmill
column20: Thanks to almost a decade of hard work by local citizens, foundations (such as the Historic Quaker Bridge Foundation led by Nate Clark), PHMC, and PennDOT, the Quaker Bridge was spared demolition and instead lives on as the centerpiece of the Historic Quaker Bridge Park. It is the first bypassed bridge to be converted to a park onsite in Pennsylvania. According to Nate Clark to www.historicbridges.org, ''The Historic Quaker Bridge is a 126-foot-long; Victorian-era Cleveland Bridge Company Pratt through-truss near Greenville; Mercer County, Pennsylvania. Built in 1898 to carry Williamson Road over the Little Shenango River in Mercer County, between Erie and Pittsburgh, this strong-yet-graceful pin-connected span was listed on The National Register of Historic Places in 1988. Quaker is believed to be the fourth state-owned historic metal truss bridges yet saved in Pennsylvania, and the FIRST in Western PA. It also is said to be the very first such state-owned bridge in the commonwealth -- vs. wooden covered bridges -- ever to be retired and preserved in-place. At the moment, while its replacement is being completed 100 feet upstream, the existing structure remains in the bridge inventory of PennDOT until it is formally vacated and conveyed, later this summer. The good news is that, after a 33-month-long effort to save it, the scheduled truss bridge razing and scrapping was successfully averted. One more structure listed on the National Register of Historic Places gets to survive. Significantly, the footing for the cut-stone west abutment supporting the truss rests within the canal basin of the 'Erie Extension' of the Beaver and Lake Erie Canal (~1845-1871), between Beaver Falls and Erie, PA. Now, county residents and tourists, alike, will soon have a truly special place to take time out of their hectic lives to stop, relax and enjoy this graceful bridge and its beautiful natural surroundings. They'll be able to picnic next to it and then take a leisurely stroll (or wheelchair ride) across this charming span to absorb and appreciate the dramatic geometry of its elegant, Victorian-era architecture silhouetted against the sky. They'll also have a chance to witness a lone Blue Heron flying just above the river's surface on its morning and evening 'patrols', right under the bridge's open-grate steel deck. There is a variety of other riparian wildlife along the river's banks to be observed, and massive Silver Maple, Sycamore and Black Walnut trees form a natural backdrop that graces the downstream side of the picturesque bridge. Here is a 'thumbnail' background on this structure: Located ~9 miles east of PA/OH state line, and ~1.5 miles northeast of Greenville, Mercer County in PennDOT District 1-0. Carried Williamson Road/SR 4006 over Little Shenango River in Hempfield Township. Single-lane, pin-connected, 126-foot-long Pratt through-truss erected by the Cleveland Bridge Company in 1898. Listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1988. Worthy preservation candidate was offered to a responsible party through PennDOT's Historic Bridge Marketing Program. Remarkably good physical condition of metal truss, after 108 years of continuous service. New replacement bridge built on different alignment, roughly 100 feet upstream from and nearly parallel with Quaker Bridge. Quaker Bridge remained in service during most of the construction of the new Williamson Road stream crossing. Span to be retired in-place and re-used to provide pedestrian-only 'bridge park' over Little Shenango River. Offers unique ''context-sensitive design'' mitigation for adjacent, modern concrete beam replacement bridge. Harmonious for over a century with both the built and natural environment at this site.''

The Montour Railroad was organized in 1877 to connect the Imperial Coal Company with Montour Junction along the Ohio River. The railroad was extended to the south between 1912 and 1917 to reach additional coal mines. This expansion included a bridge over PA 980. The Montour line was abandoned by 1986, and the bridge was torn down. Three years later the Montour Trail Council was organized, and the alignment has since been converted to carry the Montour Trail. In 2000, a new bridge over PA 980 was installed. It is a welded Pratt thru truss.

column16: Last surviving multi-span concrete arch in Mercer County
column20: The Race Street Bridge is one of two concrete arch bridges in Mercer County, and it is the only multi-span example. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1921, two span, 125'-long, reinforced concrete deck arch bridge is supported on concrete abutments and a concrete bullnosed pier. The parapets have large flat panels separated by pyramidal-topped posts. The bridge, designed by the county engineer, is an example of a type that was common by 1921.''

column18: Allegheny County, Vernon Covell, American Bridge
column20: The Ninth Street (Rachel Carson Bridge is one of the ''Three Sisters Bridges,'' which are three self-anchored suspension bridges side by side by side over the Allegheny River connecting downtown Pittsburgh with the North Shore. The three previous bridges were replaced at the same time due to navigational clearance requirements. The Pittsburgh Art Commission mandated suspension bridges for the replacement structures. Since the foundations were unsuitable for conventional anchorages, the self-anchored design was used. This was the first time the self-anchored design was used in the United States. The Ninth Street Bridge was renamed after Rachel Carson, an important environmentalist from the Pittsburgh area (Springdale). Her work led to the ban of DDT.

The bridge was built to replace a Warren through truss over the former Three Rivers Railroad (a subsidiary of the Pittsburgh & Lake Erie) that served the Monongahela Valley steel mills. It is a typical thru girder.

The Ravensburg Bridge consists of two deck cantilevers connected by a 150 foot high, 65 foot long mound of slag, a by-product from the steel-making process. The USS Clairton mill is one of the few that remain in the Monongahela Valley. The bridge is unusual since the center suspended span is much thicker than the anchor spans.

column2: Ravensburg Bridge Over Wheeling & Lake Erie Railroad
column20: The Ravensburg Bridge consists of two deck cantilevers connected by a 150 foot high, 65 foot long mound of slag, a by-product from the steel-making process. The USS Clairton mill is one of the few that remain in the Monongahela Valley. The bridge is unusual since the center suspended span is much thicker than the anchor spans.

column2: Ravenswood Bridge (William S. Ritchie, Jr. Bridge)
column16: 7th longest continuous span in the world, 2002
column20: The Ravenswood Bridge has a main span of 900 feet, making it the third longest-spanning continuous truss bridge in American and the seventh longest in the world (as of 2002). The bridge was built as part of a realignment and widening of US 33, which previously crossed the Ohio River between Pomeroy, Ohio, and Mason, West Virginia. Though the bridge was completed in 1981, the Ohio US 33 connection between the bridge and Pomeroy was not completed until 2003.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 40'-long and 19' wide stone arch bridge built ca. 1914 is laid up in rusticated ashlar. The corresponding parapets step down over the flared wingwalls. The bridge retains its original masonry pattern and crisp mortar joints, and it appears to be complete. It is, however, the newest of the seven nearly identical stone arch bridges dating from ca. 1905 to ca. 1915 in the county.''

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1976; Only suspension bridge in Texas still used for vehicular traffic
column20: The Regency Suspension Bridge is one of the largest, highest swinging suspension bridges (suspension bridge with an unstiffened deck) in the country. It is the last suspension bridge in Texas still in use for vehicular traffic. According to the plaque at the bridge, ''This area's first Colorado River bridge was at Regency, on Mills-San Saba County line. Built 1903, it served ranchers and farmers for going to market, but fell in 1924, killing a boy, a horse, and some cattle. Its successor was demolished by a 1936 flood. With 90 per cent of the work done by hand labor, the Regency Suspension Bridge was erected in 1939. It became the pride of the locality, and youths gathered there in the 1940s to picnic, dance, and sing. Bypassed by paved farm roads, it now (1976) survives as one of the last suspension bridges in Texas.'' Today the bridge still carries local traffic, and it is marketed as a tourist attraction.

The Regis Malady Bridge is similar to the Speers-Belle Vernon Bridge (I-70) over the Monongahela. Though not an unusual design, it is one of three in Pennsylvania (the other example is the Pennsylvania Turnpike Bridge (I-276) over the Delaware River in Philadelphia).
The Renfrew Bridge is a common example of a 1970's state-standard stringer on a low-volume road. Examples on larger roads typically had concrete parapet-mount guard rail.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, oldest non-railroad truss bridge on the North Branch Susquehanna River in Pennsylvania
column20: The Retreat Bridge is the oldest truss bridge (other than railroad bridges) over the North Branch of the Susquehanna River in Pennsylvania. It was originally erected ca. 1910 about 5 miles upstream and moved to its current location ca. 1930. The bridge was moved to provide access to the Retreat State Hospital, which closed in 1981. In 1988, the state opened the State Correctional Institution at Retreat. Please note the bridge is not open to the general public and cameras are prohibited on or across the bridge. The picture on the site is the view from US 11.

The bridge was built as part of the 1951 Western Extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike. All mainline vehicular overpasses were either thru girders or deck girders in the extension. The bridge will be replaced as part of the Turnpike widening, which will happen sometime after 2010. The Unity Center Road bridge is an uncommon thru girder overpass that has a separate sidewalk.

column2: Richmond - San Rafael Bridge (John F. McCarthy Memorial Bridge)
column15: Double deck cantilever with Warren approach spans
column16: The bridge is one of the longest truss bridges in the world
column18: Caltrans; rehabilitated by Ben Gerwick, Inc., Tutor-Saliba, Skanska

column15: Warren riveted with a steel stringer approach span
column20: The Rick Road Bridge is unusual since it consists of a truss and a beam span. The center pier is very thick, as if it was once part of something else, like a former bridge. Though there was a canal a few miles downstream along Elk Creek, there is no evidence a canal was ever in the vicinity of the Rick Road Bridge. According to the PAHBI, ''The two span, 95'-long bridge, built in 1915, consists of a 58'-long, eight panel, riveted, Warren with verticals pony truss and a 37'-long steel stringer span. It is supported on a concrete pier and concrete abutments with flared wingwalls.'' The pony truss is supported by a helper bent at midspan.

The old bridge, built in 1947, is alongside the replacement bridge. It is used as a fishing pier. Edward Rickenbacker (1890 - 1973) was a fighter pilot in both World Wars and was president of Eastern Airlines.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Whittaker & Diehl (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 2 span, 187'-long, built up thru girder bridge placed in 1934 is supported on ashlar abutments and an ashlar cutwater pier. The cantilevered sidewalk has a lattice railing.''

column18: Pennsylvania Railroad / Fort Pitt Bridge Works
column20: The Ridge Avenue (formerly West Ohio Street) and Ridge Avenue Extension (formerly Ridge Avenue) bridges are rare examples of Warren pony trusses in which the lower chords are composed of built-up plates, forming a girder. The wide sidewalks are outside of the trusses are supported by plate girders on their outside edges. These bridges and the Smithfield Street Bridge are the only truss bridges in Allegheny County with three parallel trusses. The bridge is deteriorated, so it will either be rehabilitated or replaced. Being a pony truss, the trusses themselves have the potential to be salvaged and reused as decorative elements on any replacement bridge.

column18: Pennsylvania Railroad / Fort Pitt Bridge Works
column20: The Ridge Avenue (formerly West Ohio Street) and Ridge Avenue Extension (formerly Ridge Avenue) bridges are rare examples of Warren pony trusses in which the lower chords are composed of built-up plates, forming a girder. The southern sidewalk is outside the trusses and is supported by a plate girder on its outside edge. These bridges and the Smithfield Street Bridge are the only truss bridges in Allegheny County with three parallel trusses. The bridge was closed to westbound traffic in the 1970's? when a pipeline was placed on the deck. It was closed to eastbound traffic in the late 1990's?.

column15: Skewed thru girder and floorbeam system
column20: The 1947 Ridge Road Overpass is one of the oldest state designed and owned girder freeway overpasses in Pennsylvania. The bridge is an example of a thru girder.

column16: Last remaining pony truss bridge in Monroe County
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The single span, 138'-long , rivet-connected Warren pony truss built in 1932 has a polygonal top chord. The floor system and bottom chords are encased in concrete. The diagonals are rolled sections. The bridge is finished with lattice railings. Although unaltered, the bridge is a late example of its type and design, and it is not historically or technologically significant. The DL&W main line spanned by the bridge has historical significance as a major coal hauling railroad and a variety of resources have been evaluated as significant because of that association. The DL&W was established in the 1850s and reached the height of its development of the main line from 1905-1915. This bridge is not evaluated as significant because of its later date of construction and its lack of association with a major improvement project or realignment. It is not the first bridge at this location, but a later replacement bridge built jointly by the state and the railroad for increased highway capacity.''

column18: The Ohio Bridge Corporation (U.S. Bridge Company)?
column20: The Ridgewood Drive Bridge is a common example of a welded Warren polygonal truss in Ohio. It replaced a pony truss bridge from 1911.

column2: Rio Vista Bridge (Helen Madere Memorial Bridge)
column16: Longest vertical lift bridge in region
column20: The Rio Vista Bridge is the longest vertical lift bridge in the region. Caltrans is working on a study to either widen or replace the bridge.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, last remaining simple thru truss in Delaware
column20: Excluding railroad bridges, the Rising Sun Lane Bridge is the last remaining simple thru truss bridge of any type in the entire state of Delaware. New Castle County developed a standard style of large-membered riveted truss bridges in the late 1920's. Other than this thru truss, only two comparable pony truss bridges remain. DelDOT should be applauded for rehabilitating the bridge in 2009-2010.

column18: George H. Dunham (Engineer); Concrete Steel Bridge Company, Clarksburg, WV (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1922, 3 span, 235'-long (1 @ 76'-5'', 1 @ 83', 1 @ 75'-5''), reinforced concrete deck arch bridge is supported on concrete bullnosed piers and concrete abutments with flared wingwalls. Ca. 1960 the raised panel parapets topping the spandrels were removed and replaced with beam guiderails.''

column2: Ritchey Drive Overpass East of Clear Ridge
column20: In 1940, the first stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike opened between Irwin and Somerset. The original mainline overpasses consisted of arched concrete rigid frames, steel thru girders, and concrete tee beams. The remaining tee beams were replaced in the 1990's. Beginning in the late 1990's and continuing through at least 2020, the entire original turnpike is being reconstructed and widened. Almost all original overpasses are being replaced as part of the project. This will include the Ritchey Drive Overpass East of Clear Ridge. It is an example of an arched concrete rigid frame. The original balustrades have been replaced. The bridge is noteworthy since it is skewed. It therefore has a main span 5 feet longer than the standard overpass. The bridge has also been in many postcards since it is at the edge of the Clear Ridge Cut, the largest road cut on the original Pennsylvania Turnpike.

column2: Ritchey Drive Overpass West of Clear Ridge
column20: In 1940, the first stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike opened between Irwin and Somerset. The original mainline overpasses consisted of arched concrete rigid frames, steel thru girders, and concrete tee beams. The remaining tee beams were replaced in the 1990's. Beginning in the late 1990's and continuing through at least 2020, the entire original turnpike is being reconstructed and widened. Almost all original overpasses are being replaced as part of the project. This will include the Ritchey Drive Overpass West of Clear Ridge. It is an example of an arched concrete rigid frame. The original balustrades have been replaced. The bridge is noteworthy that it has the highest vertical clearance of any rigid frame bridge over the Turnpike.
The River Road Overpass is an uncommon steel deck arch built as an interstate overpass. It is the only deck steel arch in the county, and is one of only two over the entire stretch of Interstate 79.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The 1925 River Street Bridge (Cambridge Street Bridge) was built in 1925 by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts Metropolitan District Commission. The bridge is an example of a three span elliptical arch. Like the similar Western Avenue Bridge, the concrete is formed into decorative elements rather than faced with stone or brick. The arch rings are accented to resemble voussoirs with accented keystones. The top chord below the solid parapet is also molded. The bridge piers are accented with simulated stone pattern. By 2010 the bridge exhibits spalling, especially with some of its neoclassical decorative elements. It is to be rehabilitated.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, McClintic-Marshall Company
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1934, skewed, riveted, 2 span, 295'-long, Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments and piers. The trusses have rolled section verticals and diagonals and built up lower and upper chords. The bridge has no innovative or distinctive details. Built to a state highway department standard design used with great frequency since the mid 1920s, the bridge is an undistinguished example of a common technology. Nor is the highway historically significant. Although now designated US 6, it was not a part of the original highway developed across Pennsylvania's northern tier. In the 1910s and 1920s it was part of SR 5, promoted as the Lakes to the Sea Highway, one of the many tourist trails in the state. Following the adoption of the federal numbering system in 1926 it was renumbered SR 19. Its was redesignated as part of US 6 following WW II.''

column2: River Walk Footbridge Between Crocket Street and Commerce Street
column20: In response to the 1921 flood, a bypass channel was constructed to bypass the U-shaped section of the San Antonio River in downtown. A 1929 report recommended developing and beautifying the bypassed portion of the river, though the Great Depression halted the project until the late 1930's. From 1939 to 1941, walkways along the river, stairs from street level to the river, and concrete arch footbridges were constructed over the river. This is one such concrete arch bridge.

column2: River Walk Footbridge East of Alamo Street
column20: In 1968, the San Antonio River was extended to the convention center and World's Fair park. This stone-faced concrete pedestrian bridge was built to span this extension and to connect the Convention Center to the stores on the other side of Commerce Street.

column2: River Walk Footbridge East of St Mary's Street
column20: In response to the 1921 flood, a bypass channel was constructed to bypass the U-shaped section of the San Antonio River in downtown. A 1929 report recommended developing and beautifying the bypassed portion of the river, though the Great Depression halted the project until the late 1930's. From 1939 to 1941, walkways along the river, stairs from street level to the river, and concrete arch footbridges were constructed over the river. This is one such concrete arch bridge.

column2: River Walk Footbridge North of Commerce Street
column20: In 1988, the Rivercenter mall was constructed, and the San Antonio River and River Walk were extended to the mall's food court. This bridge is one of a few similar pedestrian bridges to span this extension.

column2: River Walk Footbridge North of Market Street
column20: In 1968, the San Antonio River was extended to the convention center and World's Fair park. In 1988, the Rivercenter mall was constructed, and the San Antonio River and River Walk were extended to the mall's food court. The extension created a point where the river extensions converge. This pedestrian bridge spans the 1968 extension at the point.

column2: River Walk Footbridge South of Commerce Street
column20: In 1968, the San Antonio River was extended to the convention center and World's Fair park. In 1988, the Rivercenter mall was constructed, and the San Antonio River and River Walk were extended to the mall's food court. The extension created a point where the river extensions converge. This pedestrian bridge spans the 1988 extension at the point.

column2: River Walk Footbridge South of Market Street
column20: In response to the 1921 flood, a bypass channel was constructed to bypass the U-shaped section of the San Antonio River in downtown. A 1929 report recommended developing and beautifying the bypassed portion of the river, though the Great Depression halted the project until the late 1930's. From 1939 to 1941, walkways along the river, stairs from street level to the river, and concrete arch footbridges were constructed over the river. This is one such concrete arch bridge.

column2: River Walk Footbridge West of Losoya Street
column20: In 1968, the San Antonio River was extended to the convention center and World's Fair park. This concrete arch bridge is built over the extension where it meets the San Antonio River. It was designed to match the original 1941 concrete arch bridges.

column2: River Walk Footbridge West of South St Mary's Street
column20: In response to the 1921 flood, a bypass channel was constructed to bypass the U-shaped section of the San Antonio River in downtown. A 1929 report recommended developing and beautifying the bypassed portion of the river, though the Great Depression halted the project until the late 1930's. From 1939 to 1941, walkways along the river, stairs from street level to the river, and concrete arch footbridges were constructed over the river. This bridge is located over the south end of the U-shaped river section where it meets the bypass channel.
In 1988, the Rivercenter mall was constructed, and the San Antonio River and River Walk were extended to the mall's food court. This mall crosses the extension with this bridge.

In 1988, the Rivercenter mall was constructed, and the San Antonio River and River Walk were extended to the mall's food court. The food court and courtyard surrounds the beginning of this extension, formed into a small lake with a central river viewing platform and stage. This bridge leads to the platform / stage.

column15: Parker thru truss main spans with Pratt deck truss approached
column20: The Riverton Bridge reopened in October 2008 as a pedestrian bridge as part of the Great Allegheny Passage Trail, connecting Pittsburgh with Washington D.C. As part of the US $1 million conversion to the trail bridge, the southern approach, including a Warren thru truss, was removed, and an ADA compliant ramp was added. The bridge was built in 1891 by Pencoyd Bridge Construction. Pencoyd Iron Works started to build bridges in 1859, and the company built the Upper Steel Arch Bridge over the Niagara River. The company was acquired by US Steel in 1902. The Riverton Bridge was built as a railroad bridge to connect US Steel blast furnace in Duquesne with the National Tube Works in McKeesport. The bridge was first used by the Pennsylvania Railroad and most recently used by the Union Railroad before its conversion to a trail bridge.
The Riverview Drive Bridge is a state-standard example of a concrete tee beam. At some point, the road and the bridge were turned over to the Township.

column2: Robert 'Bob' C. Beach Bridge (West Buckeye Bridge)
column15: Three-hinged tied glue-laminated timber arch with FRP deck
column20: The Bob Beach Bridge was designed in cooperation with West Virginia University. It was funded by FHWA under a special program to encourage new technology. This bridge is an innovative glue-laminated three-hinged timber arch. It is believed to be the longest of its type in the world. The original deck was a fiber-reinforced polymer. Unfortunately, there were many problems with the original deck, which had to be replaced in 2009. Monongalia County and WVDOH should be commended for building such an innovative bridge.

Senator Robert C. Byrd is the longest serving senator in US History, and is currently the President pro tempore of the Senate. Born in 1917, he began serving in the senate in 1959. As chair of the Committee on Appropriations, Senator Byrd has been able help obtain federal funding for many projects in West Virginia. As a result, many, many things are named after him. The Robert C. Byrd Bridge is just one of the examples. (Yes, the Robert C. Byrd Bridge is not part of the Robert C. Byrd Highway which is not connected with the Robert C. Byrd Highway System). The Robert C. Byrd Bridge was completed in 1994, replacing the 1926 6th Street Bridge. The old bridge was also a cantilever, similar to the Ironton Russell Bridge. The Gothic-style spires of the old bridge (which were located on the top of the towers) were saved and located in various places in Huntington.

column2: Robert D. Fleming Bridge (62nd Street Bridge)
column20: The deck cantilever is unusual for bridges in the region in that the bottom chord has a very shallow curve. Typically the curves are much more pronounced, such as the Highland Park or George Stuart Memorial bridges over the Allegheny. The deck also has a vertical curved profile. Robert D. Fleming served in the state House of Representatives from 1938-1950 and in the state Senate from 1950-1972.

column18: City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works
column20: The McAfee Bridge is a very uncommon example of a one-hinged spandrel braced deck arch. The bridge was rehabilitated in 1981 in which the stone arch approaches were removed and the deck was widened. All of the original architectural features were removed. However, due to the rarity of the structure, the bridge is still historically significant. Robert McAfee was Secretary of the Commonwealth for Pennsylvania from 1905  1915, who formerly managed an ironworks near the bridge.

column18: Allegheny County, Vernon Covell, American Bridge
column20: The Sixth Street (Roberto Clemente) Bridge is one of the ''Three Sisters Bridges,'' which are three self-anchored suspension bridges side by side by side over the Allegheny River connecting downtown Pittsburgh with the North Shore. The three previous bridges were replaced at the same time due to navigational clearance requirements. The Pittsburgh Art Commission mandated suspension bridges for the replacement structures. Since the foundations were unsuitable for conventional anchorages, the self-anchored design was used. This was the first time the self-anchored design was used in the United States. Instead of being replaced, the previous Sixth Street Bridge was relocated to cross the Neville Island Back Channel of the Ohio River at Coraopolis. That bridge was demolished in 1994. The Sixth Street Bridge was renamed after Roberto Clemente, a famous Puerto Rican baseball player with the Pittsburgh Pirates and humanitarian. He is considered to be one of the all time greatest players. The Clemente Bridge is closed during Pirates baseball games to be used as a pedestrian walkway. The bridge is one of three Pittsburgh bridges with decorative lighting, thanks to Pittsburgh History and Landmarks Foundation (PHLF), the Riverlife Task Force, the City of Pittsburgh, and Duquesne Light.

After WWII, most bridges with main spans under 400 feet or crossing non-navigable waterways were girders. The 1963 Rochester Beaver Bridge, however, is a deck cantilever truss. The truss configuration is also uncommon. While the main span of the bridge is a Warren truss, the ends of the anchor spans are in the configuration of a Pratt truss. The trusses make a V shape over the piers instead of a diamond shape. While the bridge may not be common, it sure is interesting.

column16: Locally famous in that, until 2009, the name changed yearly based on the outcome of the 'Battle of the Bridge' football game
column20:
From 1988-2009, the order of the Rochester-Monaca Bridge's was decided each year by the winner of the Rochester and Monaca football game. Monaca High School closed after the 2009-2010 school year, merging with Center Area High School to form Central Valley High School. With the end of the ''Battle of the Bridge'', the bridge may forever be officially known as the Rochester-Monaca Bridge, although locals will likely still refer to the bridge by both names.

The bridge is a continuous truss that opened in 1986. Like the nearby Vanport Bridge, the top chord is flat and the bottom chord curves downward to form points over intermediate piers. The bridge replaced an unusual three-tower cantilever similar to the Ambridge-Aliquippa Bridge. That bridge, built in 1930, replaced a suspension bridge similar to the 1905 Newell Bridge, located just over the Ohio/West Virginia Border. The Rochester-Monaca Bridge is one of the few major modern truss bridges in Pennsylvania. It is the second newest major vehicular truss bridge in Western Pennsylvania, after the opening of the Point Marion Bridge over the Monongahela River in 2009.

The 1902 Rock School Road Bridge is an early example of a riveted Pratt truss. It can also be classified as a queen post, since there is only one panel between the inclined endposts. The bridge is one of several similar Nelson & Buchanan truss bridges in the county. Unlike some of the other bridges that have been restored, the Rock School Road Bridge still retains its historic integrity.

column15: Pratt pin-connected, cast and wrought iron
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: There are only a handful of similar remaining bridges in Pennsylvania and Ohio by the Columbia Bridge Works. According to the PAHBI, ''The one-span, 57'-long, wrought- and cast-iron Pratt pony truss bridge is supported on stone abutments. The chords and verticals are composed of I-beams. The lower chords are bars with bolted lap-joint splices. The diagonals are wrought iron rods. The bridge members are joined by a combination of pin connections and compression fittings. The verticals are compression fittings with cast-iron pieces at the top and lower chord connections. In 1967 the open grid steel deck was placed, and the floorbeams received welded cover plates. The ca. 1885 bridge is a rare and complete example of a cast- and wrought-iron truss bridge. It is historically and technologically significant. Based on the details, especially the use of rolled wrought-iron I beams for the compression members and the distinctive lower chord bars with bolted lap-joint splices, the bridge is attributed to the Columbia Bridge Works of Dayton, OH.''

column16: Utah Historic Site, only riveted Parker truss in state
column18: Minneapolis Steel & Machinery Co. (Fabricators), C. F. Dinsmore Co. (Erector)
column20: According to the Utah Historic Site Plaque, ''Constructed in 1924, the Rockville Bridge incorporates distinctive characteristics in its method of construction and is the only surviving example of a rigid Parker through truss type bridge in the state of Utah. The Rockville Bridge is historically significant in the region as the first direct link between Zion National Park and the North Rim of the Grand Canyon. Between 1924 and 1928 the Rockville Bridge provided the primary automobile route from Utah's National Parks to the Grand Canyon.''

column15: Pratt pin-connected with full-slope Pratt pony approach
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Rockville-Mt Nebo Road Bridge is in an isolated, scenic area of Preston County. The bridge is located a mile down a rough, rocky road. Do not attempt to visit the bridge in a car; you MUST have a vehicle with high ground clearance. However, due to the beauty of the bridge and the surrounding area, the trip is well worth it. The Rockville-Mt Nebo Road Bridge is an unusual combination of a single four panel pony truss and five panel thru truss. Due to the stars in the portal bracing of the thru truss, the bridge is attributed to the King Bridge Company. The builders plates have been removed. Unfortunately, the bridge has not been well maintained. Horizontal bracing as well as compression members exhibit severe section loss; some are almost completely rusted through. Given the remote area of the bridge, it is most likely it will be closed to traffic and abandoned in the future. A replacement would not be cost-effective. Bridgemapper.com would like to thank Evan Wiegand of Hagerstown, Maryland, for driving us to photograph the bridge.

column18: Lackawanna Steel Construction Corporation of Buffalo, New York
column20: The Rockwood Avenue Bridge is a nice example of an Ohio state-standard 1930's Parker truss. Ohio state-standard trusses are much less common than those in other states (such as Pennsylvania), since a smaller percentage of roads are state-owned. Note that most of the members are rolled beams instead of v-laced built-up beams that are more common in other states.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: Roger's Bridge is a small five panel pony truss bridge dating from the late 1800's. It is attributed to the Columbia Bridge Works since the vertical compression members are made of rolled I-section wrought iron instead of built-up, V laced members. The bridge is possibly the only surviving bridge by the Columbia Bridge Works in Washington or any of the nearby counties. As such, the bridge has been determined to be historically and technologically significant. Due to deterioration, the bridge has been closed to traffic.

column2: Rodi Road Ramp Chalfant Run Bridge
column20: In 1941, a new alignment of US 22 was constructed from Churchill to Monroeville. Part of the new route was an upgraded alignment of Rodi Road along Chalfant Run. Where US 22 leaves the Chalfant Run valley, an interchange was built with Rodi Road. This 1942 bridge over Chalfant Run was built for a ramp connecting US 22 with Rodi Road. It is a state-standard 1920's through 1950's tee beam bridge. The substructure is lined with terra cotta to protect it from acid mine runoff.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Roosevelt Bridge is one of the largest bridges over the San Antonio River. It is a three span elliptical closed spandrel arch. Architectural treatments include accented arch rings, concrete balustrades, and accented towers at the piers.

According to the PAHBI, ''The one-span, 190'-long, riveted, steel Parker thru truss bridge dates stylistically to ca. 1935, and it is an example of a commonly used state standard design of the period. It is located on a bypassed section of state highway. The trusses are fabricated from built-up steel members and rolled sections and is supported on concrete abutments. The original riveted lattice railings are inside one truss line and at the cantilevered sidewalk.''

Rosita's Bridge connects the La Villita village and Arneson River Theatre. It is named after Rosita Fernandez. Rosita was a beloved performer and icon of San Antonio. She was the featured performer at the Arneson River Theatre's summer-long Fiesta Noche del Rio, which was a fund raiser for children's charities. She also performed in television programs and acted in movies. The bridge was built in the project to beautify the San Antonio River in 1939 - 1941.

column16: Texas Historic Bridge
column18: Texas State Highway Department, Austin Bridge Company (Contractor)
column20: According to the Texas Historic Bridge plaque, ''Named for a former mayor of Llano, the Roy B. Inks Bridge was built in 1936 to carry State Highway 29 (now State Highway 16) over the Llano River. The Inks Bridge replaced an earlier 1892 truss bridge at this location, which had been swept away by a 42-foot flood crest on June 14, 1935. The Hayden-Cartwright Act provided emergency relief funding to replace this and other bridges lost during the catastrophic flooding of 1935. The Inks Bridge was designed by the Texas Highway Department's Bridge Division during the fall of 1935. It is composed of four 200-foot Parker truss spans resting on concrete ''cutwater'' piers. The construction contract was awarded to the Austin Bridge Company in January of 1936, and the new bridge was opened to traffic on September 16, 1936. The bridge features the original west side pedestrian walkway with lattice railings and all-riveted construction typical of the 1930's. In 2006, the Texas Department of Transportation added a new, wider pedestrian walkway to the east side in conjunction with this bridge rehabilitation project.''

The Rudolph Run Road Bridge was one of a diminishing number of Parker pony truss bridges in Greene County. According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, the bridge had "some distinctive details including the design of the upper chords with bolt spacers rather than battens or lacing on the bottom of the built up box section." The bridge suffered from much section loss in the stringers. After being closed to traffic for several years, the bridge was replaced in 2009. The new bridge cost $800,000.

column2: Rudolph Run Road Bridge South of Strawn Hill Road
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1921, reinforced concrete, elliptical deck arch bridge has incised flat paneled parapets that flare at the bridge approach. A cattle guard has been bolted to the bridge's east elevation. The bridge is an example of a common type used with great frequency by the state highway department since the early 20th century. It has no innovative or distinguishing details.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Runks Bridge is a two-span Pratt through truss bridge. It exhibits the distinctive details of bridges built by the Pittsburgh Bridge Company, Nelson & Buchanan agents. The bridge was closed to traffic sometime around 2009 due to damage in the western span causing the top chord to buckle upwards and the top chord to sag downwards at the second pinned connection from the pier. This damage is unfortunate, since the bridge is historically significant and had been well maintained, last painted in 2003. According to Nevin Byers (see the iceandcoal.org link), the spans were formerly part of a three-span bridge at another location.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1979
column18: Built by Jesse Beard, rehabilitated by Larson Design Group (Design) and Lycoming Supply (Contractor)
column20: According to TripAdvisor.com (see the external link), ''The Rupert Bridge is located between the Town of Bloomsburg and Montour Township in Columbia County. Spanning Fishing Creek, the bridge can be found on Twp. Rte. 449, off 4001, and near Pa. Rte. 42, in the village of Rupert . At a cost of $1,637, the Rupert bridge was built in 1847 by Jesse W. Beard. It was named after the nearby village which was settled by Leonard Rupert in 1788. Rupert established a ferry across the river and his home became a popular stop off place for travelers.''

column18: The Ohio Bridge Corporation (U.S. Bridge Company)?
column20: The Rush Run Road Bridge is a Warren welded polygonal pony from 1991. It was built on the abutments of the previous truss bridge. The base of the southwest endpost of the old bridge still remains, sticking out a bit from the ground. The Rush Run Road Bridge is heavily skewed. Note how the segments at the ends of the top chord are not symmetrical.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1937, riveted, single span, 205'-long, Parker thru truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with flared, stepped, wingwalls. Built to a state highway department standard design developed in the mid 1920s, it has no innovative or distinctive details. It was erected as part of the rebuilding efforts following the devastating 1936 St. Patrick's Day flood. Over 275 bridges, mostly in the western and central portions of Pennsylvania, were destroyed or damaged beyond repair. To replace them the department turned to established technologies like riveted metal truss bridges, used in the state since ca. 1890.''

The 1911 Russellville Bridge, serving 80 vehicles per day, was demolished in 2006. It was replaced by a new girder on a different alignment. The old bridge was eligible for the National Register of Historic Places. It was similar to many other West Virginia concrete arches, such as the existing (as of 2008) WV 4 WV 16 Big Otter Creek Bridge in Clay County.

According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1920, reinforced concrete, closed spandrel deck arch bridge has flared wingwalls and beam guiderail railings that were added at an unspecified date. The reinforced concrete deck arch bridge gained popularity quickly in the 1900s and was used with great frequency.'' The beam guide rails were replaced by plain parapets when the southern spandrel wall was rebuilt in ca. 2009.

The Sabraton Avenue Bridge is the only open spandrel concrete arch bridge in the county. Unlike many open spandrel concrete arch bridges, it has not been rehabilitated, and the road deck is still original.

column16: Only pony truss (functioning as a truss) in county
column20: The Sackett Hollow Road Bridge is the last remaining pony truss bridge in McKean County that still functions as a truss. According to the PAHBI (JPH Reviewer), 'It is traditionally composed of built-up compression members and eyebar tension members. Rolled floorbeams with U-shaped hangers support steel stringers and a wood deck. The lower panel point connections have been altered by bolts replacing rivets at the pin plates and by welds at the pins (ca. 1960).'

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, last remaining pin-connected bridge over the Kiskiminetas River
column20: According to the PAHBI (MEM Reviewer), ''The 3 span (1 @ 214'-10 1/2'', 2 @ 215'-5''), pin-connected Parker thru truss bridge is supported on a substructure of ashlar abutments with wingwalls and 2 ashlar piers. The trusses are traditionally composed with built up box section upper chords and end posts, and the lower chords are eyebars. Vertical and diagonal members are laced, toe-out channels. It is one of two nearly identical bridges built in the county in 1906-07 using funds from the Act of 1896 (see 64 0136 0050 1938). Most of the lower panel points of this bridge have been repaired with new welded material, and some outer pin nuts have been welded.'' The bridge is the last remaining pin-connected truss bridge over the Kiskiminetas River.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The 1,900 feet long, 100 feet high Salisbury Viaduct was one of the Western Maryland Railway's longest bridges. The Western Maryland Railway's Connellsville Subdivision connected Cumberland, Maryland, with Connellsville, Pennsylvania. Delayed by a construction accident that claimed 6 lives, the bridge was completed in January of 1912. It was used until 1975. In the 1990's, the bridge was taken over by the Allegheny Trail Alliance. A concrete deck was built in place of the former railroad deck. The bridge opened to trail users as part of the Great Allegheny Passage in 1998.

The 1941 Salladasburg Bridge is a late example of a state-standard truss bridge. Most bridge building was suspended for World War II. With technological advancements during the war, bridges that would have been truss bridges were built as beam bridges after the war. According to EPV of the PAHBI, ''The single span, 158'-long riveted steel Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls. The top and bottom chords are built-up sections. Rolled beam sections are used for the vertical and diagonal members. Rolled floorbeams and stringers support the concrete deck. A concrete sidewalk is cantilevered outside one truss, and has a lattice railing. The bridge built in 1941 is a late example of the type that was widely used throughout the state since the late 1920s and it is not technologically distinguished.''

In 1955, Folsom Dam was constructed on the American River for flood control, hydroelectric power, and water supply/irrigation purposes. Since the previous Salmon Falls Road alignment and crossing were to be inundated by the resulting Folsom Lake, a new higher bridge was completed just before the completion of the dam. Note the previous bridge, a concrete girder, still exists under the lake. The new Salmon Falls Bridge is a late example of a riveted Warren through truss. If the bridge would have been built ten years later, it probably would have been a welded/bolted girder.

The bridge was built as part of the 1951 Western Extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike. All mainline vehicular overpasses were either thru girders or deck girders in the extension. The bridge will be replaced as part of the Turnpike widening, which will happen sometime after 2010. The Saltsburg Road Bridge is an example of a deck girder.

column2: San Antonio River North Floodgate Bridge
column20: In response to the 1921 flood, a bypass channel was constructed to bypass the U-shaped section of the San Antonio River in downtown. In 1929, Robert Hugman presented a plan for the 'Shops of Romula and Aragon' along the bypassed river. This plan recommended floodgates at the north end of the bypassed section. According to the River Walk's website, this plan was delayed due to the Great Depression, though resurrected in the late 1930's. The paths along the river including pedestrian bridges were completed in 1941. This structure was built to hide the northern floodgates.

column2: San Jacinto Boulevard North Campus Bridge
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: San Jacinto Boulevard runs north south through the University of Texas's campus along Waller Creek, crossing it twice. Both bridges are similar two-span concrete arches.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The City of Houston as well as all of Harris County have no truss bridges and just two concrete arch bridges. The San Jacinto Street Bridge is the older of the two. The bridge is an example of an open spandrel barrel arch, which is less common than the ribbed arch. The area surrounding Buffalo Bayou in Houston is to be redeveloped. One proposal is to upgrade the San Jacinto Bridge to accommodate two-way traffic, eliminating the adjacent Fannin Bridge.

After World War II, few closed spandrel concrete arches were built anywhere, except as culverts (an arch under fill). The 1950 Sandy Creek Road Bridge is the newest public-owned closed spandrel concrete arch bridge in the county. The newest open spandrel concrete arches in the county also date from 1950, built for the Penn Lincoln Parkway East.

column18: Cella, Molnar & Associates, Inc.; Jacobs Construction Services / Boh Bros. Construction Co.
column20: The bridge opened to traffic on June 28, 2007. At 70 feet, it is the tallest bridge in Lee County. The final cost for the Sanibel Causeway replacement was $137 million.

The bridge carries US 1 Bypass along the top deck and a railroad on the bottom deck. The railroad deck has a separate retractable span. The New Hampshire DOT took control of the bridge from the Maine - New Hampshire Interstate Bridge Authority in January 2008 so New Hampshire can rehabilitate the bridge.

column2: Saw Mill Run Blvd Bridge over Saw Mill Run
column20: The bridge is a large example of an arched culvert.

column2: Saw Mill Run Blvd Bridge over South Main Street
column20: The bridge is an early example of a PA Department of Highways steel stringer overpass built for a highway. It is a late example of a Pennsylvania Department of Highways bridge built with concrete balustrade railings. Most bridges from the 1950's used PA standard guardrails.

The bridge was built as part of the 1951 Western Extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike. All mainline vehicular overpasses were either thru girders or deck girders in the extension. The bridge will be replaced as part of the Turnpike widening, which will happen sometime after 2010. The Saxonburg Road Bridge is an example of a thru girder.

column15: Closed spandrel elliptical stone arch, S-bridge
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1975
column20: The S Bridge is probably the oldest bridge in all of western Pennsylvania. It was built for the National Road (also known as the Cumberland Road), which was the first federal highway, connecting Baltimore with Wheeling, West Virginia. It was completed through Washington County by 1818. The bridge is called an S bridge because the approaches are built at an angle to the creek crossing. The National Road (now US 40) was rebuilt and straightened in 1929, when the bridge was bypassed by a new bridge. The southern half of the western approach was removed for the alignment of the new road and bridge. The only other original National Road bridge known to survive in Pennsylvania is the Great Crossings Bridge over the Youghiogheny River, although that bridge was flooded by the Youghiogheny Reservoir in the 1940's and only reappears every 20 or so years in times of drought. Years after it was bypassed, the S-Bridge was restored and turned into a historic bridge park. While the Washington County covered bridges are more well known, this bridge is older and thus more historic!

column15: Spandrel braced deck arch with Pratt webbing
column18: City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works, Henry Rust
column20: The burning of the Schenley Casino and damage to the adjacent trestle over Junction Hollow in 1896 led to the construction of both the Panther Hollow Bridge and the Schenley Bridge. The bridges are rare surviving three-hinged arch bridges from the 19th century. While very similar, the Panther Hollow Bridge's arch is made up of four ribs, with two stone approach arches on each side. The Schenley Bridge's arch is made up of six ribs with only one larger stone arch approach on each side. The Schenley Bridge is in a prominent cultural and educational center of Pittsburgh, connecting Carnegie Mellon University and Phipps Conservatory with the University of Pittsburgh and the Carnegie Museum and Library. After falling into disrepair in the 1990's, the bridge was restored in 1994.

column2: Schenley Park Tufa Bridge Near Schenley Drive
column15: Closed spandrel elliptical concrete arch, faced with tufa
column18: City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works, George W. Burke, Superintendent of Parks
column20: In 1908, two large reinforced concrete arch bridges were built for the Schenley Park Bridle Path. As a decorative feature for Schenley Park, the bridges were faced with tufa, which is a white, porous, cryptocrystalline calcium carbonate that is deposited in streams. The tufa used in these bridges came from Ohio. Interestingly this bridge is an elliptical arch, and the bridge near Serpentine Drive over Panther Hollow Run is a semicircular arch.

column2: Schenley Park Tufa Bridge Near Serpentine Drive
column15: Closed spandrel semicircular concrete arch, faced with tufa
column18: City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works, George W. Burke, Superintendent of Parks
column20: In 1908, two large reinforced concrete arch bridges were built for the Schenley Park Bridle Path. As a decorative feature for Schenley Park, the bridges were faced with tufa, which is a white, porous, cryptocrystalline calcium carbonate, which is deposited in streams. The tufa used in these bridges came from Ohio. Interestingly this bridge is a semicircular arch, and the bridge near Schenley Drive over Phipps Run is an elliptical arch.

According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, ''The single-span, 32'-long, steel stringer bridge, built in 1922, is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls, and has a brick-paved roadway and standard design concrete balustrades. It has no innovative or distinguishing details, and is an example of the most common 20th century bridge type in the state.''

The Scioto-Darby Road Bridge is the last remaining pin-connected Pratt truss bridge in Pickaway County. The bridge has not had a major rehabilitation since it opened. The future of the bridge is uncertain, especially since the condition of the superstructure and substructure is a 3 of 9 (critical).

The Scott Bridge, with a span of only 36 feet, is one of the shortest truss bridges in the region. The top chord of the trusses barely comes up to the road deck. It is one of the few pin-connected Pratt trusses in Washington County. According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, the bridge ''has the floor beams above the lower chords. It is a light bridge with the upper chords and inclined end posts being toe-out channels with laced webs. The flooring system is modern. with new floor beams connected to the verticals by welding. Deep stringers support an open grid deck, and modern welded channel and angle railings have been placed inside the truss lines.''

column2: Scrubgrass Creek Bridge (Rankin Chapel Road Bridge)
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1988
column20: According to the National Register of Historic Places form, ''The Bridge in Clinton Township is a representative example of a Pratt through truss bridge. It was built in 1887 by the Smith Bridge Company of Toledo, Ohio. It is made of typically configured members and its only decorative feature is a bridge plate on the portal. As a well preserved represented of a type of bridge used frequently in northwestern Pennsylvania, this bridge warrants listing on the National Register.'' The bridge was damaged when it was struck by a vehicle in 2003, and it was replaced in 2009. An interpretive sign placed to mitigate the loss of the historic bridge reads, ''During the oil boom years of the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, a number of modern iron and steel bridges were built to improve traffic within the Kennerdell vicinity. The S.R. 2005 Bridge over Scrubgrass Creek was constructed in 1887 by the Toledo Bridge Company. The bridge was built following the decline of the Kennerdell woolen mill complex, although the settlement at the location continued to serve residents of the community. The bridge was constructed during a period when oil production was a significant industry for Clinton Township and Venango County.''
The Scullton Road Bridge is an example of a state-standard stringer. It replaced a covered bridge, which still stands next to the bridge.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1-span, 40'-long stone arch bridge with dressed red sandstone voussoirs is supported on stone abutments. It has semi-coursed rubble masonry spandrel walls and parapets with an arched profile. The date of construction and builder of the bridge are undocumented by available records. The bridge dates by style to ca. 1895. The bridge is historically significant as a contributing resource to the potential Newport historic district. The NR-nomination specifically mentions the bridge as a contributing resource. The bridge dates from the district's period of significance and is associated historically with the significant themes of transportation and commerce.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Farris Engineering Company (Farris Bridge Company), Victor C. Minteer
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The one span, 91'-long Warren with a polygonal top chord pony truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments. It was built in 1929. The upper and lower chords are rolled I section, and they are connected by rivets at the gusset plates except for the interior bars of the lower chords that are pinned rather than riveted. The gusset plates were used to connect the heavy, wide diagonals to the lower chord.... The pinned lower chord is a technologically significant detail.''

Seven Creeks Road crosses Castile Run several times in the area of the bridge. However, all crossings to the west are fords. If you are visiting this bridge, approach it from the east. The bridge is the largest of a few remaining Parker pony truss bridges in Greene County. The builder is not documented, although it was possibly built by the Penn Bridge Company, which built the other Greene County Parker truss bridges from the same time period. The steel stamp reads Phoenix.

column15: Tied arch supporting a Pratt thru truss
column20: The National Register-Eligible Seventh Street Bridge is the last remaining thru truss in Potter County. In 1983 a tied arch structure was added to support the bridge; it no longer functions as a truss. This is an innovative solution to extend the life of the historic bridge. Once again the bridge is threatened with demolition. Hopefully Coudersport can again preserve this historic structure.

column15: Haunched tee beam with an open spandrel arch span, concrete girder spans, and concrete tee beam spans
column20: The Seventh Street Viaduct was built in 1913 with open spandrel arches over the channels of the Clear Fork Trinity River and concrete deck girder spans everywhere else. In 1955 the Clear Fork Trinity River was channelized, and the western half of the bridge was replaced. Haunched concrete tee beam spans were built over the river, as shown in the photograph. The surviving arch span is the easternmost span of the bridge. View the bridge in the Virtual Earth link to see the arch span. In 2010 or 2011, the 1913 portion of the bridge (including the arch) is to be replaced.

column16: Last remaining two-span thru truss over Conemaugh River
column20: According to the PAHBI (MEM Reviewer), ''The bridge was field inspected because the bridge inspection folder could not be located. The 2 span, 377'-long riveted Parker thru truss bridge built in 1933 is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls and a concrete pier with terra cotta protection from acid coal mine runoff. The upper chords and inclined end posts are built up box sections, and the lower chords are tow out angles with battens. The web members are rolled. The bridge exhibits no innovative or distinctive details. It is an example of a standard design that the state highway department used with great frequency during the 1930s, and neither the bridge nor its setting are historically or technologically significant.''

The modern Sewickley Bridge replaced a cantilever thru truss of the same dimensions in 1981. The new bridge was built on the piers of the former structure from 1911. The plaque and a few of the finials from the previous bridge survive. While the bridge is of similar form to the previous bridge, it lacks hinges, making the bridge a continuous truss.

The Shamrock Bridge is a late example of a Parker pony truss from 1936. It is rare to see such a bridge not built to a Pennsylvania Department of Highways Standard Plan. The builder's plaque contains just the date and the names of the County Commissioners; the engineering company is omitted. Other riveted Parker trusses in the county have been built by the Penn Bridge Company. The bridge appears to be older than it is, since it is built on the ashlar abutments of the previous bridge.
The Shanksville Road Bridge is an example of a state-standard multi-beam bridge.
The bridge served as an entrance to the now defunct Sharon Steel Mill.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Bethlehem Steel Company (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1937, skewed, 2 span, 340'-long, rivet-connected Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls and a concrete pier. The upper chords, lower chords, and verticals in the end panels are built up. The diagonals and other verticals are rolled I sections.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Wrought Iron Bridge Company, rehabilitated in 2010 by Kinsley Construction
column20: The historically significant Sheep Bridge was rehabilitated in 2010 by PennDOT. As a result, the weight limit was raised from 3 tons to 15 tons. As part of the project, the deck was replaced and the bridge was painted blue from green. It is one of the few bridges in the state that has been rehabilitated instead of replaced. According to the PAHBI, ''The single span, 186'-long, pin-connected, double intersection Pratt (or Whipple) thru truss bridge built in 1889 is supported on ashlar abutments. The bridge has eye bar lower chords and built-up upper chords of standard metal sections. The eye bar diagonals extend across two panels. U-shaped hangers carry rolled section floorbeams, steel stringers, and an open grid deck placed in 1950. It has double-loop floorbeam hangers in the end panels, a detail associated with Wrought Iron Bridge Co. bridges. It has lattice portals with builders plaques and medallions with the ''1889'' date. Original railings have been replaced by welded channel railings (ca. 1950). W-beam guide railings have been placed to the inside of the channel railings (ca. 1980). The survey has identified fewer than 10 pre-1890 Whipple truss bridges. This is one of two complete examples in York County (the other is BMS# 66 4017 0030 0000, built in 1884), both fabricated by the Wrought Iron Bridge Co., one of the nation's leading late-19th-century metal bridge builders. The bridge is a historically and technologically significant example of its type/design.''

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, American Bridge Company
column20: The Shelocta Bridge is an early example of a Pennsylvania state-standard truss bridge. Pennsylvania typically built Parker pony truss bridges. The Shelocta Bridge is the less common state-standard example of a polygonal Warren truss. Interestingly, Pennsylvania experimented with a polygonal Warren with some pinned connections a year or two after the completion of the all-riveted Shelocta Bridge.
In 1965, the Shenango River Dam was completed, impounding water to form the Shenango River Lake. A new bridge and a filled causeway were created to carry PA Route 18 over the lake.

column2: Shenango Valley Freeway Shenango River Bridge
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1956, 4 span continuous span, 378'-long, skewed steel stringer bridge (1 @ 85', 2 @ 104', 1 @ 85') is supported on concrete abutments and concrete piers. The bridge is built as 2 independent structures with the highway divider placed over the joint. The bridge has splice plates, steel I beam diaphragms, and 4 rail high steel railings.''

The Sherwood-Greenbrier Road Bridge is a 1930's standard WVDOH Warren pony truss. Though there may be other similar examples in West Virginia, there are none nearby. In fact, the bridge is the only truss bridge in all of Doddridge County! That being the case, the bridge deserves to be preserved as locally being the last of its kind.

The Shippingport Bridge is the only curved cantilever (in that the suspended span is a thru truss and the anchor spans are deck trusses) over the entire Ohio River. It is located adjacent to the Beaver Valley Nuclear Generating Station. The now-decommissioned Shippingport Atomic Power Station (the predecessor to the current facility) was the world's first peacetime atomic power station.

The first bridge over the Ohio River at Point Pleasant, West Virginia, was the infamous 1928 Silver Bridge. It was called the Silver Bridge due to its aluminum paint. The Silver Bridge was an unusual eyebar chain suspension bridge in which the eyebar chain was also the top chord of the stiffening truss at the center and ends of the bridge. The eyebar chains were composed of two eyebars per link of high strength steel (instead of several eyebars per link). Without extra parallel eyebars for redundancy, one broken link could impose excessive loading on the other eyebar, leading to the collapse of the chain and therefore the bridge. This is exactly what happened on December 15, 1967, when a tiny crack in an eyebar became critical. 46 people died in the tragedy. The disaster led to modern bridge inspection standards. The replacement bridge, the Silver Memorial Bridge, was quickly built to replace the Silver Bridge. It opened in 1969. The sister bridge to the Silver Bridge was at St Marys, WV, located further upstream over the Ohio River. As a result of the disaster, the St Marys Bridge was demolished for precautionary reasons and replaced with a similar cantilever. One other similar bridge, the Hercilio Luz Bridge in Florianopolis, Brazil, still exists, though it was closed to vehicular traffic in 1991.

The Simeon Willis Memorial Bridge (13th Street Bridge) is one of the few Ohio River crossings constructed in the 1980's. A second bridge at Ashland was first proposed in the early 1970's. It was to cross the river at either 34th Street or 45th Street, as part of a bypass of Ashland. Eventually the bypass was cancelled and downtown merchants got their way, and the new bridge was built parallel to the existing Ben Williamson Bridge (12th Street Bridge), forming a one-way couplet. Simeon Willis Memorial Bridge was repainted bright blue in 2005 (painting had just begun on the south end when the photograph was taken), and the Ben Williamson Bridge was repainted bright green in 2007. The blue and green represent the colors of Ashland, Kentucky.

According to the PAHBI, ''The 3 panel, 39'-long, pin-connected Pratt pony truss bridge with the floor beams above the lower chords is supported on ashlar abutments with wingwalls. The trusses are traditionally composed, and have no innovative or distinctive details. The outriggers are original, but their welded connections to the floor beams are not.''

The Simpson Hollow Bridge is a lightly-traveled full slope pony truss in a beautiful setting. The bridge is one of a few remaining in the county built by the York Bridge Company. Spanning 78 feet, it is a tall example, with trusses almost high enough to be a thru truss. As with several Fayette County pony trusses, the bearings were encased in concrete.

column18: Allegheny County, Fort Pitt Bridge Works, Warren and Wetmore
column20: The Sixteenth Street Bridge might be the most beautiful bridge in Pittsburgh. Like many city bridges from the time, the design was heavily influenced by the Pittsburgh Art Commission. The firm Warren & Wetmore, most famous for Grand Central Station, designed the architectural aspects of the bridge. At the ends of the arches above the sidewalk are four stone pylons that rise approximately 62 feet above the deck. They are topped with bronze armillary spheres by New York sculptor Leo Lentilli. The spheres contain winged horses and the signs of the zodiac. Other decorations on the pylons include a frieze of 6 fish below the spheres and carvings above the sidewalks.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, M Bennett & Sons (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 122'-long, riveted Parker pony truss bridge built in 1934 is supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls. The trusses are traditionally composed with rolled section used for the web members. The cantilevered sidewalks are finished with lattice railings.'' The bridge is to be replaced in 2010 with a two-span steel beam bridge.

column16: Part of the Allegheny Portage Railroad National Historic Site; Oldest bridge in Blair County
column18: Fenlon, Darling, and Company (Contractor), R. Klininmouth (Builder)
column20: The Skew Arch Bridge is one of three remaining bridges constructed as part of the Portage Railroad, a 36 mile railroad carrying Pennsylvania Canal boats over the Allegheny Mountains between Johnstown and Hollidaysburg. The original Portage Railroad operated from 1834 to 1854. The Skew Arch Bridge was the only roadway bridge built to span the railroad. Since a canal could not be constructed over mountains, a pre-locomotive railroad was built. The canal boats were loaded onto mule and horse pulled rail cars and brought up and down the mountains by a series of 10 inclines. According to HAER, ''This bridge carried the Huntingdon-Blairsville Turnpike, also called the Northern Turnpike, across Inclined Plane No. 6 of the Allegheny Portage Railroad on the east slope of Allegheny Mountain. It was originally designed, and partially built, to be perpendicular to the incline, but in 1833 its alignment was altered to the present skew arrangement, to facilitate the traffic on the steep grade of the turnpike. The firm of Fenlon, Darling, and Company was the contractor for this work. In 1849 one of the wing walls collapsed and was rebuilt. The ashlar stone was cut from local sandstone quarries and the bridge was constructed without mortar. The overall length of the bridge measures 70'. The with at the ends of the curved abutments measures 43'.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1908, reinforced concrete, closed spandrel deck arch bridge has plain spandrel walls and flared wingwalls. The original railings were replaced with structure mounted guiderail railings in 1996, a change that compromises historical integrity. The reinforced concrete deck arch bridge gained popularity quickly in the 1900s and was used with great frequency. Somerset County built a number in the 1900s and 1910s.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1888, pin connected, single span, 46'-long, Pratt pony truss bridge is attributed to the Wrought Iron Bridge Company because it has the distinctive upper and lower chord cast iron connections found on documented bridges by the prominent Ohio bridge designer and fabricator. The bridge appears to be complete, and it stands out in the county as one of the important metal truss bridges that chronicle the evolution of the development and eventual standardization of the technology. The bridge is historically and technologically significant.'' The Smith Road Bridge was damaged in a flood in 2006. A modern beam was placed on the inside of the western truss as a temporary rehabilitation measure. The bridge was listed on the Pennsylvania Bridge Marketing Site in 2009 and is to be replaced in 2011 unless anyone relocates it.

The Smithfield Street Bridge is on the National Register of Historic Places and is Pittsburgh's most famous bridge. It is the oldest bridge in Pittsburgh and is the oldest public-owned truss bridge in Allegheny County. The bridge is also the longest-spanning lenticular truss in the country. Gustav Lindenthal went on to design many famous bridges, such as the Queensboro Bridge and the Hell Gate Bridge in New York City. The bridge originally had just two lines of trusses and carried two lanes. The bridge was widened in 1889 and in 1911 on the eastern side to carry two trolley tracks. The Mt. Washington Transit tunnel was created to connect the trolley tracks on the bridge with trolley lines in the South Hills. In the 1980's, the Pittsburgh subway system was built, and the trolleys were rerouted to the former Panhandle Railroad Bridge. As part of the 1994 rehabilitation, the former trolley side of the Smithfield Street Bridge was converted to carry one lane of inbound Traffic. Also as part of the 1994 rehabilitation, the bridge was repainted its original colors (blue, orange, and yellow) from silver.

According to the PAHBI (MEM Reviewer), ''The 8 span, 1,355' long Smithton Bridge built in 1956 consists of from the south a 52'-long, built up steel stringer span, a 3 span continuous Warren with verticals deck truss (1 @ 216', 1 @ 288', 1 @ 216'), 3 simply supported Warren with verticals deck truss spans (3 @ 151'-5'') and a 100' deck girder span. The continuous truss spans are deepest over the bearings where the negative moment is greatest. Cantilevered deck sections are supported on built up brackets. The substructure consists of concrete abutments and column and cap beam bents.''

column15: Haunched deck girder and floorbeam system
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, S. J. Groves & Son (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1613'-long, 12-span viaduct, built in 1953, consists of five continuous steel, riveted, deck girder main spans with a stringer and floorbeam floor system and seven simply supported steel stringer approach spans. The maximum deck girder span is 235'. The bridge is supported on concrete abutments and columns and it has steel balustrades.''

This is one of only two Allegheny County stone arch bridges identified as Historically Significant from the 1986 Pennsylvania Historical and Museum Commission (PHMC) survey. It is notable for its high quality, locally quarried rock, faced ashlar construction, dressed voussoirs, and curved course finished parapet.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1988
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 2-span, humpbacked limestone arch bridge (ca. 1850) with stone parapets is listed in the National Register. The northwest wingwall collapsed ca. 1990 and has been repaired and repointed with the addition of concrete coping. Otherwise, there has been no change in the bridge's status since the previous survey. Shotcrete was applied to the arch intrados prior to 1986.''

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Roberts Paving Company
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 55'-long and 32' wide, reinforced concrete, rigid frame bridge has flared wingwalls and paneled parapets, the western one of which has been repaired. The fasciae are scored. The earliest extant examples of rigid frame bridge in Pennsylvania date to the late 1920s, and the technology was used for many of the 1937-1950 Pennsylvania Turnpike overpass bridges. This example is not early or technologically innovative. It crosses the former Lincoln Highway, but it was built well after the route was part of the state system highway.''

column16: Only Warren thru truss in Somerset County
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The single span, 148'-long and 19' wide, 6 panel, riveted Warren thru truss with verticals bridge is supported on concrete abutments. The trusses are traditionally composed, and repairs to the lower chords have been done with in kind material bolted to the original fabric.''

Interstate 64 crosses the Kanawha River four times in the Charleston area. The South Charleston Bridge is an example of a haunched deck girder. The other bridges are all trusses or arches. The South Charleston Bridge is only two lanes wide in each direction, which creates a bottleneck during peak traffic periods. Therefore, a new parallel bridge to carry eastbound traffic is under construction, to be completed in 2010. The new bridge is to cost 200 million. It will be a concrete segmental box girder, with a main span of 760 feet, and side spans of 460 feet and 540 feet. That main span will be the largest of its type in all of America.

column18: City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works
column20: A pedestrian bridge spanning the railroad existed at this location before McArdle Roadway was constructed. Since the approach (consisting of stairs) was removed for the construction of the roadway, this pedestrian overpass was built in its place. The railroad replaced their pedestrian overpasses in the South Side with welded trusses in the 1990's. The new bridge is nearby at 10th Street. Instead of demolishing their part of the bridge when the railroad did, the City of Pittsburgh just closed off their part of the bridge, allowing it to remain a bridge to nowhere. The connection to South 8th Street on the northern end was also terminated with the construction of South Stadium. The design is interesting that extra aesthetic members were added connecting the portal with the top of the railings, making the bridge appear to be a bowstring (instead of a standard Parker or camelback). In 2011, the bridge to nowhere was demolished, as part of the Lower McArdle Roadway Bridge rehabilitation.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Karl A Miller (Engineer), Tonawanda Eng. Corp (Contractor)
column20: According to the Historic American Engineering Record (HAER), ''Fires and floods during the early days of the oil industry promoted the frequent replacement of the bridge. The most recent, a tied plate-girder through arch designed by Crawford County Engineer Karl A. Miller, and its twin in Oil City, Venango County, are examples of bridge building at the twilight of riveted steel superstructure design and the local efforts of a gifted engineer.'' According to the PAHBI, ''The 1939, single span, 185'-long, tied arch bridge was designed and built by the Tonawanda Engineering Corporation. It is supported on ashlar abutments. The ribs are built-up riveted box sections and the ties are pin connected eyebars. The bridge is historically and technologically significant as an example of a rare type and design in Pennsylvania.''

column16: Last remaining lenticular pony truss in Pennsylvania, eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The South High Street Bridge has been closed to vehicular traffic an incorporated into a park. Benches were added spanning the length of the historic bridge. This is an excellent example of adaptive reuse! According to the Historic American Engineering Record (HAER), ''The South High Street Bridge is one of four surviving lenticular truss bridges in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and one of fifty remaining in the United States. The truss derives its name from the lens shape created by the upper and lower chords of the span. This 80'-9'' bridge is typical of the early polygonal pony truss designs patented by William O. Douglas and built by the Berlin Iron Bridge Company of East Berlin, Connecticut. The Berlin Iron Bridge Company was the main producer of this unusual truss form, which was erected in many rural and urban settings throughout the United States between 1878 and 1900.''
