According to the PAHBI, ''The one-span, 81'-long, 5-panel, pin-connected, metal lenticular pony truss bridge built ca. 1890 has built-up upper chord, end posts, and verticals, and eye-bar diagonals and lower chord. Built-up fishbelly floorbeams support steel stringers and a wood deck with wood railings inside of the truss lines. The bridge has been altered by the addition of extra diagonals in the second and fourth panels and plate welded to the upper chords and end posts (ca. 1960). The alterations are noteworthy but not considered significant enough to adversely affect the integrity of the rare bridge type and design. Lenticular truss bridges were a patented design of the Berlin Iron Bridge Co. of Berlin, CT. The company fabricated and erected hundreds of lenticular truss bridges throughout primarily New England and New York from the late 1870s to 1900. Pennsylvania was not a major market for Berlin Iron Bridge, but the company did erect a modest number of bridges in the state, especially in some northern tier counties. No less than five lenticular truss highway bridges from 1878 to 1900 have been identified in Pennsylvania. Surviving examples document a historically important variation in late-19th-century metal truss bridge technology.''

column18: Pennsylvania Railroad / City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works / Fort Pitt Bridge Works
column20: The bridge is historically significant since it was built as a joint project between Pittsburgh and the Pennsylvania Railroad to improve at grade crossings. The bridge was recently repainted (2007) with an artistic paint scheme, as evidenced in the photograph.

column18: F. H. Shaw (Lewistown Borough Engineer), R. R. Meyers (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The skewed, one-span, 92'-long, reinforced concrete, closed spandrel arch bridge, built in 1921, is supported on concrete abutments. The spandrel walls have a coursed ashlar veneer. Original railings have been removed and replaced by concrete balustrades (ca. 1955), although earlier stone end posts remain. The bridge was built jointly by the borough and county, and it has since been taken over by the state highway department. The bridge has no unusual or noteworthy features, and has been altered by loss of the original railings. A stone veneer was frequently applied to reinforced concrete arch bridges to give the appearance of a traditional stone arch bridge.''

column2: South Main Street Bridge over Saw Mill Run
column20: The thru girder is unusual in that the sidewalks are supported between thru girders, instead of being cantilevered outward. Therefore the bridge consists of four parallel girders instead of two. The bridge was replaced in 2009 as part of a project to improve traffic congestion in the West End Circle area.

The South Mary's Street Bridge is similar to the North Mary's Street North Bridge. The bridge is a concrete tee beam with an ornate concrete balustrade. The balustrade curves up over the center pier, inverse of the haunched beams. A decorative light standard is located on the balustrade over the pier.

column15: Closed spandrel semicircular concrete arch culvert
column20: In 1962, the Penn Lincoln Parkway East Bridge over the Thompson Run Valley was completed northeast of the South McCully Drive Bridge. To minimize the length of the Parkway bridge, fill was used to build up the western abutment. This fill required Thompson Run to be relocated along Thompson Run Road. A new alignment of the Old William Penn Highway was built between Jefferson Road and McCully Drive, keeping the roadway north of the new Parkway. This left a cut-off section of the old roadway (now called South McCully Drive) on the south side of the Parkway. Based this cut-off section was connected to Thompson Run Road with a bridge over Thompson Run. This South McCully Drive Bridge is an unadorned arch culvert. It is an arch culvert since fill separates the roadway and the arch.

column18: Independent Bridge Company / City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works
column20: The bridge was rehabilitated / restored in 2007. It was repainted gray with green railings, which was a standard paint scheme for Pittsburgh bridges of the 1920's. The original bridge railings were also preserved in the project. These uncommon railings were also used on the former Bloomfield Bridge, which was nearby.

The South Morgan Street Bridge is a typical example of a post World War II state-designed steel stringer. It represents the first generation of state-designed bridges after World War II, when many roads were being upgraded. As of 2008, the bridge retained its original deck and railings. The structure was rehabilitated in 2008, after the photograph was taken.

column18: Pennsylvania Railroad / City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works
column20: The bridge is historically significant since it was built as a joint project between Pittsburgh and the Pennsylvania Railroad to improve at grade crossings. In the 1920's, Pratt pony trusses with large, built-up members were much more commonly built than Warren trusses, except in Allegheny County.

The South Park Drive Bridge spans the South Canal in Brandywine Creek Park. The 1978 bridge retains the railings of the previous bridge in an attempt to give it a historic look. The bridge is a beam structure, despite the arched fascia panels.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The South Presa Street Bridge is one of San Antonio's three remaining lenticular pony truss bridges. All were built by the Berlin Iron Bridge Company of Connecticut. Other than in Texas, lenticular truss bridges were mostly built in the northeast. After a flood in 1921, the San Antonio River was to be bypassed and this section to be filled in. While the bypass channel was constructed, public outcry prevented this section of river from being destroyed. According to a City of San Antonio press release, ''The Presa St. Bridge, which was built in 1890, remains at its original site on South Presa between Nueva and Market streets. The bridge was manufactured by the Berlin Iron Bridge Company of East Berlin, Connecticut. The company's ability to incorporate Victorian design schemes into their work is what attracted the City to have them fabricate the Presa Street Bridge. Today it is one of three Berlin bridges that remain on the San Antonio River Walk.'' The bridge was rehabilitated in 2009. It was repainted black in accordance with SHPO standards.

column15: Parker thru truss with Warren deck truss approaches
column20: The South Side Bridge, eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, is one of Charleston's most historic bridges. It is of an unusual configuration consisting of a Parker thru truss with Warren deck truss approach spans on either side. The bridge was restored in 1990. John and Ruth McGee paid to have decorative lighting installed on the bridge in 2000. Two similar bridges in Charleston have since been illuminated thanks to the McGees.

column15: Cable suspension with stiffening thru girder
column18: Allegheny County, George S. Richardson, American Bridge
column20: The South Tenth Street Bridge is the only public-owned vehicular cable suspension bridge in not only Pittsburgh, but in the entire Monongahela and Allegheny river watershed. The others in Pittsburgh are eyebar chain self-anchored suspensions. The design was mandated by the Pittsburgh Art Commission. The bridge is noteworthy as being the longest spanning bridge over the Monongahela River. The historic bridge is to be rehabilitated.

column2: South Tenth Street Footbridge over Norfolk Southern Railroad
column20: A pedestrian bridge over the railroad existed near this location at South 8th Street. In the 1990's, the railroad replaced their railroad crossings in the South Side. The new bridge and stairs directly connects to South Tenth Street. It is a welded Pratt thru truss. There is a similar crossing at South Fifteenth Street.

column2: Southbound US Route 11 Fishing Creek Bridge
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 2 span, 230'-long Parker pony truss bridge is supported on a concrete substructure. The roadway was dualized in 1970, and an adjacent multi-beam structure carries northbound traffic. The concrete deck and safety shape parapets were placed in 1970. The rivet-connected trusses utilize rolled sections for the verticals and diagonals, but built-up sections are used for the truss chords. Rolled floorbeams and stringers support the concrete deck, which has stay-in-place forms.''

The Southpointe Boulevard Bridge was constructed in 1990 for Southpointe, a development that is part golf course community and part office park. Structurally, the bridge is an ordinary prestressed concrete beam bridge. Aesthetic features were added to the bridge to make it resemble the early 1900's Washington County arch bridges. Concrete fascia panels simulate an arch shape. These fascia panels, as well as the parapets, have incised panels, just like the old concrete arch bridges. The bridge also has art deco-style concrete end caps. The bridge is one of few modern bridges to include architectural details.

column15: K truss with deck girder and deck warren truss approaches
column20: The Speers Railroad Bridge was built to carry Pittsburgh and West Virginia Railroad. The rail line, which also included a similar though smaller bridge over the nearby Youghiogheny River, was built to connect the railroad from Pittsburgh to Connellsville. In Connellsville, the line connected with the Western Maryland Railroad. Unfortunately for the railroad, the line opened in 1930 as America entered the Great Depression. Both bridges are rare K-truss examples, in which the trusses form the letter K. They are likely the only K trusses in all of Pennsylvania and in the surrounding states. The bridges were also designed to be expandable with a lower deck able to carry another track. Note the openings in the trusses above the piers. The lower track and approaches were never built.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Pennsylvania Department of Highways built a new alignment of PA 71, opening between 1949 and 1951, to connect Bentleyville and Belle Vernon (Legislative Route 268). The new bridge over the Monongahela River, the Speers-Belle Vernon Bridge, was built as the nearly identical twin to the PA 51 bridge at Elizabeth (also built the same year). While the main arched continuous truss has the same dimensions as the bridge at Elizabeth, the Speers-Belle Vernon Bridge is longer, with deck truss approaches on each side. With the passage of the Interstate Highway Act, LR 268 and the bridge were expanded to be part of I-70 (originally I-70S). In the 1992-1993 renovation, sloped trusses were added to widen the approach deck trusses, lengthening the acceleration and deceleration lanes for the interchanges at each end of the bridge. (Dating from before interstate standards were put in place, the original bridge does not meet current standards.) The structure was repainted white from dark green during the renovation. Although the design of the bridge is not unusual, it is one of only three such bridges in Pennsylvania. (The third example is the I-276 Pennsylvania Turnpike Bridge over the Delaware River in Philadelphia.) The bridge is considered Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places since it was part of a major post-War Pennsylvania Department of Highways road and bridge building project.

Pymatuning State Park's Spillway Trail uses the old railroad grade from the Erie and Pittsburgh branch of the Pennsylvania Railroad through the park. The bridge over the Linesville Spillway was constructed in ca. 1930. According to TrailLink.com, ''The beautiful trail, adjacent to Linesville Rd crosses the 1930 Pymatuning spillway, a popular scenic attraction where there are so many carp that it is known as the place where ''ducks walk on fishes' backs.'' The area includes campgrounds, a fish hatchery and the Game Commission Wildlife Learning Center at the spillway. The spillway is a very popular (and busy) viewing area during peak waterfowl migration times.''

The Sportman Club Road Bridge is the last remaining truss bridge over the West Branch Clarion River. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1938, skewed, single span, 123'-long, rivet-connected Parker pony truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls. The top and bottom chords are built-up members, and the verticals and diagonals are rolled I beam sections. The bridge is an example of a state highway department standard design rivet-connected truss bridge that was used with great frequency beginning in the mid 1920s. It has no innovative or distinctive details.''

column15: Pratt pin-connected retrofitted with load-bearing tied arch
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The single span, 85'-long, tied arch bridge was erected in 1994 around a 1901, traditionally composed, pin connected, Pratt thru truss bridge. The arch is supported by skewbacks anchored to the vertical faces of the original abutments. Suspended steel rod hangers pick up rolled section floorbeams that support steel stringers and a timber deck. The trusses bridge is not tied to the arch. It supports only its own weight.''

column15: Thru girder with jack arch deck
column18: Pennsylvania Railroad / Fort Pitt Bridge Works
column20: With the 2007 and 2008 demolitions of the Mosside Blvd Bridge and the Boulevard of the Allies Viaduct, the bridge is one of the last multi-span thru-girders in the area. It is also one of the longest. A concrete slab span was added to the southern approach in 1975. The bridge still has a brick wearing surface. In 2009 the bridge was damaged by an overweight truck, and has been closed to traffic ever since.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, D. Goldberg & Sons (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The viaduct carries a two-lane road and a sidewalk over French Creek, two tracks of the Meadville Branch of Conrail (formerly the Erie Railroad main line), a parkway, and some structures in the city of Meadville. The Erie Railroad sought to establish a fourth major trunk line between Chicago and the east coast, but it paled in comparison to the rival PRR, B&O, and NY Central railroads.... The 12-span continuous, 944'-long, concrete encased steel stringer viaduct, built in 1951, is supported on concrete column bents and concrete abutments. The bridge consists of three continuous span sections and a single simple span. The longest continuous section is 455'-long and consists of six spans. The stringers are fabricated from rolled I-sections with cover plates in the regions of maximum moments. The viaduct has Moderne styled horizontally scored concrete parapets. Concrete encasement was favored in the state because it provided protection for the steel and eliminated the need to periodically paint the beams.''

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1979
column20: The 1875 Sprowl's Covered Bridge is an example of a subdivided king post truss. The bridge was closed in 2000 due to extensive damage from mining, in which the abutments cracked and the truss twisted. The bridge was repaired and reopened. Such engineering work and maintenance will preserve the historic bridge for the future.

column18: The Ohio Bridge Company (U.S. Bridge Company)
column20: Welded Warren truss bridges were built in Ohio by the Ohio Bridge Corporation starting in 1952. The Sprucevale Bridge is a nice two span example. It retains its 1950's character with the metal grate road and original railings (though guide rail has also been added). The trusses are interesting in that the top chord is not flat (parallel to the deck) at the tallest panel as is usual in most truss bridges. Instead, the trusses come to a point.

Traffic patterns on the bridge are quite unusual since vehicles drive on the left. A tall concrete barrier separates the lanes, so many drivers are unaware they are driving on what is usually the wrong side of the road. The bridge is an uncommon thru girder built of horizontal stringers (rather than the usual vertical plates). All original structures of the Penn Lincoln Parkway are considered to be historically significant, since the Parkway is an early example of a post-World War II urban highway.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, possibly only pin-connected double intersection Warren in Pennsylvania
column20: The St Vincent High Bridge was likely the only vehicular pin-connected double intersection Warren deck truss bridge in Pennsylvania. In 2009, it was replaced by a modern bridge. While the bridge was marketed on the state's Adopt a Bridge website for relocation, no group was able to do so. The structure was originally built to carry the Pennsylvania Railroad. Instead of replacing the bridge, the railroad relocated it to span an open cut in 1920. According to the PAHBI (MEM Reviewer), ''The main span of the ca. 1890, 3 span, 228' long bridge is a 157' long, pin-connected double intersection Warren deck truss with subdivided panels. The approach spans are built up deck girders. The bridge is supported on ashlar abutments. The truss is 20'-9'' deep. The design of the flooring system, where the asphalt deck is supported on railroad ties suggests that the bridge was originally a rail carrying facility. The bridge is significant as a rare example of type and design. It also appears to be remarkably complete, and its idiosyncratic design illustrates the evolution of metal truss bridges.''

column15: Wooden Howe thru truss supported by load-bearing stringers
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The St. Mary's Covered Bridge is the last remaining covered bridge in Huntingdon County. Built in 1896, three of the county's all-metal truss bridges are older. Note that with the Howe Truss design, the compression members are wooden and the tension members are metal. This is typical of transitional structures from all wood to all metal construction. The bridge was built on an old alignment of US 522.

St Petersburg Center is a small commercial area consisting of two buildings along Brush Run. One building, which spans Brush Run, houses the acclaimed Pittsburgh Youth Ballet Company & School. A bridge connects the parking lots on either side of Brush Run. It is a steel stringer in poor condition, with some components of the fascia stringers rusted through.

The former Star City Bridge, known locally as the Blue Bridge, was built in 1950 and replaced in stages in 2002 with a wider girder bridge. It was one of two thru truss bridges over the Monongahela River in West Virginia in 2002. Both have since been demolished. The bridge was once a familiar landmark on the route from I-79 South to West Virginia University.

The State Line Road Bridge is the last pin-connected truss bridge in Erie County. The bridge is on the border of Ohio, so it is possible for the driver to be in Pennsylvania and the passenger to be in Ohio when crossing the bridge. It is owned by Pennsylvania. In 1996 the bridge was replaced. Instead of demolishing the trusses, they were placed on the beams of the new bridge to serve as railings.

column15: Pratt half-hip pin-connected placed on load-bearing steel stringers
column20: The State Line Road Bridge is the last pin-connected truss bridge in Erie County. The bridge is on the border of Ohio, so it is possible for the driver to be in Pennsylvania and the passenger to be in Ohio when crossing the bridge. It is owned by Pennsylvania. In 1996 the bridge was replaced. Instead of demolishing the trusses, they were placed on the beams of the new bridge to serve as railings.

column16: Only remaining Parker truss bridge in Jefferson County
column20: The State Route 3013 Bridge is an example of a state-standard Parker pony truss. It is the last remaining Parker truss bridge in Jefferson County.
The bridge is near the United States Steel Clairton Coke Works. It retains its original state standard concrete balustrades.

The bridge was one of only two thru girders over the Shenango River. It was the main bridge in downtown Sharon. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1916, 2 span, 184'-long, built up thru girder bridge is supported on concrete abutments and cylindrical concrete piers. The deck, cantilevered sidewalks, railings, and 33 stringers were replaced in 1980.''

column2: Steubenville Pike Raccoon Creek Bridge, Old Alignment
column20: According to pahighways.com, in 1928 the William Penn Highway (US 22) was under construction from West Virginia to Potato Garden Road. An unpaved road previously existed at that location. It is likely that this concrete arch bridge was built as part of this construction project. The bridge is an example of a segmental concrete arch. While most concrete arch bridges at that time were designed by Chaney & Armstrong (later Chaney Engineering Company), the bridge stylistically does not look like any of their works. Nor does the bridge look like a state-standard concrete arch. In 1970, US 22 was straightened and widened and the bridge bypassed. The old bridge is one of the few bypassed bridges still standing next to its replacement in Pennsylvania.
This is a later example of an Allegheny County stone arch bridge built under Charles Davis. After over100 years, the superstructure is still rated satisfactory (6 out of 9).

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: George G. Wickline, Texas Highway Department; Earl Yates & Son, Contractors, Fort Worth, Texas
column20: According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''An example of Fort Worth's exceptional network of railroad grade separation structures, the Stockyards Viaduct serves as a good example of a cooperative effort by the Texas Highway Department and the U.S Bureau of Public Roads to eliminate dangerous grade crossings in Texas during the Great Depression.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The one span, 132'-long, pin-connected Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on stone abutments with wingwalls. It is dated to ca. 1890. The floorbeams are above the eye bar lower chords and are framed into the lower portion of the verticals that are toe-out channels with laced webs.... There are many alterations including replacement of an inclined end post, and welded cover plates on the upper chords. The bridge is not as complete as the other example in the county. Because of the alterations, the bridge is not historically or technologically significant.'' According to Nathan Holth of www.historicbridges.org, the bridge is attributable to the Morse Bridge Company due to the distinctive portal knee bracing, lack of sway bracing, and circular-shaped nuts used in the pin connections.
The Stoystown Road Beaverdam Creek Bridge was an example of a state-standard concrete tee beam. The bridge was demolished a few weeks after the photograph was taken.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Roberts Paving Company
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 54'-long and 37' wide, reinforced concrete, rigid frame bridge built in 1938 has flared wingwalls and is finished with Moderne-style balustrades. The earliest extant examples of rigid frame bridge in Pennsylvania date to the late 1920s, and the technology was used for many of the 1937-1950 Pennsylvania Turnpike overpass bridges. This example is not early or technologically innovative. It crosses the former Lincoln Highway, but it was built well after the route was part of the state system of highway. The bridge is not historically or technologically significant, and it is not located in a potential historic district. Its detailing reflects period aesthetics and the moldable qualities of concrete.''

The 1904 Stroud Bridge is an early riveted Pratt truss bridge. The structure is unusual because all members are back to back angles riveted together; there is no V-lacing. This configuration is rarely seen as a small stream crossing. In this area, most truss bridges comprised of angles were built by the railroads as vehicular overpasses.
According to the PAHBI, ''The 1920, riveted, single span, 126'-long, Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with flared wingwalls. The trusses are composed from built up members.''

column15: Continuous deck girder, five parallel girders
column18: Allegheny County, John F. Graham, Jr., SAI Consulting Engineers, Casey Company Contractor
column20: The current Sutersville Bridge replaced a deteriorated, weight-restricted steel pin-connected truss. The old bridge was upstream of the current bridge. The bridge is an example of a steel stringer. Rather than use hammerhead piers, the new piers are curved for aesthetics.
The Sutton Road Bridge is a riveted Warren pony truss, similar to the nearby Flat Road Bridge. The bridge's deck has been removed.

column18: Chaney & Armstrong Company (County Engineers), Dickey & Saxon (Contractors)
column20: The 1925 Swart Bridge over Tenmile Creek is one of the most decorative concrete arch bridges in Washington County. As you can see in the photograph, the concrete arch, abutments, and parapets have incised panels, and the parapets have articulated posts.

The Swarts Hill Road Bridge was one of two similar Warren riveted pony truss bridges in Greene County. It was demolished in 2008. The photograph shows the bridge during demolition, with one set of trusses on the ground and the other set still in place. The other bridge, the Hillside Lane Bridge, is still standing (as of 2009). Built in 1893, the Swarts Hill Road Bridge was one of the oldest riveted truss bridges in the region. It was also an early example of a Warren truss, which was not a common pin-connected design (pin-connected truss bridges pre-dated riveted gusset plate truss bridges). The light trusses were composed of angles connected by bolts. In 1995 the bridge was rehabilitated, when a helper bent was installed to support the middle floorbeam. The other floorbeams were replaced with welded connections.

column15: Thru girder and floorbeam system, deck girder on trussed bents
column18: City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works
column20: The bridge was reconstructed in 1915 from a previous bridge on site. The bridge crosses the Four Mile Run valley. The run has been completely covered up. The bridge is unusual due to the combination of thru girder and deck girder spans. Though called the Swinburne Bridge, Frazier Street actually crosses the bridge. The north end of the bridge used to be the intersection of Frazier Street and Swinburne Street. The construction of the Parkway East in the 1950's wiped out Frazier Street from the bridge to its continuation on the hill above. The Parkway also destroyed Swinburne Street's connection to the valley below. Therefore, the bridge is now just a part of Swinburne Street.

The Swinging Bridge near Everett is an unusual non-standardized suspension bridge. It is considered a swinging bridge, since its deck is not stiffened by girders or trusses. The bridge has a homemade appearance. The towers are built from wooden poles. Some of the suspender cables are chains. The bridge has bolted and welded connections, suggesting that it is newer than about 1960 when riveted connections were phased out. Since the bridge is privately-owned, it does not have to meet safety standards or have regular inspections.

In 1940, the first stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike opened between Irwin and Somerset. The original mainline overpasses consisted of arched concrete rigid frames, steel thru girders, and concrete tee beams. The remaining tee beams were replaced in the 1990's. Beginning in the late 1990's and continuing through at least 2020, the entire original turnpike is being reconstructed and widened. Almost all original overpasses are being replaced as part of the project, including the Taylor Road Overpass.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1932, single-span, 70'-long, steel, built-up riveted thru girder bridge, built in 1932, is supported by concrete abutments with wingwalls. The bridge has a concrete deck and a steel lattice railings. Girder bridges were introduced by the railroad industry in the 1850s, and they have been used on vehicular roadways in Pennsylvania since the late 19th century. The bridge is not technologically significant, but it contributes to the Tyrone Historic District.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Tenth Street Bridge was a Baltimore deck truss bridge, located just south of the Beaver Falls Lower Dam. It was built for the Riverview Trolley Company and was converted to a vehicular bridge in 1926. This National Register eligible bridge was closed in 1978 and demolished around 2000. There are no similar bridges anywhere in the region. Since the bridge was located next to the Penn Bridge Company, could it have been built by that company?

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: State of Pennsylvania Board of Public Grounds and Buildings, G. A. Flink (Engineer), M. H. Stebbins (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The one span, 181' long, riveted, camelback thru truss bridge fabricated in 1917 is supported on stone abutments. The trusses are traditionally composed, and there are minor repairs/in kind replacement of deteriorated parts of members, but the bridge is not altered. It is located on the boundary of the PHMC identified Susquehanna Mills HD that is composed of brick textile mills and frame houses. 10th Street and Shamokin Creek are boundaries, and the bridge is included in the district. It is a contributing resource based on its date of construction and integrity. 10th Street is a major crossing into the district. The bridge contributes to the historic character of the district.''

column15: Simulated Burr arch truss supported by steel stringers
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1979
column20: The Bailey Covered Bridge is the only Burr arch truss covered bridge in Washington County. The bridge was originally built in 1887, according to the National Bridge Inventory. In 1994 it burned down. The National Bridge Inventory lists 2001 as the reconstruction date. The new bridge is a steel stringer with a simulated, non-load bearing truss. It is not a historical reconstruction. Only the wooden arches were salvaged from the old bridge.

The bridge was designed with a large center span to avoid river piers. The City of Pittsburgh does not own any bridge as such. It was built as part of the Herr's Island redevelopment and renewal. It replaced a Parker truss from 1939.

column15: Deck arch (3-hinged main span, 2-hinged side spans); deck girder, cantilever girder, and thru girder approach spans
column18: Allegheny County, Vernon Covell, Fort Pitt Bridge Works
column20: The bridge is similar to the Washington Crossing Bridge (the next bridge upstream). While the bridge also incorporates architectural features such as stone pylons on concrete towers at the arch piers, the structural members themselves were designed without decoration. For example, the arches only have two ribs, and simple vertical members rise from the arches to support the bridge. The bridge is also different from the Washington Crossing Bridge since only the center arch is three-hinged (the others are two-hinged). The bridge has a longer overall length, since it crosses Herr's Island (redesignated Washington's Landing). A thru girder spans the railroad at the north end of the bridge, and a cantilevered (suspended) girder spans the back channel. The bridge used to be green (as seen in pghbridges.com) until it was repainted blue in the extensive rehabilitation/restoration in 2006-2007. The rehabilitation was done very well, since the original railings were retained, period light fixtures were installed and an open guardrail was added separating the travel lanes from the sidewalk (instead of concrete barrier). The back channel spans must be replaced to accommodate a new PA 28 grade separated interchange.

In 1955, US 290 (now I-35) was upgraded to a freeway though Austin, with two lanes in each direction. The road was only about 80 feet wide, including shoulders. Several rigid frame bridges were built over the freeway, including this one on 32nd Street. I-35 soon became congested, and this section of road was widened in 1972. Since there was insufficient room to widen the road along the shoulders, northbound and southbound express lanes were built over the highway. As a result, this stretch of I-35 is an unusual three-level highway in which express lanes, frontage roads, and local lanes are all on different levels.

This unremarkable girder bridge is the largest bridge over the eight-mile long North Fork of the Blackwater River. It spans the Thomas Park Lake, which is a reservoir constructed as a water supply reservoir for the City of Thomas. Note the reservoir is at an elevation of 3,080 feet. The North Fork Blackwater River, the Youghiogheny River, and the North Branch Potomac River all start in the same area around the southwest point of the West Virginia Maryland border.

column15: Town lattice wooden covered truss supported by load-bearing steel beams
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to Indiana County Parks Covered Bridge website, ''In June 1877 a county bridge over Crooked Creek near the property of John and Amos Thomas was approved for construction with the County to be responsible for two-thirds of the cost and John Thomas responsible for the remaining one-third of the bridge cost. The bridge was not erected until 1879 when a notice was published for a ''covered lattice bridge on the ''Kittanning and Indiana Road''. Amos Thomas was the contractor and Morton Fleming the superintendant of the bridge which was constructed at a cost of $545. Abutment stones and lumber were secured from the nearby area and the bridge was completed in November of 1879. The bridge was once known as Thomas Ford Bridge; prior to the construction of the bridge there was a fording (stream crossing) in this location. When the railroad was constructed in this area in the early 1900's the bridge was known as Thomas Station Bridge. The original Thomas Bridge was reported to be the only Town lattice truss bridge in the United States constructed with a single supporting chord, rather than the normal two chords. The Thomas Bridge was completely reconstructed in 1998 at a cost of slightly more than $1,000,000. The current bridge has a 20-ton weight limit. The Thomas Bridge crosses over Crooked Creek in Armstrong Township, near Yarnick's Farm Market.'' When the bridge was reconstructed, load-bearing steel beams were added. The bridge no longer functions as a truss bridge.

column16: Outstanding New Bridge of 1991 by the Association for Bridge Construction and Design
column18: Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission, URS Consultants (Engineer), National Engineering and Contracting Company (General Contractor), High Steel Structures (Steel Fabricator), Middle States Steel Construction Company (Steel Erection), Bethlehem Steel Corporati
column20: The Thomas J. Fee Bridges were the only Turnpike river bridges built in the last four decades of the 20th century. The bridges opened on November 1, 1991, at a cost of $16.5 million. As with most large Pennsylvania Turnpike extension bridges, they are built from high-strength weathering steel. Thomas J. Fee was a Pennsylvania State Representative and a Lawrence County Commissioner.

column16: Outstanding New Bridge of 1991 by the Association for Bridge Construction and Design
column18: Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission, URS Consultants (Engineer), National Engineering and Contracting Company (General Contractor), High Steel Structures (Steel Fabricator), Middle States Steel Construction Company (Steel Erection), Bethlehem Steel Corporati
column20: The Thomas J. Fee Bridges were the only Turnpike river bridges built in the last four decades of the 20th century. The bridges opened on November 1, 1991, at a cost of $16.5 million. As with most large Pennsylvania Turnpike extension bridges, they are built from high-strength weathering steel. Thomas J. Fee was a Pennsylvania State Representative and a Lawrence County Commissioner.

According to the PAHBI, ''The bridge carries two lanes and one shoulder of a highway and one sidewalk over the Lehigh River, CNJ RR, LC & N RR, Lehigh Valley RR, the canal, Railway St., Whiate St., Allen St., and Franklin St. in an urban area. The river is at the western end of the viaduct, which crosses the borough of Weissport. The structure is the dominant feature in the town. When originally placed in 1938, the 1,539'-long deck truss bridge with girder and stringer approach spans was 34' wide and finished with standard concrete balustrades. It was a major grade crossing elimination project. In 1981, the historic appearance of the bridge was changed significantly when the balustrades were removed, the deck was widened to 42', and modern concrete barriers were installed. The trusses were also strengthened.''

column16: Recognized by an Ohio Historical Marker
column20: What is now the Thomas Malone Covered Bridge once crossed Middle Run on OH 154 between Lisbon and Elkton. Instead of being torn down, Elkrun Township converted it into a storage shed and moved it twice. In 1971 Thomas Malone, a covered bridge historian, saw the bridge being used as a shed along Pine Hollow Road. Though his efforts, the bridge was restored and moved to Beaver Creek State Park. It is one of a few covered bridges in Columbiana County.

column18: J. E. Greiner Company, Evitts Creek Water Company
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1932, 11 span, 726'-long, reinforced concrete deck arch bridge has a 4 span main span (4 @ 66'). The approach spans are enclosed in concrete retaining walls. The bridge was erected in association with the 1931-1932 development of Koon Lake Reservoir, created to supplement the 1912-1913 Lake Gordon reservoir.''

The Thompson Run Road Bridge over Thompson Run is similar to the nearby one over Leak Run. Both are Allegheny County-designed concrete arches with the same arch design. This design was used from the 1910's to the 1940's. This bridge is very similar to the Leak Run Bridge, except the Leak Run Bridge has flat parapets. The parapets of the Thompson Run Bridge, have concrete capstones at the ends of the bridge, like most the Allegheny County-designed bridges. The Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory lists a date of 1941 for the bridge. If so, it is 25 years newer than the similar Leak Run Bridge.

column2: Thompson Run Road Leak Run Bridge
column20: The 1916 Thompson Run Road Leak Run Bridge was built by Allegheny County under James Chalfant's tenure. Under Charles Davis, Chalfant's predecessor, small arch bridges were built from stone. Chalfant modernized the design with concrete arches. Though many of his concrete arch bridges were faced with stone, others, such as this one, were not. The smaller bridges were less likely to be faced with stone. The bridge has flat parapets without concrete capstones, unlike most other similar bridges.

The 1920 Thompsonville Bridge was built to serve an old alignment of Washington Road (now US 19) over Brush Run in the village of Thompsonville. In 1940, US 19 was widened and straightened and the Thompsonville Bridge bypassed. Renamed Camp Lane, the concrete arch now just serves a light amount of traffic. The bridge is decorated with paneled spandrel walls and parapets. This decoration is seen on other Washington County concrete arch bridges, indicating that the Thompsonville Bridge was designed by the Chaney Engineering Company (formerly Chaney & Armstrong, Engineers) for Washington County.

The Western Extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike opened on December 26, 1951. Records show that this bridge was completed in 1952. Unlike the original mainline which used thru girder, rigid frame, and concrete tee beam overpasses, the Western Extension used thru girders and deck girders (stringers) for the mainline. This bridge is one of such stringer bridges.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The historic Thornton Bridge is a rare full-slope four panel pin-connected Pratt truss. Most comparable pony truss bridges of this span length would have five panel half-hip trusses. The Thornton Bridge is nearly identical to the approach span of the Rockville-Mt Nebo Road Bridge, also over Big Sandy Creek in Preston County. Both were constructed in 1893 and are the same length. Therefore, the bridge is attributed to the King Bridge Company. Preservation is essential for such a rare bridge on a dirt road that serves fewer than two cars per hour.

column16: Last remaining Parker truss over the Allegheny River north of Interstate 80
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Bates and Rogers (Contractor)
column20: The Tidioute Bridge is the last remaining Parker truss bridge over the Allegheny River north of Interstate 80. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1933, riveted, two span, 551'-long (1 @ 269', 1 @ 268') , Parker thru truss bridge is supported on a substructure that incorporates parts of an earlier ashlar substructure. The heavy trusses are composed from built up members. Built to a state standard design, the bridge has no innovative or distinctive details.''

column16: Oldest girder over the Allegheny River downstream of New York
column20: As a sign of things to come, the 1961 Tionesta Bridge was the first girder bridge to replace a truss bridge over the Allegheny River downstream of New York. By 2014, this will happened to all but 4 of the 16 pre-World War II truss bridges. The Tionesta Bridge was built on the piers of the previous bridge.

column15: Steel stringer supporting a Pratt pony truss
column20: The Toad Hollow Road Bridge was a Pratt pony truss bridge until 1988 when it was rehabilitated. Steel stringers were added below the deck to support the structure. For some reason, the tension members were removed from the truss, giving it an incomplete appearance.

The Township Road 125 Bridge is a very rare bowstring arch truss. The bridge is probably the most historic 19th century bridge in this entire region of Ohio! Based on the trusswork of the arch, the bridge is attributed to the Massillon Bridge Company. Only a few similar bowstring bridges survive anywhere in the country. The others have been modified, strengthened, abandoned, or converted to pedestrian facilities. The TR 125 Bridge is still open to vehicular traffic, although it is near the end of a dead-end rural road. Based on the appearance of the bridge, it is possible it was relocated or even shortened.
The Township Road 289 Bridge is the last remaining pin-connected thru truss bridge in Jefferson County. Based on details, it can be attributed to the Canton Bridge Company.

The Township Road 2A Bridge is one of only two pin-connected bridges in Perry County, Ohio. The other, Township Road 96 over Painter Creek, is to be demolished (last confirmed by www.oldohiobridges.com in 2007). The Township Road 2A Bridge was rehabilitated in 1988, in which the deck was redone.

The TR 332 Bridge (Greene County Bridge No. 102) is one of just a few remaining similar Parker pony truss bridges in Greene County. It is attributed to the Penn Bridge Company, based on similar bridges. The bridge serves as a driveway to a farm on the north side of Small Creek. It appears that the road once continued, since other sections of TR 332 still exist to the north. The bridge consists of built-up top chords and inclined end posts. The lower chords, verticals, and diagonals consist of channels with battens. The bridge was rehabilitated around 2007, when it was repainted and some rivets replaced with bolts. In 2010, the County Commissioners announced the replacement of the bridge.

Bridgemapper.com rediscovered the long abandoned Township Route 428 Bridge in March of 2007. The bridge is an example of a full slope pin-connected Pratt pony truss. It is attributed to the York Bridge Company since it exhibits the company's distinctive grid-like railings. The York Bridge Company was active from 1901 to 1916. The bridge is similar to others built around 1905, including the Meadow Run Road Bridge in Fayette County. Unfortunately, the east abutment of the abandoned bridge is failing. It is only a matter of time until the bridge collapses into the creek.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The one span, 156'-long 8-panel, pin connected, Parker thru truss is dated to 1900. The upper chords and end posts are built up box sections, and the interior diagonals and verticals are toe-out channels with lacing. The outside panel diagonals and lower chords are eye bars. The floorbeams are framed into the bottoms of the verticals. Although the bridge represents the era of standardized details, it is a complete and large example of the Parker truss design used for long spans. The design concentrates capacity at the center of the span where stresses are the greatest. The bridge is historically and technologically significant because of its completeness, relative rareness of the truss design, and because it is among the oldest dozen surviving Parker thru truss bridges in the state.''

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1996
column18: Texas Highway Department, D. C. Greer (Highway Engineer), Austin Bridge Company (Contractor)
column20: The Travis Street Bridge is an example of a state-standard thru truss. The bridge is noteworthy that it five Parker truss spans. It is one of the longest bridges of its type in Texas. One of the reasons it was not replaced is that the Route 71 LaGrange Bypass was built in an alternate location to divert thru traffic around LaGrange.
This is an excellent example of the Allegheny County stone arch bridge designed under Charles Davis. There is minimal damage and deterioration to the original stonework.

column15: Steel multi-beam girder, fascia beams encased in concrete
column16: National Historic Landmark
column20: The Triple Underpass is located at Dealy Plaza, the location of the John F. Kennedy assassination. The grassy knoll is on the right of the photograph. Some conspiracy theorists believe shots were fired from one of two people on the bridge. Officially they came from the Texas School Book Depository Building. Once shots were fired, the motorcade took cover underneath the bridge. While the bridge will be forever be remembered because of the assassination, it was once thought of as the city's front door. From the Dallas Morning News on August 20, 1935, ''The triple underpasswill be one of the most imposing sights in Dallas. It will be located at the front door' of Dallas since it will be the entrance for Highway No. 1 into the city -- the most heavily traveled highway in Texas.'' The Sixth Floor Museum's website describes the history surrounding the construction of the bridge: ''A significant planning solution to alleviate the city's traffic problems came in the 1930s, a triple underpass. Constructed over Bryan's original town site, this major new gateway afforded access to the western edge of downtown Dallas. After razing buildings, engineers sloped three major streets down to the west to converge into one. These three streets -- Elm to the north, Main in the center, and Commerce on the south -- pass beneath a railroad bridge that connected the rail yards on the north to Union Terminal Station two blocks to the south. This structural triangular arrangement is known locally as the triple underpass, a civic accomplishment of engineering genius. The arched gateway, constructed of concrete with distinctive Art Deco-style detailing, opened to wide acclaim and created a commanding entrance to the city from the west and an impressive exit from the east. During the fervor of the 1936 Texas Centennial, G.B. Dealey officially dedicated the triple underpass by riding in the first car that passed through it.''

column15: Queenpost with multiple kingpost spans, wooden covered
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1980
column20: The Trostletown Covered Bridge was completed in 1873, according to its portal sign. Other sources state the bridge was built in 1845. The bridge was taken over and restored by the Stoystown Lions Club in 1965 and again in 1993 - 1996. It was rededicated on September 28, 1996. The bridge is the only three span covered bridge in Somerset County.

column16: National Historic Civil Engineering Landmark, largest concrete bridge in America
column20: According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''When the Lackawanna Railroad's 39.6-mile Clarks Summit-Halstead Cutoff in northeastern Pennsylvania was dedicated on Saturday, November 6, 1915, the 2,375-foot-long, 240-foot-high Tunkhannock Viaduct stood at its west end. The total excavation for the cutoff had amounted to 13,318,000 cubic yards, more than half of that rock; into its substructures had gone 800,000 cubic yards of concrete. The Tunkhannock alone had required 1140 tons of steel, and 167,000 cubic yards of concrete containing 89,000 barrels or 1,093 carloads of cement. More than 50 years after its building, the Tunkhannock Viaduct still merits the title of largest concrete bridge in America, if not the world. It has been compared to the nearly two-thousand-year old Pont du Gard in southern France; mainly because of its tall proportions and high semicircular main arches. Its moldings serve to break the vertical lines. The veneer that was applied to exposed surfaces at the top of Tunkhannock in the 1940s has started to peel away.''

The Tunnel Bridge is a three-panel pony truss. Though the builder plate does not remain, the bridge is attributed to the York Bridge Company due to its similarity with the Lower Meadow Run Bridge. It also exhibits the distinctive rectangular railings. The bridge is a late example of a pin-connected pony truss. The bridge was recently rehabilitated, and the endposts were encased in concrete.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, last remaining Pennsylvania truss in county
column20: According to the PAHBI (MEM Reviewer), ''The one span, 402' Pennsylvania thru truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with flared wingwalls from an earlier bridge. The trusses are traditionally composed. The upper chords and inclined end posts are built up box sections, and the verticals are rolled I section. Bracing members are built up. The upper panel point connections are riveted, but the intermediate connections and the lower panel point connections throughout are pinned with the exception of the end panels of the lower chords, which are riveted. The bridge is long, but it has no innovative details.'' The bridge was replaced in 2010 with a wider, modern structure.

Tunnelton is the town at the northern end of what was once the Kingwood Tunnel on the B&O Railroad mainline between Baltimore and Wheeling. The 4,137 foot long tunnel opened in 1852 as the longest tunnel in America. It featured the first use of prefabricated iron arch segments in its construction. In 1911 the B&O Railroad was widened and realigned and a new tunnel was bored. The old tunnel was used until the 1950's, when it was abandoned and sealed. While the date of the Tunnelton Footbridge is not documented, it is possible the bridge dates from the widening of the tracks around 1911.

column18: City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works
column20: The bridge is built on the piers of the previous bridge, which was a double intersection Warren through truss. The Pennsylvania Railroad operated a roundhouse near the bridge. Parallel railroad tracks used to take up the entire width of the main span. The structure is one of only two surviving City of Pittsburgh Parker thru trusses.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, R. C. Burket (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The skewed, super elevated, 245'-long, T beam bridge built in 1937 is composed of 2, 2-span continuous spans. It is technologically and historically significant as an early example of the continuous design applied to T beam bridges. The bridge was designed by the state highway department and built by a local contractor. The continuous haunched beams reflect a structural need for deeper beams over the piers where the negative moments were greatest.'' In 2010 the Tyrone Forge Bridge was rehabilitated, as seen in the photograph. As part of the rehabilitation, the expansion bearing on the center pier was converted to a fixed bearing. New concrete parapets were constructed, replicating the art deco vertical scoring of the original ones. The project is an excellent example of bridge rehabilitation.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Texas Highway Department, Julian Montgomery (Highway Engineer); Cage Bros & L.A. Turner (Contractors)
column20: The U.S. Highway 190 Colorado River Bridge is one of a few similar thru cantilevers built by the State Highway Commission in Texas in the late 1930's. The advantage of a cantilever bridge is the potential for a long center span. Therefore, such bridges were most often built over wide, navigable rivers. It is unusual that Texas occasionally used a standardized design for smaller crossings. Other than a deck continuous truss, most similar Colorado River Bridges in the area were simple Parker thru trusses.

The Uffington Bridge is the only deck truss over the Monongahela River in West Virginia. The bridge was originally blue, as were all other WVDOH bridges in the 1970's. In 2003-2004 the bridge was repainted the standard West Virginia green.

column15: Parker pin-connected with riveted Warren pony approach trusses
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places; according to Skelly & Loy, the bridge was the longest active pin-connected truss (until its demolition in 2007)
column18: Pennsylvania Steel Company of Steelton, PA
column20: The bridge was photographed in June of 2007 on the last day it was open to traffic. According to the consulting firm Skelly & Loy, '' Built in 1904 by the Pennsylvania Steel Company, it is one of the longest highway bridges in Pennsylvania. Each of its 14 spans has 28 pin connections. Before the construction of the new bridge, it was the longest pin-connected truss bridge known to carry traffic. The original bridge was determined eligible for listing in the National Register of Historic Places.'' Regardless of the bridge's significance, it was demolished in 2007.

column15: Closed spandrel elliptical concrete arch, faced with ashlar
column18: Allegheny County, James Chalfant, Vernon Covell
column20: In Oakdale there are two similar stone-faced concrete arches at the intersection of State Street and Union Avenue. The Union Avenue Bridge is the newer of the two, dating from 1925. Allegheny County chief engineer Charles Davis designed many stone arch bridges for small crossings. After his death in 1907, his successor, James Chalfant, modernized the design using stone-faced concrete arches. Rather than rusticated ashlar, his arches were faced with coursed ashlar and stepped voussoirs along the arch ring. After Chalfant's death in 1922, his successor, Vernon Covell, did not continue with the stone facing of the concrete arch. The lone exception is the Union Avenue Bridge, which is styled like the perpendicular State Street Bridge. It is likely that Covell's only stone-faced concrete arch was built from an older Chalfant plan, or that it was built to maintain uniformity with the four year older State Street Bridge.

The Union Avenue Extension Bridge was built as a new alignment for Union Avenue due to the construction of Interstate 279 in the 1980's. It is the only interstate overpass in Allegheny County that is a haunched girder with the parallel girders coming to a point over a central pier.

column2: Union Pacific West Fork Trinity River Bridge
column15: Pratt pin-connected with wooden trestle approaches
column20: Between 2010 and 2015, the USACE is going to construct a channel to bypass the Fort Worth downtown section of the Trinity River. This channel will be along the Union Pacific Railroad. The project may result in alterations or even replacement of this railroad bridge.

The bridge was built as part of the 1951 Western Extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike. All mainline vehicular overpasses were either thru girders or deck girders in the extension. The bridge will be replaced as part of the Turnpike widening, which will happen sometime after 2010. The Unity Center Road bridge is an uncommon thru girder overpass that has a separate sidewalk.

column2: University Drive Northbound Clear Fork Trinity River Bridge
column15: Warren polygonal riveted with approach continuous stringers
column16: Last remaining pony truss in Tarrant County
column20: The University Drive Northbound Bridge is the last remaining pony truss in Tarrant County. In 1951, University Drive was widened. Instead of replacing the 1936 bridge, this bridge was built parallel to the existing bridge to carry northbound traffic. Both bridges were modified in 1967 in which all of the bridge except for the truss span was rebuilt.

column2: University Drive Southbound Clear Fork Trinity River Bridge
column15: Parker riveted with approach continuous stringers
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, last remaining thru truss in Tarrant County
column20: The University Drive Southbound Bridge is the last remaining thru truss in Tarrant County. In 1951, University Drive was widened. Rather than replace the bridge, a new northbound bridge was constructed next to the existing bridge. Both bridges were modified in 1967 in which all of the bridge except for the truss span was rebuilt.

column2: US 19 Bridge Over Tenmile Creek Tributary
column20: The 1917 US 19 Bridge over a tributary of Tenmile Creek is noteworthy for being one of the oldest Pennsylvania Department of Highways tee beam bridges in the state. It is the oldest in Washington County. Only one other state-designed example was built before 1929. The state probably built nearly a thousand bridges of this type. Most were built from about 1930 to 1960. Meanwhile, the state also built several other types of standard plan bridges, most starting around 1930. Therefore, this bridge is an important early example. The bridge has paneled concrete parapets instead of what became the standard open balustrade around 1930. Note that US 19 is identified as Route 325 on the plaque. The bridge predates US numbered highways.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, D. Mallett (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1942, 4 simple span, 220'-long, steel stringer bridge (1 @ 38', 3 @ 64') is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls and 2-column concrete cap beam bents. It has no innovative or distinguishing details and is an example of the most common 20th century bridge type in the state. . . . Route 19, the Perry Highway was one of at least 50 tourist trails developed from existing state roads and promoted by private organizations in the 1910s and 1920s. Originally designated Route 88 by the state highway department, the Perry Highway connected Pittsburgh and Erie on a meandering route that passed through only one major town along the way, Mercer. ''

The US 19 Neshannock Creek Bridge is distinctive in that the sway bracing was moved to the outside of the top chord to increase vertical clearance. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1928, riveted, single span, 133'-long, Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on concrete abutments with flared wingwalls. The heavy trusses are composed of built up members. Connections were changed in 1975 from rivets to high strength bolts at some lower panels points and at the battens of the lower chords.''

column18: Richardson, Gordon and Associates (now HDR), Foster and Creighton Company (Contractor), original NB side
column20: The Summersville Reservoir was completed in 1966. As a result of the lake, a new, high level crossing was built for US 19. The first bridge was completed in 1963. The cantilever deck truss won two ASIC awards, including an Award of Merit, awarded to the 10 most beautiful new bridges in a given year. The category was for a long span bridge. Due to high traffic volumes, US 19 was widened to two lanes in each direction to become the Mountaineer Expressway. The twin bridge was completed in 1994. The photograph is from the older, southbound side.

column18: Richardson, Gordon and Associates (now HDR), Foster and Creighton Company (Contractor), original NB side
column20: The Summersville Reservoir was completed in 1966. As a result of the lake, a new, high level crossing was built for US 19. The first bridge was completed in 1963. The cantilever deck truss won two ASIC awards, including an Award of Merit, awarded to the 10 most beautiful new bridges in a given year. The category was for a long span bridge. Due to high traffic volumes, US 19 was widened to two lanes in each direction to become the Mountaineer Expressway. The twin bridge was completed in 1994. The photograph is from the older, southbound side.

column2: US 219 Black Fork Cheat River Bridge
column20: US 219 used to cross two similar state-standard deck girders with concrete balustrades in Parsons, West Virginia. There the Black Fork and Shavers Fork of the Cheat River converge to form the Cheat River. The bridge over the Black Fork has 8 main spans, which is much larger than the one over the Shavers Fork which only has 3 main spans. WVDOH has decided to replace the bridges, starting with the Shavers Fork Bridge, which was replaced in 2007. The US 219 Black River Bridge is significant for being the only vehicular bridge over the Black Fork Cheat River.

column2: US 219 Shavers Fork Cheat River Bridge
column20: In Parsons, West Virginia, the Shavers Fork and the Black Fork of the Cheat River converge to form the Cheat River. US 219 runs through Parsons, crossing both the Shavers Fork and the Black Fork. Similar state-standard deck girder bridges with concrete balustrades were built in 1941. WVDOH has decided to replace the bridges, starting with the Shavers Fork Bridge, which was replaced in 2007.

column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Latrobe Construction
column20: According to the PAHBI (MEM Reviewer), ''The skewed 1951, 658'-long deck truss bridge has a 4-span continuous Warren deck truss (140', 160', 160', 140') with a single span stringer approach span. It is supported on a reinforced substructure of concrete abutments and piers on spread footings. The upper and lower chords are built up sections, and the floor beams, stringers, and diagonal and vertical members are rolled section. K bracing is used for the lower lateral and sway bracing. The bridge is finished with cantilevered deck sections, and the safety shape barriers were added in 1997.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: Construction began on the first National Road (Cumberland Road) crossing of the Casselman River (then known as Castleman's River) in 1813. The first bridge, the Little Crossings Bridge, as seen on this website, is a stone arch. The area was called Little Crossings. The Great Crossings was the crossing of the larger Youghiogheny River. In the 1930's, much of the National Road (also known as the Cumberland Road) was widened and realigned. This newer bridge, The US 40 Casselman River Bridge, is an example of the latest in 1930's technology. It is a state-standard Pratt thru truss. The bridge is eligible for the National Register of Historic Places due to its association with the National Road. In 1975, Interstate 68 was built as an upgrade to US 40, crossing the river with twin steel girder bridges. It is interesting to see the latest road and bridge technologies from 1813, 1932, and 1975 next to each other. Since a state park was formed around the Little Crossings Bridge, and the US 40 Casselman River Bridge was rehabilitated in 2008, hopefully all three crossings will remain next to each other for years to come.

According to the PAHBI, ''The skewed, 2-span, rivet-connected Pratt thru truss bridge built in 1941 is composed of standard built-up and rolled sections. It has a cantilevered sidewalk with standard-design metal railing, a concrete deck, and is supported on concrete abutments and piers. The bridge is a standard rivet-connected truss of a type used extensively by the state highway department from the late 1920s through the 1940s. The Pratt truss design was developed prior to 1860 and continued in use through the mid-20th-century. This late example, although long span and wide, has no unusual or noteworthy features.''

column15: Haunched steel continuous girder and floorbeam system
column20: The US Route 422 Shenango River Viaduct consists of two parallel haunched girder bridges. The bridges have the longest total length of any bridge over the Shenango River.

column15: Haunched steel continuous girder and floorbeam system
column20: The US Route 422 Shenango River Viaduct consists of two parallel haunched girder bridges. The bridges have the longest total length of any bridge over the Shenango River.

column2: US Route 422 Slippery Rock Creek Bridge
column16: Only open spandrel arch bridge in Lawrence County
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Osborne Construction Co.
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The plain, 5-span, 510'-long, ribbed open spandrel arch bridge was built in 1950. Each of the 3 open spandrel arch spans has four ribs and plain spandrel columns. The approach spans are T beam spans about the length of a spandrel bay. In 1984 the bridge was redecked and safety-shape barriers were placed inside the original steel railings. The bridge was featured in an advertisement for the Concrete Reinforcing Steel Institute in the May 1956 issue of Civil Engineering. The bridge is a late and plain example of a bridge type that is common in Pennsylvania. While its aesthetics reflect post-war modernism, the bridge is not technologically or aesthetically distinguished. Neither the bridge nor its setting are historically or technologically significant.''

The US Route 50 Bridge in Fellowsville is a closed spandrel concrete arch with plain spandrel walls. At some point the bridge was rehabilitated and the parapets were removed and replaced by guide rail.

The US Route 50 Cheat River Bridge is the last remaining Pratt state-standard truss bridge in Preston County. It is also the last Pratt truss bridge over the main Cheat River. Although West Virginia built many similar truss bridges, few in the region survive. The US 50 bridge over the Tygart Valley River near Grafton was similar to this bridge. It was replaced in 2002 by a weathering steel deck girder. While the Cheat River is one of the most scenic rivers in the state, there are not many scenic bridges left that cross it.

The 1929 Valley Brook Road Bridge is a state-standard concrete arch bridge. It has an accented arch ring and state-standard balustrades. The structure retains excellent historic integrity with few alterations. The bridge is also in good condition, with the superstructure rated a 6 of 9 (satisfactory) and a sufficiency rating of 73 percent.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The 1888 Valley Crossroad Bridge is the oldest documented truss bridge in McKean County. Though it retains decorative plaques, the builder is not identified. The portal bracing is similar to other bridges by the Pittsburgh Bridge Company, Nelson & Buchanan agents. Typically, Nelson and Buchanan bridges have builders plaques on the diagonal endposts, not at the top of the portal bracing. Therefore, it would make sense that the builder is not identified on those plaques over the portal. However, the railings with the rectangular pattern is similar to bridges by the York Bridge Company, which did not exist in 1888. It is possible the bridge was rehabilitated by the York Bridge company in the early 1900's, in which the original builders plaques were removed and the signature railings were added. According to GMK's evaluation in the PAHBI, 'The single span, 146'-long, pin-connected Pratt thru truss bridge built in 1888 is supported by concrete abutments. The trusses are traditionally composed, with built up box section upper chords, channels with lacing verticals, and eye bar diagonals and lower chords. The oldest of nine remaining pin connected truss bridge in the county, and one of the oldest examples in PADOT Dist. 2-0 (north central PA), it is historically and technologically significant as a complete example of its type and design.'

column18: Nelson & Buchanan Company?, Fort Pitt Bridge Works (Contractor)
column20: The 1904 Valleyview Road Bridge is a riveted Pratt pony truss. The bridge consists of eight panels, more than the typical pony truss, especially one of such small size (59 feet). The bridge is unusual in that the panels are taller than they are wide. Stylistically, the bridge looks like it was designed by the Nelson & Buchanan company, which designed many bridges in Washington County. The plaques are shaped like parallelograms, a signature of the Nelson & Buchanan Company. However, the plaques give only the county commissioners and the name of the fabricator, the Fort Pitt Bridge Works.

column15: Closed spandrel elliptical concrete arch (non-load bearing) with load-bearing I beams.
column16: Possibly eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Rehabilitated by the Corman Construction Company of Maryland
column20: The Van Buren Street Bridge is an embellished, ornate concrete arch / girder bridge which beautifies Brandywine Creek Park. It was built to carry a 48 inch water main between Wilmington's two reservoirs, as well as to carry a crossing in the park. As such, it was a joint project by Wilmington's Water Commission and Park Commission. Since the bridge was designed to carry a water main, the roadway was supported above the line by lattice girders. Aside from the normal wear and tear of a concrete arch bridge, the leaking water main also contributed to the bridge's deterioration. As part of the 1998 rehabilitation, the water main was removed and the original girders were replaced by load-bearing I-beams spanning between piers. The roadway deck and fill was replaced. The reconstructed bridge is therefore a beam bridge with decorative, non-load bearing arches.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Pittsburg Bridge Company, Nelson & Buchanan Agents
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The two-span, 277'-long, pin-connected Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on an ashlar substructure with concrete caps. It was built in 1891 by the Pittsburgh Bridge Co. It has the distinctive connection of the floorbeams above the lower chords that are typical of the fabricator. There are minor alterations including steel cables added at to the lower chords, rivets replaced by bolts, and there are welded repairs to some lower panel points. The bridge is a documented and early example of an important technology, and it has unusual details such as the floorbeam connections to the truss. It is historically and technologically significant.''
The Van Voorhis Bridge is a riveted thru truss bridge from 1916. It is the last-remaining riveted truss bridge in Washington County. The bridge maintains historic integrity.

According to the PAHBI (MEM Reviewer), ''The main span of the 3 span, 489' long bridge is a 310' long riveted Parker thru truss. The approach spans are built up stringer spans of 83' and 94' in length. The trusses are traditionally composed with all members being built up. The main span is long, but none of the details or its length itself are innovative or distinctive. The cantilevered sidewalks were finished with standard state highway department metal railings, but the originals are on the main span only. Those at the approaches are modern replacements.''

The Vanport Bridge is the busiest Ohio River crossing in Beaver County. It was built in 1970 as part of the new Beaver Valley Expressway. The bridge is a continuous truss, in which the top chord is flat and the bottom chord curves downward to form points over the intermediate piers. It is the third-newest vehicular truss bridge in Western Pennsylvania.

The Varner Road Bridge is an arch composed of two closed spandrel ribs at each side, done this way to reduce the amount of material needed for the bridge. Arches of this design are rare in Pennsylvania. They are much more common in West Virginia and elsewhere.

column2: Venango Veterans Memorial Bridge (Gravel Run Road Bridge)
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1893, pin connected, two span, 261'-long, Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on an ashlar pier and abutments. It was fabricated by the Wrought Iron Bridge Company, and the hip floor beam hangers have their distinctive four-pronged detail. The cantilevered sidewalk is finished with a handsome lattice railing. Crawford County is rich in pin connected, metal truss bridges with 35 ranging in date from 1870 through the early 20th century remaining. This bridge stands out as a long, complete, multiple span example of its type and design. Adding to its significance is its documentation to a prominent fabricator. The bridge is historically and technologically significant.'' The bridge was closed to traffic around 2003. It was closed to pedestrians in 2010 after severe deterioration was found. It is to be demolished in the summer of 2010.

column2: Venetian Causeway Between Miami and Biscayne Island
column18: David Volkert & Associates / GLF Construction Corp.
column20: The bridge was designed to mimic the appearance of the original Venetian Causeway.

column2: Venetian Causeway Between Rivo Alto and Belle Islands
column15: Bascule; Concrete Tee Beam Approach Spans
column20: The other bascule span on the western Venetian Causeway was replaced in 1999.

column15: Continuous haunched deck girder; concrete girder approach spans
column20: The bridge is the newest major river crossing in Pittsburgh, carrying I-579 over the Allegheny. It is the widest bridge in Pittsburgh, carrying 7 lanes (plus 3 shoulders). The bridge is to be rehabilitated in 2012.

column18: Michael Baker Corporation, The Dravo Contracting Company, National Engineering & Contracting, Inc., Danis Industries Corporation, Mashuda Corporation, S.J. Groves & Sons
column20: The Veterans Memorial Bridge was the second cable-stayed bridge to be built over the Ohio River. The East Huntington Bridge in Cabell County was the first. In the 1950's the Weirton-Steubenville area experienced severe traffic congestion because there were only two Ohio River crossings, each with just one lane in each direction. One of these bridges carried US 22, which, before interstates were built, was the main east-west route connecting the New York area with Pittsburgh, Columbus, and Cincinnati. Preliminary engineering on a new bridge began in 1961. It was not until 1978 that the project received federal approval. Construction began the next year. Meanwhile, the first cable-stayed bridge in America opened in 1978 (the Ed Hendler Bridge over the Columbia River). As with any pioneering bridge design, complications delayed the Veterans Memorial Bridge project. The bridge finally opened on May 1, 1990, after 11 years of construction. The bridge has cables up to 800 feet long (the Ohio main span is 820 feet long; the West Virginia main span is 690 feet long). The tower is an impressive 360 feet tall. The West Virginia approach, the Robert C. Byrd Highway, was finally completed in 1993. As of 2009, there are four more cable-stayed bridges over the Ohio River, with at least one more on the way.

The Vietnam Veterans Memorial Bridge over the Ohio River is part of Interstate 470, the only three-digit interstate in West Virginia. The highway opened in 1978 as a bypass for congested Wheeling and the restrictive Wheeling Tunnel only 10 years after I-70 was completed. The bridge is the longest in the region, with a main span of 780 feet and a total length of just under a mile. It was rehabilitated in 2005, when the arch was repainted from blue (as seen in the picture) to the WV standard green. However, the thousands of feet of approach girders remain the original blue.

column2: Virgin River / Webb Hill Trail Bridge
column20: The Virgin River / Webb Hill Trail Bridge connects the Virgin River Trail with the Webb Hill Trail. The bridge is part of St George's 25 miles of trail. It is a prefabricated welded pony truss.
The bridge is to be rehabilitated after completion of the Rankin Bridge rehabilitation project. It is the last remaining thru cantilever bridge over the Monongahela River.

The bridge was built as an entrance over Turtle Creek to the Westinghouse Airbrake Company (WABCO) factories. A large WABCO logo was painted on the side of the bridge when it opened. WABCO merged with MotivePower Industries in 1999 and was renamed Wabtec. The bridge was constructed around 1960, during the same period when Turtle Creek was channelized for flood control. The flood control project was completed in 1966. The nearby Wilmerding Bridge (Bridge Street Bridge) was replaced at the conclusion of the project, and opened in 1971. The WABCO bridge is a rare example of a modern thru girder. Most thru girders were built before WWII, except in areas where height clearance is important. Therefore, a thru girder was probably chosen to provide more clearance above the flood-prone creek.
The Waco Drive Bridge is a steel multi-beam girder bridge typical of bridges built in the period following World War II.

column15: Parker riveted with steel stringer approaches
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Waco Road Bridge is an example of a state-standard Parker truss built during the Great Depression. It was located on the highway that connected the Dallas Fort Worth area with Waco and Austin, which has been bypassed by I-35.

column2: Waco Steel Bridge (Washington Avenue Bridge at Brazos River)
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: John W. Maxoy (Engineer); Joseph H. Sparks of St. Joseph, Missouri (Contractor)
column20: The Waco Steel Bridge is a monumental example of a Pennsylvania truss. Only a few Pennsylvania truss bridges still exist in Texas. According to TexasEscapes.com, ''Built in 1902, the Waco Steel Bridge was billed as the longest single span bridge in the world. Considerably shorter than the Suspension Bridge, nonetheless, it was first in its own category and as such was the subject of postcards. The South side of the bridge is now the site for the Vietnam War Memorial--listing the 64 Wacoans and McLennan Countians who lost their lives in Vietnam.'' The bridge was rehabilitated in 2009 and repainted black, which was its original color. Despite its important historic significance the bridge is often ignored, since the nearby Waco Suspension Bridge is promoted as the tourist attraction.

column15: Cable, Warren stiffening truss; Warren riveted pony truss (north approach)
