column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1970; Texas Historic Civil Engineering Landmark, 1976; Outstanding Engineering Achievement, Texas Society of Professional Engineers
column18: Waco Bridge Company, Thomas M. Griffith (Engineer), rebuilt by the Missouri Valley Bridge and Iron Company
column20: The Waco Suspension Bridge is one of the oldest and most significant historic bridges in the State of Texas. According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''When completed in 1869, the 475'-0''-long Waco Suspension Bridge was the state's first major suspension bridge. The first bridge to span the Brazos River, it originally featured two castellated pink brick towers. The span opened as a toll bridge on January 7, 1870. Its toll houses feature stepped gable roofs, parapets, and round arched openings. Financed by the Waco Bridge Company, it is an example of a bridge built at the initiative of local business leaders during the Reconstruction when local governments had difficulty funding large capital projects. McLennan County purchased the bridge in 1889, freed it of tolls, and turned it over to the city of Waco. It was reconstructed by the Missouri Valley Bridge and Iron Company between 1913 and 1914. The Waco Suspension Bridge was closed to vehicular traffic in 1971. The original structure was designed by Thomas M. Griffith, an engineer who had worked for the John A. Roebling's Sons Company. The Waco Suspension Bridge was nominated to the National Register of Historic Places in 1970.''

The 1911 Walker Hill Road Bridge is the newer of only two remaining Warren pony truss bridges in Greene County. Based on its details, the bridge appears to have been built by either the Penn Bridge Company or the York Bridge Company. The Penn Bridge Company is more likely, since the company built several other bridges in Greene County.

column2: Walkway to the Institute of Texan Cultures Bridge
column20: The Tower of the Americas was built as part of HemisFair '68, the World's Fair held in San Antonio in 1968. Another large structure, the State of Texas's pavilion, became the Institute of Texan Cultures after the fair ended. In 1986 - 1988, the grounds of the World's Fair were redeveloped and renamed HemisFair Park. The bridge over the Walkway to the Institute of Texan Cultures was part of this redevelopment, which included waterfalls, fountains, and landscaping.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The single-span, 88'-long, seven-panel, steel pin-connected Pratt pony truss bridge, built in 1892, is constructed of built-up steel members and eyebars. It is supported on masonry abutments with wingwalls and its railings are fabricated from single steel pipes. Unlike many such small pony truss bridges, the bridge has no outriggers.''

column16: Only steel arch bridge in Clarion County
column20: The Walls Memorial Bridge is the only arch bridge constructed over a non-navigable waterway in Pennsylvania in the late 1900's. The bridge spans a dammed section of the Clarion River, therefore having a deep channel. As part of the bridge project, US 322 was realigned. The old bridge was originally a half thru Pennsylvania truss. When the river was dammed, the old bridge was raised and converted to a traditional thru truss. It was replaced in 1987.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1996
column18: Texas Highway Commission, Gibb Gilchrist (Highway Engineer), G. G. Wickline (Bridge Engineer), R. E. Schiller (Resident Engineer); Austin Bridge Company (Contractor)
column20: According to the Historic Bridge Foundation, ''This Multi-span Parker through truss bridge was built in 1932. This location, a common crossing point for Austin Colony settlers, became the nucleus of the city of Columbus. An earlier bridge built in 1884 collapsed in 1928 as a motorist was crossing. The current bridge, which was opened in 1932, overlooks Beason's Park on the Colorado. The park was built by Colorado County and the LCRA.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The single span, 63'-long, pin-connected, wrought iron Pratt pony truss bridge built in 1889 is supported on stone abutments. The bridge is composed of Phoenix section upper chords with cast-iron connecting pieces, built-up verticals, and eye bar diagonals and lower chords. Built-up floorbeams and rolled stringers support the timber deck. The bridge was fabricated by the Phoenix Bridge Co. of Phoenixville, PA, and erected by their agents Dean & Westbrook of New York. The company was instrumental in refining and popularizing metal truss bridge technology during the last half of the 19th century. The Phoenix column, patented in 1861, was one of the first successful attempts to substitute built-up wrought iron sections for cast iron for use with compression members. Truss bridges with Phoenix column members were used widely by railroads through the mid 1880s and for highway applications through the mid 1890s. It is mostly the later highway examples, such as this 1889 bridge, that have survived in small numbers in Pennsylvania. The bridge is historically and technologically distinguished.''
The concrete parapets were removed and replaced with guide rail sometime between 1997 and 2008. The arch is noted for its skew.

The Wana Bridge is an early example of a state-standard riveted Pratt truss bridge. Note that the first and last verticals are v-laced, which is not seen in later state-standard bridges. As seen in the photograph, additional end diagonals and portal bracing have been added to strengthen the western end of the bridge. This is not a good sign for the future of the bridge.

column16: Only rigid frame bridge in Monroe County
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 82'-long rigid frame bridge has horizontally scored abutment stems and wingwalls. 3-high metal railings with concrete end posts line the roadway. The bridge is a representative example of a common bridge type used for overpasses crossing major highways in the 1950s.''

column15: Deck arch (3-hinged); deck girder approach spans
column18: Allegheny County, Vernon Covell / McClintic - Marshall Company / Benno Janssen (Architect)
column20: The Washington Crossing Bridge is another Pittsburgh bridge in which the architects dictated the design. Decorative features include Allegheny County seal escutcheons over the center hinge of the arches, obelisks at the ends of the bridge, and reliefs of the seals of the original thirteen states and Allegheny County on the railings. The bridge commemorates the river crossing of George Washington 1753. During the crossing, George Washington fell out of his raft and was rescued by his guide, Christopher Gist.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, only open spandrel arch in Delaware
column18: John E. Greiner (Preliminary Design), Benjamin H. Davis (Final Design), Vance W. Torbet (Architect)
column20: According to the HAER report by P.A.C. Spero & Company with Kidde Consultants, ''The Washington Street Bridge (State Highway Bridge No. 576) is a multiple span monumental concrete arch bridge. The main span, an open spandrel arch, is 250 feet long. There are two arch spans flanking the center arch; both are solid spandrel arches. The approach spans are 70' long and 85' long. The roadway is 40' from curb to curb and 14' sidewalks run down either side. The substructure is concrete. The bridge is highly embellished, with a rusticated surface treatment simulating stone, cast stone urn-shaped balustrades, cast iron light standards, and monumental pylons carrying bronze tablets and ornamental bronze lanterns, and topped with carved eagles. The main span arch has incised 'voussoirs' and a 'keystone'. There are eight ornamental pylons located in line with the railings; the four larger shafts, 40' tall, are located over the piers of the main span, and the smaller 23.5 foot shafts mark the portals. The eagles mounted on the larger pylons are carved from Onondaga Litholite. The pylons at the main span carry bronze tablets commemorating the Revolutionary War; the War of 1812; the Mexican, Civil, and Spanish-American Wars; and two tablets commemorating the World War, one with names of the battles in which Delaware Troops fought, and the other inscribed with the names of men from the State of Delaware killed in the World War. The bridge is further elaborated with quotations from Washington, Lincoln, Theodore Roosevelt, Lowell, Tennyson and Ruskin. A stairway at the southwest corner of the bridge leads to the river below. . . . The Washington Street Bridge is significant technologically, as the only open-spandrel concrete arch bridge surveyed in Delaware, and architecturally, for the high artistic value of its monumental design. It derives additional significance from its association with the movement to memorialize the soldiers killed in the first World War.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1914, 2 span, simply supported, 182'-long, thru girder bridge is supported on concrete abutments and a concrete cutwater pier. When built, the entire bridge was encased with concrete, but the encasement was removed from all but the floorbeams and stringers in 1949. The bridge is an example of a bridge technology introduced by the railroad industry in the 1840s and used on Pennsylvania highways since the late 19th century. This example has no innovative or distinctive details. The webs of the spans are connected over the center pier by welded cover plate, but the design is not continuous because the spans are not joined at the flanges.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The riveted, 40'-long and 15' wide Pratt pony truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with wingwalls. It was fabricated by the Penn Bridge Co. ca. 1910 (commissioners on plaque elected in 1908). The trusses are traditionally composed, and the rolled section floorbeams are riveted to the vertical members using triangular shaped plates. The fascia stringers are built up to form curbs; the rest are rolled I beam sections. The design seems to be an attempt at providing a stiffer, stronger bridge. The other truss members are traditionally composed. There are welded repairs to the inclined endposts.''

column16: Oldest active truss bridge (on a public road) over the Susquehanna River in Pennsylvania (tied until late 2010)
column18: Luzerne County, E. R. Troxell, Jr. (Engineer), Penn Bridge Company (Contractor)
column20: With the 2010 demolition of the Eighth Street Bridge, the Water Street Bridge will be the oldest truss bridge on a public road over the entire Susquehanna River (excluding the West Branch) in Pennsylvania. The bridge is a source of community identity, with bridge-themed art on the Pittston side. According to the PAHBI, ''The 5 span, 1016'-long steel pin-connected Parker thru truss bridge built in 1914 is traditionally composed of eye bar tension members and built-up compression members of standard sections. It is supported on stone piers and abutments with extensive concrete repairs including concrete caps, and encased or replaced cutwaters. The deck, stringers, and truss bearings were replaced in 1984. Welded repairs included plate welded to some diagonals at the lower panel points. Original railings have been replaced by W-beam guide rails at the roadway face of the trusses and a tubular metal railing at the cantilevered sidewalk. The altered bridge is a late example of the pin-connected truss bridge type/design that was introduced about 1870 by engineer Charles Parker. The Parker truss is a variation of the Pratt truss with a polygonal top chord. The type/design continued to be used for longer span crossings through the first decades of the 20th century because of economy of design, ease of erection, and pin connections, which were still considered a favorable means of handling secondary stresses in longer span trusses. The bridge was fabricated by the Penn Bridge Co., a prolific builder in the state since the 1870s.''

Though many truss bridges have been restored in Columbiana County, the Waterford Road Bridge is not to be one of them. The bridge is very similar to the nearby State Line Road Bridge, although it is smaller. Both are half-hip pin-connected pony truss bridges, a rare design for the region. With the demolition of the Waterford Road Bridge, the design will be even rarer!

In 1940, the first stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike opened between Irwin and Somerset. The original mainline overpasses consisted of arched concrete rigid frames, steel thru girders, and concrete tee beams. The remaining tee beams were replaced in the 1990's. Beginning in the late 1990's and continuing through at least 2020, the entire original turnpike is being reconstructed and widened. Almost all original overpasses are being replaced as part of the project. This will include the Watson Road Overpass. The bridge is an example of a steel thru girder and floorbeam system.

column2: Watsontown Bridge (Nurse Helen Fairchild Memorial Bridge)
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1988; 2006 Pennsylvania Historic Preservation Award winner; last remaining concrete arch over the West Branch Susquehanna River
column18: Northumberland and Union counties, James Long (engineer), George Rockwell (contractor), Dewberry-Goodkind (rehabilitation consulting firm)
column20: The historic Watsontown Bridge is the last remaining concrete arch bridge over the West Branch Susquehanna River. It is noted for having barrel arches instead of arch ribs, which is uncommon in Pennsylvania. The bridge was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1988. It was rehabilitated in 2005 in which all of the bridge above the arch barrel was removed and replaced. PennDOT should be commended for rehabilitating instead of replacing this historic bridge! According to a PennDOT press release, ''The rehabilitation of the bridge exemplifies how a project can have positive effects on the surrounding environment and community, while delivering necessary transportation improvement, through careful planning and implementation of well-conceived solutions.... Historic preservation goals were integrated with safety improvements, a widened bridge roadway, increased load capacity and reduced future maintenance needs. The project improved an important river crossing for modern highway traffic, yet retained the important characteristics and details of a National Register-listed historic structure.'' Hopefully this bridge project can be a model for future projects.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column18: West Penn Bridge Company (Penn Bridge Company)
column20: The Watts Mill Bridge is one of the most significant bridges in Beaver County. It is a very rare example (possibly the only example left) of a wrought iron continuous pony truss from the 1870's. In most cases, such a bridge would have been two simple pony trusses or one thru truss. Before computers were used for bridge calculations beginning in the 1950's, continuous trusses were avoided due to the difficulty of calculating forces about a center pier. It is not known why this rare and unusual continuous truss was built. The bridge is also significant for being possibly the only surviving bridge of the West Penn Bridge Company, which became the Penn Bridge Company in 1879. The company moved to New Brighton, also in Beaver County. Note the unusual detail of the diagonal endpost connection with the top chord. As with other Penn Bridge Company bridges, the diagonal and the vertical are connected with separate pins. The top chord projects over the diagonal endpost. Though the bridge is sparsely used (about 50 cars a day), it is in poor condition and therefore in danger of replacement. Since the bridge is at a sharp angle of Watts Mill Road, the bridge could be a candidate for being bypassed by a new alignment. Since it is a relatively small pony truss, it could also be a candidate for relocation. If the bridge becomes available for reuse, it will be marketed on the PennDOT Bridge Marketing page.

column15: Deck girder and floorbeam system on trussed bents
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: F. M. Harper, Fort Pitt Bridge Company
column20: The Wayne Street Viaduct was one of two high-level bridges crossing Butler's industrial area along the banks of the Connoquenessing Creek built during World War I. Both were replaced in the early 2000's. According to the PAHBI, ''The 865'-long steel deck girder viaduct, built in 1915, has 12 main spans and is supported on a substructure composed of built up column bents. The viaduct was determined eligible as a contributing resource to the Butler Industrial Historic District.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The 1938, 2 simple span, built-up steel girder bridge is supported on horizontally scored concrete abutments with wingwalls and a cutwater pier. The bridge also has steel floorbeams and a reinforced concrete deck. The bridge is an example of a common type built by the railroad industry since the 1850s and used on vehicular highways since the late 19th century.''

The Wendel Road Bridge was one of the original 1939 Pennsylvania Turnpike overpasses. Almost all of the original overpasses are being replaced as part of mainline and roadway reconstruction which started around 2000. The photograph was taken two days prior to bridge demolition in March of 2007.
The Werner Road Bridge retains the characteristic details of an early 1960's Pennsylvania stringer bridge.

The Berkeley Street Bridge is an unremarkable concrete arch bridge on a local street in Uniontown. Since the bridge is wider than the roadway, grass separates the road from the edges of the bridge. Therefore, most motorists do not even realize they are crossing a bridge.

column2: West Carson Street Bridge over Chartiers Creek
column20: The bridge was constructed as a pony truss, with unusually tall trusses. The design is similar to that of the West End Bridge, built a few years later. In 1978 the bridge was converted to a thru truss by the addition of lateral bracing. This is the only pony truss on the website that was converted to a thru truss.

column2: West Chester Bypass High Street Overpass
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Nello L. Teer Company (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The bridge was constructed in 1953 as part of the West Chester bypass project. The bypass was built by the state highway department from 1953 to 1955 to carry US 202 and US 322 around downtown West Chester. The project was typical of urban highway improvements undertaken by the department from the late 1940s through the 1960s. The bypass project was not historically or technologically significant, although it has had an impact on the pattern of suburban development around West Chester.... The skewed, 88'-long steel stringer bridge Moderne style horizontally scored abutments, wing walls, and pilasters forming the railing end posts. The metal railings are a standard design of the state highway department from the 1950s. The stringers are built-up beams with crossbracing. The bridge is one in a series of similarly styled bridges on the West Chester bypass. It has no technologically distinguishing features...''

Though the West Chestnut Street Bridge is an example of a 1930's Pennsylvania state-standard truss bridge, it is the only one in Potter County. This type of bridge was built with great frequency elsewhere. It is also one of only three truss-supported bridges in the county, and one of only two that still serves vehicular traffic.

The West Crawford Street Bridge is an example of a cantilevered deck girder with hinged connections. These types of connections were often seen only up to 20 years after World War II. The bridge has a humpback look, due to the vertical curvature to clear the railroad tracks on the east bank of the river. The bridge replaced a two-span pin-connected Parker truss which replaced a Roebling suspension bridge.

column18: Allegheny County, Vernon Covell, American Bridge
column20: The West End Bridge was one of the largest thru arches in the country when constructed in 1932. The significant bridge was determined eligible for the National Register in 1979. In 1991, the bridge was rehabilitated, and the northern four pony trusses were removed for the construction of a freeway interchange. As the first bridge over the Ohio River, it is Pittsburgh's own Gateway Arch to the West.

The bridge was constructed as part of the West End Circle, which was built to connect the West End Bridge with Carson Street and the West End of Pittsburgh. The bridge was built alongside the Norfolk Southern Railroad culvert over Saw Mill Run. The road was on top of 15 to 18 feet of fill enclosed by the southern spandrel wall. The bridge was abandoned as part of the realignment of the West End Circle.

The West End Drive Bridge once carried the road over Robinson Run. When the bridge deteriorated to the point that it could no longer carry vehicles safely, it was closed to traffic. Wooden fences were added to the deck to restrict pedestrians to the center of the bridge; the edges of the roadway were too deteriorated to be safe. The railings are typical of Pennsylvania Department of Highways bridges from the 1950's.

The bridge was built as part of the 1951 Western Extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike. All mainline vehicular overpasses were either thru girders or deck girders in the extension. The bridge will be replaced as part of the Turnpike widening, which will happen sometime after 2010. The West Hardies Road Bridge is an example of a thru girder.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1988; oldest active bridge over the entire Allegheny River until its demolition in 2007
column20: The West Hickory Bridge was the oldest active truss bridge over the Allegheny River. Between 1980 and 2015, 75% of the pre-World War II Allegheny River truss bridges (downstream of New York) have been/will be demolished. Between 2005 and 2015, 4 out of the 5 truss bridges in Forest County have been/will be demolished. Since the West Hickory Bridge was the only one of those bridges listed on the National Register of Historic Places, it was perhaps the most significant. The bridge was demolished in 2007, replaced by a steel beam. The West Hickory Bridge was an example of a four span pin-connected Pratt thru truss built by the Groton Bridge Company. A tee beam approach span was added on the east side in the 1920's or 1930's. The bridge was built for the Hickory Bridge Company which operated it as a toll bridge until the bridge was taken over by the state.

column2: West Huntington Bridge (Nick Joe Rahal II Bridge)
column20: The 1968 cantilever bridge is the oldest of the three Ohio River Bridges in Huntington, West Virginia. It was built as part of the West Huntington Expressway, now US 52, though the bridge is just two lanes wide. Interstate 73 is planned to cross the country from Sault Ste. Marie, MI, to Myrtle Beach, SC, and will be an upgraded US 52 in the Huntington, WV area. If it does use the West Huntington Expressway and the West Huntington Bridge, either the bridge will either be twinned or replaced. The West Huntington Bridge was a toll bridge until the 1980's. Post World War II cantilevers are the most common type of bridge over the Ohio River.

column15: Warren riveted continuous, multi-beam approach spans
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Julian Montgomery (Engineer); Texas State Highway Department; Russ Mitchell, Inc. (Contractor)
column20: According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''At the time of its construction, this bridge was the largest regular federal aid highway project ever completed by the Texas Highway Department. . . . In planning the bridge, the Texas Highway Department collaborated with the Park Board of the City of Fort Worth in providing for an aesthetically pleasing structure that would be in harmony with the environment of Trinity Park. The architectural aspects of the piers and abutments were designed with beauty as well as functionality in mind. . . . On the outside of each abutment and tower there are abstract decorative features in the concrete surfaces. Pedestrian seats located at the top of the tower piers are flanked by 4'-0''-wide glazed polychrome terra cotta panels featuring the artistically rendered heads of longhorn steer.'' The bridge is an example of a Warren deck truss. It is the only deck truss in the region, and it is probably the longest deck truss bridge in Texas.

column2: West Market Street San Antonio River Bridge
column20: In the mid to late 1920's, many San Antonio River Bridges were replaced with concrete tee beam bridges. The West Market Street Bridge is one such example.

column2: West Market Street San Antonio River Bypass Channel Bridge
column20: As a response to a 1921 flood, a channel was dug to bypass a U-shaped stretch of the San Antonio River downtown. Work began in 1925, and the channel was completed in 1929. The West Market Street Bridge was built as part of the project to span the bypass channel.

column16: Last remaining deck truss bridge in Mercer County
column20: The West Middlesex Bridge is the last remaining example of a deck truss bridge in Mercer County. Constructed in 1941, it is a late example of the state-standard Pratt deck truss, which was built from the late 1920's to 1941. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1941, 10 span, 718'-long viaduct with a 202'-long, riveted Pratt deck truss main span is supported on concrete abutments and concrete two column and beam cap beam bents. The approach spans are steel stringers. The concrete parapets and deck date from 1982.''

column15: Pennsylvania pin-connected (2 spans) with a pin-connected Parker and concrete box beam approach spans
column16: Last remaining Pennsylvania truss over the entire Susquehanna River in Pennsylvania
column20: The West Nanticoke Bridge is noteworthy for being the last Pennsylvania truss over the entire Susquehanna River. By 2015 there will only be about 10 Pennsylvania truss bridges in all of Pennsylvania. Covered bridges will be 20 times as common! According to the PAHBI, '''The 24 span, 1,922'-long bridge consists of three, 263'-long, Pennsylvania thru truss spans built in 1914, and 21, 54'-long, prestressed concrete box beam approach spans built in 1987. The pin connected truss spans are traditionally composed of built up compression members and eye bar tension members. The northernmost span has been altered by replacement of the lower chord eye bars with steel channels and replacement of the pin connections with bolt connections at the lower panel points. The Pennsylvania truss, a variation of the Pratt truss with subdivided panels and polygonal top chord, was developed by bridge engineers of the Pennsylvania RR about 1875.''

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, only Parker truss over the entire Youghiogheny River
column20: The West Newton Bridge is the last-remaining Parker truss bridge over the Youghiogheny River. According to the PAHBI (MEM Reviewer), ''The 3 span, 490' long and 22.9' wide, pin-connected, Parker thru truss is supported on ashlar abutments with wingwalls. The 160' long trusses are traditionally composed, and the floor beams are built up. The bridge appears to be complete. The stringers were replaced in 1958. The bridge is historically and technologically significant as a complete example of its design, which is not common in the state. Details that are not original to the bridge are the beam guide rail inside the truss lines and the metal fence-like railings on the cantilevered sidewalk.'' The bridge was rehabilitated and repainted in 2010, extending its service life for many years to come.

column2: West North Avenue at Brighton Road Bridge
column15: Concrete encased thru girder and floorbeam system
column20: The concrete encased thru girder is 88 feet wide to carry the intersection of North Avenue and Brighton Road over the Norfolk Southern Railroad (Formerly the Fort Wayne Division of the Pennsylvania Railroad). The bridge is eligible for the National Register of Historic Places since it was built in conjunction with the railroad's improvements. The bridge replaced a metal truss from 1905, probably similar to the two truss bridges nearby.

column2: West Park Bridge over Norfolk Southern Railroad
column18: City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works?
column20: The bridge was built to be a decorative crossing for a path in West Park (formerly Allegheny Commons). It appears that the bridge had smaller approach arches that were crudely filled in. The deteriorated bridge was closed sometime around 2000. Deteriorated deck sections were removed, allowing light to pass between the ribs. The bridge is to be replaced.

The bridge is a rare example of a Pratt through truss with vertical endposts. The bridge is very unusual in that the skew is achieved by the addition of one shorter extra panel to the opposite sides of the parallel trusses. Therefore, the bridge is not symmetrical. The bridge was built to connect the Pennsylvania Railroad with the stockyards on Herr's Island (now known as Washington's Landing). In 1999, the bridge was converted for trail use, and switchback ramps were added to the north end. The bridge is an excellent example of adaptive reuse.

column16: Likely eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The 1907 West Penn Trail Bridge No. 1 was constructed in 1907 as part of a realignment of the Pennsylvania Railroad. The railroad entered a tunnel through Bow Ridge at the east end. The bridge is located near the site where the 1827 Pennsylvania Canal Aqueduct once crossed the river. The aqueduct also had a tunnel through Bow Ridge, the third tunnel built in America. The canal was abandoned and replaced by the 1864 Pennsylvania Railroad nearby. The 1864 bridge was replaced by the existing 1907 bridge. Due to the construction of the Conemaugh River Dam, the railroad was realigned in 1950 with a High Level deck truss bridge. In the 1990's, the bypassed 1907 railroad right-of-way became the West Penn Trail.

column15: Open spandrel concrete arch widened by concrete tee beams
column20: The West Twenty-Fourth Street Bridge opened in 1928 as a conventional open spandrel ribbed concrete arch. Note the central arches in the photograph. In 1939 the bridge was widened on both sides by concrete tee beams. To maintain the appearance of an arch bridge, arch-shaped fascia panels were added to both sides to hide the beams.

column2: West Virginia Route 26 Little Sandy Creek Bridge
column20: With a main span of 80 feet, the WV Route 26 Little Sandy Creek Bridge is the longest-spanning concrete arch bridge in Preston County. Note the decorative spandrel walls accenting the arch ring. The bridge is one of many similar concrete arch bridges in the state. In the mid to late 1900's, the concrete balustrades or parapets were removed and replaced with guide rail, as seen in the photograph. In 2008 the bridge was rehabilitated, in which the guide rail was replaced with concrete barrier parapets. The sides of the arches were faced with new concrete, and the decorative accents were replicated. The renovated bridge is an excellent example of a bridge rehabilitation.

column2: Westbound Texas State Highway 71 Pedernales River Bridge
column20: In 1942, the Mansfield Dam was constructed west of Austin, forming Lake Travis on the Colorado River and its tributary, the Pedernales River. A few years later, TX 71 was realigned, with a new high-level deck truss bridge over the Pedernales River. The bridge is an example of a Warren deck truss, a rare type in Texas. In 1986, TX 71 was widened to two lanes in each direction. Rather than replace the bridge, a new beam structure was built along the south side of the bridge. Since the widened bridge has no center divider, motorists crossing the bridge have no idea that the two sides of the road are separate bridges.

The Western Avenue Bridge is a concrete stringer bridge dating from 1945. It has paneled parapets, matching several other concrete arch bridges in Washington County. Concrete was used frequently after World War II due to the high cost and shortages of steel.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Western Avenue Bridge is one of two parallel concrete arch Charles River Bridges built by the Metropolitan District Commission in the mid 1920's. The bridge is an example of a concrete segmental arch. It incorporates decorative features such as arch rings accented to resemble molded voussoirs. The concrete is horizontally scored between the arch rings. The Western Avenue Bridge is slated to be rehabilitated, and the decorative elements will be restored.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: Western Center was one of several state hospitals in the area built for the mentally handicapped. The facility closed in 2000 and the land sold to a private developer. Southpointe II will be built on the property. It will be a mixed residential, retail, and commercial development. The future of the Western Center Entrance Drive bridge is not known. According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, the bridge is a ''single span reinforced concrete deck arch bridge finished with parapets with scored panels. The limits of the bridge are defined by blocky, pedimented panels at the east end and larger, hip-roofed pylons at the west or campus end of the bridge The southwest pylon may have been a guard house at one point, but its openings are now blank.'' The bridge has been determined to be historically significant based on its association with Western Center.
The Westlake Drive Bridge is an unremarkable arched culvert, in which the roadway sits on fill over a large steel pipe.
The Westover Bridge is the main Monongahela River crossing in Morgantown. It is an unremarkable deck girder from 1977. The bridge replaced a thru truss, which replaced a suspension bridge.

column15: Parker pin-connected with load-bearing Bailey pony trusses
column16: Documented by the Historic American Engineering Record
column20: The Wheeling and Belmont Bridge is a rare surviving pin-connected Parker truss with vertical endposts. The bridge opened in 1893 as a replacement for a covered bridge carrying the National Road over the Wheeling Island Back Channel. The bridge was first rehabilitated in 1950, when a grate was installed to replace the wooden roadway. In the 1980's, the floorbeams had become structurally unsound, and the bridge was closed. Instead of immediately replacing the bridge, a temporary load-bearing Bailey pony truss was installed inside the Parker trusses in 1987. This is an innovative solution, which surprisingly is not often duplicated. After 11 years, the replacement bridge opened in 1998 immediately to the south, and the old bridge was abandoned. The original plan was to convert the historic bridge into a pedestrian and bicycle bridge, though ten years later nothing has been done. Due to Wheeling being a city known for another historic bridge, the Wheeling Suspension Bridge, and the rarity of the Wheeling and Belmont Bridge's design, it is essential that the bridge be restored.

column2: Wheeling and Elm Grove Boulevard Bridge (Bethlehem Boulevard Bridge)
column20: The Wheeling and Elm Grove Avenue Bridge is a standard-design WVDOH post World War II stringer bridge. The bridge retains its original appearance.

column2: Wheeling Stone Arch Bridge (Main Street Bridge)
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Wheeling Stone Arch Bridge is located at the southern border of downtown Wheeling. With a main span of 159 feet, it is the largest stone arch in the region. It is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, ''The 53'-long and 51' wide reinforced concrete deck arch bridge built in 1919 is one of at least 15 similar deck arch bridges in Washington County designed by or attributed to the Chaney & Armstrong, Engineers, later styled as Chaney Engineering Company, in the 1910s and 1920s for the county. Most, like this example, are finished with incised panel parapets topped with beveled coping and plain spandrel walls. The arch ring is set off by extending beyond the face of the spandrel walls.''

column15: Wire rope suspension with wooden Howe stiffening truss
column16: U.S. National Historic Landmark, Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: Simply put, the Wheeling Suspension Bridge is a U.S. National Historic Landmark, listed in 1976. According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''The Wheeling Bridge is perhaps the most important extant antebellum civil engineering structure in North America.'' What makes the bridge so significant? Arguably it is the bridge which proved the adaptability and usefulness of the suspension design. The modern form of the suspension bridge (one with towers and a level deck) was first built in 1801 in western Pennsylvania by James Finley. However, early suspension bridges used iron chains, in which one broken link led to a total bridge collapse. While many similar bridges were initially built, the type was all but abandoned in America within 20 years. However, engineers in Europe began to improve and advance the suspension bridge design. Charles Ellet studied in Europe and began to design revolutionary suspension bridges in America. Since the 1830's, he had proposed suspension bridge designs that could span 1,000 feet, which at the time was thought to be impossible. Finally, in the 1840's, he got the chance to build such a bridge when he beat John Roebling for the commission for a bridge over the Ohio River at Wheeling, Virginia (now West Virginia). The 1,010 foot Wheeling Suspension Bridge, the first bridge ever built over the Ohio River and America's oldest surviving suspension bridge built as a vehicular bridge, opened in 1849 after three years of construction. Unfortunately, just five years later the bridge collapsed in a windstorm. The bridge was rebuilt by John Roebling (who also designed the Brooklyn Bridge). Roebling modified the bridge by replacing Ellet's cables (comprised of separate strands fastened together) with his wire rope. In addition, diagonal cable stays were added from the towers to stiffen the bridge and to match other Roebling bridges. The bridge has been refurbished many times since, enabling it to still carry vehicular traffic 160 years after it first opened. Today, engineers continue to build record-breaking long-span designs. As of 2009, the Akashi-Kaikyo Bridge in Japan is the longest, with a main span of 6,532 feet. In the early 1800's, a 1,000 foot span was thought to be impossible. In the early to mid 21st century, a $7.5 billion bridge to connect the Italian Peninsula with Sicily is to be built spanning 2 miles! This is what the Wheeling Suspension Bridge started!!!
The bridge was built to serve as access to the Metsa Machine Company plant (now WHEMCO). The southern approach to the bridge has been removed.

column16: The bridge was recycled from a railroad turntable
column20: The White Bridge Road Bridge is an unusual thru girder in which the girders are deepest at their center sections. This is because the girders were once used for a railroad turntable. According to the PAHBI, ''The 2 span, 114'-long bridge has a 74'-long, built-up thru girder main span and a 40'-long, rolled beam thru girder approach span. The main span girders are deepest in the middle where bending is the greatest. The bridge was constructed from salvaged turntable girders purchased from the Pennsylvania Railroad by Blair County to replace a bridge lost in the devastating 1936 St. Patrick's Day flood.'' There was another similar bridge surveyed in the PAHBI, but it has since been replaced.

column15: Wooden covered Queenpost on load-bearing steel stringers
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The White Covered Bridge is the longest covered bridge in Greene County. Up until its rehabilitation in 2008, the bridge was truss-supported. As part of the rehabilitation, much of the bridge was rebuilt. This included some of the main truss members. As part of the project, the structure was retrofitted with load-bearing steel stringers.

The Whiteley Road Bridge is a concrete arch bridge from 1920. The bridge has aesthetic features such as paneled parapets with a bush hammer finish. In 1992 one end was replaced. Whiteley Road is an old alignment of PA 21, which was realigned in 1950 and widened in 1966.

column16: Possibly the only one of its type, the oldest bridge in Greene County
column20: Despite the wealth of rare historic bridges in Greene County, the Whites Ridge Road Bridge is probably the most significant bridge of any type or design. It was built in 1877 by the Massillon Bridge Company, the same company that built the 1878 Pollocks Mill Bridge. It is the oldest bridge of any type (including covered) remaining in Greene County. The bridge has the characteristic lattice portals typical of Massillon Bridge Company structures of the late 1870's. The bridge is an unusual hybrid of a Pratt truss and a double intersection Pratt truss (Whipple), in which the diagonals extend over two panels just in the center of the bridge. For that reason, the type is listed on this website as a Pratt variant. David Hammond of the Wrought Iron Bridge Company patented this unnamed truss type (Historicbridges.org calls this type a Hammond truss). After Bridgemapper.com's discovery of this bridge, Historicbridges.org discovered at least two other examples, both built by the Wrought Iron Bridge Company. The Whites Ridge Road Bridge is abandoned and fenced off. Being likely the last remaining Massillon example of its type, the bridge could be a great addition to a park or trail. It reflects the time of the mid to late 1800's, full of experimentation and patent infringement.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Pittsburg Bridge Company, Nelson & Buchanan Agents
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1 span, 93'-long, pin-connected, Pratt thru truss bridge built in 1896 is supported on stone abutments. It is composed of standard built-up section members and eye bars and has Z-shaped plate floorbeam hangers (a distinctive Pittsburgh Bridge Co. detail) and lattice portals. The timber deck was replaced by an open steel grid deck in 1960. W-beam guiderail railings have replaced earlier railings. Fabricated by the Pittsburgh Bridge Company and erected by Nelson & Buchanan of Chambersburg, the bridge is a complete example of the pin-connected Pratt truss bridge type and design that dominated highway bridge building in the late 19th century. Pin-connected truss bridges were once common in the region, but they are increasingly rare with four examples from 1889 to 1896 identified in Adams County. Of the four remaining pin-connected truss bridges, this is the only Pratt thru truss, and it was built by a noteworthy builder in the region. It is historically and technologically significant.'' PennDOT offered the bridge to third parties to relocate and reuse the bridge. Unfortunately, no group was able to reuse the bridge.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1897, pin connected, single span, 80'-long, Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments with concrete wingwalls. The five panel trusses are traditionally composed. The bridge was built by the King Bridge Company, one of the largest and most diversified bridge fabricators of the late 19th century. Crawford County is rich in pin connected, metal truss bridges. A total of 35 ranging in date from 1870 through the early 20th century remain in the county population. This bridge stands out as a complete example of metal truss bridge built by a prominent manufacturer. It is historically and technologically significant. The bridge appears to be complete.''

According to the PAHBI, ''The 31'-long and 19' wide stone arch bridge, built ca. 1914, is laid up in rusticated ashlar, and it has flared wingwalls. Several stones of the parapet have been displaced by vehicle impact, and the bridge was inappropriately repointed ca. 1970.''

column15: Trestle, inverted queenpost, inverted kingpost on trussed bents
column20: The Wilksboro Street Footbridge is an unusual pedestrian trestle in the Brighton Heights neighborhood of Pittsburgh. It is not often that such a large bridge is built just to carry pedestrians. The bridge is also unusual due to the inverted kingpost and queenpost bracing of the deck. The bridge was closed to pedestrians in 2007, not long after the photograph was taken.

The Willard Road Bridge is the only deck truss bridge in the entire region that serves vehicular traffic. Based on the thickness of the members, the bridge was most likely built for the Penn Central Railroad. As trains became heavier in the early twentieth century, the older bridges were often moved to serve as highway overpasses. The concrete parapets appear to date from the relocation date of 1930.

column2: William Penn Highway Bridge Over Pennsylvania Route 259
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, A. E. O'Block (Contractor)
column20: According to the PAHBI, ''The 1952, single span, 43'-long, skewed T beam bridge has concrete abutments with wingwalls and standard concrete balustrades. It is an example of a very common bridge type that was used with great frequency beginning in the 1910s and continuing through the 1950s.'' The bridge was replaced in 2009 as part of a project to widen US Route 22.

column2: William Penn Highway Chalfant Run Bridge
column20: In 1941, a new alignment of US 22 was constructed from Churchill to Monroeville. This new alignment was bypassed in 1962 by the Penn Lincoln Parkway East (I-376) and is now known as Business US 22. Two large bridges were constructed for the 1942 alignment, including this bridge over Chalfant Run. It is an example of a deck girder bridge in which perpendicular floorbeams are cantilevered outwards from above the girders, giving a deck that is wider than the width between the main girders. The 1942 alignment was built as a three lane highway. It was widened in 1957 to five lanes. It is possible that the William Penn Highway Bridge over Chalfant Run was widened to four lanes in 1957 by adding the perpendicular floorbeams. The bridge was rehabilitated in 2008 and repainted green from gray.

column15: Pratt pin-connected supplemented by steel stringers
column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, documented by HAER
column18: Samuel White (Engineer of the South Park St Bridge), Phoenix Bridge Company (Fabrication of members), James F. Smith and W.R. Flickner (Abutments), Emery C. Read and Clyde M. Read (Engineers of the Williams Road Bridge)
column20: The Williams Road Bridge was originally constructed in Franklin Borough carrying South Park Street over French Creek in 1884. The bridge was built by Samuel White of Beaver Falls, Pennsylvania, using Phoenix Columns manufactured by the Phoenix Bridge Company. The South Park Street Bridge consisted of two spans. When the bridge was closed in the early 1900's, Col. S.C. Lewis, President of the Atlantic Refining Company, began to lobby for a new bridge, which was constructed in 1909. The old bridge was dismantled and stored. The central pier and western abutment for the South Park Street Bridge still remain. In 1911, the Venango County Commissioners recommended that the county assist in building a new bridge over Sugar Creek in Plum Township near the Valley School House. A contracted was awarded to James Smith and W.R. Flickner for $700 In November of 1911, the commissioners advertized for bids for ''the arranging, cutting and fitting up the necessary parts taken from the old South Park Street Bridge, and for the erection and construction of a span 72 feet 4 inches long, to be erected upon masonry abutments now ... being erected and built at the site of what is known as the Shorts Bridge.'' The Williams Road Bridge was completed in the summer of 1912. The bridge carried Williams Road with little alteration until the late 1900's, when supplementary stringers were added to reinforce the connections along the bottom chord. According to HAER, ''Williams Road Bridge is a unique vernacular example of a late-nineteenth century pin-connected Pratt through truss adapted for re-use as a county bridge in the late twentieth century. It is of engineering interest for its rare patented Phoenix columns, manufactured by the Phoenix Bridge Company of Phoenixville, Pennsylvania.'' According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1880 bridge is a rare example of a pin connected Pratt thru truss bridge fabricated with Phoenix columns. It does not have the Phoenix Iron Co.'s patented connecting pieces, indicating that the columns were ordered from Phoenix but assembled into a bridge with local thinking about connections. A simple sleeve with pin plates has been used for both upper and lower panel point connections with those for the upper ones inside the built up upper chords. The bridge appears to be unaltered, and it is an important early example of truss bridge technology. It reflects the period of experimentation as reflected in the idiosyncratic details. The bridge may be unique. There is no makers plaque.''

The Williamson Road Bridge is a common example of a concrete beam bridge. It replaced the historic Quaker Bridge on a new alignment. Due to the hard work of PennDOT, PHMC, the Historic Quaker Bridge Foundation (led by Nathan Clark), and others, the bypassed bridge will be converted into a bridge park.

According to the PAHBI, ''The skewed, 3-span, 369'-long bridge is composed of a riveted, 257'-long steel Parker truss main span and stringer approach spans. It is supported on a concrete substructure. The bridge was built to a state design in 1932, and the trusses are traditionally composed with built up box section end posts and chords. The diagonal members are built up. Metal railings are used inside the truss line and on the cantilevered sidewalk. The portal braces are massive because of the extreme skew of the bridge. The bridge has no innovative or distinctive details, and it is typical of the department's designs of the period.''

column15: Warren pin-connected, cast and wrought iron
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1978; Rare surviving cast and wrought iron hybrid; Oldest Warren truss in Pennsylvania; Rare surviving bridge designed by Wendell Bollman
column18: Wendell Bollman, Patapsco Bridge & Iron Works of Baltimore
column20: The picture is of the bridge at its previous location (TR 381 over CSX Railroad). According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''Designed by the renowned self-taught engineer Wendell C. Bollman in 1871, this bridge is the last remaining span on the B&O's Pittsburgh Division associated with Bollman. The bridge originally carried the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad over Wills Creek. It was moved about 1910 to the present location after it was no longer able to carry safely the newer and heavier locomotives.'' After years of abandonment, the bridge was moved again to carry the Great Allegheny Passage Trail over Scratch Hill Road. The bridge is one of the oldest truss bridges in all of Pennsylvania. It is perhaps the only pin-connected Warren thru truss in the state.

column18: Allegheny County, Levi Bird Duff, Richardson Gordon and Associates
column20: The 1971 Wilmerding Bridge at Patton Street replaced a thru girder located one block to the west at Bridge Street. The Bridge Street Bridge was similar to the nearby Spring Hill Wall Borough Bridge, except that the girder over the creek was taller than the approach girders. The first bridge on the site was a pony truss. The entire town of Wilmerding was created (construction started in 1890) as a company town for the Westinghouse Airbrake Company. Around 1960, Turtle Creek was straightened and channelized for flood control. The project was completed in 1966, and construction on the new bridge began in 1970. The bridge features Allegheny County standard railings used since after World War II.

column15: Continuous haunched deck girder; concrete girder approach spans
column20: The bridge has three parallel girders. It was built on the piers of the previous 1928 Clairton - Glassport Bridge, which was a Pratt deck cantilever (three cantilevered spans and two approach spans). That bridge was designed by Allegheny County. The approach spans to the new bridge are concrete girders. The bridge was rehabilitated in 2011.

column2: Wilson's Mill Covered Bridge (Wilson Lowton Bridge)
column15: Thru girder, formerly an 1887 covered bridge
column16: The arsoned covered bridge was Listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1979
column20: What do most covered bridges look like if you remove the covered portion? They look like this bridge, now a steel girder. The 1887 Wilson's Mill Covered Bridge was a covered queen post truss bridge over Cross Creek in Cross Creek County Park. At some point, probably in the 1950's, the bridge was retrofitted with load-bearing riveted girders. On September 27, 2002, the bridge was the victim of arson. Since the bridge was supported by steel thru girders, only the historic wooden portion was damaged. That portion was removed and is supposed to be restored, although no visible progress had been made five years later when this photograph was taken. Railings were added to the steel superstructure of the covered bridge, which was reopened to carry traffic.

column15: Cable suspension with wooden Warren stiffening truss
column20: The Windgap Suspension Bridge was built as a pedestrian crossing on an old alignment of Singer Avenue. Since the current roadway bridge dates from 1985, the suspension bridge probably replaced the bridge that was later replaced in 1985. On the Windgap (Pittsburgh) side, the wire rope was strung over pulleys at the top of the tower. On the McKees Rocks side, the rope was bolted to the tower and the anchorages offset. The bridge was heavily damaged in the 2004 Hurricane Ivan flood and removed in 2007, not long after the photograph was taken.

The Winfield/Eleanor Bridge is an excellent example of a cantilever bridge from the first generation of 'modern' bridges built following World War II. Up until its renovation in 2009 (the photo dates from 2005) the bridge retains its original appearance, especially the silver paint and the 1950's standard railings. If comparable projects are any indication, the deck (including the railings) will likely be replaced, concrete barriers will be installed, and the bridge will be repainted West Virginia standard green.

According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1895, pin connected, single span, 53'-long, Pratt pony truss bridge is traditionally composed with built up box section upper chords, metal angle with lattice verticals, and eye bar diagonals. The structure was modified ca. 1980 when lower chord eye bars, diagonal eye and pins were replaced with material of different dimensions than the original and welded outriggers were added.''
The Wise Road Extension Bridge is a typical example of a concrete slab built in the early to mid 1900's.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column18: Pittsburgh Bridge Company, Nelson & Buchanan Agents
column20: The 1894 Witherspoon Bridge is a pin-connected Pratt thru truss. Stylistically, it was built by the Pittsburgh Bridge Company when Nelson & Buchanan were agents for them. According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, ''The trusses are traditionally composed with the floor beams placed above the lower chords. The stringers and deck are wood, and the original lattice railings are inside the truss lines. In a county and region noted for a deep and varied collection of metal truss bridges, this early and complete example stands out. It is historically and technologically significant.'' However, since the bridge is in serious condition, it will eventually be replaced.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column20: The Witherspoon Covered Bridge is the last covered bridge to carry traffic in Franklin County. It is one of two covered bridges in the county. The bridge is an example of a Burr arch truss, which is a multiple Kingpost with an arch. According to the National Bridge Inventory, the bridge still functions as a truss, which is rare for covered bridges in vehicular use.

column18: Allegheny County, Charles Davis, William Dickson
column20: Allegheny County's most beautiful of the turn of the century stone arch bridges is considered to be the Woodland Road Extension Bridge. The bridge is in excellent condition and maintains a high degree of historical accuracy. Built in 1889, it is one of the oldest examples of a county-designed arch bridge. The bridge is distinctive for its smooth stone course along the level of the road, to contrast with the rusticated ashlar masonry.

According to Skelly & Loy, ''County Bridge Number 17 or the Woodruff Bridge is a pin connected Pratt thru truss bridge. Fabricated in 1905 by the York Bridge Company, it is a single span, 125' long bridge supported on concrete abutments with wingwalls. The upper chords and inclined end posts are built up box sections, and the verticals are channels with lacing. The diagonals and the bottom chords are eye bars. U-shaped hangers suspend the rolled floorbeams. There have been welded repairs to the original railings, which are attached to the inner faces of the trusses.''

The Wool Mill Drive Bridge is a rare example of a kingpost pony truss. While the bridge appears to be similar to comparable bridges of the late 1800's, all the members are rolled and all connections are welded. This indicates the bridge probably dates from sometime in the mid 20th century.

column18: United States Maine New Hampshire Building Commission
column20: The New Hampshire side of the bridge has a large bronze plaque spanning the portal. An eagle is perched above the plaque, the seal of the United States is to the left, and the seal of New Hampshire is to the right.

column15: Haunched deck girder and floorbeam system
column20: The Worthington Bridge is a large example of a haunched deck girder and floorbeam system bridge. Designed for economy of materials, the bridge has just two girder lines, with the highway supported by floorbeams resting on top of the girders. Modern girder bridges are typically built with additional girder lines.

column16: Last remaining multi-span thru truss in county
column18: Pennsylvania Department of Highways, Westwood Construction Company
column20: The Woy Bridge is the only multi-span thru truss in the entire county. According to the PAHBI, ''The 1937, 2 span, 262'-long, riveted Pratt thru truss bridge is supported on concrete parged ashlar abutments and an ashlar pier with a concrete cutwater. Built to a state highway department standard design, the bridge is an example of a common technology with no innovative or distinctive details. It was erected as part of the rebuilding efforts following the devastating 1936 St. Patrick's Day flood. Over 275 bridges, mostly in the western and central portions of Pennsylvania, were destroyed or damaged beyond repair. Metal truss bridges were favored because of the perceived advantage of the heavy spans being able to withstand flood episodes.''

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1979
column20: The Wright Covered Bridge is one of 23 covered bridges in Washington County. In was completed in 1890, though it incorporates members from an older bridge. This is evidenced in that all but two kingpost members were sawed. The bridge was rehabilitated in 1999, in which steel stringers were added to carry the load. The Wright Bridge is located on Ridge Road near Interstate 70. In December 2005, a fascia beam of the nearby Lakeview Drive I-70 Overpass collapsed. The bridge was an adjacent concrete box beam with a bituminous deck, dating from 1956. The Ridge Road Overpass was a similar type and therefore demolished as a safety precaution. The abutments still remain. Due to this demolition, the only access to the Wright Covered Bridge is from the south.

The Wrights Ferry Bridge was built in 1972 as part of a US 30 upgrade to a limited access highway, bypassing Columbia and Wrightsville and the two-lane Columbia-Wrightsville Bridge. The bridge is a long example of a girder bridge, with a total length of over a mile. The bridge exemplifies the difference is 1920's bridge building technology with 1970's bridge building technology. The bridge is shorter than the Columbia-Wrightsville Bridge and has a lower sufficiency rating. However, the bridge is much wider, with four lanes plus shoulders.

column2: Wurtemburg and Portersville State Road Bridge
column20: Lawrence County was founded in 1849. One of the first roads built in the county was the Wurtemburg and Portersville State Road, connecting Wurtemburg and Portersville, near the current Portersville Road, PA 488. The road was laid out around 1850. This bridge appears to have served the old alignment. Jacob Van Gorder built a grist mill in the area sometime between 1845 and 1850. Therefore, it is likely the bridge was built around 1850 for the road. Note the bridge uses cut ashlar, indicating the bridge was government-funded. Cheaper structures used coursed rubble. The bridge was bypassed with a culvert and fill and abandoned. With a large tree growing in the middle of the abutment, the roadway looks to have been realigned sometime in the mid 1900's.

Pendleton County, West Virginia, has a total of one old truss bridge, which is a state-standard 1930's truss. There is also one concrete arch in the county, which has a span of 21 feet. Neither have been documented for this website. One of the more interesting state-standard tee beams is this one over Seneca Creek. It is near the famous Seneca Rocks.
The new 2006 WV 39 bridge is similar to the previous 1964 structure in that both are deck girders. The new bridge has a longer total length, has a curved approach, and has longer main spans.

column2: WV 4 WV 16 Big Otter Creek Bridge
column20: Though concrete arch bridges are common in some West Virginia counties, the WV 4 WV 16 Big Otter Creek Bridge is last remaining example in Clay County. Unfortunately the bridge is badly spalled, and it is much more likely to be replaced instead of rehabilitated. Note the architectural features of the bridge.

The WV 67 Sugarcamp Run Bridge was one of several similar Warren pony trusses built by WVDOH in the 1930's. However, neither Hancock County to the north nor Ohio County to the south have any old truss bridges (except for Ohio River bridges). Being the only regional example of the West Virginia standard truss, the Sugarcamp Run Bridge is important.

column16: Longest remaining truss bridge in Bradford County
column20: The Wyalusing Bridge is the last remaining truss bridge over the Susquehanna River in Bradford County. According to the PAHBI, ''The 12 span, 1,461'-long bridge built in 1942 is composed of 4 riveted Parker thru truss spans and 8 spans of continuous steel stringers. The stringer spans have riveted splice plates. The substructure is concrete. Safety shape barriers were placed in 1993.''

column16: Only multi span truss bridge in Cameron County
column20: As seen by the photograph, the Wykoff Run Road Bridge is in one of the most spectacular settings in the state. The bridge is an example of a state-standard Parker thru truss. It retains historic integrity, including its original lattice railings and open grid deck. According to JPH of the PAHBI, 'The 1938, 2 span, 415'-long, rivet-connected Parker thru truss bridge is supported on a concrete pier and concrete abutments. The polygonal upper chords are built up box sections, the lower chords are channels with battens, and the verticals and diagonals are rolled sections. The bridge is an example of a state highway department standard design rivet-connected truss bridge with rolled verticals and diagonals.'

column18: Chaney Engineering Company (Engineer), Farris Engineering Company (Contractor)
column20: The Wylie Avenue Bridge is one of the most ornate concrete arch bridges in Washington County. According to the Pennsylvania Historic Bridge Inventory, the ''reinforced concrete deck arch bridge is finished with incised panels with a bush hammer finish on the spandrel walls and Neo Classical-style concrete balustrades. The center post extends on the spandrel wall to accent the center of the bridge.''

The Yellow Creek Church Road Bridge appears to have been built as a railroad bridge. As trains became heavier in the twentieth century, the old bridges often were relocated to serve as overpasses. Note the thickness of the members! The bridge was rehabilitated in 1986 and repainted a coral color. Columbiana county seems to be the only one to paint its bridges that unusual color.

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1988
column20: The York Haven Road Bridge is a rare example of a pin-connected Pennsylvania truss. It was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1988. The bridge was bypassed in 1984 and subsequently abandoned. As a result, this historic bridge is still standing for new generations to enjoy. The bridge is historically significant for many reasons. It is considered a camelback Pennsylvania truss since the truss has five distinct panels. This is a rare configuration with few bridges remaining nationally with this configuration. Furthermore, the bridge was built by the Wrought Iron Bridge Company of Canton, Ohio, a nationally significant bridge fabricator. It is possibly the only known Wrought Iron Bridge Company Pennsylvania truss still standing anywhere. The bridge has an usual detail of light compression members between the eyebars along the bottom chord. A truss bridge functions as a beam. When a load is applied, the span bends downward. The top chord acts in compression and the bottom in tension. For this reason, pin-connected truss bridges have eyebars along the bottom chord and built-up compression members along the top chord. Why would there be both compression and tension members along the low chord with this bridge? It is possible that with a Pennsylvania truss bridge, the vertical members are placed far apart. Engineers may have added the compression members to resist buckling or to add stiffness to the long, thin eyebars between the panels. Had the bridge been demolished instead of abandoned, the potentially nationally significant bridge would have been lost. 26 years later (when this entry was written), the bridge can still be demolished. However, it still can be restored or relocated.
This bridge bypassed an 1888 bridge which has been abandoned. The new bridge opened almost a century later in 1984.

column15: Skewed closed spandrel segmental concrete arch
column20: The Yorks Run Road Bridge is the oldest unaltered concrete arch bridge in Preston County, West Virginia. It is also noteworthy for its large skew. The Luten Bridge Company built many similar-looking concrete arch bridges throughout West Virginia.

Until 1989, PA 281 crossed the Casselman River at this location on a two-span pin-connected Pratt truss bridge. The bridge was one of the last multi-span truss bridges over the river. In 1989, the new PA 218 bridge was completed about a half mile to the south. The truss bridge was demolished and replaced by a welded, pre-fabricated truss for pedestrians. It is unfortunate the historic bridge could not have been retained for the pedestrian crossing.

column15: Warren simple with stringer approach spans
column20: The Youghiogheny River Lake was created for flood control purposes in the 1940's. Due to the reservoir created by the new dam, a longer, higher US 40 bridge was needed. Construction began in 1939. Starting from the Fayette County side, the bridge was only a few spans away from the Somerset County side when World War II began, halting progress on the bridge. Though construction resumed after the war, technology had advanced enough so that the bridge was completed with continuous steel stringer (girder) spans instead of deck truss spans. From 2003 to 2006, a new steel girder was built immediately downstream, and the old bridge was demolished once the new bridge opened to traffic.

column2: Youghiogheny River Trail Bridge at Buena Vista
column20: The former railroad was converted to the Youghiogheny River trail in the 1990's. The bridge has plain spandrel walls and pipe railings.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places
column20: Young's Bridge is the last remaining pin-connected Pratt thru truss bridge in Beaver County. Due to the two-pin top chord endpost connection (a pin for the inclined endpost and a separate pin for the vertical member), it is attributed to the local Penn Bridge Company of Beaver Falls, Beaver County. The bridge is eligible for the National Register of Historic Places. The National Bridge Inventory date is 1935, which is either an error or the date of a rehabilitation. The bridge was seen in a KDKA CBS 2 promo for its 'Your Home' ad campaign.

The Yura's Farm Road Bridge is a small pin-connected Pratt half-hip pony truss. It is one of only a few bridges in the region built by the Champion Bridge Company. The bridge was rehabilitated in 1996, in which the bearings were encased in concrete and other bolted repairs were made. Dating from the early 1900's, the bridge is a late example of a pin-connected pony truss. There was another similar pony truss nearby on Yura's Farm Road, but it was replaced in 1996.

In the 1980's or 1990's as part of improvements to trails along Barton Creek, a new pedestrian-only bridge was built parallel to the Barton Springs Road Bridge. The bridge has become an important Austin trail link.

column2: Zilker Park Barton Springs Road Underpass
column20: The Zilker Park Barton Springs Road Underpass is a rare example of a pedestrian bridge built along a hillside under a vehicular bridge. In the 1980's, a greenway was established along Barton Creek. Due to the steep slope along the west side of the river under the Barton Springs Road Bridge, a pedestrian bridge was built over the hillside under the vehicular bridge.
The Zion Canyon Visitors Center Bridge connects the main parking lot to the visitors center. It is one of several prefabricated lightweight truss bridges in Zion National Park.

column2: Zion-Mount Carmel Highway Pine Creek Arch Bridge
column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1987
column18: Thomas H. MacDonald, Reynolds-Ely Construction Company
column20: According to the Historic American Engineering Record, ''Built of native sandstone and ashlar masonry, and designed to complement its natural surroundings, this bridge is a superb example of ''National Park Service-Rustic'' stone bridge engineering. It is unaltered and retains structural integrity. The Pine Creek Bridge is significant for its association with the Zion-Mount Carmel Highway, constructed by the National Park Service and Bureau of Public Roads in 1927-30. The highway is listed on the National Register of Historic Places and is considered significant in the contexts of tourism and engineering. The bridge is an integral and necessary component of the highway, and is also significant for its rustic style, designed to harmonize with the local setting.''

column16: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1987
column20: The Zion-Mount Carmel Tunnel Bridge is a beam bridge over the Pine Creek Canyon at the east end of the Zion-Mount Carmel Tunnel. The steel bridge has concrete parapets to serve as decorative features hiding the steel stringers and to help the bridge blend with the natural environment. The Zion-Mount Carmel Tunnel was completed in 1930. At a length of 5,613 feet (1.1 miles), it was the longest tunnel in America when constructed. The tunnel features several galleries, or windows in the wall of the tunnel. When the tunnel was first opened to traffic, drivers could park at the galleries to view the scenic canyon.

column16: Eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, last remaining load-bearing pin-connected truss over the West Branch Susquehanna River
column20: The Zorger Road Bridge is the last remaining load-bearing pin-connected truss bridge over the entire West Branch Susquehanna River. It is a rare surviving example of a railroad Whipple truss, though it has since been converted for vehicular use. The Whipple truss was the first generation long span railroad bridge. According to the PAHBI, ''The ca. 1880, single span, 180'-long, pin-connected double intersection Pratt (Whipple) thru truss bridge is supported on ashlar abutments. Designed to railroad specifications, the bridge consists of 10, 18'-long panels. It has eye bar diagonals that extend across two panels, lower chords eye bars, and built up upper chords and verticals. It is one of nine Whipple truss bridges identified by the survey, and one of two in Clearfield County (17 7222 0565 0005 is the other). The Whipple design was patented by American engineer Squire Whipple in 1847, and it was widely adopted by the railroad industry between 1865 and 1885. The bridge is historically and technologically significant as a complete and rare surviving example of the design.''
